10064-8{_}572{_}"Now it befell, upon a day, that they set out with a goodly company to attend a tourney in a certain town whither, likewise, were come many knights of renown, nobles and princes beyond count eager to prove their prowess, thither drawn by the fame of that fair lady who was to be Queen of Beauty.
10064-8{_}573{_}All lips spake of her and the wonder of her charms, how that a man could not look within her eyes but must needs fall into a passion of love for her.
10064-8{_}574{_}But the brethren smiled and paid small heed and so, together, journeyed to the city.
10064-8{_}575{_}The day of the joust being come, forth they rode into the lists, side by side, each in his triple mail and ponderous helm, alike at all points save for the golden circlet upon Duke Beltane's shining casque.
10064-8{_}576{_}And there befell, that day, a mighty shivering of lances and many a knightly deed was wrought.
10064-8{_}577{_}But, for these brethren there was none of all these knights and nobles who might abide their onset; all day long they together maintained the lists till there none remained to cope with them, wherefore the marshal would have had them run a course together for proof which was the mightier.
10064-8{_}578{_}But Beltane smiled and shook his head saying, 'Nay, it is not meet that brother strive with brother!'
10064-8{_}579{_}And Johan said: 'Since the day doth rest with us, we will share the glory together.'
10064-8{_}580{_}So, amid the acclaim of voice and trumpet, side by side they came to make obeisance to the Queen of Beauty, and gazing upon her, they saw that she was indeed of a wondrous beauty.
10064-8{_}581{_}Now in her hand she held the crown that should reward the victor, yet because they were two, she knew not whom to choose, wherefore she laughed, and brake the crown asunder and gave to each a half with many fair words and gentle sayings.
10064-8{_}582{_}But, alas, my son!
10064-8{_}583{_}from that hour her beauty came betwixt these brethren, veiling their hearts one from the other.
10064-8{_}584{_}So they tarried awhile in that fair city, yet companied together no more, for each was fain to walk apart, dreaming of this woman and the beauty of her, and each by stealth wooed her to wife.
10064-8{_}585{_}At last, upon an evening, came Johan to his brother and taking from his bosom the half of the crown he had won, kissed it and gave it to Beltane, saying: 'The half of a crown availeth no man, take therefore my half and join it with thine, for well do I know thy heart, my brother--and thou art the elder, and Duke; go therefore and woo this lady to wife, and God speed thee, my lord.'
10064-8{_}586{_}But Beltane said: 'Shame were it in me to take advantage of my years thus; doth age or rank make a man's love more worthy?
10064-8{_}587{_}So, get thee to thy wooing, my brother, and heaven's blessing on thee.'
10064-8{_}588{_}Then grew Johan full of joy, saying: 'So be it, dear my brother, but am I come not to thee within three days at sunset, then shalt know that my wooing hath not prospered.'
10064-8{_}589{_}Upon the third day, therefore, Beltane the Duke girded on his armour and made ready to ride unto his own demesne, yet tarried until sunset, according to his word.
10064-8{_}590{_}But his brother Johan came not.
10064-8{_}591{_}Therefore he, in turn, rode upon his wooing and came unto the lady's presence in hauberk of mail, and thus ungently clad wooed her as one in haste to be gone, telling her that this world was no place for a man to sigh out his days at a woman's feet, and bidding her answer him' Yea' or 'Nay' and let him be gone to his duty.
10064-8{_}592{_}And she, whom so many had wooed on bended knee, spake him' Yea'--for that a woman's ways be beyond all knowledge--and therewith gave her beauty to his keeping.
10064-8{_}593{_}So, forthwith were they wed, with much pomp and circumstance, and so he brought her to his Duchy with great joy and acclaim.
10064-8{_}594{_}Then would Johan have departed over seas, but Beltane ever dissuaded him, and fain these brethren would have loved each other as they had done aforetime, yet was the beauty of this woman ever betwixt them.
10064-8{_}595{_}Now, within that year, came news of fire and sword upon the border, of cruel rape and murder, so Beltane sent forth his brother Johan with an army to drive back the invaders, and himself abode in his great castle, happy in the love of his fair, young wife.
10064-8{_}596{_}But the war went ill, tidings came that Johan his brother was beaten back with much loss and he himself sore wounded.
10064-8{_}597{_}Therefore the Duke made ready to set forth at the head of a veteran company, but ere he rode a son was born to him, so needs must he come to his wife in his armour, and beholding the child, kissed him.
10064-8{_}598{_}Thereafter Duke Beltane rode to the war with a glad heart, and fell upon his enemies and scattered them, and pursued them far and smote them even to their own gates.
10064-8{_}599{_}But in the hour of his triumph he fell, by treachery, into the hands of his cruelest enemy, how it mattereth not, and for a space was lost to sight and memory.
10064-8{_}600{_}But as for Johan, the Duke's brother, he lay long sick of his wounds, so came the Duchess and ministered to him; and she was fair, and passing fair, and he was young.
10064-8{_}601{_}And when his strength was come again, each day was Johan minded to ride forth and seek the Duke his brother--but he was young, and she passing fair, wherefore he tarried still, bound by the lure of her beauty.
10064-8{_}602{_}And, upon a soft and stilly eve as they walked together in the garden, she wooed Johan with tender look and word, and wreathed her white arms about him and gave to his her mouth.
10064-8{_}603{_}And, in that moment came one, fierce and wild of aspect, in dinted casque and rusty mail who stood and watched--ah God!"
10064-8{_}604{_}Here, for a while, the hermit Ambrose stayed his tale, and Beltane saw his brow was moist and that his thin hands clenched and wrung each other.
10064-8{_}605{_}"So thus, my son, came Duke Beltane home again, he and his esquire Sir Benedict of Bourne alone of all his company, each alike worn with hardship and spent with wounds.
10064-8{_}606{_}But now was the Duke stricken of a greater pain and leaned him upon the shoulder of his esquire, faint and sick of soul, and knew an anguish deeper than any flesh may know.
10064-8{_}607{_}Then, of a sudden, madness came upon him and, breaking from the mailed arms that held him, he came hot-foot to the courtyard and to the hall beyond, hurling aside all such as sought to stay him and so reached at last my lady's bower, his mailed feet ringing upon the Atones.
10064-8{_}608{_}And, looking up, the Duchess saw and cried aloud and stood, thereafter, pale and speechless and wide of eye, while Johan's cheek grew red and in his look was shame.
10064-8{_}609{_}Then the Duke put up his vizor and, when he spake, his voice was harsh and strange: 'Greeting, good brother!'
10064-8{_}610{_}said he, 'go now, I pray you, get you horse and armour and wait me in the courtyard, yet first must I greet this my lady wife.'
10064-8{_}611{_}So Johan turned, with hanging head, and went slow-footed from the chamber.
10064-8{_}612{_}Then said the Duke, laughing in his madness, 'Behold, lady, the power of a woman's beauty, for I loved a noble brother once, a spotless knight whose honour reached high as heaven, but thou hast made of him a something foul and base, traitor to me and to his own sweet name, and 'tis for this I will requite thee!'
10064-8{_}613{_}But the Duchess spake not, nor blenched even when the dagger gleamed to strike--O sweet God of mercy, to strike!
10064-8{_}614{_}But, in that moment, came Benedict of Bourne and leapt betwixt and took the blow upon his cheek, and, stanching the blood within his tattered war-cloak, cried: 'Lord Duke, because I love thee, ne'er shalt thou do this thing until thou first slay me!'
10064-8{_}615{_}A while the Duke stood in amaze, then turned and strode away down the great stair, and coming to the courtyard, beheld his brother Johan armed at all points and mounted, and with another horse equipped near by.
10064-8{_}616{_}So the Duke laughed and closed his vizor and his laughter boomed hollow within his rusty casque, and, leaping to the saddle, rode to the end of the great tilt-yard, and, wheeling, couched his lance.
10064-8{_}617{_}So these brethren, who had loved each other so well, spurred upon each other with levelled lances but, or ever the shock came--O my son, my son!--Johan rose high in his stirrups and cried aloud the battle-cry of his house 'Arise!
10064-8{_}618{_}Arise!
10064-8{_}619{_}I shall arise!'
10064-8{_}620{_}and with the cry, tossed aside his lance lest he might harm the Duke his brother--O sweet clemency of Christ!--and crashed to earth-- and lay there--very still and silent.
10064-8{_}621{_}Then the Duke dismounted and, watched by pale-faced esquires and men-at-arms, came and knelt beside his brother, and laid aside his brother's riven helm and, beholding his comely features torn and marred and his golden hair all hatefully bedabbled, felt his heart burst in sunder, and he groaned, and rising to stumbling feet came to his horse and mounted and rode away 'neath grim portcullis and over echoing drawbridge, yet, whithersoever he looked, he saw only his brother's dead face, pale and bloody.
10064-8{_}622{_}And fain he would have prayed but could not, and so he came into the forest.
10064-8{_}623{_}All day long he rode beneath the trees careless of his going, conscious only that Benedict of Bourne rode behind with his bloody war-cloak wrapped about him.
10064-8{_}624{_}But on rode the Duke with hanging head and listless hands for before his haggard eyes was ever the pale, dead face of Johan his brother.
10064-8{_}625{_}Now, as the moon rose, they came to a brook that whispered soft-voiced amid the shadows and here his war-horse stayed to drink.
10064-8{_}626{_}Then came Sir Benedict of Bourne beside him, 'Lord Duke,' said he, 'what hast thou in thy mind to do?'
10064-8{_}627{_}'I know not,' said the Duke, 'though methinks 'twere sweet to die.'
10064-8{_}628{_}'Then what of the babe, lord Duke?'
10064-8{_}629{_}and, speaking, Sir Benedict drew aside his cloak and showed the babe asleep beneath.
10064-8{_}630{_}But, looking upon its innocence, the Duke cried out and hid his face, for the babe's golden curls were dabbled with the blood from Sir Benedict's wound and looked even as had the face of the dead Johan.
10064-8{_}631{_}Yet, in a while, the Duke reached out and took the child and setting it against his breast, turned his horse.
10064-8{_}632{_}Said Sir Benedict: 'Whither do we ride, lord Duke?'
10064-8{_}633{_}Then spake the Duke on this wise: 'Sir Benedict, Duke Beltane is no more, the stroke that slew my brother Johan killed Duke Beltane also.
10064-8{_}634{_}But as for you, get you to Pentavalon and say the Duke is dead, in proof whereof take you this my ring and so, farewell.'
10064-8{_}635{_}Then, my Beltane, God guiding me, I brought thee to these solitudes, for I am he that was the Duke Beltane, and thou art my son indeed."
10064-8{_}636{_}CHAPTER VI  HOW BELTANE FARED FORTH OF THE GREEN   Thus spake the hermit Ambrose and, having made an end, sat thereafter with his head bowed upon his hands, while Beltane stood wide-eyed yet seeing not, and with lips apart yet dumb by reason of the wonder of it; therefore, in a while, the hermit spake again:  "Thus did we live together, thou and I, dear son, and I loved thee well, my Beltane: with each succeeding day I loved thee better, for as thine understanding grew, so grew my love for thee.
10064-8{_}637{_}Therefore, so soon as thou wert of an age, set in thy strength and able to thine own support, I tore myself from thy sweet fellowship and lived alone lest, having thee, I might come nigh to happiness."
10064-8{_}638{_}Then Beltane sank upon his knees and caught the hermit's wasted hands and kissed them oft, saying:  "Much hast thou suffered, O my father, but now am I come to thee again and, knowing all things, here will I bide and leave thee nevermore."
10064-8{_}639{_}Now in the hermit's pale cheek came a faint and sudden glow, and in his eyes a light not of the sun.
10064-8{_}640{_}"Bethink thee, boy," said he, "the blood within thy veins is noble.
10064-8{_}641{_}For, since thou art my son, so, an thou dost leave me and seek thy destiny thou shalt, perchance, be Duke of Pentavalon--an God will it so."
10064-8{_}642{_}But Beltane shook his head.
10064-8{_}643{_}Quoth he:  "My father, I am a smith, and smith am I content to be since thou, lord Duke, art my father.
10064-8{_}644{_}So now will I abide with thee and love and honour thee, and be thy son indeed."
10064-8{_}645{_}Then rose the hermit Ambrose to his feet and spake with eyes uplifted:  "Now glory be to God, Who, in His mercy, hath made of thee a man, my Beltane, clean of soul and innocent, yet strong of arm to lift and succour the distressed, and therefore it is that you to-day must leave me, my well-beloved, for there be those whose need of thee is greater even than mine."
10064-8{_}646{_}"Nay, dear my father, how may this be?"
10064-8{_}647{_}Now hereupon Ambrose the Hermit stood awhile with bent head, and spake not, only he sighed full oft and wrung his hands.
10064-8{_}648{_}"I thought but of myself!"
10064-8{_}649{_}he groaned, "great sorrow is oft-times greatly selfish.
10064-8{_}650{_}Alas, my son--twenty weary years have I lived here suing God's forgiveness, and for twenty bitter years Pentavalon hath groaned 'neath shameful wrong--and death in many hateful shapes.
10064-8{_}651{_}O God have mercy on a sinner who thought but on himself!
10064-8{_}652{_}List, my son, O list!
10064-8{_}653{_}On a day, as I kneeled before yon cross, came one in knightly armour and upon his face, 'neath the links of his camail, I saw a great scar--the scar this hand had wrought.
10064-8{_}654{_}And, even as I knew Sir Benedict, in that same moment he knew me, and gave a joyous cry and came and fell upon his knee and kissed my hand, as of old.
10064-8{_}655{_}Thereafter we talked, and he told me many a woeful tale of Pentavalon and of its misery.
10064-8{_}656{_}How, when I was gone, rose bitter fight and faction, barons and knights striving together which should be Duke.
10064-8{_}657{_}In the midst of the which disorders came one, from beyond seas, whom men called Ivo, who by might of sword and cunning tongue made himself Duke in my place.
10064-8{_}658{_}Sir Benedict told of a fierce and iron rule, of the pillage and ravishment of town and city, of outrage and injustice, of rack and flame and gibbet--of a people groaning 'neath a thousand cruel wrongs.
10064-8{_}659{_}Then, indeed, did I see that my one great sin a thousand other sins had bred, and was I full of bitter sorrow and anguish.
10064-8{_}660{_}And, in my anguish, I thought on thee, and sent to thee Sir Benedict, and watched thee wrestle, and at stroke of sword, and praised God for thy goodly might and strength.
10064-8{_}661{_}For O, dear my son, meseemeth that God hath raised thee up to succour these afflicted, to shield the weak and helpless--hath made thee great and mightier than most to smite Evil that it may flee before thee.
10064-8{_}662{_}So in thee shall my youth be renewed, and my sins, peradventure, purged away."
10064-8{_}663{_}"Father!"
10064-8{_}664{_}said Beltane rising, his blue eyes wide, his strong hands a-tremble, "O my father!"
10064-8{_}665{_}Then Ambrose clasped those quivering hands and kissed those wide and troubled eyes and spake thereafter, slow and soft:  "Now shall I live henceforth in thee, my son, glorying in thy deeds hereafter.
10064-8{_}666{_}And if thou must needs--bleed, then shall my heart bleed with thee, or if thou meet with death, my Beltane, then shall this heart of mine die with thee."
10064-8{_}667{_}Thus speaking, the hermit drew the sword from Beltane's girdle and held the great blade towards heaven.
10064-8{_}668{_}"Behold, my son," said he, "the motto of our house, 'I will arise!'
10064-8{_}669{_}So now shalt thou arise indeed that thy destiny may be fulfilled.
10064-8{_}670{_}Take hold upon thy manhood, my well-beloved, get thee to woeful Pentavalon and, beholding its sorrows, seek how they may be assuaged.
10064-8{_}671{_}Now my Beltane, all is said--when wilt thou leave thy father?"
10064-8{_}672{_}Quoth Beltane, gathering his cloak about him:  "An so it be thy wish, my father, then will I go this hour."
10064-8{_}673{_}Then Ambrose brought Beltane into his humble dwelling where was a coffer wrought by his own skilful fingers; and from this coffer he drew forth a suit of triple mail, wondrously fashioned, beholding the which, Beltane's eyes glistened because of the excellence of its craftsmanship.
10064-8{_}674{_}"Behold!"
10064-8{_}675{_}quoth the hermit, "'tis an armour worthy of a king, light is it, yet marvellous strong, and hath been well tried in many a desperate affray.
10064-8{_}676{_}'Tis twenty years since these limbs bore it, yet see--I have kept it bright from rust lest, peradventure, Pentavalon should need thee to raise again the battle cry of thy house and lead her men to war.
10064-8{_}677{_}And, alas dear son, that day is now!
10064-8{_}678{_}Pentavalon calls to thee from out the gloom of dungeon, from the anguish of flame, and rack, and gibbet--from blood-soaked hearth and shameful grave she calls thee-- so, my Beltane, come and let me arm thee."
10064-8{_}679{_}And there, within his little hut, the hermit Ambrose, Duke of Pentavalon that was, girt the armour upon Beltane the mighty, Duke of Pentavalon to be, if so God willed; first the gambeson of stuffed and quilted leather, and, thereafter, coifed hauberk and chausses, with wide sword-belt clamped with broad plates of silver and studs of gold, until my Beltane stood up armed in shining mail from head to foot.
10064-8{_}680{_}Then brought Ambrose a wallet, wherein were six gold pieces, and put it in his hand, saying:  "These have I kept against this day, my Beltane.
10064-8{_}681{_}Take them to aid thee on thy journey, for the county of Bourne lieth far to the south."
10064-8{_}682{_}"Do I then journey to Bourne, my father?"
10064-8{_}683{_}"Aye, to Sir Benedict, who yet doth hold the great keep of Thrasfordham.
10064-8{_}684{_}Many sieges hath he withstood, and daily men flee to him --stricken men, runaway serfs, and outlaws from the green, all such masterless men as lie in fear of their lives."
10064-8{_}685{_}Said Beltane, slow and thoughtful:  "There be many outlaws within the green, wild men and sturdy fighters as I've heard.
10064-8{_}686{_}Hath Sir Benedict many men, my father?"
10064-8{_}687{_}"Alas!
10064-8{_}688{_}a pitiful few, and Black Ivo can muster bows and lances by the ten thousand--"  "Yet doth Sir Benedict withstand them all, my father!"
10064-8{_}689{_}"Yet must he keep ever within Bourne, Beltane.
10064-8{_}690{_}All Pentavalon, save Bourne, lieth 'neath Ivo's iron foot, ruled by his fierce nobles, and they be strong and many, 'gainst whom Sir Benedict is helpless in the field.
10064-8{_}691{_}'Tis but five years agone since Ivo gave up fair Belsaye town to ravishment and pillage, and thereafter, builded him a mighty gallows over against it and hanged many men thereon."
10064-8{_}692{_}Now hereupon, of a sudden, Beltane clenched his hands and fell upon his knees.
10064-8{_}693{_}"Father," said he, "Pentavalon indeed doth cry, so must I now arise and go unto her.
10064-8{_}694{_}Give me thy blessing that I may go."
10064-8{_}695{_}Then the hermit laid his hands upon Beltane's golden head and blessed him, and whispered awhile in passionate prayer.
10064-8{_}696{_}Thereafter Beltane arose and, together, they came out into the sunshine.
10064-8{_}697{_}"South and by west must you march, dear son, and God, methinks, shall go beside thee, for thy feet shall tread a path where Death shall lie in wait for thee.
10064-8{_}698{_}Let thine eyes be watchful therefore, and thine ears quick to hear.
10064-8{_}699{_}Hearken you to all men, yet speak you few words and soft.
10064-8{_}700{_}But, when you act, let your deeds shout unto heaven, that all Pentavalon may know a man is come to lead them who fears only God.
10064-8{_}701{_}And so, my Beltane, fare-thee-well!
10064-8{_}702{_}Come, kiss me, boy; our next kiss, perchance--shall be in heaven."
10064-8{_}703{_}And thus they kissed, and looked within each other's eyes; then Beltane turned him, swift and sudden, and strode upon his way.
10064-8{_}704{_}But, in a little, looking back, he saw his father, kneeling before the cross, with long, gaunt arms upraised to heaven.
10064-8{_}705{_}CHAPTER VII  HOW BELTANE TALKED WITH ONE HIGHT GILES BRABBLECOMBE, WHO WAS A NOTABLE AND LEARNED ARCHER   The morning was yet young when my Beltane fared forth into the world, a joyous, golden morning trilling with the glad song of birds and rich with a thousand dewy scents; a fair, sweet, joyous world it was indeed, whose glories, stealing in at eye and ear, filled him with their gladness.
10064-8{_}706{_}On strode my Beltane by rippling brook and sleepy pool, with step swift and light and eyes wide and shining, threading an unerring course as only a forester might; now crossing some broad and sunny glade where dawn yet lingered in rosy mist, anon plunging into the green twilight of dell and dingle, through tangled brush and scented bracken gemmed yet with dewy fire, by marsh and swamp and lichened rock, until he came out upon the forest road, that great road laid by the iron men of Rome, but now little better than a grassy track, yet here and there, with mossy stone set up to the glory of proud emperor and hardy centurion long since dust and ashes; a rutted track, indeed, but leading ever on, 'neath mighty trees, over hill and dale towards the blue mystery beyond.
10064-8{_}707{_}Now, in a while, being come to the brow of a hill, needs must my Beltane pause to look back upon the woodlands he had loved so well and, sighing, he stretched his arms thitherward; and lo!
10064-8{_}708{_}out of the soft twilight of the green, stole a gentle wind full of the scent of root and herb and the fresh, sweet smell of earth, a cool, soft wind that stirred the golden hair at his temples, like a caress, and so--was gone.
10064-8{_}709{_}For a while he stood thus, gazing towards where he knew his father yet knelt in prayer for him, then turned he slowly, and went his appointed way.
10064-8{_}710{_}Thus did Beltane bid farewell to the greenwood and to woodland things, and thus did the green spirit of the woods send forth a gentle wind to kiss him on the brow ere he went out into the world of men and cities.
10064-8{_}711{_}Now, after some while, as he walked, Beltane was aware of the silvery tinkle of bells and, therewith, a full, sweet voice upraised in song, and the song was right merry and the words likewise:    "O ne'er shall my lust for the bowl decline,    Nor my love for my good long bow;    For as bow to the shaft and as bowl to the wine,    Is a maid to a man, I trow."
10064-8{_}712{_}Looking about, Beltane saw the singer, a comely fellow whose long legs bestrode a plump ass; a lusty man he was, clad in shirt of mail and with a feather of green brooched to his escalloped hood; a long-bow hung at his back together with a quiver of arrows, while at his thigh swung a heavy, broad-bladed sword.
10064-8{_}713{_}Now he, espying Beltane amid the leaves, brought the ass to a sudden halt and clapped hand to the pommel of his sword.
10064-8{_}714{_}"How now, Goliath!"
10064-8{_}715{_}cried he.
10064-8{_}716{_}"_Pax vobiscum,_ and likewise _benedicite_!
10064-8{_}717{_}Come ye in peace, forsooth, or is it to be _bellum internecinum?_ Though, by St. Giles, which is my patron saint, I care not how it be, for mark ye, _vacuus cantat coram latrone viator,_ Sir Goliath, the which in the vulgar tongue signifieth that he who travels with an empty purse laughs before the footpad--moreover, I have a sword!"
10064-8{_}718{_}But Beltane laughed, saying:  "I have no lust to thy purse, most learned bowman, or indeed to aught of thine unless it be thy company."
10064-8{_}719{_}"My company?"
10064-8{_}720{_}quoth the bowman, looking Beltane up and down with merry blue eyes, "why now do I know thee for a fellow of rare good judgment, for my company is of the best, in that I have a tongue which loveth to wag in jape or song.
10064-8{_}721{_}Heard ye how the birds and I were a-carolling?
10064-8{_}722{_}A right blithesome morn, methinks, what with my song, and the birds' song, and this poor ass's bells--aye, and the flowers a-peep from the bank yonder.
10064-8{_}723{_}God give ye joy of it, tall brother, as he doth me and this goodly ass betwixt my knees, patient beast."
10064-8{_}724{_}Now leaning on his quarter-staff Beltane smiled and said:  "How came ye by that same ass, master bowman?"
10064-8{_}725{_}"Well--I met a monk!"
10064-8{_}726{_}quoth the fellow with a gleam of white teeth.
10064-8{_}727{_}"O!
10064-8{_}728{_}a ponderous monk, brother, of most mighty girth of belly!
10064-8{_}729{_}Now, as ye see, though this ass be sleek and fat as an abbot, she is something small.
10064-8{_}730{_}'And shall so small a thing needs bear so great a mountain o' flesh?'
10064-8{_}731{_}says I (much moved at the sight, brother).
10064-8{_}732{_}'No, by the blessed bones of St. Giles (which is my patron saint, brother), so thereafter (by dint of a little persuasion, brother) my mountainous monk, to ease the poor beast's back, presently got him down and I, forthwith, got up-- as being more in proportion to her weight, sweet beast!
10064-8{_}733{_}O!
10064-8{_}734{_}surely ne'er saw I fairer morn than this, and never, in so fair a morn, saw I fairer man than thou, Sir Forester, nor taller, and I have seen many men in my day.
10064-8{_}735{_}Wherefore an so ye will, let us company together what time we may; 'tis a solitary road, and the tongue is a rare shortener of distance."
10064-8{_}736{_}So Beltane strode on beside this garrulous bowman, hearkening to his merry talk, yet himself speaking short and to the point as was ever his custom; as thus:  BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}737{_}"How do men call thee, tall brother?"
10064-8{_}738{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}739{_}"Beltane."
10064-8{_}740{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}741{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}742{_}'Tis a good name, forsooth I've heard worse--and yet, forsooth, I've heard better.
10064-8{_}743{_}Yet 'tis a fairish name--'twill serve.
10064-8{_}744{_}As for me, Giles Brabblecombe o' the Hills men call me, for 'twas in the hill country I was born thirty odd years agone.
10064-8{_}745{_}Since then twelve sieges have I seen with skirmishes and onfalls thrice as many.
10064-8{_}746{_}Death have I beheld in many and divers shapes and in experience of wounds and dangers am rich, though, by St. Giles (my patron saint), in little else.
10064-8{_}747{_}Yet do I love life the better, therefore, and I have read that 'to despise gold is to be rich.'"
10064-8{_}748{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}749{_}"Do all bowmen read, then?"
10064-8{_}750{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}751{_}"Why look ye, brother, I am not what I was aforetime--_non sum quails eram _--I was bred a shaveling, a mumbler, a be-gowned do-nothing--brother, I was a monk, but the flesh and the devil made of me a bowman, heigho--so wags the world!
10064-8{_}752{_}Though methinks I am a better bowman than ever I was a monk, having got me some repute with this my bow."
10064-8{_}753{_}BELTANE (shaking his head).
10064-8{_}754{_}"Methinks thy choice was but a sorry one for--"  BOWMAN (laughing).
10064-8{_}755{_}"Choice quotha!
10064-8{_}756{_}'Twas no choice, 'twas forced upon me, _vi et armis._ I should be chanting prime or matins at this very hour but for this tongue o' mine, God bless it!
10064-8{_}757{_}For, when it should have been droning psalms, it was forever lilting forth some blithesome melody, some merry song of eyes and lips and stolen kisses.
10064-8{_}758{_}In such sort that the good brethren were wont to gather round and, listening,-- sigh!
10064-8{_}759{_}Whereof it chanced I was, one night, by order of the holy Prior, drubbed forth of the sacred precincts.
10064-8{_}760{_}So brother Anselm became Giles o' the Bow--the kind Saints be praised, in especial holy Saint Giles (which is my patron saint!).
10064-8{_}761{_}For, heed me--better the blue sky and the sweet, strong wind than the gloom and silence of a cloister.
10064-8{_}762{_}I had rather hide this sconce of mine in a hood of mail than in the mitre of a lord bishop--_nolo episcopare,_ good brother!
10064-8{_}763{_}Thus am I a fighter, and a good fighter, and a wise fighter, having learned 'tis better to live to fight than to fight to live."
10064-8{_}764{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}765{_}"And for whom do ye fight?"
10064-8{_}766{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}767{_}"For him that pays most, _pecuniae obediunt omnia,_ brother."
10064-8{_}768{_}BELTANE (frowning).
10064-8{_}769{_}"Money?
10064-8{_}770{_}And nought beside?"
10064-8{_}771{_}BOWMAN (staring).
10064-8{_}772{_}"As what, brother?"
10064-8{_}773{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}774{_}"The justice of the cause wherefore ye fight."
10064-8{_}775{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}776{_}"Justice quotha--cause!
10064-8{_}777{_}O innocent brother, what have such matters to do with such as I?
10064-8{_}778{_}See you now, such lieth the case.
10064-8{_}779{_}You, let us say, being a baron (and therefore noble!)
10064-8{_}780{_}have a mind to a certain other baron's castle, or wife, or both--(the which is more usual) wherefore ye come to me, who am but a plain bowman knowing nought of the case, and you chaffer with me for the use of this my body for so much money, and thereafter I shoot my best on thy behalf as in mine honour bound.
10064-8{_}781{_}Thus have I fought both for and against Black Ivo throughout the length and breadth of his Duchy of Pentavalon.
10064-8{_}782{_}If ye be minded to sell that long sword o' thine, to none better market could ye come, for there be ever work for such about Black Ivo."
10064-8{_}783{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}784{_}"Aye, 'tis so I hear."
10064-8{_}785{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}786{_}"Nor shall ye anywhere find a doughtier fighter than Duke Ivo, nor a leader quicker to spy out the vantage of position and attack."
10064-8{_}787{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}788{_}"Is he so lusty a man-at-arms?"
10064-8{_}789{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}790{_}"With lance, axe, or sword he hath no match.
10064-8{_}791{_}I have seen him lead a charge.
10064-8{_}792{_}I have watched him fight afoot.
10064-8{_}793{_}I have stormed behind him through a breach, and I know of none dare cope with him--unless it be Sir Pertolepe the Red."
10064-8{_}794{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}795{_}"Hast ne'er heard tell, then, of Benedict of Bourne?"
10064-8{_}796{_}BOWMAN (clapping hand to thigh).
10064-8{_}797{_}"Now by the blood and bones of St. Giles 'tis so!
10064-8{_}798{_}Out o' the mouth of a babe and suckling am I corrected!
10064-8{_}799{_}Verily if there be one to front Black Ivo 'tis Benedict o' the Mark.
10064-8{_}800{_}To behold these two at handstrokes--with axes--ha, there would be a sweet affray indeed--a sight for the eyes of holy archangels!
10064-8{_}801{_}Dost know aught of Sir Benedict, O Innocence?"
10064-8{_}802{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}803{_}"I have seen him."
10064-8{_}804{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}805{_}"Then, my soft and gentle dove-like youth, get thee to thy marrow-bones and pray that kind heaven shall make thee more his like, for in his shoes doth stand a man--a knight--a very paladin!"
10064-8{_}806{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}807{_}"Who fighteth not for--hire.
10064-8{_}808{_}Sir Bowman!"
10064-8{_}809{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}810{_}"Yet who hireth to fight, Sir Dove-eyed Giant, for I have fought for him, ere now, within his great keep of Thrasfordham within Bourne.
10064-8{_}811{_}But, an ye seek employ, his is but a poor service, where a man shall come by harder knocks than good broad pieces."
10064-8{_}812{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}813{_}"And yet, 'spite thy cunning and all thy warring, thy purse goeth empty!"
10064-8{_}814{_}BOWMAN.
10064-8{_}815{_}"My purse, Sir Dove?
10064-8{_}816{_}Aye, I told thee so for that I am by nature cautious--_sicut mos est nobis_!
10064-8{_}817{_}But thy dove's eyes are honest eyes, so now shall you know that hid within the lining of this my left boot be eighty and nine gold pieces, and in my right a ring with stones of price, and, moreover, here behold a goodly chain."
10064-8{_}818{_}So saying, the bowman drew from his bosom a gold chain, thick and long and heavy, and held it up in the sunlight.
10064-8{_}819{_}"I got this, Sir Dove, together with the ring and divers other toys, at the storming of Belsaye, five years agone.
10064-8{_}820{_}Aha!
10064-8{_}821{_}a right good town is Belsaye, and growing rich and fat against another plucking."
10064-8{_}822{_}"And how came Belsaye to be stormed?"
10064-8{_}823{_}Quoth Giles the Bowman, eying his golden chain:  "My lord Duke Ivo had a mind to a certain lady, who was yet but a merchant's daughter, look ye.
10064-8{_}824{_}But she was young and wondrous fair, for Duke Ivo hath a quick eye and rare judgment in such pretty matters.
10064-8{_}825{_}But she (and she but a merchant's daughter!)
10064-8{_}826{_}took it ill, and when Duke Ivo's messengers came to bear her to his presence, she whined and struggled, as is ever woman's way, and thereafter in the open street snatched a dagger and thereupon, before her father's very eye did slay herself (and she but a merchant's daughter!
10064-8{_}827{_}), whereat some hot-head plucked out sword and other citizens likewise, and of my lord Duke's messengers there none escaped save one and he sore wounded.
10064-8{_}828{_}So Belsaye city shut its gates 'gainst my lord Duke and set out fighting-hoards upon its walls.
10064-8{_}829{_}Yet my lord Duke battered and breached it, for few can match him in a siege, and stormed it within three days.
10064-8{_}830{_}And, by Saint Giles, though he lost the merchant's daughter methinks he lacked not at all, for the women of Belsaye are wondrous fair."
10064-8{_}831{_}The rising sun made a glory all about them, pouring his beams 'twixt mighty trees whose knotted, far-flung branches dappled the way here and there with shadow; but now Beltane saw nought of it by reason that he walked with head a-droop and eyes that stared earthward; moreover his hands were clenched and his lips close and grim-set.
10064-8{_}832{_}As for Giles o' the Bow, he chirrupped merrily to the ass, and whistled full melodiously, mocking a blackbird that piped amid the green.
10064-8{_}833{_}Yet in a while he turned to stare at Beltane rubbing at his square, shaven chin with strong, brown fingers.
10064-8{_}834{_}"Forsooth," quoth he, nodding, "thou'rt a lusty fellow, Sir Gentleness, by the teeth of St. Giles, which is my patron saint, ne'er saw I a goodlier spread of shoulder nor such a proper length of arm to twirl an axe withal, and thy legs like me well--hast the makings of a right lusty man-at-arms in thee, despite thy soft and peaceful look!"
10064-8{_}835{_}"Yet a lover of peace am I!"
10064-8{_}836{_}said Beltane, his head yet drooping.
10064-8{_}837{_}"Peace, quotha--peace?
10064-8{_}838{_}Ha?
10064-8{_}839{_}by all the holy saints--peace!
10064-8{_}840{_}A soft word!
10064-8{_}841{_}A woman's word!
10064-8{_}842{_}A word smacking of babes and milk!
10064-8{_}843{_}Out upon thee, what hath a man with such an arm--aye, and legs--to do with peace?
10064-8{_}844{_}An you would now, I could bring ye to good service 'neath Duke Ivo's banner.
10064-8{_}845{_}'Tis said he hath sworn, this year, to burn Thrasfordham keep, to hang Benedict o' the Mark and lay waste to Bourne.
10064-8{_}846{_}Aha!
10064-8{_}847{_}you shall see good fighting 'neath Ivo's banner, Sir Dove!"
10064-8{_}848{_}Then Beltane raised his head and spake, swift and sudden, on this wise:  "An I must fight, the which God forbid, yet once this my sword is drawn ne'er shall it rest till I lie dead or Black Ivo is no more."
10064-8{_}849{_}Then did the archer stare upon my Beltane in amaze with eyes full wide and mouth agape, nor spake he for awhile, then:  "Black Ivo--thou!"
10064-8{_}850{_}he cried, and laughed amain.
10064-8{_}851{_}"Go to, my tender youth," said he, "methinks a lute were better fitted to thy hand than that great sword o' thine."
10064-8{_}852{_}Now beholding Beltane's gloomy face, he smiled within his hand, yet eyed him thoughtfully thereafter, and so they went with never a word betwixt them.
10064-8{_}853{_}But, in a while, the archer fell to snuffing the air, and clapped Beltane upon the shoulder.
10064-8{_}854{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}855{_}quoth he, "methinks we reach the fair Duchy of Pentavalon; smell ye aught, brother?"
10064-8{_}856{_}And now, indeed, Beltane became aware of a cold wind, foul and noisome, a deadly, clammy air breathing of things corrupt, chilling the flesh with swift unthinking dread; and, halting in disgust, he looked about him left and right.
10064-8{_}857{_}"Above--above!"
10064-8{_}858{_}cried Giles o' the Bow, "this is Sir Pertolepe's country--look you heavenward, Sir Innocence!"
10064-8{_}859{_}Then, lifting his eyes to the shivering leaves overhead, Beltane of a sudden espied a naked foot--a down-curving, claw-like thing, shrivelled and hideous, and, glancing higher yet, beheld a sight to blast the sun from heaven: now staring up at the contorted horror of this shrivelled thing that once had lived and laughed, Beltane let fall his staff and, being suddenly sick and faint, sank upon his knees and, covering his eyes, crouched there in the grass the while that grisly, silent thing swayed to and fro above him in the gentle wind of morning and the cord whereby it hung creaked faintly.
10064-8{_}860{_}"How now--how now!"
10064-8{_}861{_}cried Giles; "do ye blench before this churlish carrion?
10064-8{_}862{_}Aha!
10064-8{_}863{_}ye shall see the trees bear many such hereabouts.
10064-8{_}864{_}Get up, my qualmish, maid-like youth; he ne'er shall injure thee nor any man again--save by the nose--faugh!
10064-8{_}865{_}Rise, rise and let us be gone."
10064-8{_}866{_}So, presently Beltane, shivering, got him to his feet and looking up, pale-faced, beheld upon the ragged breast a parchment with this legend in fair, good writing:  HE KILLED A DEER  Then spake Beltane 'twixt pallid lips:  "And do they hang men for killing deer in this country?"
10064-8{_}867{_}"Aye, forsooth, and very properly, for, heed me, your ragged rogues be a plenty, but a stag is a noble creature and something scarcer-- moreover they be the Duke's."
10064-8{_}868{_}"By whose order was this done?"
10064-8{_}869{_}"Why, the parchment beareth the badge of Sir Pertolepe, called the Red.
10064-8{_}870{_}But look you, Sir Innocent, no man may kill a deer unless he be of gentle blood."
10064-8{_}871{_}"And wherefore?"
10064-8{_}872{_}"'Tis so the law!"
10064-8{_}873{_}"And who made the law?"
10064-8{_}874{_}"Why--as to that," quoth Giles, rubbing his chin, "as to that--what matters it to you or me?
10064-8{_}875{_}Pah!
10064-8{_}876{_}come away lest I stifle!"
10064-8{_}877{_}But now, even as they stood thus, out of the green came a cry, hoarse at first but rising ever higher until it seemed to fill the world about and set the very leaves a-quiver.
10064-8{_}878{_}Once it came, and twice, and so--was gone.
10064-8{_}879{_}Then Beltane trembling, stooped and caught up his long quarter-staff, and seized the bowman in a shaking hand that yet was strong, and dragging him from the ass all in a moment, plunged into the underbrush whence the cry had come.
10064-8{_}880{_}And, in a while, they beheld a cottage upon whose threshold a child lay--not asleep, yet very still; and beyond the cottage, his back to a tree, a great hairy fellow, quarter-staff in hand, made play against five others whose steel caps and ringed hauberks glittered in the sun.
10064-8{_}881{_}Close and ever closer they beset the hairy man who, bleeding at the shoulder, yet swung his heavy staff; but ever the glittering pike-heads thrust more close.
10064-8{_}882{_}Beside the man a woman crouched, young and of comely seeming, despite wild hair and garments torn and wrenched, who of a sudden, with another loud cry, leapt before the hairy man covering him with her clinging body and, in that moment, her scream died to a choking gasp and she sank huddled 'neath a pike-thrust.
10064-8{_}883{_}Then Beltane leapt, the great sword flashing in his grasp, and smote the smiter and set his feet upon the writhing body and smote amain with terrible arm, and his laughter rang out fierce and wild.
10064-8{_}884{_}So for a space, sword clashed with pike, but ever Beltane, laughing loud, drave them before him till but two remained and they writhing upon the sward.
10064-8{_}885{_}Then Beltane turned to see Giles o' the Bow, who leaned against a tree near by, wide-eyed and pale.
10064-8{_}886{_}"Look!"
10064-8{_}887{_}he cried, pointing with quivering finger, "one dead and one sore hurt--Saint Giles save us, what have ye done?
10064-8{_}888{_}These be Sir Pertolepe's foresters--behold his badge!"
10064-8{_}889{_}But Beltane laughed, fierce-eyed.
10064-8{_}890{_}"How, bowman, dost blench before a badge, then?
10064-8{_}891{_}I was too meek and gentle for thee ere this, but now, if thou'rt afraid--get you gone!"
10064-8{_}892{_}"Art surely mad!"
10064-8{_}893{_}quoth Giles.
10064-8{_}894{_}"The saints be my witness here was no act of mine!"
10064-8{_}895{_}So saying he turned away and hasted swift-footed through the green.
10064-8{_}896{_}Now when the bowman was gone, Beltane turned him to the hairy man who yet kneeled beside the body of the woman.
10064-8{_}897{_}Said he:  "Good fellow, is there aught I may do for thee?"
10064-8{_}898{_}"Wife and child--and dead!"
10064-8{_}899{_}the man muttered, "child and wife--and dead!
10064-8{_}900{_}A week ago, my brother--and now, the child, and then the wife!
10064-8{_}901{_}Child and wife and brother--and dead!"
10064-8{_}902{_}Then Beltane came, minded to aid him with the woman, but the hairy man sprang before her, swinging his great staff and muttering in his beard; therefore Beltane, sick at heart, turned him away.
10064-8{_}903{_}And, in a while, being come to the road once more, he became aware that he yet grasped his sword and beheld its bright steel dimmed here and there with blood, and, as he gazed, his brow grew dark and troubled.
10064-8{_}904{_}"'Tis thus have I made beginning," he sighed, "so now, God aiding me, ne'er will I rest 'till peace be come again and tyranny made an end of!"
10064-8{_}905{_}Then, very solemnly, did my Beltane kneel him beside the way and lifting the cross hilt of his sword to heaven kissed it, and thereafter rose.
10064-8{_}906{_}And so, having cleansed the steel within the earth, he sheathed the long blade and went, slowfooted, upon his way.
10064-8{_}907{_}CHAPTER VIII  HOW BELTANE HELD DISCOURSE WITH A BLACK FRIAR  The sun was high, and by his shadow Beltane judged it the noon hour; very hot and very still it was, for the wind had died and leaf and twig hung motionless as though asleep.
10064-8{_}908{_}And presently as he went, a sound stole upon the stillness, a sound soft and beyond all things pleasant to hear, the murmurous ripple of running water near by.
10064-8{_}909{_}Going aside into the green therefore, Beltane came unto a brook, and here, screened from the sun 'neath shady willows, he laid him down to drink, and to bathe face and hands in the cool water.
10064-8{_}910{_}Now as he lay thus, staring sad-eyed into the hurrying waters of the brook, there came to him the clicking of sandalled feet, and glancing up, he beheld one clad as a black friar.
10064-8{_}911{_}A fat man he was, jolly of figure and mightily round; his nose was bulbous and he had a drooping lip.
10064-8{_}912{_}"Peace be unto thee, my son!"
10064-8{_}913{_}quoth he, breathing short and loud, "an evil day for a fat man who hath been most basely bereft of a goodly ass --holy Saint Dunstan, how I gasp!"
10064-8{_}914{_}and putting back the cowl from his tonsured crown, he puffed out his cheeks and mopped his face.
10064-8{_}915{_}"Hearkee now, good youth, hath there passed thee by ever a ribald in an escalloped hood--an unhallowed, long-legged, scurvy archer knave astride a fair white ass, my son?"
10064-8{_}916{_}"Truly," nodded Beltane, "we parted company scarce an hour since."
10064-8{_}917{_}The friar sat him down in the shade of the willows and sighing, mopped his face again; quoth he:  "Now may the curse of Saint Augustine, Saint Benedict, Saint Cuthbert and Saint Dominic light upon him for a lewd fellow, a clapper-claw, a thieving dog who hath no regard for Holy Church--forsooth a most vicious rogue, _monstrum nulla virtute redemptum a vitiis_!"
10064-8{_}918{_}"Good friar, thy tongue is something harsh, methinks.
10064-8{_}919{_}Here be four saints with as many curses, and all for one small ass!"
10064-8{_}920{_}The friar puffed out his cheeks and sighed:  "'Twas a goodly ass, my son, a fair and gentle beast and of an easy gait, and I am one that loveth not to trip it in the dust.
10064-8{_}921{_}Moreover 'twas the property of Holy Church!
10064-8{_}922{_}To take from thy fellow is evil, to steal from thy lord is worse, but to ravish from Holy Church--_per de_ 'tis sacrilege, 'tis foul blasphemy thrice--aye thirty times damned and beyond all hope of redemption!
10064-8{_}923{_}So now do I consign yon archer-knave to the lowest pit of Acheron--_damnatus est_, amen!
10064-8{_}924{_}Yet, my son, here--by the mercy of heaven is a treasure the rogue hath overlooked, a pasty most rarely seasoned that I had this day from my lord's own table.
10064-8{_}925{_}'Tis something small for two, alack and yet--stay--who comes?"
10064-8{_}926{_}Now, lifting his head, Beltane beheld a man, bent and ragged who crept towards them on a stick; his face, low-stooped, was hid 'neath long and matted hair, but his tatters plainly showed the hideous nakedness of limbs pinched and shrunken by famine, while about his neck was a heavy iron collar such as all serfs must needs wear.
10064-8{_}927{_}Being come near he paused, leaning upon his staff, and cried out in a strange, cracked voice:  "O ye that are strong and may see the blessed sun, show pity on one that is feeble and walketh ever in the dark!"
10064-8{_}928{_}And now, beneath the tangled hair, Beltane beheld a livid face in whose pale oval, the eyeless sockets glowed fierce and red; moreover he saw that the man's right arm was but a mutilated stump, whereat Beltane shivered and, bowing his head upon his hands, closed his eyes.
10064-8{_}929{_}"Oho!"
10064-8{_}930{_}cried the friar, "and is it thou, Simon?
10064-8{_}931{_}Trouble ye the world yet, child of Satan?"
10064-8{_}932{_}Hereupon the blind man fell upon his knees.
10064-8{_}933{_}"Holy father," he groaned, clasping his withered arms upon his gaunt breast, "good Friar Gui I die of hunger; aid me lest I perish.
10064-8{_}934{_}'Tis true I am outlaw and no man may minister unto me, yet be merciful, give me to eat--O gentle Christ, aid me--"  "How!"
10064-8{_}935{_}cried the friar, "dare ye speak that name, ye that are breaker of laws human and divine, ye that are murderer, dare ye lift those bloody hands to heaven?"
10064-8{_}936{_}"Holy sir," quoth Beltane, "he hath but one; I pray you now give him to eat."
10064-8{_}937{_}"Feed an outlaw!
10064-8{_}938{_}Art mad, young sir?
10064-8{_}939{_}Feed a murderer, a rogue banned by Holy Church, a serf that hath raised hand 'gainst his lord?
10064-8{_}940{_}He should have hanged when the witch his daughter burned, but that Sir Pertolepe, with most rare mercy, gave to the rogue his life."
10064-8{_}941{_}"But," sighed Beltane, "left him to starve--'tis a death full as sure yet slower, methinks.
10064-8{_}942{_}Come, let us feed him."
10064-8{_}943{_}"I tell thee, fond youth, he is excommunicate.
10064-8{_}944{_}Wouldst have me contravene the order of Holy Church?
10064-8{_}945{_}Go to!"
10064-8{_}946{_}Then my Beltane put his hand within his pouch and taking thence a gold piece held it out upon his palm; said he:  "Friar, I will buy the half of thy pasty of thee!"
10064-8{_}947{_}Hereupon Friar Gui stared from the gold to the pasty, and back again.
10064-8{_}948{_}"So much!"
10064-8{_}949{_}quoth he, round-eyed.
10064-8{_}950{_}"Forsooth 'tis a noble pasty and yet-- nay, nay, tempt me not--_retro Sathanas!_" and closing his eyes he crossed himself.
10064-8{_}951{_}Then Beltane took out other two gold pieces and set them in the blind man's bony hand, saying:  "Take these three gold pieces and buy you food, and thereafter--"  "Gold!"
10064-8{_}952{_}cried the blind man, "gold!
10064-8{_}953{_}Now the Saints keep and bless thee, young sir, sweet Jesu love thee ever!"
10064-8{_}954{_}and fain would he have knelt to kiss my Beltane's feet.
10064-8{_}955{_}But Beltane raised him up with gentle hand, speaking him kindly, as thus:  "Tell now, I pray you, how came ye to slay?"
10064-8{_}956{_}"Stay!
10064-8{_}957{_}stay!"
10064-8{_}958{_}cried Friar Gui, "bethink thee, good youth--so much gold, 'tis a very fortune!
10064-8{_}959{_}With so much, masses might be sung for his wretched soul; give it therefore to Holy Church, so shall he, peradventure, attain Paradise."
10064-8{_}960{_}"Not so," answered Beltane, "I had rather he, of a surety, attain a full belly, Sir Friar."
10064-8{_}961{_}Then, turning his back upon the friar, Beltane questioned the blind man again, as thus:  "Tell me, an ye will, how ye came to shed blood?"
10064-8{_}962{_}and the outlaw, kneeling at Beltane's feet answered with bowed head:  "Noble sir, I had a daughter and she was young and fair, therefore came my lord Pertolepe's chief verderer to bear her to my lord.
10064-8{_}963{_}But she cried to me and I, forgetting my duty to my lord, took my quarter-staff and, serf though I was, smote the chief verderer that he died thereafter, but, ere he died, he named my daughter witch.
10064-8{_}964{_}And, when they had burned her, they put out mine eyes, and cut off my hand, and made of me an outlaw.
10064-8{_}965{_}So is my sin very heavy upon me."
10064-8{_}966{_}Now when the man had made an end, Beltane stood silent awhile, then, reaching down, he aided the blind man to his feet.
10064-8{_}967{_}"Go you to Mortain," said he, "seek out the hermit Ambrose that liveth in Holy Cross Thicket; with him shall you find refuge, and he, methinks, will surely win thy soul to heaven."
10064-8{_}968{_}So the blind man blessed my Beltane and turning, crept upon his solitary way.
10064-8{_}969{_}"Youth," said the friar, frowning up into Beltane's gentle eyes, "thou hast this day put thy soul in jeopardy--the Church doth frown upon this thy deed!"
10064-8{_}970{_}"And yet, most reverend sir, God's sun doth shine upon this my body!"
10064-8{_}971{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}972{_}"He who aideth an evil-doer is enemy to the good!"
10064-8{_}973{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}974{_}"Yet he who seeketh to do good to evil that good may follow, doeth no evil to good."
10064-8{_}975{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}976{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}977{_}thou art a menace to the state--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}978{_}"So shall I be, I pray God, the whiles this state continue!"
10064-8{_}979{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}980{_}"Thou art either rogue or fool!"
10064-8{_}981{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}982{_}"Well, thou hast thy choice."
10064-8{_}983{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}984{_}"Alack!
10064-8{_}985{_}this sorry world is full of rogues and fools and--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}986{_}"And friars!"
10064-8{_}987{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}988{_}"Who seek the salvation of this wretched world."
10064-8{_}989{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}990{_}"As how?"
10064-8{_}991{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}992{_}"Forsooth we meditate and pray--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}993{_}"And eat!"
10064-8{_}994{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}995{_}"Aye verily, we do a little in that way as the custom is, for your reverent eater begetteth a devout pray-er.
10064-8{_}996{_}The which mindeth me I grow an hungered, yet will I forego appetite and yield thee this fair pasty for but two of thy gold pieces.
10064-8{_}997{_}And, look ye, 'tis a noble pasty I had this day from my lord Pertolepe's own table."
10064-8{_}998{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}999{_}"That same lord that showed mercy on yonder poor maimed wretch?
10064-8{_}1000{_}Know you him?"
10064-8{_}1001{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1002{_}"In very sooth, and 'tis a potent lord that holdeth me in some esteem, a most Christian knight--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1003{_}"That ravisheth the defenceless!
10064-8{_}1004{_}Whose hands be foul with the blood of innocence--"  FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1005{_}"How--how?
10064-8{_}1006{_}'Tis a godly lord who giveth bounteously to Holy Church--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1007{_}"Who stealeth from the poor--"  FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1008{_}"Stealeth!
10064-8{_}1009{_}Holy Saint Dunstan, dare ye speak thus of so great a lord--a son of the Church, a companion of our noble Duke?
10064-8{_}1010{_}Steal, forsooth!
10064-8{_}1011{_}The poor have nought to steal!"
10064-8{_}1012{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1013{_}"They have their lives."
10064-8{_}1014{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1015{_}"Not so, they and their lives are their lord's, 'tis so the law and--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1016{_}"Whence came this law?"
10064-8{_}1017{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1018{_}"It came, youth--it came--aye, of God!"
10064-8{_}1019{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1020{_}"Say rather of the devil!"
10064-8{_}1021{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1022{_}"Holy Saint Michael--'tis a blasphemous youth!
10064-8{_}1023{_}Never heard ears the like o' this--"  BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1024{_}"Whence cometh poverty and famine?"
10064-8{_}1025{_}FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1026{_}"'Tis a necessary evil!
10064-8{_}1027{_}Doth it not say in Holy Writ, 'the poor ye have always with you'?"
10064-8{_}1028{_}BELTANE.
10064-8{_}1029{_}"Aye, so shall ye ever--until the laws be amended.
10064-8{_}1030{_}So needs must men starve and starve--"  FRIAR.
10064-8{_}1031{_}"There be worse things!
10064-8{_}1032{_}And these serfs be born to starve, bred up to it, and 'tis better to starve here than to perish hereafter, better to purge the soul by lack of meat than to make of it a fetter of the soul!"
10064-8{_}1033{_}"Excellently said, holy sir!"
10064-8{_}1034{_}quoth Beltane, stooping of a sudden.
10064-8{_}1035{_}"But for this pasty now, 'tis a somewhat solid fetter, meseemeth, so now do I free thee of it--thus!"
10064-8{_}1036{_}So saying, my Beltane dropped the pasty into the deeper waters of the brook and, thereafter, took up his staff.
10064-8{_}1037{_}"Sir Friar," said he, "behold to-day is thy soul purged of a pasty against the day of judgment!"
10064-8{_}1038{_}Then Beltane went on beside the rippling waters of the brook, but above its plash and murmur rose the deeptoned maledictions of Friar Gui.
10064-8{_}1039{_}CHAPTER IX  WHEREIN IS SOME ACCOUNT OF THE PHILOSOPHY OF FOLLY AND THE WISDOM OF A FOOL   As the day advanced the sun grew ever hotter; birds chirped drowsily from hedge and thicket, and the warm, still air was full of the slumberous drone of a myriad unseen wings.
10064-8{_}1040{_}Therefore Beltane sought the deeper shade of the woods and, risking the chance of roving thief or lurking foot-pad, followed a devious course by reason of the underbrush.
10064-8{_}1041{_}Now as he walked him thus, within the cool, green twilight, watchful of eye and with heavy quarter-staff poised upon his shoulder, he presently heard the music of a pipe now very mournful and sweet, anon breaking into a merry lilt full of rippling trills and soft, bubbling notes most pleasant to be heard.
10064-8{_}1042{_}Wherefore he went aside and thus, led by the music, beheld a jester in his motley lying a-sprawl beneath a tree.
10064-8{_}1043{_}A long-legged knave was he, pinched and something doleful of visage yet with quick bright eyes that laughed 'neath sombre brows, and a wide, up-curving mouth; upon his escalloped cape and flaunting cock's-comb were many little bells that rang a silvery chime as, up-starting to his elbow, he greeted my Beltane thus:  "Hail, noble, youthful Sir, and of thy sweet and gracious courtesy I pray you mark me this--the sun is hot, my belly lacketh, and thou art a fool!"
10064-8{_}1044{_}"And wherefore?"
10064-8{_}1045{_}questioned Beltane, leaning him upon his quarter-staff.
10064-8{_}1046{_}"For three rarely reasonable reasons, sweet sir, as thus:--item, for that the sun burneth, item, my belly is empty, and item, thou, lured by this my foolish pipe art hither come to folly.
10064-8{_}1047{_}So I, a fool, do greet thee, fool, and welcome thee to this my palace of ease and pleasaunce where, an ye be minded to list to the folly of a rarely foolish fool, I will, with foolish jape and quip, befool thy mind to mirth and jollity, for thou art a sad fool, methinks, and something melancholic!"
10064-8{_}1048{_}Quoth Beltane, sighing:  "'Tis a sad world and very sorrowful!"
10064-8{_}1049{_}"Nay--'tis a sweet world and very joyful--for such as have eyes to see withal!"
10064-8{_}1050{_}"To see?"
10064-8{_}1051{_}quoth Beltane, frowning, "this day have I seen a dead man a-swing on a tree, a babe dead beside its cradle, and a woman die upon a spear!
10064-8{_}1052{_}All day have I breathed an air befouled by nameless evil; whithersoever I go needs must I walk 'twixt Murder and Shame!"
10064-8{_}1053{_}"Then look ever before thee, so shalt see neither."
10064-8{_}1054{_}"Yet will they be there!"
10064-8{_}1055{_}"Yet doth the sun shine in high heaven, so must these things be till God and the saints shall mend them.
10064-8{_}1056{_}But if thou must needs be doleful, go make thee troubles of thine own but leave the woes of this wide world to God!"
10064-8{_}1057{_}"Nay," said Beltane, shaking his head, "how if God leave these things to thee and me?"
10064-8{_}1058{_}"Why then methinks the world must wag as it will.
10064-8{_}1059{_}Yet must we repine therefore?
10064-8{_}1060{_}Out upon thee for a sober, long-legged, doleful wight.
10064-8{_}1061{_}Now harkee!
10064-8{_}1062{_}Here sit I--less fool!
10064-8{_}1063{_}A fool who hath, this day, been driven forth of my lord's presence with blows and cruel stripes!
10064-8{_}1064{_}And wherefore?
10064-8{_}1065{_}'Twas for setting a bird free of its cage, a small matter methinks--though there be birds--and birds, but mum for that!
10064-8{_}1066{_}Yet do I grieve and sigh therefore, O doleful long-shanks?
10064-8{_}1067{_}Not so--fie on't!
10064-8{_}1068{_}I blow away my sorrows through the music of this my little pipe and, lying here, set my wits a-dancing and lo!
10064-8{_}1069{_}I am a duke, a king, a very god!
10064-8{_}1070{_}I create me a world wherein is neither hunger nor stripes, a world of joy and laughter, for, blessed within his dreams, even a fool may walk with gods and juggle with the stars!"
10064-8{_}1071{_}"Aye," nodded Beltane, "but how when he awake?"
10064-8{_}1072{_}"Why then, messire," laughed the fellow, leaping nimbly to his feet, "why then doth he ask alms of thee, as thus: Prithee most noble messire, of thy bounty show kindness to a fool that lacks everything but wit.
10064-8{_}1073{_}So give, messire, give and spare not, so may thy lady prove kind, thy wooing prosper and love strengthen thee."
10064-8{_}1074{_}Now when the jester spake of love, my Beltane must needs sigh amain and shake a doleful head.
10064-8{_}1075{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}1076{_}said he, "within my life shall be no place for love, methinks."
10064-8{_}1077{_}"Heigho!"
10064-8{_}1078{_}sighed the jester, "thy very look doth proclaim thee lover, and 'tis well, for love maketh the fool wise and the wise fool, it changeth saints into rogues and rogues into saints, it teacheth the strong man gentleness and maketh the gentle strong.
10064-8{_}1079{_}'Tis sweeter than honey yet bitter as gall--Love!
10064-8{_}1080{_}ah, love can drag a man to hell or lift him high as heaven!"
10064-8{_}1081{_}"Aye verily," sighed Beltane, "I once did dream of such a love, but now am I awake, nor will I dream of love again, nor rest whiles Lust and Cruelty rule this sorrowful Duchy--"  "Ha, what would ye then, fond youth?"
10064-8{_}1082{_}"I am come to smite them hence," said Beltane, clenching mighty fists.
10064-8{_}1083{_}"How?"
10064-8{_}1084{_}cried the jester, wide of eye.
10064-8{_}1085{_}"Alone?"
10064-8{_}1086{_}"Nay, methinks God goeth with me.
10064-8{_}1087{_}Moreover, I have this sword!"
10064-8{_}1088{_}and speaking, Beltane touched the hilt of the great blade at his side.
10064-8{_}1089{_}"What--a sword!"
10064-8{_}1090{_}scoffed the jester, "think ye to mend the woes of thy fellows with a sword?
10064-8{_}1091{_}Go to, thou grave-visaged, youthful fool!
10064-8{_}1092{_}I tell thee, 'tis only humour and good fellowship can mend this wretched world, and there is nought so lacking in humour as a sword--unless it be your prating priest or mumbling monk.
10064-8{_}1093{_}A pope in cap and bells, now-- aha, there would be a world indeed, a world of joy and laughter!
10064-8{_}1094{_}No more gloom, no more bans and damnings of Holy Church, no more groaning and snivelling in damp cloister and mildewed chapel, no more burnings and hangings and rackings--"  "Yet," said Beltane, shaking his head, "yet would kings and dukes remain, Christian knights and godly lords to burn and hang and rack the defenceless."
10064-8{_}1095{_}"Aye, Sir Gravity," nodded the jester, "but the Church is paramount ever; set the pope a-blowing of tunes upon a reed and kings would lay by their sceptres and pipe too and, finding no time or lust for warring, so strife would end, swords rust and wit grow keen.
10064-8{_}1096{_}And wit, look you, biteth sharper than sword, laughter is more enduring than blows, and he who smiteth, smiteth only for lack of wit.
10064-8{_}1097{_}So, an you would have a happy world, lay by that great sword and betake thee to a little pipe, teach men to laugh and so forget their woes.
10064-8{_}1098{_}Learn wisdom of a fool, as thus: 'Tis better to live and laugh and beget thy kind than to perish by the sword or to dangle from a tree.
10064-8{_}1099{_}Here now is advice, and in this advice thy life, thus in giving thee advice so do I give thee thy life.
10064-8{_}1100{_}And I am hungry.
10064-8{_}1101{_}And in thy purse is money wherewith even a fool might come by food.
10064-8{_}1102{_}And youth is generous!
10064-8{_}1103{_}And thou art very young!
10064-8{_}1104{_}Come, sweet youthful messire, how much for thy life--and a fool's advice?"
10064-8{_}1105{_}Then Beltane smiled, and taking out one of his three remaining gold pieces, put it in the jester's hand.
10064-8{_}1106{_}"Fare thee well, good fool," said he, "I leave thee to thy dreams; God send they be ever fair--"  "Gold!"
10064-8{_}1107{_}cried the jester, spinning the coin upon his thumb, "ha, now do I dream indeed; may thy waking be ever as joyous.
10064-8{_}1108{_}Farewell to thee, thou kind, sweet, youthful fool, and if thou must hang some day on a tree, may every leaf voice small prayers for thy gentle soul!"
10064-8{_}1109{_}So saying, the jester nodded, waved aloft his bauble, and skipped away among the trees.
10064-8{_}1110{_}But as Beltane went, pondering the jester's saying, the drowsy stillness was shivered by a sudden, loud cry, followed thereafter by a clamour of fierce shouting; therefore Beltane paused and turning, beheld the jester himself who ran very fleetly, yet with three lusty fellows in close pursuit.
10064-8{_}1111{_}"Messire," panted the jester, wild of eye and with a trickle of blood upon his pallid face, "O sweet sir--let them not slay me!"
10064-8{_}1112{_}Now while he spake, and being yet some way off, he tripped and fell, and, as he lay thus the foremost of his pursuers, a powerful, red-faced man, leapt towards him, whirling up his quarter-staff to smite; but, in that moment, Beltane leapt also and took the blow upon his staff and swung it aloft, yet stayed the blow, and, bestriding the prostrate jester, spake soft and gentle, on this wise:  "Greeting to thee, forest fellow!
10064-8{_}1113{_}Thy red face liketh me well, let us talk together."
10064-8{_}1114{_}But, hereupon, as the red-faced man fell back, staring in amaze, there came his two companions, albeit panting and short of breath.
10064-8{_}1115{_}"What, Roger," cried one, "doth this fellow withstand thee?"
10064-8{_}1116{_}But Roger only growled, whiles Beltane smiled upon the three, gentle-eyed, but with heavy quarter-staff poised lightly in practised hand; quoth he:  "How now, would ye harm the fool?
10064-8{_}1117{_}'Tis a goodly fool forsooth, yet with legs scarce so nimble as his wit, and a tongue--ha, a golden tongue to win all men to humour and good fellowship--"  "Enough!"
10064-8{_}1118{_}growled red-faced Roger, "Sir Pertolepe's foresters we be, give us yon scurvy fool then, that we may hang him out of hand."
10064-8{_}1119{_}"Nay," answered Beltane, "first let us reason together, let us hark to the wisdom of Folly and grow wise--"  "Ha, Roger!"
10064-8{_}1120{_}cried one of the men, "tap me this tall rogue on his golden mazzard!"
10064-8{_}1121{_}"Or," said Beltane, "the fool shall charm thy souls to kindliness with his pipe--"  "Ho, Roger!"
10064-8{_}1122{_}cried the second forester, "split me this tall talker's yellow sconce, now!"
10064-8{_}1123{_}"Come," growled Roger, threatening of mien, "yield us the fool, 'tis an arrant knave hath angered his lord!"
10064-8{_}1124{_}"What matter for that," said Beltane, "so he hath not angered his God?
10064-8{_}1125{_}Come now, ye be hearty fellows and have faces that might be honest, tell me, how long will ye serve the devil?"
10064-8{_}1126{_}"Devil?
10064-8{_}1127{_}Ha, what talk be this?
10064-8{_}1128{_}We serve no devil!"
10064-8{_}1129{_}"Aye," nodded Beltane, "though they call him Pertolepe the Red, hereabouts."
10064-8{_}1130{_}"Devil!"
10064-8{_}1131{_}cried Black Roger aghast.
10064-8{_}1132{_}And, falling back a step he gaped in amaze from Beltane to his gaping fellows.
10064-8{_}1133{_}"Devil, forsooth!"
10064-8{_}1134{_}he gasped, "aha, I've seen many a man hang for less than this--"  "True," sighed Beltane, "men hang for small matters here in Pentavalon, and to hang is an evil death, methinks!"
10064-8{_}1135{_}"So, so!"
10064-8{_}1136{_}nodded Black Roger, grim-smiling, "I've watched them kick a fair good while, betimes!"
10064-8{_}1137{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}1138{_}cried Beltane, his eyes widening, "those hands of thine, belike, have hanged a man ere this?"
10064-8{_}1139{_}"Aye, many a score.
10064-8{_}1140{_}Oho!
10064-8{_}1141{_}folk know Black Roger's name hereabouts.
10064-8{_}1142{_}I carry ever a noose at my girdle here--behold it!"
10064-8{_}1143{_}and he showed a coil of rope that swung at his belt.
10064-8{_}1144{_}Now looking from the man's grim features to this murderous cord, Beltane blenched and shivered, whereat Black Roger laughed aloud, and pointed a scornful finger.
10064-8{_}1145{_}"Look'ee, 'tis fair, good rope this, and well-tried, and shall bear even thy great carcase sweetly--aye, sweetly--"  "How--would'st hang me also?"
10064-8{_}1146{_}said Beltane faintly, and the heavy quarter-staff sagged in his loosened grip.
10064-8{_}1147{_}"Hang thee--aye.
10064-8{_}1148{_}Thou didst withstand us with this fool, thou hast dared miscall our lord--we be all witnesses to it.
10064-8{_}1149{_}So now will we--"  But swift as lightning-flash, Beltane's long quarter-staff whirled and fell, and, for all his hood of mail, Black Roger threw wide his arms and, staggering, fell upon his face and so lay; then, fierce and grim, he had leapt upon the other two, and the air was full of the rattle and thud of vicious blows.
10064-8{_}1150{_}But these foresters were right lusty fellows and they, together, beset my Beltane so furiously, right and left, that he perforce gave back 'neath their swift and grievous blows and, being overmatched, turned and betook him to his heels, whereat they, incontinent, pursued with loud gibes and fierce laughter.
10064-8{_}1151{_}But on ran Beltane up the glade very fleetly yet watchful of eye, until, seeing one had outstripped his fellow, he checked his going somewhat, stumbling as one that is spent, whereat the forester shouted the louder and came on amain.
10064-8{_}1152{_}Then did my cunning Beltane leap aside and, leaping, turned and smote the fellow clean and true upon the crown, and, laughing to see him fall, ran in upon the other forester with whirling quarter-staff.
10064-8{_}1153{_}Now this fellow seeing himself stand alone, stayed not to abide the onset, but turning about, made off into the green.
10064-8{_}1154{_}Then Beltane leaned him, panting, upon his staff, what time the fallen man got him unsteadily to his legs and limped after his comrade; as for the jester, he was gone long since; only Black Roger lay upon his face and groaned faintly, ever and anon.
10064-8{_}1155{_}Wherefore came Beltane and stood above him as one in thought and, seeing him begin to stir, took from him his sword and coil of rope and loosing off his swordbelt, therewith bound his hands fast together and so, dragged him 'neath a tree that stood hard by.
10064-8{_}1156{_}Thus when at last Black Roger opened his eyes, he beheld Beltane standing above him and in his hand the deadly rope.
10064-8{_}1157{_}Now, looking from this to the desolation about him, Black Roger shivered, and gazing up into' the stern face above, his florid cheek grew pale.
10064-8{_}1158{_}"Master," said he hoarsely, "what would ye?"
10064-8{_}1159{_}"I would do to thee as thou hast done to others."
10064-8{_}1160{_}"Hang me?"
10064-8{_}1161{_}"Aye!"
10064-8{_}1162{_}quoth Beltane, and setting the noose about his neck, cast the rope across a branch.
10064-8{_}1163{_}"Master, how shall my death profit thee?"
10064-8{_}1164{_}"The world shall be the better, and thy soul know less of sin, mayhap."
10064-8{_}1165{_}"Master," said Black Roger, stooping to wipe sweat from his face with fettered hands, "I have store of money set by--"  But Beltane laughed with pallid lips, and, pulling upon the rope, dragged Black Roger, choking, to his feet.
10064-8{_}1166{_}"Master," he gasped, "show a little mercy--"  "Hast ever shown mercy to any man--speak me true!"
10064-8{_}1167{_}"Alack!--no, master!
10064-8{_}1168{_}And yet--"  "How then shall ye expect mercy?
10064-8{_}1169{_}Thou hast burnt and hanged and ravished the defenceless, so now shall be an end of it for thee, yet--O mark me this, thy name shall live on accursed in memory long after thou'rt but poor dust."
10064-8{_}1170{_}"Aye, there be many alive to curse Black Roger living, and many dead to curse me when I'm dead; poor Roger's soul shall find small mercy hereafter, methinks--ha, I never thought on this!"
10064-8{_}1171{_}"Thou had'st a mother--"  "Aye, but they burned her for a witch when I was but a lad.
10064-8{_}1172{_}As for me, 'tis true I've hanged men, yet I was my lord's chief verderer and did but as my lord commanded."
10064-8{_}1173{_}"A man hath choice of good or evil."
10064-8{_}1174{_}"Aye.
10064-8{_}1175{_}So now, an I must die--I must, but O master, say a prayer for me-- my sins lie very heavy--"  But Beltane, trembling, pulled upon the rope and swung Black Roger writhing in mid-air; then, of a sudden, loosing the rope, the forester fell and, while he lay gasping, Beltane stooped and loosed the rope from his neck.
10064-8{_}1176{_}"What now?"
10064-8{_}1177{_}groaned the forester, wild-eyed, "Sweet Jesu--ah, torture me not!"
10064-8{_}1178{_}"Take back thy life," said Beltane, "and I pray God that henceforth thou shalt make of it better use, and live to aid thy fellows, so shall they, mayhap, some day come to bless thy memory."
10064-8{_}1179{_}Then Black Roger, coming feebly to his knees, looked about him as one that wakes upon a new world, and lifted wide eyes from green earth to cloudless sky.
10064-8{_}1180{_}"To live!"
10064-8{_}1181{_}quoth he, "to live!"
10064-8{_}1182{_}And so, with sudden gesture, stooped his head to hide his face 'neath twitching fingers.
10064-8{_}1183{_}Hereupon Beltane smiled, gentle-eyed, yet spake not, and, turning, caught up his staff and went softly upon his way, leaving Black Roger the forester yet upon his knees.
10064-8{_}1184{_}CHAPTER X  HOW BELTANE MADE COMRADE ONE BLACK ROGER THAT WAS A HANGMAN   The sun was low what time Beltane came to a shrine that stood beside the way, where was a grot built by some pious soul for the rest and refreshment of wearied travellers; and here also was a crystal spring the which, bubbling up, fell with a musical plash into the basin hollowed within the rock by those same kindly hands.
10064-8{_}1185{_}Here Beltane stayed and, when he had drunk his fill, laid him down in the grateful shade and setting his cloak beneath his head, despite his hunger, presently fell asleep.
10064-8{_}1186{_}When he awoke the sun was down and the world was become a place of mystery and glooming shadow; a bird called plaintively afar off in the dusk, the spring bubbled softly near by, but save for this a deep silence brooded over all things; above the gloom of the trees the sky was clear, where bats wheeled and hovered, and beyond the purple upland an orbed moon was rising.
10064-8{_}1187{_}Now as Beltane breathed the cool, sweet air of evening and looked about him drowsily, he suddenly espied a shadow within the shadows, a dim figure--yet formidable and full of menace, and he started up, weapon in fist, whereupon the threatening figure stirred and spake:  "Master--'tis I!"
10064-8{_}1188{_}said a voice.
10064-8{_}1189{_}Then Beltane came forth of the grot and stared upon Black Roger, grave-eyed.
10064-8{_}1190{_}"O Hangman," said he, "where is thy noose?"
10064-8{_}1191{_}But Roger quailed and hung his head, and spake with eyes abased:  "Master, I burned it, together with my badge of service."
10064-8{_}1192{_}"And what would ye here?"
10064-8{_}1193{_}"Sir, I am a masterless man henceforth, for an I hang not men for Sir Pertolepe, so will Sir Pertolepe assuredly hang me."
10064-8{_}1194{_}"And fear ye death?"
10064-8{_}1195{_}"Messire, I--have hanged many men and--there were women also!
10064-8{_}1196{_}I have cut me a tally here on my belt, see--there be many notches--and every notch a life.
10064-8{_}1197{_}So now for every life these hands have taken do I vow to save a life an it may be so, and for every life saved would I cut away a notch until my belt be smooth again and my soul the lighter."
10064-8{_}1198{_}"Why come ye to me, Black Roger?"
10064-8{_}1199{_}"For that this day, at dire peril, I saw thee save a fool, Master.
10064-8{_}1200{_}So now am I come to thee to be thy man henceforth, to follow and serve thee while life remain."
10064-8{_}1201{_}"Why look now," quoth Beltane, "mine shall be a hard service and a dangerous, for I have mighty wrongs to set aright."
10064-8{_}1202{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}1203{_}belike thou art under some vow also, master?"
10064-8{_}1204{_}"Aye, verily, nor will I rest until it be accomplished or I am slain.
10064-8{_}1205{_}For mark this, lonely am I, with enemies a many and strong, yet because of my vow needs must I smite them hence or perish in the adventure.
10064-8{_}1206{_}Thus, he that companies me must go ever by desperate ways, and 'tis like enough Death shall meet him in the road."
10064-8{_}1207{_}"Master," quoth Black Roger, "this day have ye shown me death yet given me new life, so beseech thee let me serve thee henceforth and aid thee in this thy vow."
10064-8{_}1208{_}Now hereupon Beltane smiled and reached forth his hand; then Black Roger falling upon his knee, touched the hand to lip, and forehead and heart, taking him for his lord henceforth, and spake the oath of fealty: but when he would have risen, Beltane stayed him:  "What, Black Roger, thou hast sworn fealty and obedience to me--now swear me this to God:--to hold ever, and abide by, thy word: to shew mercy to the distressed and to shield the helpless at all times!"
10064-8{_}1209{_}And when he had sworn, Black Roger rose bright-eyed and eager.
10064-8{_}1210{_}"Lord," said he, "whither do we go?"
10064-8{_}1211{_}"Now," quoth Beltane, "shew me where I may eat, for I have a mighty hunger."
10064-8{_}1212{_}"Forsooth," quoth Roger, scratching his chin, "Shallowford village lieth but a bowshot through the brush yonder--yet, forsooth, a man shall eat little there, methinks, these days."
10064-8{_}1213{_}"Why so?"
10064-8{_}1214{_}"For that 'twas burned down, scarce a week agone--"  "Burned!--and wherefore?"
10064-8{_}1215{_}"Lord Pertolepe fell out with his neighbour Sir Gilles of Brandonmere-- upon the matter of some wench, methinks it was--wherefore came Sir Gilles' men by night and burned down Shallowford with twenty hunting dogs of Sir Pertolepe's that chanced to be there: whereupon my lord waxed mighty wroth and, gathering his company, came into the demesne of Sir Gilles and burned down divers manors and hung certain rogues and destroyed two villages--in quittance."
10064-8{_}1216{_}"Ah--and what of the village folk?"
10064-8{_}1217{_}"My lord, they were but serfs for the most part, but--for Sir Pertolepe's dogs--twenty and two--and roasted alive, poor beasts!"
10064-8{_}1218{_}But here Black Roger checked both speech and stride, all at once, and stood with quarter-staff poised as from the depth of the wood came the sound of voices and fierce laughter.
10064-8{_}1219{_}"Come away, master," he whispered, "these should be Sir Pertolepe's men, methinks."
10064-8{_}1220{_}But Beltane shook his head:  "I'm fain to see why they laugh," said he, and speaking, stole forward soft-footed amid the shadows; and so presently parting the leaves, looked down into an open dell or dingle full of the light of the rising moon; light that glinted upon the steel caps and hauberks of some score men, who leaned upon pike or gisarm about one who sat upon a fallen tree--and Beltane saw that this was Giles the Bowman.
10064-8{_}1221{_}But the arms of Giles were bound behind his back, about his neck hung a noose, and his face showed white and pallid 'neath the moon, as, lifting up his head, he began to sing:    "O ne'er shall my lust for the bowl decline,    Nor my love for my good long bow;    For as bow to the shaft and as bowl to the wine,    Is a--"  The rich voice was strangled to a gasping sob as the rope was tightened suddenly about the singer's brawny throat and he was swung, kicking, into the air amid the hoarse gibes and laughter of the men-at-arms.
10064-8{_}1222{_}But, grim and silent, Beltane leaped down among them, his long blade glittering in the moonlight, and before the mighty sweep of it they fell back, crowding upon each other and confused; then Beltane, turning, cut asunder the cord and Giles Brabblecombe fell and lay 'neath the shade of the tree, wheezing and whimpering in the grass.
10064-8{_}1223{_}And now with a clamour of cries and fierce rallying shouts, the men-at-arms, seeing Beltane stand alone, set themselves in array and began to close in upon him.
10064-8{_}1224{_}But Beltane, facing them in the tender moonlight, set the point of his sword to earth and reached out his mailed hand in salutation.
10064-8{_}1225{_}"Greeting, brothers!"
10064-8{_}1226{_}said he, "why seek ye the death of this our brother?
10064-8{_}1227{_}Come now, suffer him to go his ways in peace, and God's blessing on ye, one and all."
10064-8{_}1228{_}Now at this some laughed and some growled, and one stood forth before his fellows staring upon Beltane 'neath close-drawn, grizzled brows:  "'Tis a rogue, and shall dance for us upon a string!"
10064-8{_}1229{_}laughed he.
10064-8{_}1230{_}"And this tall fellow with him!"
10064-8{_}1231{_}said another.
10064-8{_}1232{_}"Aye, aye, let us hang 'em together," cried others.
10064-8{_}1233{_}"Stay!"
