10064-8{_}1234{_}said Beltane, "behold here money; so now will I ransom this man's life of ye.
10064-8{_}1235{_}Here be two pieces of gold, 'tis my all--yet take them and yield me his life!"
10064-8{_}1236{_}Hereupon the men fell to muttering together doubtfully, but in this moment the grizzled man of a sudden raised a knotted fist and shook it in the air.
10064-8{_}1237{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}1238{_}cried he, pointing to Beltane, "look ye, Cuthbert, Rollo--see ye not 'tis him we seek?
10064-8{_}1239{_}Mark ye the size of him, his long sword and belt of silver--'tis he that came upon us in the green this day and slew our comrade Michael.
10064-8{_}1240{_}Come now, let us hang him forthwith and share his money betwixt us after."
10064-8{_}1241{_}Then my Beltane sighed amain, and sighing, unsheathed his dagger.
10064-8{_}1242{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}1243{_}said he, "and must we shed each other's blood forsooth?
10064-8{_}1244{_}Come then, let us slay each other, and may Christ have pity on our souls!"
10064-8{_}1245{_}Thus saying, he glanced up at the pale splendour of the moon, and round him on the encircling shadows of the woods dense and black beneath the myriad leaves, and so, quick-eyed and poised for action, waited for the rush.
10064-8{_}1246{_}And, even as they came upon him, he sprang aside where the gloom lay blackest, and they being many and the clearing small, they hampered each other and fell into confusion; and, in that moment, Beltane leapt among them and smote, and smote again, now in the moonlight, now in shadow; leaping quick-footed from the thrust of sword and pike, crouching 'neath the heavy swing of axe and gisarm; and ever his terrible blade darted with deadly point or fell with deep-biting edge.
10064-8{_}1247{_}Hands gripped at him from the gloom, arms strove to clasp him, but his dagger-hand was swift and strong.
10064-8{_}1248{_}Pike heads leapt at him and were smitten away, axe and gisarm struck, yet found him not, and ever, as he leapt, he smote.
10064-8{_}1249{_}And now in his ears were cries and groans and other hateful sounds, and to his nostrils came a reek of sweating flesh and the scent of trampled grass; while the moon's tender light showed faces wild and fierce, that came and went, now here--now there; it glinted on head-piece and ringed mail, and flashed back from whirling steel--a round, placid moon that seemed, all at once, to burst asunder and vanish, smitten into nothingness.
10064-8{_}1250{_}He was down--beaten to his knee, deafened and half blind, but struggling to his feet he staggered out from the friendly shadow of the trees, out into the open.
10064-8{_}1251{_}A sword, hard-driven, bent and snapped short upon his triple mail, the blow of a gisarm half stunned him, a goring pike-thrust drove him reeling back, yet, ringed in by death, he thrust and smote with failing arm.
10064-8{_}1252{_}Axe and pike, sword and gisarm hedged him in nearer and nearer, his sword grew suddenly heavy and beyond his strength to wield, but stumbling, slipping, dazed and with eyes a-swim, he raised the great blade aloft, and lifting drooping head, cried aloud the battle-cry of his house-- high and clear it rang above the din:  "Arise!
10064-8{_}1253{_}Arise!
10064-8{_}1254{_}I will arise!"
10064-8{_}1255{_}And even in that moment came one in answer to the cry, one that leapt to his right hand, a wild man and hairy who plied a gleaming axe and, 'twixt each stroke, seemed, from hairy throat, to echo back the cry:  "Arise!
10064-8{_}1256{_}Arise!"
10064-8{_}1257{_}And now upon his left was Black Roger, fierce-eyed behind his buckler.
10064-8{_}1258{_}Thereafter a voice hailed them as from far away, a sweet, deep voice, cheery and familiar as one heard aforetime in a dream, and betwixt every sentence came the twang of swift-drawn bow-string.
10064-8{_}1259{_}"O tall brother, fall back!
10064-8{_}1260{_}O gentle paladin, O fair flower of lusty fighters, fall back and leave the rest to our comrades, to me and my good bow, here!"
10064-8{_}1261{_}So, dazed and breathless, came Beltane on stumbling feet and leaned him gasping in the shadow of a great tree whereby stood Giles o' the Bow with arrows planted upright in the sod before him, the which he snatched and loosed so fast 'twas a wonder to behold.
10064-8{_}1262{_}Of a sudden he uttered a shout and, setting by his bow, drew sword, and leaping from the shadow, was gone.
10064-8{_}1263{_}But, as for Beltane, he leaned a while against the tree as one who is very faint; yet soon, lifting heavy head, wondered at the hush of all things, and looking toward the clearing saw it empty and himself alone; therefore turned he thitherwards.
10064-8{_}1264{_}Now as he went he stumbled and his foot struck a something soft and yielding that rolled before him in the shadow out--out into the full brilliance of the moon, and looking down, he beheld a mangled head that stared up at him wide-eyed and with mouth agape.
10064-8{_}1265{_}Then Beltane let fall his reeking sword and staggering out into the light, saw his bright mail befouled with clotted blood, and of a sudden the world went black about him and he fell and lay with his face among the trampled grass.
10064-8{_}1266{_}In a while he groaned and opened his eyes to find Black Roger bathing his face what time Giles o' the Bow held wine to his lips, while at his feet, a wild figure grim and ragged, stood a tall, hairy man leaning upon a blood-stained axe.
10064-8{_}1267{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}1268{_}cried the bowman.
10064-8{_}1269{_}"Come now, my lovely fighter, my gentle giant, sup this--'tis life, and here behold a venison steak fit for Duke Ivo's self, come--"  "Nay, first," says Beltane, sitting up, "are there many hurt?"
10064-8{_}1270{_}"Aye, never fear for that, my blood-thirsty dove, they be all most completely dead save one, and he sore wounded, _laus Deo, amen!_"  "Dead!"
10064-8{_}1271{_}cried Beltane, shivering, "dead, say you?"
10064-8{_}1272{_}"Aye, Sir Paladin, all sweetly asleep in Abraham's bosom.
10064-8{_}1273{_}We three here accounted for some few betwixt us, the rest fell 'neath that great blade o' thine.
10064-8{_}1274{_}O sweet Saint Giles!
10064-8{_}1275{_}ne'er saw I such sword-work--point and edge, sa-ha!
10064-8{_}1276{_}And I called thee--dove!--aye 'dove' it was, I mind me.
10064-8{_}1277{_}O blind and worse than blind!
10064-8{_}1278{_}But _experientia docet_, tall brother!"
10064-8{_}1279{_}Now hereupon Beltane bowed his head and clasping his hands, wrung them.
10064-8{_}1280{_}"Sweet Jesu forgive me!"
10064-8{_}1281{_}he cried, "I had not meant to slay so many!"
10064-8{_}1282{_}Then he arose and went apart and, kneeling among the shadows, prayed long and fervently.
10064-8{_}1283{_}CHAPTER XI  WHICH TELLS HOW THREE MIGHTY MEN SWARE FEALTY TO BELTANE: AND HOW GOOD FRIAR MARTIN DIGGED A GRAVE IN THE WILD   Now when Beltane's mighty hunger was assuaged he sat--his aching head yet ringing with the blow--and stared up at the moon, sad and wistful-eyed as one full of heaviness the while Black Roger standing beside him gazed askance at the archer who sat near by whistling softly and busied with certain arrows, cleaning and trimming them ere he set them back in his quiver.
10064-8{_}1284{_}And presently Black Roger spake softly, low-stooping to Beltane's ear:  "Lord, we have saved the life of yon prating archer-fellow, and behold my belt lacketh for one notch, which is well.
10064-8{_}1285{_}So come, let us go our ways, thou and I, for I love not your talkers, and this fellow hath overmuch to say."
10064-8{_}1286{_}But now, ere Beltane could make reply, came the hairy man--but behold his rags had given place to fair garments of tanned leather (albeit something small) together with steel cap and shirt of ringed mail, and, about his middle, a broad belt where swung a heavy sword; being come to Beltane he paused leaning upon his axe, and gazed upon him fierce-eyed:  "Messire," said he, "who ye are I know not, what ye are I care not, for art quick of foot and mighty of arm, and when ye fight, cry a point of war, a battle-shout I knew aforetime ere they enslaved and made of me a serf--and thus it is I would follow thee."
10064-8{_}1287{_}Quoth Beltane, his aching head upon his hand:  "Whither?"
10064-8{_}1288{_}"To death if needs be, for a man must die soon or late, yet die but once whether it be by the steel, or flame, or rope.
10064-8{_}1289{_}So what matter the way of it, if I may stand with this my axe face to face with Gilles of Brandonmere, or Red Pertolepe of Garthlaxton Keep: 'twas for this I followed his foresters."
10064-8{_}1290{_}"Who and whence are you?"
10064-8{_}1291{_}"Walkyn o' the Dene they call me hereabouts--though I had another name once--but 'twas long ago, when I marched, a lad, 'neath the banner of Beltane the Strong!"
10064-8{_}1292{_}"What talk be this?"
10064-8{_}1293{_}grunted Black Roger, threatening of mien, "my lord and I be under a vow and must begone, and want no runaway serf crawling at our heels!"
10064-8{_}1294{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}1295{_}quoth Walkyn, "spake I to thee, hangman?
10064-8{_}1296{_}Forsooth, well do I know thee, Roger the Black: come ye into the glade yonder, so will I split thy black poll for thee--thou surly dog!"
10064-8{_}1297{_}Forth leapt Black Roger's sword, back swung Walkyn's glittering axe, but Beltane was between, and, as they stood thus came Giles o' the Bow:  "Oho!"
10064-8{_}1298{_}he laughed, "must ye be at it yet?
10064-8{_}1299{_}Have we not together slain of Sir Pertolepe's foresters a round score?--"  "'Twas but nineteen!"
10064-8{_}1300{_}growled Roger, frowning at Walkyn.
10064-8{_}1301{_}"So will I make of this hangman the twentieth!"
10064-8{_}1302{_}said Walkyn, frowning at Roger.
10064-8{_}1303{_}"'Tis a sweet thought," laughed the archer, "to it, lads, and slay each other as soon as ye may, and my blessings on ye.
10064-8{_}1304{_}As for us, Sir Paladin, let us away--'tis true we together might give check to an army, yet, minding Sir Pertolepe's nineteen foresters, 'twere wiser to hie us from Sir Pertolepe's country for the nonce: so march, tall brother--march!"
10064-8{_}1305{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}1306{_}snarled Walkyn, "fear ye Red Pertolepe yet, bowman?
10064-8{_}1307{_}Well, we want ye not, my lord and I, he hath a sword and I an axe--they shall suffice us, mayhap, an Pertolepe come.
10064-8{_}1308{_}So hie thee hence with the hangman and save thy rogue's skin."
10064-8{_}1309{_}"And may ye dangle in a noose yet for a prating do-nothing!"
10064-8{_}1310{_}growled Roger.
10064-8{_}1311{_}"Oho!"
10064-8{_}1312{_}laughed Giles, with a flash of white teeth, "a hangman and a serf--must I slay both?"
10064-8{_}1313{_}But, ere he could draw sword, came a voice from the shadows near by--a deep voice, clear and very sweet:  "Oh, children," said the voice, "oh, children of God, put up your steel and pray for one whose white soul doth mount e'en now to heaven!"
10064-8{_}1314{_}and forth into the light came one clad as a white friar--a tall man and slender, and upon his shoulder he bare a mattock that gleamed beneath the moon.
10064-8{_}1315{_}His coarse, white robe, frayed and worn, was stained with earth and the green of grass, and was splashed, here and there, with a darker stain; pale was he, and hollow-cheeked, but with eyes that gleamed 'neath black brows and with chin long and purposeful.
10064-8{_}1316{_}Now at sight of him, fierce-eyed Walkyn cried aloud and flung aside his axe and, falling on his knees, caught the friar's threadbare robe and kissed it.
10064-8{_}1317{_}"Good brother!"
10064-8{_}1318{_}he groaned, "O, gentle brother Martin, pity me!"
10064-8{_}1319{_}"What, Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}1320{_}quoth the friar.
10064-8{_}1321{_}"What do ye thus equipped and so far from home?"
10064-8{_}1322{_}"Home have I none, henceforth, O my father."
10064-8{_}1323{_}"Ah!
10064-8{_}1324{_}What then of thy wife, Truda--of thy little son?"
10064-8{_}1325{_}"Dead, my father.
10064-8{_}1326{_}Red Pertolepe's men slew them this day within the green.
10064-8{_}1327{_}So, when I had buried them, I took my axe and left them with God: yet shall my soul go lonely, methinks, until my time be come."
10064-8{_}1328{_}Then Friar Martin reached out his hand and laid it upon Walkyn's bowed head: and, though the hand was hard and toil-worn, the touch of it was ineffably gentle, and he spake with eyes upraised to heaven:  "O Christ of Pity, look down upon this stricken soul, be Thou his stay and comfort.
10064-8{_}1329{_}Teach him, in his grief and sorrow, to pity the woes of others, that, in comforting his fellows, he may himself find comfort."
10064-8{_}1330{_}Now when the prayer was ended he turned and looked upon the others, and, beholding Beltane in his might and glittering mail, he spake, saluting him as one of rank.
10064-8{_}1331{_}"Sir Knight," said he, "do these men follow thee?"
10064-8{_}1332{_}"Aye, verily," cried the archer, "that do I in sooth--_Verbum sat sapienti_--good friar."
10064-8{_}1333{_}"Not so," growled Roger, "'tis but a pestilent archer that seeketh but base hire.
10064-8{_}1334{_}I only am my lord's man, sworn to aid him in his vow."
10064-8{_}1335{_}"I also," quoth Walkyn, "an so my lord wills?"
10064-8{_}1336{_}"So shall it be," sighed Beltane, his hand upon his throbbing brow.
10064-8{_}1337{_}"And what have ye in mind to do?"
10064-8{_}1338{_}"Forsooth," cried Giles, "to fight, good friar, _manibus pedibusque_."
10064-8{_}1339{_}"To obey my lord," said Roger, "and speak good Saxon English."
10064-8{_}1340{_}"To adventure my body in battle with joyful heart," quoth Walkyn.
10064-8{_}1341{_}"To make an end of tyranny!"
10064-8{_}1342{_}sighed Beltane.
10064-8{_}1343{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}1344{_}said the friar, "within this doleful Duchy be tyrants a many, and ye are but four, meseemeth; yet if within your hearts be room for pity--follow me, and I will show you a sight, mayhap shall nerve you strong as giants.
10064-8{_}1345{_}Come!"
10064-8{_}1346{_}So Beltane followed the white friar with the three upon his heels who wrangled now no more; and in a while the friar paused beside a new-digged grave.
10064-8{_}1347{_}"Behold," said he, "the bed where we, each one, must sleep some day, and yet 'tis cold and hard, methinks, for one so young and tender!"
10064-8{_}1348{_}So saying he sighed, and turning, brought them to a hut near by, an humble dwelling of mud and wattles, dim-lighted by a glimmering rush.
10064-8{_}1349{_}But, being come within the hut Beltane stayed of a sudden and held his breath, staring wide-eyed at that which lay so still: then, baring his head, sank upon his knees.
10064-8{_}1350{_}She lay outstretched upon a bed of fern, and looked as one that sleeps save for the deathly pallor of her cheek and still and pulseless bosom: and she was young, and of a wondrous, gentle beauty.
10064-8{_}1351{_}"Behold," said the friar, "but one short hour agone this was alive--a child of God, pure of heart and undefiled.
10064-8{_}1352{_}These gentle hands lie stilled forever: this sweet, white body (O shame of men!)
10064-8{_}1353{_}blasted by brutality, maimed and torn--is nought but piteous clay to moulder in the year.
10064-8{_}1354{_}Yet doth her radiant soul lie on the breast of God forever, since she, for honour, died the death--Behold!"
10064-8{_}1355{_}So saying, the friar with sudden hand laid bare the still and marble bosom; and, beholding the red horror wrought there by cruel steel, Beltane rose up, and taking off his cloak, therewith reverently covered the pale, dead beauty of her, and so stood awhile with eyes close shut and spake, soft-voiced and slow, 'twixt pallid lips:  "How--came this--thing?"
10064-8{_}1356{_}"She was captive to Sir Pertolepe, by him taken in a raid, and he would have had her to his will: yet, by aid of my lord's jester, she escaped and fled hither.
10064-8{_}1357{_}But Sir Pertolepe's foresters pursued and took her and--so is she dead: may God requite them!"
10064-8{_}1358{_}"Amen!"
10064-8{_}1359{_}quoth Giles o' the Bow, hoarse-voiced, "so do they all lie dead within the green!"
10064-8{_}1360{_}"Save one!"
10064-8{_}1361{_}said Roger.
10064-8{_}1362{_}"But he sore wounded!"
10064-8{_}1363{_}quoth Walkyn.
10064-8{_}1364{_}"How!"
10064-8{_}1365{_}cried the friar aghast, "have ye indeed slain Sir Pertolepe's foresters?"
10064-8{_}1366{_}"Nineteen!"
10064-8{_}1367{_}nodded Roger, grimly.
10064-8{_}1368{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}1369{_}cried the friar, "may God save the poor folk hereabouts, for now will Sir Pertolepe wreak vengeance dire upon them."
10064-8{_}1370{_}"Then," said Beltane, "then must I have word with Sir Pertolepe."
10064-8{_}1371{_}Now when he said this, Black Roger stared agape and even the archer's tongue failed him for once; but Walkyn smiled and gripped his axe.
10064-8{_}1372{_}"Art mad, tall brother!"
10064-8{_}1373{_}cried Giles at length, "Sir Pertolepe would hang thee out of hand, or throw thee to his dogs!"
10064-8{_}1374{_}"Lord," said Roger, "Sir Pertolepe hath ten score men-at-arms in Garthlaxton, beside bowmen and foresters."
10064-8{_}1375{_}"There should be good work for mine axe!"
10064-8{_}1376{_}smiled Walkyn.
10064-8{_}1377{_}"None the less must I speak with him," said Beltane, and turned him to the door.
10064-8{_}1378{_}"Then will I die with thee, lord," growled Roger.
10064-8{_}1379{_}"So will I come and watch thee die--hangman, and loose a shaft or two on mine own account!"
10064-8{_}1380{_}But now, of a sudden, Walkyn raised a warning hand.
10064-8{_}1381{_}"Hark!"
10064-8{_}1382{_}said he: and, in a while, as they listened, upon the stillness came a rustle of leaves and thereafter a creeping step drawing slowly nearer: then swift and soft-treading, Walkyn stole out into the shadows.
10064-8{_}1383{_}Very soon he returned, leading a woman, pale and haggard, who clasped a babe within her threadbare cloak; her eyes were red and sore with much weeping and upon the threshold she paused as one in sudden fear, but espying the friar, she uttered a cry:  "O Father Martin--good father--pray, pray for the soul of him who is father to my child, but who at dawn must die with many others upon my lord Duke's great gallows!"
10064-8{_}1384{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}1385{_}cried the friar, wringing his hands, "what news is this?"
10064-8{_}1386{_}"O good friar," sobbed the woman, "my lord's hand hath been so heavy upon us of late--so heavy: and there came messengers from Thrasfordham in Bourne bidding us thither with fair promises:--and my father, being head of our village, hearkened to them and we made ready to cross into Bourne.
10064-8{_}1387{_}But my lord came upon us and burned our village of Shallowford and lashed my father with whips and thereafter hanged him, and took my man and many others and cast them into the great dungeon at Belsaye-- and with the dawn they must hang upon the Duke's great gallows."
10064-8{_}1388{_}So she ended and stood weeping as one that is hopeless and weary.
10064-8{_}1389{_}But of a sudden she screamed and pointed at Black Roger with her finger:  "'Tis Roger!"
10064-8{_}1390{_}she cried, "'tis Black Roger, that slew my father!"
10064-8{_}1391{_}Then Roger the Black groaned and hid his face within his arm and shrank before the woman's outstretched finger and, groaning, cowered to his knees; whereupon the archer turned his back and spat upon the floor while Walkyn glared and fingered his great axe: but in this moment my Beltane came beside him and laid his hand on Roger's stooping shoulder.
10064-8{_}1392{_}"Nay," said he, "this is my friend henceforth, a man among men, who liveth to do great things as thus: To-night he will give back to thee the father of thy child, and break open the dungeon of Belsaye!"
10064-8{_}1393{_}Thus spake my Beltane while all stared at his saying and held their peace because of their amaze: only Black Roger turned of a sudden and caught his hand and kissed it savagely.
10064-8{_}1394{_}"Sir," said the woman, peering up in Beltane's face, "Lord--ah, would ye mock the weak and helpless--"  "Nay," said Beltane gently, "as God seeth me, to-night the prisoners shall go free, or this man and I die with them.
10064-8{_}1395{_}So now be comforted--go you to Bourne, to Sir Benedict within Thrasfordham Keep, and say you come from Beltane, Duke of Pentavalon, who swore thee, by the honour of the Duke Beltane his father, that never again shall a man hang from the great gallows of Black Ivo the usurper--from this night it shall cease to be!"
10064-8{_}1396{_}Now would the woman have knelt and kissed his hand, but Beltane smiled and brought her to the door.
10064-8{_}1397{_}Then, wondering and amazed, she made her obeisance to Beltane and with her babe clasped to her bosom went forth into the night.
10064-8{_}1398{_}Thereafter Beltane turned and looked grave-eyed upon the three.
10064-8{_}1399{_}"My masters," quoth he, "ye have heard my words, how this night I go to take down Black Ivo's great gallows.
10064-8{_}1400{_}Come ye with me?
10064-8{_}1401{_}Aye or no?"
10064-8{_}1402{_}"Aye, lord!"
10064-8{_}1403{_}cried the three in one acclaim.
10064-8{_}1404{_}"Do ye then stand with me henceforth 'gainst Black Ivo and all his might?
10064-8{_}1405{_}Aye or no?"
10064-8{_}1406{_}"Aye, lord!"
10064-8{_}1407{_}cried they again.
10064-8{_}1408{_}Then Beltane smiled and drew his sword and came to them, the great blade gleaming in his hand.
10064-8{_}1409{_}"'Tis well!"
10064-8{_}1410{_}said he, "but first come now and lay your hands here upon my sword and swear me this, each one,--To follow ever where I shall lead, to abide henceforth in brotherhood together, to smite evil within you and without, to be pitiful to the weak, and to honour God at all times."
10064-8{_}1411{_}Then did the three, being upon their knees, lay their hands upon the sword and swear the oath as Beltane commanded; now came the white friar and stared upon the sword and beholding the motto graven in the steel, lifted up his hand to heaven and cried aloud:--  "Now greeting and fair greeting to thee, lord Duke, may thy body be strong for war and thy head wise in the council, for Pentavalon hath dire need of thee, Beltane, son of Duke Beltane the Strong.
10064-8{_}1412{_}Moreover I was sent to thee by Sir Benedict of Bourne who bids thee 'Arise and follow' for that the time is at hand."
10064-8{_}1413{_}"How," cried Beltane, "art thou indeed from Sir Benedict?"
10064-8{_}1414{_}"Even so, lord.
10064-8{_}1415{_}In Thrasfordham be seven hundred chosen men-at-arms, and within Bourne, mayhap a thousand more.
10064-8{_}1416{_}It is become a haven for those that flee from tyranny and bitter wrong.
10064-8{_}1417{_}As for me, I journey where I will within the Duchy, serving the poor and ministering to the broken-hearted, and everywhere is black sin and suffering and death.
10064-8{_}1418{_}So now in the name of these oppressed do I give thee welcome to this thy sorrowful Duchy, and may God make of thee Duke indeed!"
10064-8{_}1419{_}Quoth Beltane:  "Duke am I in blood and Duke will I yet be in very sooth an God so will it."
10064-8{_}1420{_}Then turning to the three, who stood hearkening open-mouthed and wide of eye, he smiled and reached to them his hand.
10064-8{_}1421{_}"Good friends," said he, "knowing nought of me yet were ye willing to follow my fortunes.
10064-8{_}1422{_}For this do I thank ye one and all, and so shall my fortune, high or low, be thine, henceforth.
10064-8{_}1423{_}To-day is Ivo Duke, and I thy companion-in-arms, no more, no less--this, I pray you all, remember."
10064-8{_}1424{_}So saying, Beltane sheathed his sword and beholding Friar Martin on his knees beside that muffled figure, he knelt also, and the three with him.
10064-8{_}1425{_}Thereafter at a sign from the friar, Beltane stooped and raised this slender, shrouded figure in his arms and reverently bore it out into the shadows.
10064-8{_}1426{_}And there, all in the tender radiance of the moon, they buried her whose name they never knew, and stood a while in silence.
10064-8{_}1427{_}Then, pointing to the new-turned earth, Friar Martin spake soft-voiced:  "Lo, here--in but a little time, wild flowers shall bloom above her-- yet none purer or sweeter than she!
10064-8{_}1428{_}In a little shall the grass be green again, and she sleep here forgot by all--save God!
10064-8{_}1429{_}And God, my brothers, is a gentle God and very pitiful--so now do we leave her in God's abiding care."
10064-8{_}1430{_}And presently they turned, soft-footed, and went upon their way leaving the place to solitude.
10064-8{_}1431{_}But from the vault of heaven the stars looked down upon that lonely grave like the watching eyes of holy angels.
10064-8{_}1432{_}CHAPTER XII  WHICH TELLS HOW DUKE IVO'S GREAT GALLOWS CEASED TO BE   Scarce a mile without the walls of the fair city of Belsaye my lord Duke had builded him a great gallows, had set it high upon a hill for all the world to see; from whose lofty cross-beams five score rogues had hanged ere now, had writhed and kicked their lives away and rotted there in company, that all the world might know how potent was the anger of my lord Duke Ivo.
10064-8{_}1433{_}Day in, day out, from rosy morn till dewy eve, it frowned upon Belsaye, a thing of doom whose grim sight should warn rebellious townsfolk to dutiful submission; by night it loomed, a dim-seen, brooding horror, whose loathsome reek should mind them how all rogues must end that dared lift hand or voice against my lord Duke, or those proud barons, lords, and knights who, by his pleasure, held their fiefs with rights of justice, the high, the middle and the low.
10064-8{_}1434{_}Day in, day out, the men of Belsaye eyed it askance 'neath scowling brows and, by night, many a clenched hand was shaken and many a whispered malediction sped, toward that thing of doom that menaced them from the dark.
10064-8{_}1435{_}To-night the moon was full, and thus, following Friar Martin's bony outstretched finger, Beltane of a sudden espied afar the Duke's great gallows, rising grisly and stark against the moon's round splendour.
10064-8{_}1436{_}So for a space, standing yet within the shade of the woods, Beltane stared fierce-eyed, the while Giles, with Roger at his elbow, pointed out divers shapes that dangled high in air, at sight of which the friar knelt with bowed head and lips that moved in prayer: and Walkyn, scowling, muttered in his beard.
10064-8{_}1437{_}"Messire," said the archer, "my lord Duke's gallows is great and very strong, and we but five all told!"
10064-8{_}1438{_}"I have mine axe!"
10064-8{_}1439{_}quoth Walkyn.
10064-8{_}1440{_}"Had we fifty axes we scarce should bring it down ere dawn: moreover, the night is very still and sounds carry far--"  "Nathless," quoth Roger, "to-night we surely shall destroy it--my lord hath said so."
10064-8{_}1441{_}"Aye--but how?"
10064-8{_}1442{_}questioned Giles.
10064-8{_}1443{_}"In Belsaye is that pale fox Sir Gui of Allerdale with many trusty men-at-arms to hold the town for Black Ivo and teach Belsaye its duty: how may we destroy my lord Duke's gallows 'neath the very beards of my lord Duke's garrison, wilt tell me that, my good, Black Rogerkin?"
10064-8{_}1444{_}"Aye," nodded Roger, "that will I--when I have asked my lord."
10064-8{_}1445{_}So saying, he came and touched Beltane and humbly put the question.
10064-8{_}1446{_}Then, with his gaze yet upon the gallows, Beltane sighed and answered:  "There hath been no rain for weeks, look you: the underbrush is dry, methinks, and should burn well!"
10064-8{_}1447{_}"Aye, for sure," said Roger, "we shall burn Black Ivo's gallows to ashes, bowman, and a good end 'twill be."
10064-8{_}1448{_}"By fire!"
10064-8{_}1449{_}cried the archer, aghast, "but lord, so soon as they shall see the flames, Sir Gui and his men will sally out upon us!"
10064-8{_}1450{_}"Nay," said Beltane, "for we shall sally in."
10064-8{_}1451{_}"Into Belsaye, mean you, lord?"
10064-8{_}1452{_}"Certes," answered Beltane, "how else may we break open the dungeon?
10064-8{_}1453{_}The night is young yet, but we have much to do--follow!"
10064-8{_}1454{_}So saying, Beltane turned and keeping ever within the shadow of the trees, set off towards that distant hill where stood the gallows, black against the moon.
10064-8{_}1455{_}Swiftly they went and for the most part in silence, for Beltane's mind was busied upon many matters.
10064-8{_}1456{_}So betimes they climbed the hill and stood at last beneath the gallows, and, glancing up, Beltane beheld noisome shapes, black and shrivelled, that once had lived and laughed.
10064-8{_}1457{_}Forthwith he drew his sword and fell to cutting down the brush, whereat friar Martin, girding up his frock, took Walkyn's sword and fell to likewise.
10064-8{_}1458{_}Now, as Beltane laboured thus, he was suddenly aware of a wild and ragged figure, the which started up before him as if from the very ground.
10064-8{_}1459{_}An old man he was, bent with years, yet with eyes that burned fierce and undimmed 'neath hoary brows, and shrivelled hands that gripped upon a rusty sword.
10064-8{_}1460{_}"Who are ye," he cried, harsh-voiced, "who are ye that disturb this woeful place?
10064-8{_}1461{_}'Tis here that men are dragged to die--and, being dead, do hang i' the air to rot and rot--and thereby hangs a tale of wolves that howl and birds that shriek, aha!--carrion crows and hook-billed kites--they be well gorged since Ivo came.
10064-8{_}1462{_}'Caw!'
10064-8{_}1463{_}they cry, 'caw!'
10064-8{_}1464{_}-- soft child's flesh and the flesh of tender maids--aha!--I know--I've watched--I've seen!
10064-8{_}1465{_}Ah!
10064-8{_}1466{_}since my lord Duke Beltane died, what sights these eyes have seen!"
10064-8{_}1467{_}"Old man," quoth Beltane, bending near, "who art thou?"
10064-8{_}1468{_}"I am the ghost that haunts this place, but, ages since, I was Sir Robert Bellesme of Garthlaxton Keep.
10064-8{_}1469{_}But my wife they slew, my daughter ravished from me--and my son--Ah!
10064-8{_}1470{_}Christ--my son!
10064-8{_}1471{_}They hanged him here --yonder he hung, and I, his father, watched him die.
10064-8{_}1472{_}But, by night, when all was still, I crept hither and found a hole to shelter me.
10064-8{_}1473{_}And here I stayed to watch over him--my son who hung so quiet and so still.
10064-8{_}1474{_}And the rough wind buffeted him, the cruel rain lashed him, and the hot sun scorched him, but still he hung there, so high!--so high!
10064-8{_}1475{_}Yet I waited, for the strongest rope will break in time.
10064-8{_}1476{_}And upon a moony night, he fell, and I gathered him in my arms, close here against my heart, and buried him--where none can know--save God.
10064-8{_}1477{_}Many others have I buried also, for the strongest cords must break in time!
10064-8{_}1478{_}And folk do say the devil bears them hence, since none are ever found--but I know where they lie--six hundred and seventy and nine--I know--these hands have buried them and I have kept a tally.
10064-8{_}1479{_}Ah!--but you, gentle youth, what would ye here?"
10064-8{_}1480{_}"Burn down the gallows," said Beltane, "'tis an accursed thing, so shall it shame earth and heaven no longer."
10064-8{_}1481{_}"How!--how!"
10064-8{_}1482{_}cried the ancient man, letting fall his rusty sword, "Destroy Black Ivo's gibbet?
10064-8{_}1483{_}Dare ye--dare ye such a thing indeed?
10064-8{_}1484{_}Are there men with souls unconquered yet?
10064-8{_}1485{_}Methought all such were old, or dead, or fled away--dare ye this, youth?"
10064-8{_}1486{_}"Aye," nodded Beltane.
10064-8{_}1487{_}"Watch now!"
10064-8{_}1488{_}and hereupon he, together with the others, fell to hewing down the dry brush with might and main, and piling it about the gibbet's massy beams, while the ancient man, perched upon a rock hard by, watched them 'neath his shaggy brows and laughed soft and shrill.
10064-8{_}1489{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}1490{_}he cried, "the fire ye kindle here shall set the Duchy in a flame mayhap, to burn Black Ivo with Gui of Allerdale and Red Pertolepe--mayhap!
10064-8{_}1491{_}For them, fire on earth and flame in hell--aha!
10064-8{_}1492{_}To burn the gibbet!
10064-8{_}1493{_}'tis well bethought: so shall carrion kite and jay go light-bellied hereabouts, mayhap, oho!
10064-8{_}1494{_}'Caw,' they shall cry, 'Caw-- give us to eat--fair white flesh!'
10064-8{_}1495{_}Yet how may they eat when the gallows is no more?"
10064-8{_}1496{_}Thus spake he with shrill laughter while Beltane laboured until the sweat ran from him, while Walkyn's great axe flashed and fell near by and steel glittered among the underbrush that clothed the slopes of the hill.
10064-8{_}1497{_}Very soon they had stacked great piles of kindling about the gallows' weather-beaten timbers--twigs below, faggots above--cunningly ordered and higher than Beltane's head.
10064-8{_}1498{_}Now as Beltane leaned upon his sword to wipe the sweat from his eyes, came Roger and Walkyn yet panting from their labour.
10064-8{_}1499{_}"Master," said Roger, "they should burn well, I trow, and yet--"  "And yet," quoth Walkyn, "these beams be thick: methinks, when the others go, one man should stay to tend the fires until the flame gets fair hold--"  "And that man I!"
10064-8{_}1500{_}said Roger.
10064-8{_}1501{_}"No, no," frowned Walkyn, "an one of us must die, it shall be me--"  But now came the ancient man, leaning upon his ancient weapon.
10064-8{_}1502{_}"No, children," said he, "'tis for age to die--death is sweet to the old and weary: so will I tend the fire.
10064-8{_}1503{_}Yet, beseech thee, grant me this: that these my hands shall fire the gallows whereon they hanged my son, long ago: young was he, and tall--scarce yet a man--they hanged him yonder, so high--so high--so far beyond my care: and the carrion birds--kites, see you, and crows--and the wind and rain and dark--Ah, God!
10064-8{_}1504{_}my son!
10064-8{_}1505{_}I am but an old man and feeble, yet, beseech thee, let this be the hand to fire Black Ivo's gibbet!"
10064-8{_}1506{_}Then Beltane took from his pouch flint and steel and tinder and gave them to the old man's trembling fingers as Giles o' the Bow came running with the stalwart friar behind him.
10064-8{_}1507{_}So, while the five stood hushed and wide of eye, the old man knelt before them in his rags and struck flint to steel.
10064-8{_}1508{_}Once he struck, and twice--and behold a spark that leapt to a small flame that died to a glow; but now, flat upon his belly lay Giles and, pursing his lips, puffed and blew until the glow brightened, spread, and burst into a crackling flame that leapt from twig to twig.
10064-8{_}1509{_}And when the fire waxed hot, Beltane took thence a glowing brand, and, coming to the other great pile, fired it therewith.
10064-8{_}1510{_}Up rose the flames high and higher until they began to lick, pale-tongued, about the gibbet's two great supporting timbers, and ever as they rose, Walkyn and Roger, Giles and the friar, laboured amain, stacking logs near by wherewith to feed the fires.
10064-8{_}1511{_}"Enough," said Beltane at last, "it shall suffice, methinks."
10064-8{_}1512{_}"Suffice?"
10064-8{_}1513{_}cried the old man, his eyes bright in the ruddy glow, "aye, it shall suffice, sweet boy.
10064-8{_}1514{_}See--see, the timbers catch e'en now.
10064-8{_}1515{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}1516{_}burn, good fire--eat, hungry flame!
10064-8{_}1517{_}O, happy sight--would my dear son were here--they hanged his fair young body, but his soul--Ha, his soul!
10064-8{_}1518{_}O souls of hanged men--O spirits of the dead, come about me, ye ghosts of murdered youth, come and behold the gibbet burn whereon ye died.
10064-8{_}1519{_}What--are ye there, amid the smoke, so soon?
10064-8{_}1520{_}Come then, let us dance together and trip it lightly to and fro--merrily, merrily!
10064-8{_}1521{_}Hey boy, so ho then--so ho, and away we go!"
10064-8{_}1522{_}Hereupon, tossing up gaunt arms, the old man fell to dancing and capering amid the sparks and rolling smoke, filling the air with wild talk and gabbling high-pitched laughter that rose above the roar of the fires.
10064-8{_}1523{_}And so in a while Beltane, sighing, turned and led the way down the hill towards the glooming shadow of the woods; but ever as they went the flames waxed fiercer behind them and the madman's laughter shrilled upon the air.
10064-8{_}1524{_}Swift-footed they plunged into the underbrush and thus hidden began to close in upon Belsaye town.
10064-8{_}1525{_}And of a sudden they heard a cry, and thereafter the shattering blare of a trumpet upon the walls.
10064-8{_}1526{_}And now from within the waking city rose a confused sound, a hum that grew louder and ever more loud, pierced by shout and trumpet-blast while high above this growing clamour the tocsin pealed alarm.
10064-8{_}1527{_}Thus, in a while the trembling citizens of Belsaye, starting from their slumber, stared in pallid amaze beholding afar a great and fiery gibbet whose flames, leaping heavenward, seemed to quench the moon.
10064-8{_}1528{_}CHAPTER XIII  HOW THEY BRAKE OPE THE DUNGEON OF BELSAYE   Being yet in the shade of the woods, Beltane paused, hearkening to the distant uproar of Belsaye town and watching the torches that hovered upon its walls and the cressets that glowed on tower and bartizan.
10064-8{_}1529{_}"Messire Beltane," quoth the friar, setting his rumpled frock in order, "are ye minded still to adventure breaking ope the dungeon of Belsaye?"
10064-8{_}1530{_}"Aye, verily!"
10064-8{_}1531{_}nodded Beltane.
10064-8{_}1532{_}"Know you the city, good friar?"
10064-8{_}1533{_}"That do I, my brother: every lane and street, every hole and corner of it--'twas there I first drew breath.
10064-8{_}1534{_}A fair, rich city, freed by charter long ago--but now, alas, its freedom snatched away, its ancient charter gone, it bleeds 'neath a pale-cheeked tyrant's sway--a pallid man who laughs soft-voiced to see men die, and smiles upon their anguish.
10064-8{_}1535{_}O Belsaye, grievous are thy wrongs since Ivo came five years agone and gave thee up to pillage and to ravishment.
10064-8{_}1536{_}O hateful day!
10064-8{_}1537{_}O day of shame!
10064-8{_}1538{_}What sights I saw--what sounds I heard--man-groans and screams of women to rend high heaven and shake the throne of God, methinks.
10064-8{_}1539{_}I see--I hear them yet, and must forever.
10064-8{_}1540{_}Jesu, pity!"
10064-8{_}1541{_}and leaning against a tree near by, the stalwart friar shivered violently and hid his eyes.
10064-8{_}1542{_}"Why, good brother Martin," said Beltane, setting an arm about him, "doth memory pain thee so, indeed?
10064-8{_}1543{_}good Brother Martin, be comforted--"  "Nay, nay--'tis past, but--O my son, I--had a sister!"
10064-8{_}1544{_}said the good friar, and groaned.
10064-8{_}1545{_}Yet in a while he raised his head and spake again: "And when Duke Ivo had wrought his will upon the city, he builded the great gibbet yonder and hanged it full with men cheek by jowl, and left Sir Gui the cruel with ten score chosen men for garrison.
10064-8{_}1546{_}But the men of Belsaye have stubborn memories; Sir Gui and his butchers slumber in a false security, for stern men are they and strong, and wait but God's appointed time.
10064-8{_}1547{_}Pray God that time be soon!"
10064-8{_}1548{_}"Amen!"
10064-8{_}1549{_}said Beltane.
10064-8{_}1550{_}Now, even as he spake came the sound of a distant tucket, the great gates of Belsaye swung wide, and forth rode a company of men-at-arms, their bascinets agleam 'neath the moon.
10064-8{_}1551{_}"Now!"
10064-8{_}1552{_}spake the friar, "and you are for Belsaye, my brother, follow me; I know a way--albeit a moist way and something evil--but an you will follow,--come!"
10064-8{_}1553{_}So saying Friar Martin set off among the trees, and Beltane, beckoning to the others, followed close.
10064-8{_}1554{_}Fast strode the friar, his white robe fluttering on before, through moonlight and shadow, until they reached a brook or freshet that ran bubbling betwixt flowery banks; beside this strode the tall friar, following its winding course, until before them, amid the shadow--yet darker than the shadow --loomed high an embattled flanking tower of the walls of Belsaye town; but ever before them flitted the friar's white gown, on and on until the freshet became a slow-moving river, barring their advance--a broad river that whispered among the reeds on the one side and lapped against rugged wall on the other.
10064-8{_}1555{_}Here the friar stayed to glance from gloomy wall and turret to fast waning moon on their left, then, girding up his gown, he stepped down into the reeds, and a moment later they saw him--to their amaze-- fording the river that flowed scarce knee deep.
10064-8{_}1556{_}So, needfully, Beltane followed, and, stepping into the water found his feet upon a narrow causeway cunningly devised.
10064-8{_}1557{_}Thus, slowly and carefully, because of the flowing of the water, they came betimes to where the friar waited in the shadow of the massy wall; yet, even as they came near, the friar waved his arm, stooped--and was gone; whereon my Beltane stared amazed and the three muttered uneasily behind him.
10064-8{_}1558{_}But, coming nearer, Beltane espied above the hurrying waters the curve of an arch or tunnel, and pointing it to the others, took a great breath and, stooping beneath the water, stumbled on and on until it shallowed, and he was free to breathe again.
10064-8{_}1559{_}On he went, through water now breast-high, with slimy walls above him and around, seeing naught by reason of the pitchy blackness, and hearing only the smothered splash of those behind, and gasping breaths that boomed hollow in the dark.
10064-8{_}1560{_}Yet presently he saw a gleam before him that broadened with each step, and, of a sudden, was out beneath the sky--a narrow strip wherein stars twinkled, and so beheld again friar Martin's white frock flitting on, ghost-like, before.
10064-8{_}1561{_}In a while he brought them to a slimy stair, and climbing this, with ever growing caution, they found themselves at last beneath the frowning shadow of the citadel within the walls of Belsaye town.
10064-8{_}1562{_}Now, looking north, Beltane beheld afar a fiery gallows that flamed to heaven, and from the town thitherward came a confused hum of the multitude who watched; but hereabouts the town seemed all deserted.
10064-8{_}1563{_}"The dungeons lie beneath our feet," whispered Friar Martin.
10064-8{_}1564{_}"Come!"
10064-8{_}1565{_}So, keeping ever in the shadow of the great square keep, they went on, soft-treading and alert of eye till, being come to the angle of the wall, the friar stayed of a sudden and raised a warning hand.
10064-8{_}1566{_}Then came Beltane with Walkyn close behind, and peering over the friar's broad shoulders, they beheld a sentinel who stood with his back to them, leaning on his spear, to watch the burning gallows, his chain-mail agleam and his head-piece glittering as he stirred lazily in time to the merry lilt he sang softly.
10064-8{_}1567{_}Then, or ever Beltane could stay him, Walkyn o' the Dene laid by his axe, and, his soaked shoes soundless upon the stones, began to steal upon the unconscious singer, who yet lolled upon his spear some thirty paces away.
10064-8{_}1568{_}With great body bowed forward and hairy fingers crooked, Walkyn stole upon him; six paces he went, ten--twenty--twenty-five-- the soldier ceased his humming, stood erect and turned about; and Walkyn leapt--bore him backward down into the shadow--a shadow wherein their bodies writhed and twisted silently awhile.
10064-8{_}1569{_}When Walkyn rose out of the shadow and beckoned them on.
10064-8{_}1570{_}So, following ever the friar's lead, they came to a narrow doorway that gave upon a small guard-room lighted by a smoking torch socketed to the wall.
10064-8{_}1571{_}The place was empty, save for a medley of arms stacked in corners, wherefore, treading cautiously, the friar led them a-down a narrow passage and so to a second and larger chamber where burned a fire of logs.
10064-8{_}1572{_}Upon the walls hung shining head-pieces; cloaks and mantles lay where they had been flung on bench and floor, but none was there to give them let or hindrance.
10064-8{_}1573{_}Then Friar Martin took a torch that smoked near by, and, crossing to the hearth, reached down a massy key from the wall, and with this in his hand, came to a door half hidden in a corner, beyond which were steps that wound downwards into the dark, a darkness close and dank, and heavy with corruption.
10064-8{_}1574{_}But on went the friar--his torch lighting the way--down and ever down until they trod a narrow way 'twixt reeking walls, where breathed an air so close and foul the very torch languished.
10064-8{_}1575{_}At length the friar stopped before a mighty door, thick-banded with iron bars and with massy bolts, and while Beltane held the torch, he fitted key to lock and thereafter the great door swung on screaming hinge and showed a dungeon beyond--a place foul and noisome, where divers pale-faced wretches lay or crouched, blinking in the torch's glare.
10064-8{_}1576{_}"What?"
10064-8{_}1577{_}cried one, coming to his feet, a squat broad-shouldered man-- "be this the dawn so soon?
10064-8{_}1578{_}Well, we be ready, better to hang i' the clean air than rot in a dungeon, say I.
10064-8{_}1579{_}So we be ready, eh, my brothers?"
10064-8{_}1580{_}But now, some groaned and wept and others laughed, while yet others got them to their knees, bowed of head and silent.
10064-8{_}1581{_}Then went in the friar to them and laid his hands upon the squat man's shoulder and spake him gently.
10064-8{_}1582{_}"And is it Osric," said he.
10064-8{_}1583{_}"Day is not yet, my son, nor with the day shalt thou die nor any here, an ye be silent all and follow where we lead, soft-footed, so will we bring you to God's good world again.
10064-8{_}1584{_}Rise, then, each one, speak nothing, but follow!"
10064-8{_}1585{_}So then did these men, snatched of a sudden from the horror of death to the hope of new life, follow on stumbling feet, out from the noisome gloom of the dungeon, out from the clammy air breathing of death, up the narrow winding stair; and with each step came strength and manhood.
10064-8{_}1586{_}Thus as they strode forth of the frowning keep, each man bore sword or gisarm.
10064-8{_}1587{_}So, with breath in cheek, but hearts high-beating, they came one and all, to where the slimy stair led down into the gloom.
10064-8{_}1588{_}Yet here Friar Martin paused, sighing, to look behind, whence rose the distant hum of those thronging townsfolk who yet crowded wall and street and market square to watch the gallows burn.
10064-8{_}1589{_}"Now sweet Christ shield ye, good people of Belsaye!"
10064-8{_}1590{_}he sighed.
10064-8{_}1591{_}"What mean ye, my brother?"
10064-8{_}1592{_}questioned Beltane.
10064-8{_}1593{_}"Alas!
10064-8{_}1594{_}my son," groaned the friar, "I needs must think upon the coming day and of the vengeance of Sir Gui for this our work!"
10064-8{_}1595{_}"His vengeance, friar?"
10064-8{_}1596{_}"There will be torture and death busy hereabouts tomorrow, my son, for, the prisoners being gone, so will Sir Gui vent his anger on the townsfolk--'tis ever his custom--"  "Ha!"
10064-8{_}1597{_}quoth my Beltane, knitting his brows, "I had not thought on this!"
10064-8{_}1598{_}--and with the word, he turned him back, drawing on his hood of mail.
10064-8{_}1599{_}"Come, lord," whispered Black Roger in his ear, "let us be going while yet we may."
10064-8{_}1600{_}"Aye, come, my son," spake the friar, low-voiced.
10064-8{_}1601{_}"Tarry not, Belsaye is in the hand of God!
10064-8{_}1602{_}Nay, what would you?"
10064-8{_}1603{_}"I must go back," said Beltane, loosening sword in scabbard, "for needs must I this night have word with Gui of Allerdale."
10064-8{_}1604{_}"Nay," whispered the friar, with pleading hand on Beltane's arm, "'tis thing impossible--"  "Yet must I try, good brother--"  "Ah, dear my son, 'twill be thy death--"  "Why look you, gentle friar, I am in Belsaye, and Belsaye 'is in the hand of God!'
10064-8{_}1605{_}So fear not for me, but go you all and wait for me beyond the river.
10064-8{_}1606{_}And, if I come not within the hour, then press on with speed for Thrasfordham within Bourne, and say to Sir Benedict that, while _he_ liveth to draw sword, so is there hope for Pentavalon.
10064-8{_}1607{_}But now-- quick!--where lodgeth Sir Gui?"
10064-8{_}1608{_}"Within the keep--there is a stair doth mount within the thickness of the wall--nay, I will be thy guide if go indeed thou must--"  "Not so, good friar, be it thy duty to lead these prisoners to freedom and to safety within Bourne."
10064-8{_}1609{_}"Then will I come," whispered Roger hoarse and eager, as the friar turned slow-footed to follow the others adown the slippery stair, "beseech thee, lord, thy man am I, twice sworn to thee till death, so suffer me beside thee."
10064-8{_}1610{_}"Nay," said Beltane, "Pentavalon's need of thee is greater e'en than mine, therefore will I adventure this thing alone.
10064-8{_}1611{_}Go you with the friar, my Roger, and so farewell to each."
10064-8{_}1612{_}"God keep thee, noble son!"
10064-8{_}1613{_}whispered the friar, his hand upraised in blessing: but Roger stood, chin on breast and spake no word.
10064-8{_}1614{_}Then Beltane turned him and sped away, soft-treading in the shadow of the great keep.
10064-8{_}1615{_}The waning moon cast shadows black and long, and in these shadows Beltane crept and so, betimes, came within the outer guard-room and to the room beyond; and here beheld a low-arched doorway whence steps led upward,--a narrow stair, gloomy and winding, whose velvet blackness was stabbed here and there by moonlight, flooding through some deep-set arrow-slit.
10064-8{_}1616{_}Up he went, and up, pausing once with breath in check, fancying he heard the stealthy sound of one who climbed behind him in the black void below; thus stayed he a moment, with eyes that strove to pierce the gloom, and with naked dagger clenched to smite, yet heard nought, save the faint whisper of his own mail, and the soft tap of his long scabbard against the wall; wherefore he presently sped on again, climbing swiftly up the narrow stair.
10064-8{_}1617{_}Thus, in a while, he beheld a door above: a small door, yet stout and strong, a door that stood ajar, whence came a beam of yellow light.
10064-8{_}1618{_}So, with sure and steady hand, Beltane set wide the door, that creaked faintly in the stillness, and beheld a small, square chamber where was a narrow window, and, in this window, a mail-clad man lolled, his unhelmed head thrust far without, to watch the glow that leapt against the northern sky.
10064-8{_}1619{_}Then Beltane sheathed his dagger and, in three long strides was close behind, and, stooping above the man, sought and found his hairy throat, and swung him, mighty-armed, that his head struck the wall; then Beltane, sighing, laid him upon the floor and turned toward a certain arras-hung arch: but, or ever his hand came upon this curtain, from beyond a voice hailed--a voice soft and musical.
10064-8{_}1620{_}"Hugo--O Hugo, spawn of hell, hither to me!"
10064-8{_}1621{_}Then Beltane, lifting the curtain, opened the door and, striding into the chamber beyond, closed and barred the door behind him, and so stood, tall and menacing, looking on one who sat at a table busied with pen and ink-horn.
10064-8{_}1622{_}A slender man this, and richly habited: a sleepy-eyed man, pale of cheek, with long, down-curving nose, and mouth thin-lipped and masterful, who, presently lifting his head, stared up in amaze, sleepy-eyed no longer: for now, beholding Beltane the mighty, sheathed in mail from head to foot, the pen dropped from his fingers and his long pale hands slowly clenched themselves.
10064-8{_}1623{_}So, for a space, they fronted each other, speaking not, while eye met eye unswerving--the menacing blue and the challenging black, and, through the open casement near by came a ruddy glow that flickered on arras-hung wall and rugged roof-beam.
10064-8{_}1624{_}Now raising his hand, Beltane pointed toward this glowing window.
10064-8{_}1625{_}"Sir Gui," quoth he, "Lord Seneschal of Belsaye town, thou hast good eyes--look now, and tell me what ye see."
10064-8{_}1626{_}"I see," said Sir Gui, stirring not, "I see a presumptuous knave--a dog who shall be flung headlong from the turret.
10064-8{_}1627{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}1628{_}Hugo!"
10064-8{_}1629{_}he called, his black eyes yet unswerving, "O Hugo, son of the fiend, hither to me!"
10064-8{_}1630{_}"Trouble not, my lord," quoth Beltane gently, "behold, the door is barred: moreover, Hugo lieth without--pray God I have not killed him.
10064-8{_}1631{_}But, as for thee--look yonder, use thine eyes and speak me what thou dost see."
10064-8{_}1632{_}But Sir Gui sat on, his thin lips upcurling to a smile, his black eyes unswerving: wherefore came Beltane and seized him in fierce hands and plucked him to his feet and so brought him to the window.
10064-8{_}1633{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}1634{_}he cried, "look now and tell me what ye see.
10064-8{_}1635{_}Speak!
10064-8{_}1636{_}speak--for, God help me!
10064-8{_}1637{_}now am I minded to kill thee here and now, unarmed though ye be, and cast thy carrion to the dogs--speak!"
10064-8{_}1638{_}Now, beholding the mail-clad face above him, the blue eyes aflame, the pale lips tight-drawn, Sir Gui, Seneschal of Belsaye, spake soft-voiced on this wise:  "I see my lord Duke's gallows go up in flame--wherefore men shall die!"
10064-8{_}1639{_}"Aye," sighed Beltane, "said I not thine eyes were good, Lord Seneschal?
10064-8{_}1640{_}Now, use thine ears--hearken!
10064-8{_}1641{_}'Twas I and five others, men from beyond the marches, fired this night Black Ivo's gibbet, moreover, to-night also have we broke the dungeon that lieth beneath this thy keep, and set thy prisoners free--I and these five, all men from the north, mark me this well!
10064-8{_}1642{_}This have we done for a sign and portent--ha!
10064-8{_}1643{_}look!"
10064-8{_}1644{_}and Beltane pointed of a sudden to where the great gallows, outlined against the night in seething flame, swayed to and fro, crumbled, and crashed to earth 'mid whirling sparks and flame, while, from the town below rose a murmur that swelled and swelled to a shout, and so was gone.
10064-8{_}1645{_}"Behold, lord Seneschal, Black Ivo's gallows to-night hath ceased to be: here is a sign, let those heed it that will.
10064-8{_}1646{_}But for thee--this!
10064-8{_}1647{_}To-night have I burned this gallows, to-night have I freed thy prisoners.
10064-8{_}1648{_}Upon me therefore, and only me, be the penalty; for--mark me this, Seneschal!--spill but one drop of blood of these innocents of Belsaye, and, as God seeth me, so will I hunt thee down, and take thee and tear out thine eyes, and cut off thine hands, and drive thee forth to starve!
10064-8{_}1649{_}And this do I swear by the honour of my father, Beltane the Strong, Duke of Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}1650{_}But now, even as Sir Gui shrank back before the death in Beltane's look, amazed beyond all thought by his words, came a sudden shout, and thereafter a clash and ring of steel upon the stair without.
10064-8{_}1651{_}And now, above the sudden din, hoarse and loud a battle-cry arose, at the sound of which Sir Gui's jaws hung agape, and he stood as one that doubts his ears; for 'twas a cry he had heard aforetime, long ago.
10064-8{_}1652{_}"Arise!
10064-8{_}1653{_}Arise!
10064-8{_}1654{_}I will arise!"
10064-8{_}1655{_}Then Beltane cast up the bar, and, plucking wide the door, beheld the broad, mail-clad back of one who held the narrow stair where flashed pike and gisarm.
10064-8{_}1656{_}"Roger!"
10064-8{_}1657{_}he called, "Black Roger!"
10064-8{_}1658{_}"Aye, lord, 'tis I," cried Roger, parrying a pike-thrust, "make sure of thy work, master, I can hold these in check yet a while."
10064-8{_}1659{_}"My work is done, Roger.
10064-8{_}1660{_}To me--to me, I say!"
10064-8{_}1661{_}So Roger, leaping back from the stair-head, turned about and ran to Beltane, stumbling and spattering blood as he came, whereupon Beltane clapped-to the door and barred it in the face of the pursuit.
10064-8{_}1662{_}A while leaned Roger, panting, against the wall, then, beholding Sir Gui:  "How!"
10064-8{_}1663{_}he cried, "lives the pale fox yet?
10064-8{_}1664{_}Methought thy work was done, master!"
10064-8{_}1665{_}So saying, he swung aloft his bloody sword, but, even as the Seneschal waited the blow, smiling of lip, Beltane caught Black Roger's wrist.
10064-8{_}1666{_}"Stay!"
10064-8{_}1667{_}cried he, above the thunder of blows that shook the door, "would'st slay a man unarmed?"
10064-8{_}1668{_}"Aye, master, as he hath slain many a man ere now!"
10064-8{_}1669{_}quoth Roger, striving to free his arm.
10064-8{_}1670{_}"The door is giving, and there be many without: and, since to-night we must die, so let us slay the white fox first."
10064-8{_}1671{_}"Not so," said Beltane, "get you through the window--the river runs below: through the window--out, I say!"
10064-8{_}1672{_}and, with the word, he stooped and bore Black Roger to the window.
10064-8{_}1673{_}"But, lord--"  "Jump!"
10064-8{_}1674{_}cried Beltane, "jump, ere the door fall."
10064-8{_}1675{_}"But you, master--"  "Jump, I say: I will follow thee."
10064-8{_}1676{_}So, groaning, Black Roger hurled his sword far out from the window, and leaping from the sill, was gone.
10064-8{_}1677{_}Then Beltane turned and looked upon Gui of Allerdale.
10064-8{_}1678{_}"Seneschal," said he, "I who speak am he, who, an God so wills, shall be Duke of Pentavalon ere long: howbeit, I will keep my promise to thee, so aid me God!"
10064-8{_}1679{_}Thus saying, he mounted the window in his turn, and, even as the door splintered behind him, forced himself through, and, leaping wide, whirled over and over, down and down, and the sluggish river closed over him with a mighty splash; thereafter the placid waters went upon their way, bubbling here and there, and dimpling 'neath the waning moon.
10064-8{_}1680{_}CHAPTER XIV  HOW BELTANE CAME NIGH TO DEATH   Down went my Beltane, weighted in his heavy mail--down and ever down through a world of green that grew dark and ever more dark, until, within the pitchy gloom beneath him was a quaking slime that sucked viciously at foot and ankle.
10064-8{_}1681{_}Desperately he fought and strove to rise, but ever the mud clung, and, lusty swimmer though he was, his triple mail bore him down.
10064-8{_}1682{_}And now his mighty muscles failed, lights flamed before his eyes, in his ears was a drone that grew to a rushing roar, his lungs seemed bursting, and the quaking ooze yearning to engulf him.
10064-8{_}1683{_}Then my Beltane knew the bitter agony of coming death, and strove no more; but in that place of darkness and horror, a clammy something crawled upon his face, slipped down upon his helpless body, seized hold upon his belt and dragged at him fierce and strong; slowly, slowly the darkness thinned, grew lighter, and then--Ah, kind mercy of God!
10064-8{_}1684{_}his staring eyes beheld the orbed moon, his famished lungs drank deep the sweet, cool air of night.
10064-8{_}1685{_}And so he gasped, and gasping, strove feebly with arm and leg while ever the strong hand grasped at his girdle.
10064-8{_}1686{_}And now he heard, faint and afar, a sound of voices, hands reached down and drew him up-- up to good, firm earth, and there, face down among the grass, he lay awhile, content only to live and breathe.
10064-8{_}1687{_}Gradually he became aware of another sound hard by, a sharp sound yet musical, and in a little, knew it for the "twang" of a swift-drawn bow-string.
10064-8{_}1688{_}Now, glancing up, Beltane beheld an ancient tree near by, a tree warped and stunted wherein divers arrows stood, and behind the tree, Giles o' the Bow, who, as he watched, drew and loosed a shaft, which, flashing upward, was answered by a cry; whereon Giles laughed aloud.
10064-8{_}1689{_}"Six!"
10064-8{_}1690{_}he cried, "six in seven shots: 'tis sweet archery methinks, and quicker than a noose, my Rogerkin, and more deadly than thy axe, my surly Walkyn.
10064-8{_}1691{_}Let the rogues yonder but show themselves, and give me arrows enow, so will I slay all Gui's garrison ere the moon fail me quite."
10064-8{_}1692{_}But hereupon Beltane got him to his knees and made shift to stand, and, coming to the tree, leaned there, being faint and much spent.
10064-8{_}1693{_}"Aha, sweet lord," cried the archer, "a man after my very heart art thou.
10064-8{_}1694{_}What wonders have we achieved this night--paladins in sooth we be, all four!
10064-8{_}1695{_}By the blessed bones of St. Giles, all Pentavalon shall ring with our doings anon."
10064-8{_}1696{_}Said Beltane, faintly:  "Where is my good Roger?"
10064-8{_}1697{_}"Here, lord," a voice answered from the shade of a bush hard by: "'twas my comrade Walkyn dragged me up from death--even as he did thee."
10064-8{_}1698{_}"We thought you gone for good, master."
10064-8{_}1699{_}"Aye!"
10064-8{_}1700{_}cried the archer, "so would ye all be dead, methinks, but for me and this my bow."
10064-8{_}1701{_}"Friends," said Beltane, "'tis by doings such as this that men do learn each other's worth: so shall the bonds betwixt us strengthen day by day, and join us in accord and brotherhood that shall outlast this puny life.
10064-8{_}1702{_}So now let us begone and join the others."
10064-8{_}1703{_}So they turned their backs upon Belsaye town, and keeping to the brush, came at length to where upon the borders of the forest the white friar waited them, with the nine who yet remained of the prisoners; these, beholding Beltane, came hurrying to meet him, and falling upon their knees about him, strove with each other to kiss his hands and feet.
10064-8{_}1704{_}"Good fellows," said Beltane, "God hath this night brought ye out of death into life--how will ye use your lives hereafter?
10064-8{_}1705{_}List now:--even as ye have suffered, others are suffering: as ye have endured the gloom of dungeon and fear of death, so, at this hour, others do the like by reason of misrule and tyranny.
10064-8{_}1706{_}Now here stand I, together with Sir Benedict of Bourne who holdeth Thrasfordham Keep, pledged to live henceforth, sword in hand, until these evils are no more--since 'tis only by bitter strife and conflict that evil may be driven from our borders.
10064-8{_}1707{_}Thus, Pentavalon needeth men, strong-armed and resolute: if such ye be, march ye this hour to Thrasfordham within Bourne, and say to Sir Benedict that God having given you new life, so now will ye give your lives to Pentavalon, that tyranny may cease and the Duchy be cleansed of evil.
10064-8{_}1708{_}Who now among ye will draw sword for freedom and Pentavalon?"
10064-8{_}1709{_}Then sprang the squat man Osric to his feet, with clenched fist upraised and eyes ablaze 'neath his matted hair.
10064-8{_}1710{_}"That will I!"
10064-8{_}1711{_}he cried.
10064-8{_}1712{_}"And I!
10064-8{_}1713{_}And I!
10064-8{_}1714{_}And I!"
10064-8{_}1715{_}cried the rest, grim-faced and eager.
10064-8{_}1716{_}"Aye--give us but swords, and one to lead, and we will follow!"
10064-8{_}1717{_}Quoth Beltane:  "Go you then to Sir Benedict within Bourne and say to all men that Beltane the Duke hath this night burned down Black Ivo's shameful gibbet, for a sign that he is come at last and is at work, nor will he stay until he die, or Pentavalon be free!"
10064-8{_}1718{_}CHAPTER XV  HOW BELTANE HAD WORD WITH PERTOLEPE THE RED, AND HOW THEY LEFT HIM IN THE FOREST     "Since all men breathing 'neath the sky    Good or evil, soon must die,    Ho!
10064-8{_}1719{_}bring me wine, and what care I    For dying!"
10064-8{_}1720{_}It was Giles Brabblecombe singing to himself as he knelt beside a fire of twigs, and Beltane, opening sleepy eyes, looked round upon a world all green and gold and dew-bespangled; a fair world and fragrant, whose balmy air breathed of hidden flowers and blooming thickets, whence came the joyous carolling of new-waked birds; and beholding all this and the glory of it, my Beltane must needs praise God he was alive.
10064-8{_}1721{_}"Hail and good morrow to thee, brother!"
10064-8{_}1722{_}cried the bowman, seeing him astir.
10064-8{_}1723{_}"The sun shineth, look you, I sit upon my hams and sing for that this roasting venison smelleth sweet, while yonder i' the leaves be a mavis and a merle a-mocking of me, pretty rogues: for each and ever of which, _Laus Deo, Amen!_"  "Why truly, God hath made a fair world, Giles, a good world to live in, and to live is to act--yet here have I lain most basely sleeping--"  "Like any paunched friar, brother.
10064-8{_}1724{_}But a few days since, I met thee in the green, a very gentle, dove-like youth that yet became a very lion of fight and demi-god of battle!
10064-8{_}1725{_}Heroes were we all, last night--nay, very Titans--four 'gainst an army!--whiles now, within this balmy-breathing morn you shall see Walkyn o' the Bloody Axe with grim Black Rogerkin, down at the brook yonder, a-sprawl upon their bellies busily a-tickling trout for breakfast, while I, whose good yew bow carrieth death in every twang, toasting deer-flesh on a twig, am mocked of wanton warblers i' the green: and thou, who art an Achilles, a Hector, an Ajax--a very Mars--do sleep and slumber, soft and sweet as full-fed friar--Heigho!
10064-8{_}1726{_}Yet even a demi-god must nod betimes, and Titans eat, look ye."
10064-8{_}1727{_}Now looking from sun to earth and beholding the shortening of the shadows, Beltane leapt up.
10064-8{_}1728{_}Quoth he:  "Sluggard that I am, 'tis late!
10064-8{_}1729{_}And Roger was wounded last night, I mind--"  "Content you, brother, 'twas nought," said Giles bending above his cooking, "the kiss of a pike-head i' the thick o' the arm--no more."
10064-8{_}1730{_}"Yet it must be looked to--"  "I did it, brother, as I shoot--that is to say I did it most excellent well: 'twill be healed within the week."
10064-8{_}1731{_}"How then--art leech as well as bowman?"
10064-8{_}1732{_}"Quite as well, brother.
10064-8{_}1733{_}When I was a monk I learned two good things, _videlicit_: never to argue with those in authority over me, and to heal the hurts of those that did.
10064-8{_}1734{_}So, by my skill in herbs and leechcraft, Roger, having a hole in his arm, recks not of it--behold here he cometh, and Walkyn too, and _Laus Deo!_ with a trout!
10064-8{_}1735{_}Now shall we feast like any pampered prelate."
10064-8{_}1736{_}So when Beltane had stripped and bathed him in the brook, they presently sat down, all four together, and ate and talked and laughed right merrily, the while lark and thrush and blackbird carolled lustily far and near.
10064-8{_}1737{_}"Now eat, brothers," cried the bowman, full-mouthed, "eat and spare not, as I do, for to-day I smell the battle from afar: Ho!
10064-8{_}1738{_}Ho!
10064-8{_}1739{_}the noise of captains and the shouting!
10064-8{_}1740{_}Yesterday were we heroes, to-day must we be gods--yet cautious gods, for, mark me, I have but twelve shafts remaining, and with twelve shafts can but promise ye a poor twelve lives."
10064-8{_}1741{_}But now came Roger wistful-eyed, and with belt a-swing in his hand.
10064-8{_}1742{_}"Master," quoth he, "last night did we four rescue twelve.
10064-8{_}1743{_}Now I'm fain to know if for these twelve I may cut twelve notches from my belt, or must we share their lives betwixt us and I count but three?"
10064-8{_}1744{_}"Three?"
10064-8{_}1745{_}laughed Giles, "Oho--out upon thee, Rogerkin!
10064-8{_}1746{_}Our lord here claimeth six, since he the rescue planned, next, I claim three, since but for my goodly shooting ye all had died, then hath Walkyn two, since he saved thee from the fishes, which leaveth thee--one.
10064-8{_}1747{_}_Quod erat demonstrandum!_"  But now, seeing Roger's downcast look, Giles snatched the belt and gave it unto Beltane, who forthwith cut there-from twelve notches.
10064-8{_}1748{_}And, in a while, having made an end of eating, Beltane rose and looked round upon the three.
10064-8{_}1749{_}"Good comrades all," quoth he, "well do I know ye to be staunch and trusty; yet to-day am I minded to speak with him men call Pertolepe the Red, lest he shed innocent blood for that we slew his foresters--"  "Twenty lusty fellows!"
10064-8{_}1750{_}nodded Giles, with a morsel of venison on his dagger point.

10064-8{_}1752{_}quoth Roger.
10064-8{_}1753{_}"Yet he sore wounded!"

10064-8{_}1755{_}"Ha!

10064-8{_}1760{_}quoth Walkyn, reaching for his axe.

10064-8{_}1764{_}"Alone, master!"
10064-8{_}1765{_}cried Black Roger, starting to his feet.
10064-8{_}1766{_}"Alone!"
10064-8{_}1767{_}growled Walkyn, clutching his axe.
10064-8{_}1768{_}"An death must come, better one should die than four," said Beltane, "howbeit I am minded to seek out Pertolepe this day."
10064-8{_}1769{_}"Then do I come also, master, since thy man am I."

10064-8{_}1773{_}Then laughed Beltane for very gladness, and he looked on each with kindling eye.
10064-8{_}1774{_}"Good friends," quoth he, "as ye say, so let it be, and may God's hand be over us this day."
10064-8{_}1775{_}Now, as he spake with eyes uplift to heaven, he espied a faint, blue mist far away above the soft-stirring tree tops--a distant haze, that rose lazily into the balmy air, thickening ever as he watched.

10064-8{_}1780{_}"See, the smoke thickens!"
10064-8{_}1781{_}cried Beltane.
10064-8{_}1782{_}"Now, God forgive me!
10064-8{_}1783{_}the while I tarry here Red Pertolepe is busy, meseemeth!"

10064-8{_}1785{_}Fast and furious Beltane sped on, crashing through underbrush and crackling thicket, o'erleaping bush and brook and fallen tree, heedful of eye, and choosing his course with a forester's unerring instinct, praying fiercely beneath his breath, and with the three ever close behind.
10064-8{_}1786{_}"Would I had eaten less!"
10064-8{_}1787{_}panted Giles.

10064-8{_}1793{_}Now in a while they heard a sound, faint and confused: a hum, that presently grew to a murmur--to a drone--to a low wailing of voices, pierced of a sudden by a shrill cry no man's lips could utter, that swelled high upon the air and died, lost amid the growing clamour.
10064-8{_}1794{_}"They've fired the ricks first!"
10064-8{_}1795{_}panted Roger; "'tis ever Pertolepe's way!"

10064-8{_}1801{_}Soon Beltane beheld a stream that flowed athwart their way and, beyond the stream, a line of willows thick growing upon the marge; and again, beyond these clustering willows the straggling village lay.
10064-8{_}1802{_}Then Beltane, motioning the others to caution, forded the stream and coming in the shade of the osiers, drew on his hood of mail, and so, unsheathing his long sword, peered through the leaves.
10064-8{_}1803{_}And this is what he saw:  A wide road flanked by rows of scattered cottages, rude of wall and thatch; a dusty road, that led away east and west into the cool depths of the forest, and a cringing huddle of wretched village folk whose pallid faces were all set one way, where some score of men-at-arms lolled in their saddles watching a tall young maid who struggled fiercely in the grasp of two lusty fellows, her garments rent, her white flesh agleam in the sunlight.
10064-8{_}1804{_}A comely maid, supple and strong, who ever as she strove 'gainst the clutching hands that held her, kept her blazing eyes turned upon one in knightly mail who sat upon a great war-horse hard by, watching her, big chin in big mailed fist, and with wide lips up-curling in a smile: a strong man this, heavy and broad of chest; his casque hung at his saddle-bow, and his mail-coif, thrown back upon his wide shoulders, showed his thick, red hair that fell a-down, framing his square-set, rugged face.
10064-8{_}1805{_}"Ha, Cuthbert," quoth he, turning to one who rode at his elbow--a slender youth who stared with evil eyes and sucked upon his finger, "Aha, by the fiend, 'tis a sweet armful, Sir Squire?"

10064-8{_}1820{_}"Dog!"

10064-8{_}1849{_}But of a sudden the clamour died to silence, and thereafter from a hundred throats a shout went up:  "A Pertolepe!
10064-8{_}1850{_}'Tis Sir Pertolepe!"
10064-8{_}1851{_}Now in this moment Beltane laid his dagger-hand about Sir Pertolepe's broad shoulders, and set the point of his dagger 'neath Sir Pertolepe's right ear.
10064-8{_}1852{_}"Speak!"
10064-8{_}1853{_}quoth Beltane softly, and his dagger-point bit deeper, "speak now as I commanded thee!"
10064-8{_}1854{_}A while Sir Pertolepe bit savagely at his knuckle-bones, then, lifting his head, spake that all might hear:  "Ho, sirs!"
10064-8{_}1855{_}he cried, "I am fain to bide awhile and hold talk with one Beltane, who styleth himself--Duke of Pentavalon.
10064-8{_}1856{_}Hie ye back, therefore, one and all, and wait me in Garthlaxton; yet, an I come not by sunset, ride forth and seek me within the forest.
10064-8{_}1857{_}Go!"
10064-8{_}1858{_}Hereupon from the disordered ranks a sound arose, a hoarse murmur that voiced their stark amaze, and, for a while, all eyes stared upon those two grim figures that yet stood so close and brotherly.
10064-8{_}1859{_}But Sir Pertolepe quelled them with a gesture:  "Go!"
10064-8{_}1860{_}he commanded.
10064-8{_}1861{_}So their disarray fell into rank and order, and wheeling about, they marched away along the forest road with helm agleam and pennons a-dance, the while Sir Pertolepe stared after them, wild of eye and with mailed hands clenched; once he made as if to call them back: but Beltane's hand was heavy on his shoulder, and the dagger pricked his throat.
10064-8{_}1862{_}And thus stood they, side by side, until the tramp of feet was died away, until the last trembling villager had slunk from sight and the broad road was deserted, all save for Cuthbert the esquire, and divers horses that lay stiffly in the dust, silent and very still.
10064-8{_}1863{_}Then Beltane sighed and sheathed his dagger, and Sir Pertolepe faced him scrowling, fierce-eyed and arrogant.
10064-8{_}1864{_}"Ha, outlaw!"
10064-8{_}1865{_}quoth he, "give back my sword and I will cope with thee-- wolf's head though thou art--aye, and any two other rogues beside."
10064-8{_}1866{_}"Nay," answered Beltane, "I fight with such as thee but when I needs must.
10064-8{_}1867{_}What--Roger!"
10064-8{_}1868{_}he called, "go fetch hither a rope!"
10064-8{_}1869{_}"Dog--would ye murder me?"
10064-8{_}1870{_}"Not so," sighed Beltane, shaking his head, "have I not promised to leave thee alive within the greenwood?
10064-8{_}1871{_}Yet I would see thee walk in bonds first."
10064-8{_}1872{_}"Ha, dare ye bind me, then?
10064-8{_}1873{_}He that toucheth me, toucheth Duke Ivo-- dare ye so do, rogue?"
10064-8{_}1874{_}"Aye, messire," nodded Beltane, "I dare so.
10064-8{_}1875{_}Bring hither the rope, Roger."
10064-8{_}1876{_}But when Roger was come nigh, Sir Pertolepe turned and stared upon him.
10064-8{_}1877{_}"What!"
10064-8{_}1878{_}cried he, jovial of voice yet deadly-eyed, "is it my runaway hangman in very sooth.
10064-8{_}1879{_}Did I not pay thee enough, thou black-avised knave?
10064-8{_}1880{_}Did I not love thee for thy skill with the noose, thou traitorous rogue?
10064-8{_}1881{_}Now, mark me, Roger: one day will I feed thee to my hounds and watch them tear thee, as they have certain other rogues-- aha!--you mind them, belike?"
10064-8{_}1882{_}Pale of cheek and with trembling hands, Roger bound the arms of him that had been his over-lord, while Walkyn and Giles, silent and wide-eyed, watched it done.
10064-8{_}1883{_}"Whither would ye take me?"
10064-8{_}1884{_}quoth Red Pertolepe, arrogant.
10064-8{_}1885{_}"That shalt thou know anon, messire."
10064-8{_}1886{_}"How an I defy thee?"
10064-8{_}1887{_}"Then must we carry thee, messire," answered Beltane, "yet thine own legs were better methinks--come, let us begone."
10064-8{_}1888{_}Thus, presently, having forded the brook, they struck into the forest; first went Walkyn, axe on shoulder, teeth agleam; next strode Sir Pertolepe, head high, 'twixt pale-faced Roger and silent Beltane, while the bowman followed after, calling upon St. Giles beneath his breath and crossing himself: and ever and anon Walkyn would turn to look upon their scowling captive with eyes that glared 'neath shaggy brows.
10064-8{_}1889{_}Now after they had gone some while, Sir Pertolepe brake silence and spake my Beltane, proud and fierce.
10064-8{_}1890{_}"Fellow," quoth he, "if 'tis for ransom ye hold me, summon hither thy rogues' company, and I will covenant for my release."
10064-8{_}1891{_}"I seek no ransom of thee, messire," answered Beltane, "and for my company--'tis here."
10064-8{_}1892{_}"Here?
10064-8{_}1893{_}I see but three sorry knaves!"
10064-8{_}1894{_}"Yet with these same three did I o'ercome thy foresters, Sir Pertolepe."
10064-8{_}1895{_}"Rogue, thou liest--'tis thing impossible!"
10064-8{_}1896{_}"Moreover, with these three did I, last night, burn down Black Ivo's mighty gallows that stood without Belsaye town, and, thereafter set wide the dungeon of Belsaye and delivered thence certain woeful prisoners, and sent them abroad with word that I--Beltane, son of Beltane the Strong, Duke of Pentavalon, am come at last, bearing the sword of my father, that was wont to strike deep for liberty and justice: nor, having life, will I lay it by until oppression is no more."
10064-8{_}1897{_}Now indeed did Sir Pertolepe stare upon my Beltane in amaze and spake no word for wonder; then, of a sudden he laughed, scornful and loud.
10064-8{_}1898{_}"Ho!
10064-8{_}1899{_}thou burner of gibbets!"
10064-8{_}1900{_}quoth he, "take heed lest thy windy boasting bring thy lordly neck within a noose!
10064-8{_}1901{_}Art lusty of arm, yet lustier of tongue--and as to thy father, whoe'er he be--"  "Messire?"
10064-8{_}1902{_}Beltane's voice was soft, yet, meeting the calm serenity of his gaze, Sir Pertolepe checked the jeer upon his lip and stared upon Beltane as one new-waked; beheld in turn his high and noble look, the costly excellence of his armour, his great sword and belt of silver-- and strode on thereafter with never a word, yet viewing Beltane aslance 'neath brows close-knit in dark perplexity.
10064-8{_}1903{_}So, at last, they came into a little clearing deep-hid among the denser green.
10064-8{_}1904{_}Beltane paused here, and lifting mailed hand, pointed to a certain tree.
10064-8{_}1905{_}But hereupon, Sir Pertolepe, staring round about him and down upon his galling bonds, spake:  "Sir knight," said he, "who thou art I know not, yet, if indeed thou art of gentle blood, then know that I am Sir Pertolepe, Baron of Trenda, Seneschal of Garthlaxton, lord warden of the marches: moreover, friend and brother-in-arms am I to Duke Ivo--"  "Nay," said Beltane, "all this I know, for much of thee have I heard, messire: of thy dark doings, of the agony of men, the shame of women, and how that there be many desolate hearths and nameless graves of thy making, lord Pertolepe.
10064-8{_}1906{_}Thou wert indeed of an high estate and strong, and these but lowly folk and weak--yet mercy on them had ye none.
10064-8{_}1907{_}I have this day heard thee doom the innocent to death and bitter shame, and, lord, as God seeth us, it is enough!"
10064-8{_}1908{_}Sir Pertolepe's ruddy cheek showed pale, but his blue eyes stared upon Beltane wide and fearless.
10064-8{_}1909{_}"Have ye then dragged me hither to die, messire?"
10064-8{_}1910{_}"Lord Pertolepe, all men must die, aye, e'en great lords such as thou, when they have sinned sufficiently: and thy sins, methinks, do reach high heaven.
10064-8{_}1911{_}So have I brought thee hither into the wilderness that God's will may be wrought upon thee."
10064-8{_}1912{_}"How--wilt forswear thyself?"
