10064-8{_}1913{_}cried Sir Pertolepe, writhing in his bonds.
10064-8{_}1914{_}Quoth Beltane:  "Come Roger--Walkyn--bring me him to the tree, yonder."
10064-8{_}1915{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}1916{_}rogue--rogue," panted Sir Pertolepe, "would'st leave me to die in a noose, unshriven and unannealed, my soul dragged hell-wards weighted with my sins?"
10064-8{_}1917{_}Now, even as he spake, swift and sudden he leapt aside and would have fled; but Walkyn's fierce fingers dragged at his throat, and Roger's iron arms were close about him.
10064-8{_}1918{_}Desperately he fought and struggled, but mighty though he was, his captors were mighty also, moreover his bonds galled him; wherefore, fighting yet, they dragged him to the tree, and to the tree Beltane fast bound him, whiles the forest rang and echoed with his panting cries until his great voice cracked and broke, and he hung 'gainst the tree, spent and breathless.
10064-8{_}1919{_}Then spake Beltane, grim-lipped yet soft of voice:  "Lord Pertolepe, fain would I hang thee as thou hast hanged many a man ere now--but this, methinks, is a better way: for here, unless some wanderer chance to find thee, must thou perish, an so God will it.
10064-8{_}1920{_}Thus do we leave thee in the hands of God to grant thee life or death: and may he have mercy on thy guilty soul!"
10064-8{_}1921{_}Thus said Beltane, sombre of brow and pale of cheek; and so, beckoning to the others, turned away, despite Sir Pertolepe's passionate threats and prayers, and plunging into the dense underbrush, strode swift-footed from the place, with the captive's wild cries ringing in his ears.
10064-8{_}1922{_}Haphazard went Beltane, yet straining his ears to catch those mournful sounds that grew faint and fainter with distance till they were lost in the rustle of the leaves.
10064-8{_}1923{_}But, of a sudden, he stayed his going and stood with his head aslant hearkening to a sound that seemed to have reached him from the solitudes behind; and presently it came again, a cry from afar--a scream of agony, hoarse and long drawn out, a hateful sound that checked the breath of him and brought the sweat out cold upon his brow; and now, turning about, he saw that his following was but two, for Walkyn had vanished quite.
10064-8{_}1924{_}Now Giles, meeting Beltane's wide stare, must needs cough and fumble with his bow, whiles Roger stood with bowed head and fingers tight-clenched upon his quarter-staff: whereat, fierce-frowning, Beltane spake.
10064-8{_}1925{_}"Wait!"
10064-8{_}1926{_}he commanded, "wait you here!"
10064-8{_}1927{_}and forthwith turned and ran, and so running, came again at last to that obscure glade whence now came a sound of groans, mocked, thereafter, by fierce laughter.
10064-8{_}1928{_}Now, bursting from the green, Beltane beheld Sir Pertolepe writhing in his bonds with Walkyn's fierce fingers twined in his red hair, and Walkyn's busy dagger at his upturned brow, where was a great, gory wound, a hideous cruciform blotch whence pulsed the blood that covered his writhen face like a scarlet vizard.
10064-8{_}1929{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}1930{_}cried Beltane, "what hast thou done?"
10064-8{_}1931{_}Back fell Walkyn, fierce-eyed and grim yet with teeth agleam through the hair of his beard.
10064-8{_}1932{_}"Lord," quoth he, "this man hath slain wife, and child and brother, so do I know him thrice a murderer.
10064-8{_}1933{_}Therefore have I set this mark of Cain upon him, that all men henceforth may see and know.
10064-8{_}1934{_}But now, an it be so thy will, take this my dagger and slay me here and now--yet shall Red Pertolepe bear my mark upon him when I am dead."
10064-8{_}1935{_}Awhile stood Beltane in frowning thought, then pointed to the green.
10064-8{_}1936{_}"Go," said he, "the others wait thee!"
10064-8{_}1937{_}So Walkyn, obeying, turned and plunged into the green, while Beltane followed after, slow and heavy-footed.
10064-8{_}1938{_}But now, even as he went, slow and ever slower, he lifted heavy head and turned about, for above the leafy stirrings rose the mournful lilting of a pipe, clear and very sweet, that drew nearer and louder until it was, of a sudden, drowned in a cry hoarse and woeful.
10064-8{_}1939{_}Then Beltane, hasting back soft-treading, stood to peer through the leaves, and presently, his cock's-comb flaunting, his silver bells a-jingle, there stepped a mountebank into the clearing--that same jester with whom Beltane had talked aforetime.
10064-8{_}1940{_}"Beda!"
10064-8{_}1941{_}cried Sir Pertolepe faintly, his bloody face uplifted, "and is it forsooth, thou, Beda?
10064-8{_}1942{_}Come, free me of my bonds.
10064-8{_}1943{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}1944{_}why stay ye, I am Pertolepe--thy lord--know you me not, Beda?"
10064-8{_}1945{_}"Aye, full well I know thee, lord Pertolepe, thou art he who had me driven forth with blows and bitter stripes--thou art he who slew my father for an ill-timed jest--oho!
10064-8{_}1946{_}well do I know thee, my lord Pertolepe."
10064-8{_}1947{_}So saying, Beda the Jester set his pipe within his girdle, and, drawing his dagger, began to creep upon Sir Pertolepe, who shook the dripping blood from his eyes to watch him as he came.
10064-8{_}1948{_}Quote he:  "Art a good fool, Beda, aye, a good fool.
10064-8{_}1949{_}And for thy father, 'twas the wine, Beda--the wine, not I--come, free me of these my bonds--I loved thy father, e'en as I loved thee."
10064-8{_}1950{_}"Yet is my father dead, lord--and I am outcast!"
10064-8{_}1951{_}said Beda, smiling and fingering his dagger.
10064-8{_}1952{_}"So then, will ye slay me, Beda--wilt murder thy lord?
10064-8{_}1953{_}Why then, strike, fool, strike--here, i' the throat, and let thy steel be hard-driven.
10064-8{_}1954{_}Come!"
10064-8{_}1955{_}Then Sir Pertolepe feebly raised his bloody head, proffering his throat to the steel and so stood faint in his bonds, yet watching the jester calm-eyed.
10064-8{_}1956{_}Slowly, slowly the dagger was lifted for the stroke while Sir Pertolepe watched the glittering steel patient and unflinching; then, swift and sudden the dagger flashed and fell, and Sir Pertolepe staggered free, and so stood swaying.
10064-8{_}1957{_}Then, looking down upon his severed bonds, he laughed hoarsely.
10064-8{_}1958{_}"How, 'twas but a jest, then, my Beda?"
10064-8{_}1959{_}he whispered.
10064-8{_}1960{_}"A jest--ha!
10064-8{_}1961{_}and methinks, forsooth, the best wilt ever make!"
10064-8{_}1962{_}So saying, Sir Pertolepe stumbled forward a pace, groping before him like a blind man, then, groaning, fell, and lay a'swoon, his bloody face hidden in the grass.
10064-8{_}1963{_}And turning away, Beltane left him lying there with Beda the Jester kneeling above him.
10064-8{_}1964{_}CHAPTER XVI  OF THE RUEFUL KNIGHT OF THE BURNING HEART   Southward marched Beltane hour after hour, tireless of stride, until the sun began to decline; on and on, thoughtful of brow and speaking not at all, wherefore the three were gloomy and silent also--even Giles had no mind to break in upon his solemn meditations.
10064-8{_}1965{_}But at last came Roger and touched him on the shoulder.
10064-8{_}1966{_}"Master," said he, "the day groweth to a close, and we famish."
10064-8{_}1967{_}"Why, then--eat," said Beltane.
10064-8{_}1968{_}Now while they set about building a fire, Beltane went aside and wandering slow and thoughtful, presently came to a broad glade or ride, and stretching himself out 'neath a tree, lay there staring up at the leafy canopy, pondering upon Sir Pertolepe his sins, and the marvellous ways of God.
10064-8{_}1969{_}Lying thus, he was aware of the slow, plodding hoof-strokes of a horse drawing near, of the twang of a lute, with a voice sweet and melodious intoning a chant; and the tune was plaintive and the words likewise, being these:--    "Alack and woe    That love is so    Akin to pain!
10064-8{_}1970{_}That to my heart    The bitter smart    Returns again,    Alack and woe!"
10064-8{_}1971{_}Glancing up therefore, Beltane presently espied a knight who bestrode a great and goodly war-horse; a youthful knight and debonair, slender and shapely in his bright mail and surcoat of flame-coloured samite.
10064-8{_}1972{_}His broad shield hung behind his shoulder, balanced by a long lance whose gay banderol fluttered wanton to the soft-breathing air; above his mail-coif he wore a small bright-polished bascinet, while, at his high-peaked saddle-bow his ponderous war-helm swung, together with broad-bladed battle-axe.
10064-8{_}1973{_}Now as he paced along in this right gallant estate, his roving glance, by hap, lighted on Beltane, whereupon, checking his powerful horse, he plucked daintily at the strings of his lute, delicate-fingered, and brake into song anew:--    "Ah, woe is me    That I should be    A lonely wight!
10064-8{_}1974{_}That in mankind    No joy I find    By day or night,    Ah, woe is me!"
10064-8{_}1975{_}Thereafter he sighed amain and smote his bosom, and smiling upon Beltane sad-eyed, spake:  "Most excellent, tall, and sweet young sir, I, who Love's lorn pilgrim am, do give thee woeful greeting and entreat now the courtesy of thy pity."
10064-8{_}1976{_}"And wherefore pity, sir?"
10064-8{_}1977{_}quoth Beltane, sitting up.
10064-8{_}1978{_}"For reason of a lady's silver laughter.
10064-8{_}1979{_}A notable reason this; for, mark me, ye lovers, an thy lady flout thee one hour, grieve not--she shall be kind the next; an she scorn thee to-day, despair nothing--she shall love thee to-morrow; but, an she laugh and laugh--ah, then poor lover, Venus pity thee!
10064-8{_}1980{_}Then languish hope, and tender heart be rent, for love and laughter can ne'er be kin.
10064-8{_}1981{_}Wherefore a woeful wight am I, foredone and all distraught for love.
10064-8{_}1982{_}Behold here, the blazon on my shield--lo!
10064-8{_}1983{_}a riven heart proper (direfully aflame) upon a field vert.
10064-8{_}1984{_}The heart, methinks, is aptly wrought and popped, and the flame in sooth flame-like!
10064-8{_}1985{_}Here beneath, behold my motto, 'Ardeo' which signifieth 'I burn.'
10064-8{_}1986{_}Other device have I laid by for the nonce, what time my pilgrimage shall be accompt."
10064-8{_}1987{_}But Beltane looked not so much upon the shield as on the face of him that bore it, and beholding its high and fearless look, the clear, bright eyes and humorous mouth (albeit schooled to melancholy) he smiled, and got him to his feet.
10064-8{_}1988{_}"Now, well met, Sir Knight of the Burning Heart!"
10064-8{_}1989{_}quoth he.
10064-8{_}1990{_}"What would ye here, alone, within these solitudes?"
10064-8{_}1991{_}"Sigh, messire.
10064-8{_}1992{_}I sing and sigh, and sigh and sing."
10064-8{_}1993{_}"'Tis a something empty life, methinks."
10064-8{_}1994{_}"Not so, messire," sighed the rueful knight, "for when I chance to meet a gentle youth, young and well beseen--as thou, bedight in goodly mail --as thou, with knightly sword on thigh, why then, messire, 'tis ever my wont to declare unto him that she I honour is fairer, nobler, and altogether more worthy and virtuous than any other she soever, and to maintain that same against him, on horse or afoot, with lance, battle-axe or sword.
10064-8{_}1995{_}Thus, see you messire, even a love-lorn lover hath betimes his compensations, and the sward is soft underfoot, and level."
10064-8{_}1996{_}Saying which, the knight cocked a delicate eyebrow in questioning fashion, and laid a slender finger to the pommel of his long sword.
10064-8{_}1997{_}"How," cried Beltane, "would'st fight with me?"
10064-8{_}1998{_}"Right gladly would I, messire--to break the monotony."
10064-8{_}1999{_}"I had rather hear thy song again."
10064-8{_}2000{_}"Ha, liked you it in sooth?
10064-8{_}2001{_}'Tis small thing of mine own."
10064-8{_}2002{_}"And 'tis brief!"
10064-8{_}2003{_}nodded Beltane.
10064-8{_}2004{_}"Brief!"
10064-8{_}2005{_}quoth the knight, "brief!
10064-8{_}2006{_}not so, most notable youthful sir, for even as love is long enduring so is my song, it being of an hundred and seventy and eight cantos in all, dealing somewhat of the woes and ills of a heart sore smitten (which heart is mine own also).
10064-8{_}2007{_}Within my song is much matter of hearts (in truth) and darts, of flames and shames, of yearnings and burnings, the which this poor heart must needs endure since it doth constant bleed and burn."
10064-8{_}2008{_}"Indeed, messire, I marvel that you be yet alive," said Beltane gravely, whereat the young knight did pause to view him, dubious-eyed.
10064-8{_}2009{_}Quoth he:  "In sooth, most youthful and excellent sir, I have myself marvelled thereat betimes, but, since alive am I, now do I declare unto you that she for whom I sigh is the fairest, gentlest, noblest, most glorious and most womanly of all women in the world alive--"  "Save one!"
10064-8{_}2010{_}said Beltane.
10064-8{_}2011{_}"Save none, messire!"
10064-8{_}2012{_}said the young knight, eager-eyed.
10064-8{_}2013{_}"One!"
10064-8{_}2014{_}said Beltane.
10064-8{_}2015{_}"None!"
10064-8{_}2016{_}quoth the knight, as, casting aside ponderous lance he vaulted lightly from his saddle and drew his sword; but, seeing that Beltane bore no shield, paused to lay his own tenderly aside, and so faced him serene of brow and smiling of lip.
10064-8{_}2017{_}"Sweet sir," said he gaily, "here methinks is fair cause for argument; let us then discuss the matter together for the comfort of our souls and to the glory of our ladies.
10064-8{_}2018{_}As to my name--" "'Tis Jocelyn," quoth Beltane.
10064-8{_}2019{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}2020{_}exclaimed the knight, staring.
10064-8{_}2021{_}"That won a suit of triple mail at Dunismere joust, and wagered it 'gainst Black Ivo's roan stallion within Deepwold forest upon a time."
10064-8{_}2022{_}"Now, by Venus!"
10064-8{_}2023{_}cried the knight, starting back, "here be manifest sorcery!
10064-8{_}2024{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}2025{_}by the sweet blind boy, 'tis black magic!"
10064-8{_}2026{_}and he crossed himself devoutly.
10064-8{_}2027{_}But Beltane, laughing, put back his hood of mail, that his long, fair hair fell a-down rippling to his shoulders.
10064-8{_}2028{_}"Know you me not, messire?"
10064-8{_}2029{_}quoth he.
10064-8{_}2030{_}"Why," said Sir Jocelyn, knitting delicate brows, "surely thou art the forester that o'ercame Duke Ivo's wrestler; aye, by the silver feet of lovely Thetis, thou'rt Beltane the Smith!"
10064-8{_}2031{_}"Verily, messire," nodded Beltane, "and 'tis not meet that knight cross blade with lowly smith."
10064-8{_}2032{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}2033{_}quoth Sir Jocelyn, rubbing at his smooth white chin, "yet art a goodly man withal--and lover to boot--methinks?"
10064-8{_}2034{_}"Aye," sighed Beltane, "ever and always."
10064-8{_}2035{_}"Why then, all's well," quoth Sir Jocelyn with eyes a-dance, "for since true love knoweth nought of distinctions, therefore being lovers are we peers, and, being peers, so may we fight together.
10064-8{_}2036{_}So come, Sir Smith, here stand I sword in hand to maintain 'gainst thee and all men the fame and honour of her I worship, of all women alive, maid or wife or widow, the fairest, noblest, truest, and most love-worthy is--"  "Helen of Mortain!"
10064-8{_}2037{_}quoth Beltane, sighing.
10064-8{_}2038{_}"Helen?--Helen?--thou too!"
10064-8{_}2039{_}exclaimed Sir Jocelyn, and forthwith dropped his sword, staring in stark amaze.
10064-8{_}2040{_}"How--dost thou love her also?"
10064-8{_}2041{_}"Aye," sighed Beltane, "to my sorrow!"
10064-8{_}2042{_}Then stooped Sir Jocelyn and, taking up his sword, slowly sheathed it.
10064-8{_}2043{_}Quoth he, sad-eyed:  "Life, methinks, is full of disappointments; farewell to thee, Sir Smith," and sighing, he turned away; yet ere he had taken lance and shield, Beltane spake:  "Whither away, Sir Jocelyn?"
10064-8{_}2044{_}"To sigh, and sing, and seek adventure.
10064-8{_}2045{_}'Twas for this I left my goodly castle of Alain and journeyed, a lorn pilgrim, hither to Pentavalon, since when strange stories have I heard that whisper in the air, speeding from lip to lip, of a certain doughty knight-at-arms, valiant beyond thought, that beareth a sword whose mighty sweep none may abide, who, alone and unaided slew an hundred and twenty and four within the greenwood, and thereafter, did, 'neath the walls of Belsaye town burn down Duke Ivo's gibbet, who hath sworn to cut Duke Ivo into gobbets, look you, and feed him to the dogs; which is well, for I love not Duke Ivo.
10064-8{_}2046{_}All this have I heard and much beside, idle tales mayhap, yet would I seek out this errant Mars and prove him, for mine own behoof, with stroke of sword."
10064-8{_}2047{_}"And how an he prove worthy?"
10064-8{_}2048{_}questioned Beltane.
10064-8{_}2049{_}"Then will I ride with him, to share his deeds and glory mayhap, Sir Smith--I and all the ten-score lusty fellows that muster to my pennon, since in the air is whispered talk of war, and Sir Benedict lieth ready in Thrasfordham Keep."
10064-8{_}2050{_}"Two hundred men," quoth Beltane, his blue eyes agleam, "two hundred, say you?"
10064-8{_}2051{_}and, speaking, he stepped forward, unsheathing his sword.
10064-8{_}2052{_}"How now," quoth Sir Jocelyn, "what would ye, sweet smith?"
10064-8{_}2053{_}"I would have thee prove me for thy behoof, Sir Jocelyn; for I am he that with aid of five good men burned down the gibbet without Belsaye."
10064-8{_}2054{_}"Thou!"
10064-8{_}2055{_}cried Sir Jocelyn, "and thou art a smith!
10064-8{_}2056{_}And yet needs must I credit thee, for thine eyes be truthful eyes.
10064-8{_}2057{_}And did'st indeed slay so many in the green, forsooth?"
10064-8{_}2058{_}"Nay," answered Beltane, "there were but twenty; moreover I--"  "Enough!"
10064-8{_}2059{_}cried Sir Jocelyn, gaily, "be thou smith or be thou demi-god, now will I make proof of thy might and valiance."
10064-8{_}2060{_}And he drew sword.
10064-8{_}2061{_}So did these two youths face each other, smiling above their gleaming steel, and so the long blades rang together, and, thereafter, the air was full of a clashing din, in so much that Roger came running sword in hand, with Walkyn and Giles at his heels; but, seeing how matters stood, they sat them down on the sward, watching round-eyed and eager.
10064-8{_}2062{_}And now Sir Jocelyn (happy-eyed), his doleful heart forgot, did show himself a doughty knight, skipping lightly to and fro despite his heavy armour, and laying on right lustily while the three a-sprawl upon the grass shouted gleefully at each shrewd stroke or skilful parry; but, once Sir Jocelyn's blade clashed upon Beltane's mailed thigh, and straightway they fell silent; and once his point touched the links on Beltane's wide breast, and straightway their brows grew anxious and gloomy--yet none so gloomy as Roger.
10064-8{_}2063{_}But now, on a sudden, was the flash and ring of hard smitten steel, and behold, Sir Jocelyn's sword sprang from his grasp and thudded to earth a good three yards away; whereupon the three roared amain--yet none so loud as Roger.
10064-8{_}2064{_}"Now by sweet Cupid his tender bow!"
10064-8{_}2065{_}panted Sir Jocelyn--"by the cestus of lovely Venus--aye, by the ox-eyed Juno, I swear 'twas featly done, Sir Smith!"
10064-8{_}2066{_}Quoth Beltane, taking up the fallen sword:  "'Tis a trick I learned of that great and glorious knight, Sir Benedict of Bourne."
10064-8{_}2067{_}"Messire," said Sir Jocelyn, his cheek flushing, "an earl am I of thirty and two quarterings and divers goodly manors: yet thou art the better man, meseemeth, and as such do I salute thee, and swear myself thy brother-in-arms henceforth--an ye will."
10064-8{_}2068{_}Now hereupon Beltane turned, and looking upon the mighty three with kindling eye, beckoned them near.
10064-8{_}2069{_}"Lord Jocelyn," said he, "behold here my trusty comrades, valiant men all:--this, my faithful Roger, surnamed the Black: This, Giles Brabblecombe, who shooteth as ne'er did archer yet: and here, Walkyn-- who hath known overmuch of sorrow and bitter wrong.
10064-8{_}2070{_}Fain would we take thee for our comrade, Lord Jocelyn, for God knoweth Pentavalon hath need of true men these days, yet first, know this--that I, and these my three good comrades do stand pledged to the cause of the weak and woefully oppressed within this sorrowful Duchy; to smite evil, nor stay till we be dead, or Black Ivo driven hence."
10064-8{_}2071{_}"Ivo?--Ivo?"
10064-8{_}2072{_}stammered Sir Jocelyn, in blank amaze, "'tis madness!"
10064-8{_}2073{_}"Thus," said Beltane, "is our cause, perchance, a little desperate, and he who companies with us must company with Death betimes."
10064-8{_}2074{_}"To defy Black Ivo--ha, here is madness so mad as pleaseth me right well!
10064-8{_}2075{_}A rebellion, forsooth!
10064-8{_}2076{_}How many do ye muster?"
10064-8{_}2077{_}Answered Beltane:  "Thou seest--we be four--"  "Four!"
10064-8{_}2078{_}cried Sir Jocelyn, "Four!"
10064-8{_}2079{_}"But Sir Benedict lieth within Thrasfordham Keep, and God is in heaven, messire."
10064-8{_}2080{_}"Aye, but heaven is far, methinks, and Duke Ivo is near, and hath an arm long and merciless.
10064-8{_}2081{_}Art so weary of life, Sir Smith?"
10064-8{_}2082{_}"Nay," answered Beltane, "but to what end hath man life, save to spend it for the good of his fellows?"
10064-8{_}2083{_}"Art mad!"
10064-8{_}2084{_}sighed Sir Jocelyn, "art surely mad!
10064-8{_}2085{_}Heigho!--some day, mayhap, it shall be written how one Jocelyn Alain, a gentle, love-lorn knight, singing his woes within the greenwood, did meet four lovely madmen and straight fell mad likewise.
10064-8{_}2086{_}So here, upon my sword, do I swear to take thee for my brother-in-arms, and these thy comrades for my comrades, and to spend my life, henceforth, to the good of my fellows!"
10064-8{_}2087{_}So saying, Sir Jocelyn smiled his quick bright smile and reached out his hand to my Beltane, and there, leaning upon their swords, their mailed fingers clasped and wrung each other.
10064-8{_}2088{_}Thereafter he turned upon the three, but even as he did so, Walkyn uttered a fierce cry, and whirling about with axe aloft, sprang into the green, whence of a sudden rose a babel of voices, and the sound of fierce blows and, thereafter, the noise of pursuit.
10064-8{_}2089{_}A flicker of steel amid the green--a score of fierce faces all about him, and Beltane was seized from behind, borne struggling to his knees, to his face, battered by unseen weapons, dragged at by unseen hands, choked, half-stunned, his arms twisted and bound by galling thongs.
10064-8{_}2090{_}Now, as he lay thus, helpless, a mailed foot spurned him fiercely and looking up, half-swooning, he beheld Sir Pertolepe smiling down at him.
10064-8{_}2091{_}"Ha--thou fool!"
10064-8{_}2092{_}he laughed jovially, "did'st think to escape me, then --thou fool, I have followed on thy tracks all day.
10064-8{_}2093{_}By the eyes of God, I would have followed thee to hell!
10064-8{_}2094{_}I want thee in Garthlaxton--there be gibbets for thee above the keep--also, there are my hounds--aye, I want thee, Messire Beltane who art Duke of Pentavalon!
10064-8{_}2095{_}Ho!
10064-8{_}2096{_}Arnulf--a halter for his ducal throat!"
10064-8{_}2097{_}So, when they had cast a noose about his neck, they dragged Beltane, choking, to his feet, and led him away gasping and staggering through the green; and having eyes, he saw not, and having ears, he heard not, being very spent and sick.
10064-8{_}2098{_}Now, as they went, evening began to fall.
10064-8{_}2099{_}CHAPTER XVII  OF THE AMBUSHMENT NEAR THORNABY MILL   Little by little, as he stumbled along, Beltane's brain began to clear; he became aware of the ring and clash of arms about him, and the trampling of horses.
10064-8{_}2100{_}Gradually, the mist lifting, he saw long files of men-at-arms riding along very orderly, with archers and pike-men.
10064-8{_}2101{_}Little by little, amid all these hostile forms, he seemed to recognise a certain pair of legs that went on just before: sturdy legs, that yet faltered now and then in their stride, and, looking higher, he saw a broad belt whose edges were notched and saw-like, and a wide, mail-clad back that yet bent weakly forward with every shambling step.
10064-8{_}2102{_}Once this figure sank to its knees, but stumbled up again 'neath the vicious prick of a pike-head that left blood upon the bronzed skin, whereat Beltane uttered a hoarse cry.
10064-8{_}2103{_}"O Black Roger!"
10064-8{_}2104{_}he groaned, "I grieve to have brought thee to this!"
10064-8{_}2105{_}"Nay, lord," quoth Roger, lifting high his drooping head, "'tis but my wound that bleeds afresh.
10064-8{_}2106{_}But, bond or free, thy man am I, and able yet to strike a blow on thy behalf an heaven so please."
10064-8{_}2107{_}"Now God shield thee, brave Roger!"
10064-8{_}2108{_}sighed Beltane.
10064-8{_}2109{_}"O sweet St. Giles--and what of me, brother?"
10064-8{_}2110{_}spake a voice in his ear, and turning, Beltane beheld the archer smiling upon him with swollen, bloody lips.
10064-8{_}2111{_}"Thou here too, good Giles?"
10064-8{_}2112{_}"Even so, tall brother, in adversity lo!
10064-8{_}2113{_}I am with thee--since I found no chance to run other-where, for that divers rogues constrained me to abide--notably yon knave with the scar, whose mailed fist I had perforce to kiss, brother, in whose dog's carcase I will yet feather me a shaft, sweet St. Giles aiding me--which is my patron saint, you'll mind.
10064-8{_}2114{_}_Nil desperandum_, brother: bruised and beaten, bleeding and in bonds, yet I breathe, nothing desponding, for mark me, _a priori_, brother, Walkyn and the young knight won free, which is well; Walkyn hath long legs, which is better; Walkyn hath many friends i' the greenwood, which is best of all.
10064-8{_}2115{_}So do I keep a merry heart--_dum spiro spero_--trusting to the good St. Giles, which, as methinks you know is my--"  The archer grew suddenly dumb, his comely face blanched, and glancing round, Beltane beheld Sir Pertolepe beside him, who leaned down from his great white horse to smile wry-mouthed, and smiling thus, put back the mail-coif from his pallid face and laid a finger to the linen clout that swathed his head above the brows.
10064-8{_}2116{_}"Messire," said he soft-voiced, "for this I might hang thee to a tree, or drag thee at a horse's tail, or hew thee in sunder with this great sword o' thine which shall be mine henceforth--but these be deaths unworthy of such as thou--my lord Duke!
10064-8{_}2117{_}Now within Garthlaxton be divers ways and means, quaint fashions and devices strange and rare, messire.
10064-8{_}2118{_}And when I'm done, Black Roger shall hang what's left of thee, ere he go to feed my hounds.
10064-8{_}2119{_}That big body o' thine shall rot above my gate, and for that golden head--ha!
10064-8{_}2120{_}I'll send it to Duke Ivo in quittance for his gallows!
10064-8{_}2121{_}Yet first--O, first shalt thou sigh that death must needs be so long a-coming!"
10064-8{_}2122{_}But now, from where the van-ward marched, came galloping a tall esquire, who, reining in beside Sir Pertolepe, pointed down the hill.
10064-8{_}2123{_}"Lord Pertolepe," he cried joyously, "yonder, scarce a mile, flies the banner of Gilles of Brandonmere, his company few, his men scattered and heavy with plunder."
10064-8{_}2124{_}"Gilles!"
10064-8{_}2125{_}quoth Sir Pertolepe.
10064-8{_}2126{_}"Ha, is it forsooth Gilles of Brandonmere?"
10064-8{_}2127{_}"Himself, lord, and none other.
10064-8{_}2128{_}I marked plain his banner with the three stooping falcons."
10064-8{_}2129{_}"And he hath booty, say you?"
10064-8{_}2130{_}"In truth, my lord--and there be women also, three horse litters--"  "Ah--women!
10064-8{_}2131{_}Verily, good Fulk, hast ever a quick eye for the flutter of a kirtle.
10064-8{_}2132{_}Now, mark me Fulk, Thornaby Mill lieth in our front, and beyond, the road windeth steep 'twixt high banks.
10064-8{_}2133{_}Let archers line these banks east and west: let the pikemen be ambushed to the south, until we from the north have charged them with the horse--see 'tis done, Fulk, and silently--so peradventure, Sir Gilles shall trouble me no more.
10064-8{_}2134{_}Pass the word--away!"
10064-8{_}2135{_}Off rode Sir Fulk, and straightway the pounding hoofs were still, the jingle of bridle and stirrup hushed, and in its place a vague stir of bustle and excitement; of pikemen wheeling right and left to vanish southwards into the green, and of archers stringing bows and unbuckling quiver-caps ere they too wheeled and vanished; yet now Sir Pertolepe stayed four lusty fellows, and beckoning them near, pointed to the prisoners.
10064-8{_}2136{_}"Good fellows," quoth he, nodding jovially upon the archers, "here be my three rogues, see you--who must with me to Garthlaxton: one to die by slow fire, one to be torn by my hounds, and one--this tall golden-haired youth--mark him well!--to die in slow and subtle fashion.
10064-8{_}2137{_}Now these three do I put in charge of ye trusty four; guard them well, good fellows, for, an one escape, so shall ye all four die in his stead and in such fashion as he should have died.
10064-8{_}2138{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}2139{_}d'ye mark me well, my merry men?"
10064-8{_}2140{_}"Aye, lord!"
10064-8{_}2141{_}nodded the four, scowling of brow yet pale-cheeked.
10064-8{_}2142{_}"Look to it I find them secure, therefore, and entreat them tenderly.
10064-8{_}2143{_}March you at the rear and see they take no harm; choose ye some secure corner where they may lie safe from chance of stray shafts, for I would have them come hale and sound to Garthlaxton, since to die well, a man must be strong and hearty, look you.
10064-8{_}2144{_}D'ye mark me well, good fellows?"
10064-8{_}2145{_}"Aye, lord!"
10064-8{_}2146{_}growled the four.
10064-8{_}2147{_}Then Sir Pertolepe, fondling his great chin, smiled upon Beltane and lifted Beltane's glittering sword on high, "Advance my banner!"
10064-8{_}2148{_}he cried, and rode forward among his men-at-arms.
10064-8{_}2149{_}On went the company, grimly silent now save for the snort of a horse, the champing of curbing bits and the thud of slow trampling hoofs upon the tender grass, as the west flamed to sunset.
10064-8{_}2150{_}Thus in a while they came to a place where the road, narrowing, ran 'twixt high banks clothed in gorse and underbrush; a shadowy road, the which, winding downwards, was lost in a sharp curve.
10064-8{_}2151{_}Here the array was halted, and abode very still and silent, with helm and lance-point winking in the last red rays of sunset.
10064-8{_}2152{_}"O brother," whispered Giles, "ne'er saw I place sweeter or more apt for ambushment.
10064-8{_}2153{_}Here shall be bloody doings anon, and we--helpless as babes!
10064-8{_}2154{_}O me, the pity on't!"
10064-8{_}2155{_}But now with blows and gibes the four archers dragged them unto a tall tree that stood beside the way, a tree of mighty girth whose far-flung branches cast a deep gloom.
10064-8{_}2156{_}Within this gloom lay my Beltane, stirring not and speaking no word, being faint and sick with his hurts.
10064-8{_}2157{_}But Giles the archer, sitting beside him, vented by turns bitter curses upon Sir Pertolepe and humble prayers to his patron saint, so fluent and so fast that prayers and curses became strangely blent and mingled, on this wise:  "May Red Pertolepe be thrice damned with a candle to the blessed Saint Giles that is my comfort and intercessor.
10064-8{_}2158{_}May his bones rot within him with my gold chain to sweet Saint Giles.
10064-8{_}2159{_}May his tongue wither at the roots--ah, good Saint Giles, save me from the fire.
10064-8{_}2160{_}May he be cursed in life and may the flesh shrivel on his bones and his soul be eternally damned with another candle and fifty gold pieces to the altar of holy Saint Giles--"  But now hearing Roger groan, the archer paused to admonish him thus:  "Croak not, Roger, croak not," quoth he, "think not upon thy vile body --pray, man, pray--pray thyself speechless.
10064-8{_}2161{_}Call reverently upon the blessed saints as I do, promise them candles, Roger, promise hard and pray harder lest we perish--I by fire and thou by Pertolepe's hounds.
10064-8{_}2162{_}Ill deaths, look you, aye, 'tis a cruel death to be burnt alive, Roger!"
10064-8{_}2163{_}"To be torn by hounds is worse!"
10064-8{_}2164{_}growled Roger.
10064-8{_}2165{_}"Nay, my Rogerkin, the fire is slower, methinks--I have watched good flesh sear and shrivel ere now--ha!
10064-8{_}2166{_}by Saint Giles, 'tis an evil subject; let us rather think upon two others."
10064-8{_}2167{_}"As what, archer?"
10064-8{_}2168{_}"The long legs of our comrade Walkyn.
10064-8{_}2169{_}Hist!
10064-8{_}2170{_}hark ye to that bruit!
10064-8{_}2171{_}Here cometh Gilles of Brandonmere, meseemeth!"
10064-8{_}2172{_}And now from the road in front rose the sound of an approaching company, the tramp of weary horses climbing the ascent with the sound of cheery voices upraised in song; and ever the sinking sun glinted redly on helm and lance-point where sat Sir Pertolepe's mailed riders, grim and silent, while the cheery voices swelled near and more near, till, all at once, the song died to a hum of amaze that rose to a warning shout that was drowned in the blare of a piercing trumpet blast.
10064-8{_}2173{_}Whereat down swept glittering lance-point, forward leaned shining bascinet, and the first rank of Sir Pertolepe's riders, striking spurs, thundered upon them down the hill; came thereafter the shock of meeting ranks, with shouts and cries that grew to a muffled roar.
10064-8{_}2174{_}Up rose the dust, an eddying cloud wherein steel flickered and dim forms strove, horse to horse and man to man, while Sir Pertolepe, sitting his great white charger, nursed his big chin and, smiling, waited his chance.
10064-8{_}2175{_}Presently, from the eddying cloud staggered the broken remnant of Sir Gilles' van-ward, whereon, laughing fierce and loud, Sir Pertolepe rose in his stirrups with Beltane's long sword lifted high, his trumpets brayed the charge, and down the hill thundered Sir Pertolepe and all his array; and the road near by was deserted, save for the prisoners and the four archers who stood together, their faces set down-hill, where the dust rose denser and denser, and the roar of the conflict fierce and loud.
10064-8{_}2176{_}But now, above the din and tumult of the fight below, shrill and high rose the notes of a horn winded from the woods in the east, that was answered--like an echo, out of the woods in the west; and, down the banks to right and left, behold Sir Pertolepe's archers came leaping and tumbling, pursued by a hissing arrow shower.
10064-8{_}2177{_}Whereat up sprang Giles, despite his bonds, shouting amain:  "O, Walkyn o' the Long Legs--a rescue!
10064-8{_}2178{_}To us!
10064-8{_}2179{_}Arise, I will arise!"
10064-8{_}2180{_}Now while he shouted thus, came one of the four archers, and Giles was smitten to his knees; but, as the archer whirled up his quarter-staff to strike again, an arrow took him full in the throat, and pitching upon his face, he lay awhile, coughing, in the dust.
10064-8{_}2181{_}Now as his comrades yet stared upon this man so suddenly dead, down from the bank above leapt one who bore a glittering axe, with divers wild and ragged fellows at his heels; came a sound of shouting and blows hard smitten, a rush of feet and, thereafter, silence, save for the din of battle afar.
10064-8{_}2182{_}But, upon the silence, loud and sudden rose a high-pitched quavering laugh, and Giles spake, his voice yet shrill and unsteady.
10064-8{_}2183{_}"'Twas Walkyn--ha, Saint Giles bless Walkyn's long legs!
10064-8{_}2184{_}'Twas Walkyn I saw--Walkyn hath brought down the outlaws--the woods be full of them.
10064-8{_}2185{_}Oho!
10064-8{_}2186{_}Sir Pertolepe's slow fire shall not roast me yet awhile, nor his dogs mumble the carcase, my Rogerkin!"
10064-8{_}2187{_}"Aye," quoth Roger feebly, "but what of my lord, see how still he lieth!"
10064-8{_}2188{_}"Forsooth," exclaimed the archer, writhing in his bonds to stare upon Beltane, "forsooth, Roger, he took a dour ding upon his yellow pate, look ye; but for his mail-coif he were a dead man this hour--"  "He lieth very still," groaned Roger.
10064-8{_}2189{_}"Yet is he a mighty man and strong, my Rogerkin-never despond, man, for I tell thee--ha!--heard ye that outcry?
10064-8{_}2190{_}The outlaws be at work at last, they have Sir Pertolepe out-flanked d'ye see--now might ye behold what well-sped shafts can do upon a close array--pretty work-sweet work!
10064-8{_}2191{_}Would I knew where Walkyn lay!"
10064-8{_}2192{_}"Here, comrade!"
10064-8{_}2193{_}said a voice from the shade of the great tree.
10064-8{_}2194{_}"How--what do ye there?"
10064-8{_}2195{_}cried the archer.
10064-8{_}2196{_}"Wait for Red Pertolepe."
10064-8{_}2197{_}"Why then, sweet Walkyn, good Walkyn--come loose us of our bonds that we may wait with thee--"  "Nay," growled Walkyn, "ye are the bait.
10064-8{_}2198{_}When the outlaws have slain enough of them, Pertolepe's men must flee this way: so will Red Pertolepe stay to take up his prisoners, and so shall I slay him in that moment with this mine axe.
10064-8{_}2199{_}Ha!--said I not so?
10064-8{_}2200{_}Hark I they break already!
10064-8{_}2201{_}Peace now--wait and watch."
10064-8{_}2202{_}So saying, Walkyn crouched behind the tree, axe poised, what time the dust and roar of battle rolled toward them up the hill.
10064-8{_}2203{_}And presently, from out the rolling cloud, riderless horses burst and thundered past, and after them--a staggering rout, mounted and afoot, spurring and trampling each other 'neath the merciless arrow-shower that smote them from the banks above.
10064-8{_}2204{_}Horse and foot they thundered by until at last, amid a ring of cowering men-at-arms, Sir Pertolepe galloped, his white horse bespattered with blood and foam, his battered helm a-swing upon its thongs; grim-lipped and pale he rode, while his eyes, aflame 'neath scowling brows, swept the road this way and that until, espying Beltane 'neath the tree, he swerved aside in his career and strove to check his followers' headlong flight.
10064-8{_}2205{_}"Stay," cried he striking right and left.
10064-8{_}2206{_}"Halt, dogs, and take up the prisoners.
10064-8{_}2207{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}2208{_}will ye defy me-rogues, caitiffs!
10064-8{_}2209{_}Fulk!
10064-8{_}2210{_}Raoul!
10064-8{_}2211{_}Denis!
10064-8{_}2212{_}Ho, there!"
10064-8{_}2213{_}But no man might stay that maddened rush, wherefore, swearing a great oath, Sir Pertolepe spurred upon Beltane with Beltane's sword lifted for the blow.
10064-8{_}2214{_}But, from the shade of the tree a mighty form uprose, and Sir Pertolepe was aware of a hoarse, glad cry, saw the whirling flash of a broad axe and wrenched hard at his bridle; round staggered the white horse, down came the heavy axe, and the great horse, death-smitten, reared up and up, back and back, and crashing over, was lost 'neath the dust of swift-trampling hoofs.
10064-8{_}2215{_}Now presently, Beltane was aware that his bonds cramped him no longer, found Roger's arm about him, and at his parched lips Roger's steel head-piece brimming with cool, sweet water; and gulping thirstily, soon felt the numbness lifted from his brain and the mist from his eyes; in so much that he sat up, and gazing about, beheld himself alone with Roger.
10064-8{_}2216{_}Quoth he, looking down at his swollen wrists:  "Do we go free then, Roger?"
10064-8{_}2217{_}"Aye, master--though ye had a woundy knock upon the head."
10064-8{_}2218{_}"And what of Giles?"
10064-8{_}2219{_}"He is away to get him arrows to fill his quiver, and to fill his purse with what he may, for the dead lie thick in the road yonder, and there is much plunder."
10064-8{_}2220{_}"And Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}2221{_}"Walkyn, master, having slain Sir Pertolepe's horse yonder, followeth Pertolepe, minded straight to slay him also."
10064-8{_}2222{_}"Yet dost thou remain, Roger."
10064-8{_}2223{_}"Aye, lord; and here is that which thou wilt need again, methinks; I found it hard by Sir Pertolepe's dead horse."
10064-8{_}2224{_}So saying, Roger put Beltane's great sword into his hand.
10064-8{_}2225{_}Then Beltane took hold upon the sword, and rising to his feet stretched wide his arms, and felt his strength renewed within him.
10064-8{_}2226{_}Therefore he sheathed the sword and set his hand on Roger's broad, mail-clad shoulder.
10064-8{_}2227{_}"Roger," said he, "thou faithful Roger, God hath delivered us from shameful death, wherefore, I hold, He hath yet need of these our bodies."
10064-8{_}2228{_}"As how, master?"
10064-8{_}2229{_}"As I went, nigh swooning in my bonds, methought I heard tell that Sir Gilles of Brandonmere had captive certain women; so now must we deliver them, thou and I, an it may be so."
10064-8{_}2230{_}"Lord," quoth Roger, "Sir Gilles marcheth with the remnant of his company, and we are but two.
10064-8{_}2231{_}Let us therefore get with us divers of these outlaws."
10064-8{_}2232{_}"I have heard tell that to be a woman and captive to Sir Gilles or Pertolepe the Red is to be brought to swift and dire shame.
10064-8{_}2233{_}So now let us deliver these women from shame, thou and I. Wilt go with me, Roger?"
10064-8{_}2234{_}"Aye lord, that will I: yet first pray thee aid me to bind a clout upon my arm, for my wound irketh me somewhat."
10064-8{_}2235{_}And in a while, when Beltane had laved and bound up Roger's wound, they went on down the darkening road together.
10064-8{_}2236{_}CHAPTER XVIII  HOW BELTANE MET SIR GILLES OF BRANDONMERE   It was a night of wind with a flying cloud-wrack overhead whence peeped the pallid moon betimes; a night of gloom and mystery.
10064-8{_}2237{_}The woods about them were full of sounds and stealthy rustlings as they strode along the forest road, and so came to that dark defile where the fight had raged.
10064-8{_}2238{_}Of what they saw and heard within that place of slaughter it bodeth not to tell, nor of those figures, wild and fierce, that crouched to strip the jumbled slain, or snarled and quarrelled over the work.
10064-8{_}2239{_}"Here is good plunder of weapons and armour," quoth Roger, "'tis seldom the outlaws come by such.
10064-8{_}2240{_}Hark to that cry!
10064-8{_}2241{_}There died some wounded wight under his plunderer's knife!"
10064-8{_}2242{_}"God rest his soul, Amen!"
10064-8{_}2243{_}sighed Beltane.
10064-8{_}2244{_}"Come, let us hence!"
10064-8{_}2245{_}And forthwith he began to run.
10064-8{_}2246{_}So in a little while they passed through that place of horror unseen, and so came out again upon the forest road.
10064-8{_}2247{_}Ever and anon the moon sent down a feeble ray 'neath which the road lay a-glimmer 'twixt the gloom of the woods, whence came groans and wailings with every wind-gust, whereat Roger quailed, and fumbling at his sword-hilt, pressed closer upon Beltane.
10064-8{_}2248{_}"Master," he whispered, "'tis an evil night--methinks the souls of the dead be abroad--hark to those sounds!
10064-8{_}2249{_}Master, I like it not!--"  "'Tis but the wind, Roger."
10064-8{_}2250{_}"'Tis like the cries of women wailing o'er their dead, I have heard such sounds ere now; I would my belt bore fewer notches, master!"
10064-8{_}2251{_}"They shall be fewer ere dawn, Roger, I pray God!"
10064-8{_}2252{_}"Master--an I am slain this night, think ye I must burn in hell-fire-- remembering these same notches?"
10064-8{_}2253{_}"Nay, for surely God is a very merciful God, Roger.
10064-8{_}2254{_}Hark!"
10064-8{_}2255{_}quoth Beltane, and stopped of a sudden, and thus above the wailing of the wind they presently heard a feeble groaning hard by, and following the sound, beheld a blotch upon the glimmering road.
10064-8{_}2256{_}Now as they drew near the moon peeped out, and showed a man huddled 'neath a bush beside the way, whose face gleamed pale amid the shadows.
10064-8{_}2257{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}2258{_}cried Roger, stooping, "thou'rt of Brandonmere?"
10064-8{_}2259{_}"Aye--give me water--I was squire to Sir Gilles--God's love--give me-- water!"
10064-8{_}2260{_}Then Beltane knelt, and saw this was but a youth, and bidding Roger bring water from a brook near by, took the heavy head upon his knee.
10064-8{_}2261{_}"Messire," said he, "I have heard that Sir Gilles beareth women captive."
10064-8{_}2262{_}"There is--but one, and she--a nun.
10064-8{_}2263{_}But nuns are--holy women--so I withstood my lord in his--desire.
10064-8{_}2264{_}And my lord--stabbed me--so must I die--of a nun, see you!--Ah--give me--water!"
10064-8{_}2265{_}"Where doth he ride this night, messire?"
10064-8{_}2266{_}"His men--few--very weary--Sir Pertolepe's--men-at-arms--caught us i' the sunken road--Sir Gilles--to Thornaby Mill--beside the ford--O God --water!"
10064-8{_}2267{_}"'Tis here!"
10064-8{_}2268{_}quoth Roger, kneeling beside him; then Beltane set the water to the squire's eager lips, but, striving to drink he choked, and choking, fell back--dead.
10064-8{_}2269{_}So in a while they arose from their knees and went their way, while the dead youth lay with wide eyes that seemed to out-stare the pallid moon.
10064-8{_}2270{_}Now as they went on very silently together, of a sudden Black Roger caught Beltane by the arm and pointed into the gloom, where, far before them, small lights winked redly through the murk.
10064-8{_}2271{_}"Yon should be Sir Gilles' watch-fires!"
10064-8{_}2272{_}he whispered.
10064-8{_}2273{_}"Aye," nodded Beltane, "so I think."
10064-8{_}2274{_}"Master--what would ye now?"
10064-8{_}2275{_}"Pray, Roger--I pray God Sir Gilles' men be few, and that they be sound sleepers.
10064-8{_}2276{_}Howbeit we will go right warily none the less."
10064-8{_}2277{_}So saying, Beltane turned aside from the road and led on through underbrush and thicket, through a gloom of leaves where a boisterous wind rioted; where great branches, dim seen, swayed groaning in every fierce gust, and all was piping stir and tumult.
10064-8{_}2278{_}Twigs whipped them viciously, thorns dragged at them, while the wind went by them, moaning, in the dark.
10064-8{_}2279{_}But, ever and anon as they stumbled forward, guiding themselves by instinct, the moon sent forth a pale beam from the whirling cloud-wrack --a phantom light that stole upon them, sudden and ghost-like, and, like a ghost, was gone again; what time Black Roger, following hard on Beltane's heel, crossed himself and muttered fragments of forgotten prayers.
10064-8{_}2280{_}Thus at last they came to the river, that flowed before them vague in the half-light, whose sullen waters gurgled evilly among the willows that drooped upon the marge.
10064-8{_}2281{_}"Master," said Roger, wiping sweat from his face, "there's evil hereabouts--I've had a warning--a dead man touched me as we came through the brush yonder."
10064-8{_}2282{_}"Nay Roger, 'twas but some branch--"  "Lord, when knew ye a branch with--fingers--slimy and cold--upon my cheek here.
10064-8{_}2283{_}'Twas a warning, master--he dead hand!
10064-8{_}2284{_}One of us twain goeth to his death this night!"
10064-8{_}2285{_}"Let not thine heart fail therefor, good Roger: man, being dead, liveth forever--"  "Nay, but--the dead hand, master--on my cheek, here--Ah!--" Crying thus, Black Roger sprang and caught Beltane's arm, gripping it fast, for on the air, borne upon the wind, yet louder than the wind, a shrill sound rang and echoed, the which, passing, seemed to have stricken the night to silence.
10064-8{_}2286{_}Then Beltane brake from Roger's clasp, and ran on beside the river, until, beyond the sullen waters the watch-fires flared before him, in whose red light the mill loomed up rugged and grim, its massy walls scarred and cracked, its great wheel fallen to ruin.
10064-8{_}2287{_}Now above the wheel was a gap in the masonry, an opening roughly square that had been a window, mayhap, whence shone a warm, mellow light.
10064-8{_}2288{_}"Master," panted Roger, "a God's name--what was it?"
10064-8{_}2289{_}"A woman screamed!"
10064-8{_}2290{_}quoth Beltane, staring upon the lighted window.
10064-8{_}2291{_}As he spake a man laughed sleepily beside the nearest watch-fire, scarce a bow-shot away.
10064-8{_}2292{_}"Look'ee, master," whispered Roger, "we may not cross by the ford because of the watch-fires--'tis a fair light to shoot by, and the river is very deep hereabouts."
10064-8{_}2293{_}"Yet must we swim it, Roger."
10064-8{_}2294{_}"Lord, the water is in flood, and our armour heavy!"
10064-8{_}2295{_}"Then must we leave our armour behind," quoth Beltane, and throwing back his hood of mail, he began to unbuckle his broad belt, but of a sudden, stayed to point with outstretched finger.
10064-8{_}2296{_}Then, looking whither he pointed, Roger saw a tree whose hole leaned far out across the stream, so that one far-flung branch well nigh scraped the broken roof of the mill.
10064-8{_}2297{_}"Yon lieth our way, Roger--come!"
10064-8{_}2298{_}said he.
10064-8{_}2299{_}Being come to that side of the tree afar from the watch-fires, Beltane swung himself lightly and began to climb, but hearing a groan, paused.
10064-8{_}2300{_}"Roger," he whispered, "what ails thee, Roger?"
10064-8{_}2301{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}2302{_}groaned Roger, "'tis my wound irketh me; O master, I cannot follow thee this way!"
10064-8{_}2303{_}"Nay, let me aid thee," whispered Beltane, reaching down to him.
10064-8{_}2304{_}But, despite Beltane's strong hand, desperately though he tried, Black Roger fell back, groaning.
10064-8{_}2305{_}"Master," he pleaded, "O master, adventure not alone lest ill befall thee."
10064-8{_}2306{_}"Aye, but I must, Roger."
10064-8{_}2307{_}Then Roger leaned his head upon his sound arm, and wept full bitterly.
10064-8{_}2308{_}"O master,--O sweet lord," quoth he, "bethink thee now of the warning-- the dead hand--"  "Yet must I go, my Roger."
10064-8{_}2309{_}"Then--an they kill thee, lord, so shall they kill me also; thy man am I, to live or die with thee--"  "Nay, Roger, sworn art thou to redeem Pentavalon: so now, in her name do I charge thee, haste to Sir Jocelyn, an he yet live--seek Giles and Walkyn and whoso else ye may, and bring them hither at speed.
10064-8{_}2310{_}If ye find me not here, then hie ye all to Thrasfordham, for by to-morrow Sir Pertolepe and Gui of Allerdale will have raised the country against us.
10064-8{_}2311{_}Go now, do even as I command, and may God keep thee, my faithful Roger."
10064-8{_}2312{_}Then Beltane began to climb, but being come where the great branch forked, looked down to see Roger's upturned face, pale amid the gloom below.
10064-8{_}2313{_}"The holy angels have thee in their keeping, lord and master!"
10064-8{_}2314{_}he sighed, and so turned with head a-droop and was gone.
10064-8{_}2315{_}And now Beltane began to clamber out across the swirl of dark waters, while the tough bough swung and swayed beneath him in every gust of wind, wherefore his going was difficult and slow, and he took heed only to his hands and feet.
10064-8{_}2316{_}But, all at once, he heard a bitter, broken cry, and glancing up, it chanced that from his lofty perch he could look within the lighted window, and thus beheld a nun, whose slender, black-robed body writhed and twisted in the clasp of two leathern-clad arms; vicious arms, that bent her back and back across the rough table, until into Beltane's vision came the leathern-clad form of him that held her: a black-haired, shapely man, whose glowing eyes and eager mouth stooped ever nearer above the nun's white loveliness.
10064-8{_}2317{_}And thus it was that my Beltane first looked upon Sir Gilles of Brandonmere.
10064-8{_}2318{_}He had laid sword and armour by, but as the nun yet struggled in his arms, her white hand came upon and drew the dagger at his girdle, yet, ere she could strike, Sir Gilles had seen and leapt back out of reach.
10064-8{_}2319{_}Then Beltane clambered on at speed, and with every yard their voices grew more loud--hers proud and disdainful, his low and soft, pierced, now and then, by an evil, lazy laugh.
10064-8{_}2320{_}Now ever as Beltane went, the branch swayed more dizzily, bending more and more beneath his weight, and ever as he drew nearer, between the wind-gusts came snatches of their talk.
10064-8{_}2321{_}"Be thou nun, or duchess, or strolling light-o'-love, art woman--by Venus!
10064-8{_}2322{_}fair and passing fair!--captive art thou--aye, mine, I tell thee--yield thee--hast struggled long enough to save thy modesty--yield thee now, else will I throw thee to my lusty rogues without--make them sport--"  "O--beast--I fear thee not!
10064-8{_}2323{_}For thy men--how shall they harm me, seeing I shall be dead!"
10064-8{_}2324{_}Down swayed the branch, low and lower, until Beltane's mailed foot, a-swing in mid air, found something beneath--slipped away--found it again, and thereupon, loosing the branch, down he came upon the ruined mill-wheel.
10064-8{_}2325{_}Then, standing upon the wheel, his groping fingers found divers cracks in the worn masonry--moreover the ivy was thick; so, clinging with fingers and toes, up he went, higher and higher until his steel-mittened hands gripped the sill: thus, slowly and cautiously he drew himself up until his golden head rose above the sill and he could peer into the room.
10064-8{_}2326{_}Sir Gilles half stood, half sat upon the table, while the nun faced him, cold and proud and disdainful, the gleaming dagger clutched to her quick-heaving bosom; and Sir Gilles, assured and confident, laughed softly as he leaned so lazily, yet ever he watched that gleaming steel, waiting his chance to spring.
10064-8{_}2327{_}Now as they stood fronting each other thus, the nun stirred beneath his close regard, turned her head, and on the instant Beltane knew that she had seen him; knew by the sudden tremor of her lips, the widening of her dark eyes, wherein he seemed to read wonder, joy, and a passionate entreaty; then, even as he thrilled to meet that look, down swept languorous lid and curling lash, and, sighing, she laid the dagger on the table.
10064-8{_}2328{_}For a moment Sir Gilles stared in blank amaze, then laughed his lazy laugh.
10064-8{_}2329{_}"Ah, proud beauty!
10064-8{_}2330{_}'Tis surrender then?"
10064-8{_}2331{_}said he, and speaking, reached for the dagger; but even as he did so, the nun seized the heavy table and thrust with sudden strength, so that Sir Gilles, taken unawares, staggered back and back--to the window.
10064-8{_}2332{_}Then Beltane reached up into the room and, from behind, caught Sir Gilles by the throat and gripped him with iron fingers, strangling all outcry, and so, drawing himself over the sill and into the room, dragged Sir Gilles to the floor and choked him there until his eyes rolled upward and he lay like one dead.
10064-8{_}2333{_}Then swiftly Beltane took off the belt of Sir Gilles and buckled it tight about the wrists and arms of Sir Gilles, and, rending strips from Sir Gilles' mantle that lay near, therewith fast gagged and bound him.
10064-8{_}2334{_}Now it chanced that as he knelt thus, he espied the dagger where it lay, and taking it up, glanced from it to Sir Gilles lying motionless in his bonds.
10064-8{_}2335{_}But as he hesitated, there came a sudden knocking on the door and a voice spake without:  "My lord!
10064-8{_}2336{_}my lord--'tis I--'tis Lupo.
10064-8{_}2337{_}My lord, our men be few and wearied, as ye know.
10064-8{_}2338{_}Must I set a guard beyond the ford, think you, or will the four watch-fires suffice?"
10064-8{_}2339{_}Now, glancing up, scarce breathing, Beltane beheld the nun who crouched down against the wall, her staring eyes turned towards the door, her cheeks ashen, her lips a-quiver with deadly fear.
10064-8{_}2340{_}Yet, even so, she spake.
10064-8{_}2341{_}But that 'twas she indeed who uttered the words he scarce could credit, so soft and sweetly slumberous was her voice:  "My lord is a-weary and sleepeth.
10064-8{_}2342{_}Hush you, and come again with the dawn."
10064-8{_}2343{_}Now was a moment's breathless silence and thereafter an evil chuckle, and, so chuckling, the man Lupo went down the rickety stair without.
10064-8{_}2344{_}And when his step was died away, Beltane drew a deep breath, and together they arose, and so, speaking no word, they looked upon each other across the prostrate body of Sir Gilles of Brandonmere.
10064-8{_}2345{_}CHAPTER XIX  CONCERNING THE EYES OF A NUN   Eyes long, thick-lashed and darkly blue that looked up awhile into his and anon were hid 'neath languorous-drooping lids; a nose tenderly aquiline; lips, red and full, that parted but to meet again in sweet and luscious curves; a chin white, and round, and dimpled.
10064-8{_}2346{_}This Beltane saw 'twixt hood and wimple, by aid of the torch that flickered against the wall; and she, conscious of his look, stood with white hands demurely crossed upon her rounded bosom, with eyes abased and scarlet lips apart, as one who waits--expectant.
10064-8{_}2347{_}Now hereupon my Beltane felt himself vaguely at loss, and finding he yet held the dagger, set it upon the table and spake, low-voiced.
10064-8{_}2348{_}"Reverend Mother--" he began, and stopped--for at the word her dark lashes lifted and she stared upon him curiously, while slowly her red lips quivered to a smile.
10064-8{_}2349{_}And surely, surely this nun so sweet and saintly in veiling hood and wimple was yet a very woman, young and passing fair; and the eyes of her--how deep and tender and yet how passionate!
10064-8{_}2350{_}Now beholding her eyes, memory stirred within him and he sighed, whereat she sighed also and meekly bowed her head, speaking him with all humility.
10064-8{_}2351{_}"Sweet son, speak on--thy reverend mother heareth."
10064-8{_}2352{_}Now did Beltane, my Innocent, rub his innocent chin and stand mumchance awhile, finding nought to say--then:  "Lady," he stammered, "lady--since I have found thee--let us go while yet we may."
10064-8{_}2353{_}"Messire," says she, with eyes still a-droop, "came you in sooth--in quest of me?"
10064-8{_}2354{_}"Yea, verily.
10064-8{_}2355{_}I heard Sir Gilles had made captive of a nun, so came I to deliver her--an so it might be."
10064-8{_}2356{_}"E'en though she were old, and wrinkled, and toothless, messire?"
10064-8{_}2357{_}"Lady," says my Innocent, staring and rubbing his chin a little harder, "surely all nuns, young and old, be holy women, worthy a man's reverence and humble service.
10064-8{_}2358{_}So would I now bear thee from this unhallowed place--we must be far hence ere dawn--come!"
10064-8{_}2359{_}"Aye, but whither?"
10064-8{_}2360{_}she sighed, "death is all about us, messire--how may we escape it?
10064-8{_}2361{_}And I fear death no whit--now, messire!"
10064-8{_}2362{_}"Aye, but I do so, lady, since I have other and greater works yet to achieve."
10064-8{_}2363{_}"How, messire, is it so small a thing to have saved a nun--even though she be neither old, nor wrinkled, nor toothless?"
10064-8{_}2364{_}And behold, the nun's meek head was high and proud, her humility forgotten quite.
10064-8{_}2365{_}Then she frowned, and 'neath her sombre draperies her foot fell a-tapping; a small foot, dainty and slender in its gaily broidered shoe, so much at variance with her dolorous habit.
10064-8{_}2366{_}But Beltane recked nought of this, for, espying a narrow window in the opposite wall, he came thither and thrusting his head without, looked down upon the sleeping camp.
10064-8{_}2367{_}And thus he saw that Sir Gilles' men were few indeed, scarce three-score all told he counted as they lay huddled about the smouldering watch-fires, deep-slumbering as only men greatly wearied might.
10064-8{_}2368{_}Even the sentinels nodded at their posts, and all was still save for the rush of a sudden wind-gust, or the snort and trampling of the horses.
10064-8{_}2369{_}And leaning thus, Beltane marked well where the sentinels lolled upon their pikes, or marched drowsily to and fro betwixt the watch-fires, and long he gazed where the horses were tethered, two swaying, trampling lines dim-seen amid the further shadows.
10064-8{_}2370{_}Now being busied measuring with his eye the distances 'twixt sentinel and sentinel, and noting where the shadows lay darkest, he was suddenly aware of the nun close beside him, of the feel of her, soft and warm against him, and starting at the contact, turned to find her hand, small and white, upon his mailed arm.
10064-8{_}2371{_}"Sweet son," said she soft-voiced, from the shadow of her sombre hood, "thy reverend mother now would chide thee, for that having but short while to live, thou dost stand thus mumchance, staring upon vacancy-- for, with the dawn, we die."
10064-8{_}2372{_}Quoth Beltane, deeply conscious of the slender hand:  "To die, nay--nay--thou'rt too young and fair to die--"  Sighed she, with rueful smile:  "Thou too art neither old nor cold, nor bent with years, fair son.
10064-8{_}2373{_}Come then, till death let us speak together and comfort each other.
10064-8{_}2374{_}Lay by thy melancholy as I now lay by this hood and wimple, for the night is hot and close, methinks."
10064-8{_}2375{_}"Nay, lady, indeed 'tis cool, for there is much wind abroad," says Beltane, my Innocent.
10064-8{_}2376{_}"Moreover, while standing here, methinks I have seen a way whereby we may win free--"  Now hereupon she turned and looked on him, quick-breathing and with eyes brim-full of fear.
10064-8{_}2377{_}"Messire!"
10064-8{_}2378{_}she panted, "O messire, bethink thee.
10064-8{_}2379{_}For death am I prepared--to live each moment fully till the dawn, then when they came to drag me down to--to shame, then should thy dagger free me quite-- such death I'd smile to meet.
10064-8{_}2380{_}But ah!
10064-8{_}2381{_}should we strive to flee, and thou in the attempt be slain--and I alive--the sport of that vile rabblement below--O, Christ,--not that!"
10064-8{_}2382{_}and cowering, she hid her face.
10064-8{_}2383{_}"Noble lady," said Beltane, looking on her gentle-eyed, "indeed I too had thought on that!"
10064-8{_}2384{_}and, coming to the table, he took thence the dagger of Sir Gilles and would have put it in her hand, but lo!
10064-8{_}2385{_}she shrank away.
10064-8{_}2386{_}"Not that, messire, not that," she sighed, "thy dagger let it be, since true knight art thou and honourable, I pray you give me thine.
10064-8{_}2387{_}It is thy reverend mother asks," and smiling pale and wan, she reached out a white, imperious hand.
10064-8{_}2388{_}So Beltane drew his dagger and gave it to her keeping; then, having set the other in his girdle, he crossed to the door and stood awhile to hearken.
10064-8{_}2389{_}"Lady," said he, "there is no way for us but this stair, and meseemeth 'tis a dangerous way, yet must we tread it together.
10064-8{_}2390{_}Reach me now thy hand and set it here in my girdle, and, whatsoe'er befall, loose not thy hold."
10064-8{_}2391{_}So saying, Beltane drew his sword and set wide the door.
10064-8{_}2392{_}"Look to thy feet," he whispered, "and tread soft!"
10064-8{_}2393{_}Then, with her trailing habit caught up in her left hand and with her right upon his belt, the nun followed Beltane out upon the narrow stair.
10064-8{_}2394{_}Step by step they stole downwards into the dark, pausing with breath in check each time the timbers creaked, and hearkening with straining ears.
10064-8{_}2395{_}Down they went amid the gloom until they spied an open door below, beyond which a dim light shone, and whence rose the snoring of wearied sleepers.
10064-8{_}2396{_}Ever and anon a wind-gust smote the ancient mill and a broken shutter rattled near by, what time they crept a pace down the creaking stair until at last they stood upon the threshold of a square chamber upon whose broken hearth a waning fire burned, by whose uncertain light they espied divers vague forms that stirred now and then and groaned in their sleep as they sprawled upon the floor: and Beltane counted three who lay 'twixt him and the open doorway, for door was there none.
10064-8{_}2397{_}Awhile stood Beltane, viewing the sleepers 'neath frowning brows, then, sheathing his sword, he turned and reached out his arms to the nun in the darkness and, in the dark, she gave herself, warm and yielding, into his embrace, her arms clung soft about him, and he felt her breath upon his cheek, as clasping his left arm about her, he lifted her high against his breast.
10064-8{_}2398{_}And now, even as she trembled against him, so trembled Beltane also yet knew not why; therefore of a sudden he turned and stepped into the chamber.
10064-8{_}2399{_}A man started up beside the hearth, muttering evilly; and Beltane, standing rigid, gripped his dagger to smite, but even then the muttering ceased, and falling back, the man rolled over and fell a-snoring again.
10064-8{_}2400{_}So, lightly, swiftly, Beltane strode over the sprawling sleepers--out through the open doorway--out into the sweet, cool night beyond--out into the merry riot of the wind.
10064-8{_}2401{_}Swift and sure of foot he sped, going ever where the shadows lay deepest, skirting beyond reach of the paling watch-fires, until he was come nigh where the horses stamped and snorted.
10064-8{_}2402{_}Here he set the nun upon her feet, and bidding her stir not, crept towards the horses, quick-eyed and watchful.
10064-8{_}2403{_}And thus he presently espied a man who leaned him upon a long pike, his face set toward the nearest watch-fire: and the man's eyes were closed, and he snored gently.
10064-8{_}2404{_}Then Beltane shifted his dagger to his left hand, and being come within reach, drew back his mailed fist and smote the sleeper betwixt his closed eyes, and catching him as he fell, laid him gently on the grass.
10064-8{_}2405{_}Now swift and silent came Beltane to where the horses champed, and having made choice of a certain powerful beast, slipped off his chain mittens and rolled back sleeve of mail and, low-stooping in the shadow, sought and found the ropes whereto the halters were made fast, and straightway cut them in sunder.
10064-8{_}2406{_}Then, having looked to girth and bridle, he vaulted to the saddle, and drawing sword, shouted his battle-cry fierce and loud: "Arise!
10064-8{_}2407{_}Arise!"
10064-8{_}2408{_}and, so shouting, smote the frighted horses to right and left with the flat of the long blade, so that they reared up whinnying, and set off a-galloping in all directions, filling the air with the thunder of their rushing hoofs.
10064-8{_}2409{_}And now came shouts and cries with a prodigious confusion and running to and fro about the dying watch-fires.
10064-8{_}2410{_}Trumpets blared shrill, hoarse voices roared commands that passed unheeded in the growing din and tumult that swelled to a wild clamour of frenzied shouting:  "Fly!
10064-8{_}2411{_}fly!
10064-8{_}2412{_}Pertolepe is upon us!
10064-8{_}2413{_}'tis the Red Pertolepe!"
10064-8{_}2414{_}But Beltane, riding warily amid the gloom, came to that place where he had left the nun, yet found her not, and immediately was seized of a great dread.
10064-8{_}2415{_}But as he stared wildly about him, he presently heard a muffled cry, and spurring thitherwards, beheld two dim figures that swayed to and fro in a fierce grapple.
10064-8{_}2416{_}Riding close, Beltane saw the glint of mail, raised his sword for the blow, felt a shock--a searing smart, and knew himself wounded; but now she was at his stirrup, and stooping, he swung her up to the withers of his horse, and wheeling short about, spurred to a gallop; yet, as he rode, above the rush of wind and thud of hoofs, he heard a cry, hoarse and dolorous.
10064-8{_}2417{_}On galloped Beltane all unheeding, until he came 'neath the leafy arches of the friendly woods, within whose gloom needs must he ride at a hand's pace.
10064-8{_}2418{_}Thus, as they went, they could hear the uproar behind--a confused din that waxed and waned upon the wind.
10064-8{_}2419{_}But Beltane, riding slow and cautious within the green, heeded this not at all, nor the throb of his wounded arm, nor aught under heaven save the pressure of this slender body that lay so still, so warm and soft within his arm; and as he went, he began to wish for the moon that he might see her face.
10064-8{_}2420{_}Blue eyes, long and heavy-lashed!
10064-8{_}2421{_}Surely blue eyes were fairest in a woman?
10064-8{_}2422{_}And then the voice of her, liquid and soft like the call of merle or mavis.
10064-8{_}2423{_}And she was a nun!
10064-8{_}2424{_}How white and slim her hands, yet strong and resolute, as when she grasped the dagger 'gainst Sir Gilles; aye--resolute hands, like the spirit within her soft and shapely body.
10064-8{_}2425{_}And then again--her lips; red and full, up-curving to sweet, slow smile, yet withal tinged with subtle mockery.
10064-8{_}2426{_}With such eyes and such lips she might--aye, but she was a nun--a nun, forsooth!
10064-8{_}2427{_}"Messire!"
10064-8{_}2428{_}Beltane started from his reverie.
10064-8{_}2429{_}"Art cold, messire?"
10064-8{_}2430{_}"Cold!"
10064-8{_}2431{_}stammered Beltane, "cold?
10064-8{_}2432{_}Indeed no, lady."
10064-8{_}2433{_}"Yet dost thou tremble!"
10064-8{_}2434{_}"Nathless, I am not cold, lady."
10064-8{_}2435{_}"Then wherefore tremble?"
10064-8{_}2436{_}"Nay, I--I know not.
10064-8{_}2437{_}In sooth, do I so, lady?"
10064-8{_}2438{_}"Verily, sir, and therewith sigh, frequent and O, most dolorous to hear!"
10064-8{_}2439{_}Now at this, my Beltane finding naught to say, straightway sighed again; and thus they rode awhile, speaking nothing.
10064-8{_}2440{_}"Think you we are safe, messire?"
10064-8{_}2441{_}she questioned him at last.
10064-8{_}2442{_}"Tis so I pray, lady."
10064-8{_}2443{_}"Thou hast done right valiantly to-night on my behalf," says she.
10064-8{_}2444{_}"How came you in at the window?"
10064-8{_}2445{_}"By means of a tree, lady."
10064-8{_}2446{_}"Art very strong, messire, and valiant beyond thought.
10064-8{_}2447{_}Thou hast this night, with thy strong hand, lifted me up from shameful death: so, by right, should my life be thine henceforth."
10064-8{_}2448{_}Herewith she sighed, leaning closer upon his breast, and Beltane's desire to see her face grew amain.
10064-8{_}2449{_}"Messire," said she, "methinks art cold indeed, or is it that I weary thee?"
10064-8{_}2450{_}"Nay, thou'rt wondrous easy to bear thus, lady."
10064-8{_}2451{_}"And whither do ye bear me, sir--north or south?
10064-8{_}2452{_}And yet it mattereth nothing," says she, soft-voiced, "since we are safe--together!"
10064-8{_}2453{_}Now hereafter, as Beltane rode, he turned his eyes full oft to heaven-- yearning for the moon.
10064-8{_}2454{_}"What woods be these, messire?"
10064-8{_}2455{_}she questioned.
10064-8{_}2456{_}"'Tis the wilderness that lieth betwixt Pentavalon and Mortain, lady."
10064-8{_}2457{_}"Know ye Mortain, sir?"
10064-8{_}2458{_}"Yea, verily," he answered, and sighed full deep.
10064-8{_}2459{_}And as he sighed, lo, in that moment the moon peeped forth of a cloud-rift and he beheld the nun looking up at him with eyes deep and wistful, and, as she gazed, her lips curved in slow and tender smile ere her lashes drooped, and sighing, she hid her face against him in the folds of her mantle, while Beltane must needs bethink him of other eyes so very like, and yet so false, and straightway--sighed.
10064-8{_}2460{_}"Messire," she murmured, "pray now, wherefore do ye sigh so oft?"
10064-8{_}2461{_}"For that thine eyes do waken memory, lady."
10064-8{_}2462{_}"Of a woman?"
10064-8{_}2463{_}"Aye--of a woman."
10064-8{_}2464{_}"And thou dost--love her, messire?"
10064-8{_}2465{_}"Unto my dole, lady."
10064-8{_}2466{_}"Ah, can it be she doth not love thee, messire?"
10064-8{_}2467{_}"Indeed, 'tis most certain!"
10064-8{_}2468{_}"Hath she then told thee so--of herself?"
10064-8{_}2469{_}"Nay," sighed Beltane, "not in so many words, lady, and yet--"  "And yet," quoth the nun, suddenly erect, "thou must needs run away and leave her--poor sweet wretch--to mourn for thee, belike, and grieve-- aye, and scorn thee too for a faint-heart!"
10064-8{_}2470{_}"Nay, lady, verily I--"  "O, indeed me thinks she must contemn thee in her heart, poor, gentle soul--aye, scorn and despise thee woefully for running away; indeed, 'tis beyond all doubt, messire!"
10064-8{_}2471{_}"Lady," quoth Beltane, flushing in the dark, "you know naught of the matter--"  "Why then shalt thou tell me of it, messire--lo, I am listening."
10064-8{_}2472{_}So saying, she settled herself more aptly within his encircling arm.
10064-8{_}2473{_}"First, then," said Beltane, when they had ridden awhile in silence, "she is a duchess, and very proud."
10064-8{_}2474{_}"Yet is she a woman, messire, and thou a man whose arms be very strong!"
10064-8{_}2475{_}"Of what avail strong arms, lady, 'gainst such as she?"
10064-8{_}2476{_}"Why, to carry her withal, messire."
10064-8{_}2477{_}"To--to carry her!"
10064-8{_}2478{_}quoth Beltane in amaze.
10064-8{_}2479{_}"In very truth, messire.
10064-8{_}2480{_}To lift her up and bear her away with thee--"  "Nay--nay, to--bear her away?
10064-8{_}2481{_}O, 'twere thing impossible!"
10064-8{_}2482{_}"Is this duchess so heavy, messire?"
10064-8{_}2483{_}sighed the nun, "is she a burden beyond even thy strength, sir knight?"
10064-8{_}2484{_}"Lady, she is the proud Helen, Duchess of Mortain!"
10064-8{_}2485{_}quoth Beltane, frowning at the encompassing shadows.
10064-8{_}2486{_}Now was the nun hushed awhile, and when at last she spake her voice was low and wondrous gentle.
10064-8{_}2487{_}"And is it indeed the wilful Helen that ye love, messire?"
10064-8{_}2488{_}"Even she, unto my sorrow."
10064-8{_}2489{_}"Thy sorrow?
10064-8{_}2490{_}Why then, messire--forget her."
10064-8{_}2491{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}2492{_}sighed Beltane, "would I might indeed, yet needs must I love her ever."
10064-8{_}2493{_}"Alack, and is it so forsooth," quoth the nun, sighing likewise.
10064-8{_}2494{_}"Ah me, my poor, fond son, now doth thy reverend mother pity thee indeed, for thou'rt in direful case to be her lover, methinks."
10064-8{_}2495{_}Now did my Beltane frown the blacker by reason of bitter memory and the pain of his wound.
10064-8{_}2496{_}"Her lover, aye!"
10064-8{_}2497{_}quoth he, bitterly, "and she hath a many lovers--"  "Lovers!"
10064-8{_}2498{_}sighed the nun, "that hath she, the sad, sweet soul!
10064-8{_}2499{_}Lovers!
10064-8{_}2500{_}--O forsooth, she is sick of a very surfeit of lovers,--so hath she fled from them all!"
10064-8{_}2501{_}"Fled from them?"
10064-8{_}2502{_}cried Beltane, his wound forgot, "fled from them-- from Mortain?
10064-8{_}2503{_}Nay, how mean you--how--fled?"
10064-8{_}2504{_}"She hath walked, see you, run--ridden--is riding--away from Mortain, from her lords, her counsellors, her varlets, her lovers and what not-- in a word, messire, she is--gone!"
10064-8{_}2505{_}"Gone!"
10064-8{_}2506{_}quoth Beltane, breathless and aghast, "gone--aye--but whither?"
10064-8{_}2507{_}"What matter for that so long as her grave counsellors be sufficiently vexed, and her lovers left a-sighing?
10064-8{_}2508{_}O me, her counsellors!
10064-8{_}2509{_}Bald-pates, see you, and grey-beards, who for their own ends would have her wed Duke Ivo--meek, unfortunate maid!"
10064-8{_}2510{_}"Know you then the Duchess, lady?"
10064-8{_}2511{_}"Aye, forsooth, and my heart doth grieve for her, poor, sweet wretch, for O, 'tis a sad thing to be a duchess with a multitude of suitors a-wooing in season and out, vaunting graces she hath not, and blind to the virtues she doth possess.
10064-8{_}2512{_}Ah, messire, I give thee joy that, whatsoever ills may be thine, thou can ne'er be--a duchess!"
10064-8{_}2513{_}"And think you she will not wed with Ivo, lady--think you so in truth?"
10064-8{_}2514{_}"Never, while she is Helen."
10064-8{_}2515{_}"And--loveth--none of her lovers?"
10064-8{_}2516{_}"Why--indeed, messire--I think she doth--"  "Art sure?
10064-8{_}2517{_}How know you this?"
10064-8{_}2518{_}"I was her bedfellow betimes, and oft within the night have heard her speak a name unto her pillow, as love-sick maids will."
10064-8{_}2519{_}Now once again was Beltane aware of the throb and sting of his wounded arm, yet 'twas not because of this he sighed so deep and oft.
10064-8{_}2520{_}"Spake she this name--often?"
10064-8{_}2521{_}he questioned.
10064-8{_}2522{_}"Very oft, messire.
10064-8{_}2523{_}Aye me, how chill the wind blows!"
10064-8{_}2524{_}"Some lord's name, belike?"
10064-8{_}2525{_}"Nay, 'twas no lord's name, messire.
10064-8{_}2526{_}'Tis very dark amid these trees!"
10064-8{_}2527{_}"Some knight, mayhap--or lowly squire?"
10064-8{_}2528{_}"Neither, messire.
10064-8{_}2529{_}Heigho!
10064-8{_}2530{_}methinks I now could sleep awhile."
10064-8{_}2531{_}So she sighed deep yet happily, and nestled closer within his shielding arm.
10064-8{_}2532{_}But Beltane, my Innocent, rode stiff in the saddle, staring sad-eyed into the gloom, nor felt, nor heeded the yielding tenderness of the shapely young body he held, but plodded on through the dark, frowning blacker than the night.
10064-8{_}2533{_}Now as he rode thus, little by little the pain of his wound grew less, a drowsiness crept upon him, and therewith, a growing faintness.
10064-8{_}2534{_}Little by little his head drooped low and lower, and once the arm about the nun slipped its hold, whereat she sighed and stirred sleepily upon his breast.
10064-8{_}2535{_}But on he rode, striving grimly against the growing faintness, his feet thrust far within the stirrups, his mailed hand tight clenched upon the reins.
10064-8{_}2536{_}So, as dawn broke, he heard the pleasant sound of running water near by, and as the light grew, saw they were come to a grassy glade where ran a small brook--a goodly place, well-hidden and remote.
10064-8{_}2537{_}So turned he thitherward, and lifting up heavy eyes, beheld the stars paling to the dawn, for the clouds were all passed away and the wind was gone long since.
10064-8{_}2538{_}And, in a while, being come within the boskage of this green dell, feebly and as one a-dream, he checked the great horse that snuffed eagerly toward the murmuring brook, and as one a-dream saw that she who had slumbered on his breast was awake--fresh and sweet as the dawn.
10064-8{_}2539{_}"Lady," he stammered, "I--I fear--I can ride--no farther!"
10064-8{_}2540{_}And now, as one a-dream, he beheld her start and look at him with eyes wide and darkly blue--within whose depths was that which stirred within him a memory of other days--in so much he would have spoken, yet found the words unready and hard to come by.
10064-8{_}2541{_}"Lady,--thine eyes, methinks--are not--nun's eyes!"
10064-8{_}2542{_}But now behold of a sudden she cried out, soft and pitiful, for blood was upon him, upon his brow, upon his golden hair.
10064-8{_}2543{_}And still as one a-dream he felt her slip from his failing clasp, felt her arms close about him, aiding him to earth.
10064-8{_}2544{_}"Thou'rt hurt!"
10064-8{_}2545{_}she cried.
10064-8{_}2546{_}"O, thou'rt wounded!
10064-8{_}2547{_}And I never guessed!"
10064-8{_}2548{_}"'Tis but my arm--in sooth--and--"  But she hushed him with soft mother-cries and tender-spoke commands, and aiding him to the brook, laid him thereby to lave his hurt within the cool, sweet water; and, waking with the smart, Beltane sighed and turned to look up at her.
10064-8{_}2549{_}Now did she, meeting his eyes, put up one white hand, setting back sombre hood and snowy wimple, and stooping tenderly above him, behold, in that moment down came the shining glory of her lustrous hair to fall about the glowing beauty of her face, touching his brow like a caress.
10064-8{_}2550{_}Then, at last, memory awoke within him, and lifting himself upon a feeble elbow, he stared upon her glowing loveliness with wide, glad eyes.
10064-8{_}2551{_}"Helen!"
