10064-8{_}2552{_}he sighed, "O--Helen!"
10064-8{_}2553{_}And, so sighing, fell back, and lay there pale and wan within the dawn, but with a smile upon his pallid lips.
10064-8{_}2554{_}CHAPTER XX  HOW BELTANE PLIGHTED HIS TROTH IN THE GREEN   Beltane yawned prodigiously, stretched mightily, and opening sleepy eyes looked about him.
10064-8{_}2555{_}He lay 'neath shady willows within a leafy bower; before him a brook ran leaping to the sunshine and filling the warm, stilly air with its merry chatter and soft, laughing noises, while beyond the rippling water the bank sloped steeply upward to the green silence of the woods.
10064-8{_}2556{_}Now as Beltane lay thus 'twixt sleeping and waking, it seemed to him that in the night he had dreamed a wondrous dream, and fain he would have slept again.
10064-8{_}2557{_}But now from an adjacent thicket a horse whinnied and Beltane, starting at the sound, felt his wound throb with sudden pain, and looking down, beheld his arm most aptly swathed in bandages of fair, soft linen.
10064-8{_}2558{_}Now would he have sat up, but marvelled to find it so great a matter, and propping himself instead upon a weak elbow glanced about him expectantly.
10064-8{_}2559{_}And lo, in that moment, one spake near by in voice rich and soft like the call of merle or mavis:  "Beltane," said the voice, "Beltane the Smith!"
10064-8{_}2560{_}With heart quick-beating, Beltane turned and beheld the Duchess Helen standing beside him, her glorious hair wrought into two long braids wherein flowers were cunningly entwined.
10064-8{_}2561{_}Straightway he would have risen, but she forbade him with a gesture and, coming closer, sank beside him on her knees, and being there blushed and sighed, yet touched him not.
10064-8{_}2562{_}"Thou'rt hurt," said she, "so must we bide here awhile, thou to win thy strength again, and I to--minister unto thee."
10064-8{_}2563{_}Mutely awhile my Beltane gazed upon her shy, sweet loveliness, what time her bosom rose and fell tempestuous, and she bowed her head full low.
10064-8{_}2564{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2565{_}he whispered at last, "O, art thou indeed the Duchess Helen?"
10064-8{_}2566{_}"Not so," she murmured, "Helen was duchess whiles she was in Mortain, but I that speak with thee am a lonely maid--indeed a very lonely maid --who hath sighed for thee, and wept for thee, and for thee hath left her duchy of Mortain, Beltane."
10064-8{_}2567{_}"For me?"
10064-8{_}2568{_}quoth Beltane, leaning near, "was it for me--ah, was it so in very sooth?"
10064-8{_}2569{_}"Beltane," said she, looking not toward him, "last night did'st thou bear a nun within thine arms, and, looking on her with love aflame within thine eyes, did yet vow to her you loved this duchess.
10064-8{_}2570{_}Tell me, who am but a lonely maid, is this so?"
10064-8{_}2571{_}"Thou knowest I love her ever and always," he answered.
10064-8{_}2572{_}"And yet," quoth she, shaking her head and looking up with eyes of witchery, "thou did'st love this nun also?
10064-8{_}2573{_}Though 'tis true thou did'st name her 'reverend mother'!
10064-8{_}2574{_}O, wert very blind, Beltane!
10064-8{_}2575{_}And yet thou did'st love her also, methinks?"
10064-8{_}2576{_}"Needs must I--ever and always!"
10064-8{_}2577{_}he answered.
10064-8{_}2578{_}"Ah, Beltane, but I would have thee love this lonely maid dearest of all henceforth an it may be so, for that she is so very lonely and hath sought thee so long--"  "Sought me?"
10064-8{_}2579{_}he murmured, gazing on her wide-eyed, "nay, how may this be, for with my kisses warm upon thy lips thou did'st bid me farewell long time since at Mortain, within the green."
10064-8{_}2580{_}"And thou," she sighed, "and thou did'st leave me, Beltane!
10064-8{_}2581{_}O, would thou had kissed me once again and held me in thine arms, so might we have known less of sorrow.
10064-8{_}2582{_}Indeed methinks 'twas cruel to leave me so.
10064-8{_}2583{_}Beltane."
10064-8{_}2584{_}"Cruel!"
10064-8{_}2585{_}says my Beltane, and thereafter fell silent from sheer amaze the while she sighed again, and bowed her shapely head and plucked a daisy from the grass to turn it about and about in gentle fingers.
10064-8{_}2586{_}"So, Beltane," quoth she at last, "being young and cruel thou did'st leave the Duchess a lonely maid.
10064-8{_}2587{_}Yet that same night did she, this tender maid, seek out thy lowly dwelling 'mid the green to yield herself joyfully unto thee thenceforth.
10064-8{_}2588{_}But ah, Beltane!
10064-8{_}2589{_}she found the place a ruin and thou wert gone, and O, methinks her heart came nigh to breaking.
10064-8{_}2590{_}Then did she vow that no man might ever have her to his love --save only--thou.
10064-8{_}2591{_}So, an thou love her not, Beltane, needs must she-- die a maid!"
10064-8{_}2592{_}Now Beltane forgot his weakness and rose to his knees and lifted her bowed head until he might look deep within the yearning tenderness of her eyes.
10064-8{_}2593{_}A while she met his look, then blushing, trembling, all in a moment she swayed toward him, hiding her face against him; and, trembling also, Beltane caught her close within his arms and held her to his heart.
10064-8{_}2594{_}"Dost thou love me so, indeed, my lady?
10064-8{_}2595{_}Art thou mine own henceforth, Helen the Beautiful?"
10064-8{_}2596{_}"Ah, love," she murmured, "in all my days ne'er have I loved other man than thou, my Beltane.
10064-8{_}2597{_}So now do I give myself to thee; in life and death, in joy and sorrow, thine will I be, beloved!"
10064-8{_}2598{_}Quoth Beltane:  "As thou art mine, so am I thine, henceforth and forever."
10064-8{_}2599{_}And thus, kneeling together within the wilderness did they plight their troth, low-voiced and tremulous, with arms that clasped and clung and eager lips that parted but to meet again.
10064-8{_}2600{_}"Beltane," she sighed, "ah, Beltane, hold me close!
10064-8{_}2601{_}I've wearied for thee so long--so long; hold me close, beloved.
10064-8{_}2602{_}See now, as thou dost hate the pomp and stir of cities, so, for thy sake have I fled hither to the wilderness, to live with thee amid these solitudes, to be thy love, thy stay and comfort.
10064-8{_}2603{_}Here will we live for each other, and, hid within the green, forget the world and all things else--save only our great love!"
10064-8{_}2604{_}But now it chanced that, raising his head, Beltane beheld his long sword leaning against a tree hard by, and beholding it thus, he bethought him straightway of the Duke his father, of Pentavalon and of her grievous wrongs; and his clasping hands grew lax and fell away and, groaning, he bowed his head; whereat she started anxious-eyed, and questioned him, soft and piteous:  "Is it thy wound?
10064-8{_}2605{_}I had forgot--ah, love, forgive me!
10064-8{_}2606{_}See here a pillow for thy dear head--" But now again he caught her to him close and fierce, and kissed her oft; and holding her thus, spake:  "Thou knowest I do love thee, my Helen?
10064-8{_}2607{_}Yet because I love thee greatly, love, alas, must wait awhile--"  "Wait?"
10064-8{_}2608{_}she cried, "ah, no--am I not thine own?"
10064-8{_}2609{_}"'Tis so I would be worthy of thee, beloved," he sighed, "for know that I am pledged to rest not nor stay until my task be accomplished or I slain--"  "Slain!
10064-8{_}2610{_}Thou?"
10064-8{_}2611{_}"O, Helen, 'tis a mighty task and desperate, and many perchance must die ere this my vow be accomplished--"  "Thy vow?
10064-8{_}2612{_}But thou art a smith, my Beltane,--what hath humble smith to do with vows?
10064-8{_}2613{_}Thou art my love--my Beltane the Smith!"
10064-8{_}2614{_}"Indeed," sighed Beltane, "smith was I aforetime, and therewithal content: yet am I also son of my father, and he--"  "Hark!"
10064-8{_}2615{_}she whispered, white hand upon his lips, "some one comes-- through the leaves yonder!"
10064-8{_}2616{_}So saying she sprang lightly to her feet and stood above him straight and tall: and though she trembled, yet he saw her eyes were fearless and his dagger gleamed steady in her hands.
10064-8{_}2617{_}"Beltane, my love!"
10064-8{_}2618{_}she said, "thou'rt so weak, yet am I strong to defend thee against them all."
10064-8{_}2619{_}But Beltane rose also and, swaying on unsteady feet, kissed her once and so took his sword, marvelling to find it so heavy, and drew it from the scabbard.
10064-8{_}2620{_}And ever upon the stilly air the rustle of leaves grew louder.
10064-8{_}2621{_}"Beltane!"
10064-8{_}2622{_}she sighed, "they be very near!
10064-8{_}2623{_}Hearken!
10064-8{_}2624{_}Beltane--thine am I, in life, in death.
10064-8{_}2625{_}An this be death--what matter, since we die together?"
10064-8{_}2626{_}But, leaning on his sword, Beltane watched her with eyes of love yet spake no word, hearkening to the growing stir amid the leaves, until, of a sudden, upon the bank above, the underbrush was parted and a man stood looking down at them; a tall man, whose linked mail glinted evilly and whose face was hid 'neath a vizored casque.
10064-8{_}2627{_}Now of a sudden he put up his vizor and stepped toward them down the sloping bank.
10064-8{_}2628{_}Then the Duchess let fall the dagger and reached out her hands.
10064-8{_}2629{_}"Godric!"
10064-8{_}2630{_}she sighed, "O Godric!"
10064-8{_}2631{_}CHAPTER XXI  OF THE TALE OF GODRIC THE HUNTSMAN   Thus came white-haired old Godric the huntsman, lusty despite his years, bright-eyed and garrulous with joy, to fall upon his knees before his lady and to kiss those outstretched hands.
10064-8{_}2632{_}"Godric!"
10064-8{_}2633{_}she cried, "'tis my good Godric!"
10064-8{_}2634{_}and laughed, though with lips a-tremble.
10064-8{_}2635{_}"O sweet mistress," quoth he, "now glory be to the kind Saint Martin that I do see thee again hale and well.
10064-8{_}2636{_}These many days have I followed hard upon thy track, grieving for thee--"  "Yet here am I in sooth, my Godric, and joyful, see you!"
10064-8{_}2637{_}"Ah, dear my lady, thy wilfulness hath e'en now brought thee into dire perils and dangers.
10064-8{_}2638{_}O rueful day!"
10064-8{_}2639{_}"Nay, Godric, my wilfulness hath brought me unto my heart's desire.
10064-8{_}2640{_}O most joyful day!"
10064-8{_}2641{_}"Lady, I do tell thee here is an evil place for thee: they do say the devil is abroad and goeth up and down and to and fro begirt in mail, lady, doing such deeds as no man ever did.
10064-8{_}2642{_}Pentavalon is rife with war and rumours of war, everywhere is whispered talk of war--death shall be busy within this evil Duchy ere long--aye, and even in Mortain, perchance--nay, hearken!
10064-8{_}2643{_}Scarce was thy flight discovered when there came messengers hot-foot to thy guest, Duke Ivo, having word from Sir Gui of Allerdale that one hath arisen calling himself son of Beltane the Strong that once was Duke of Pentavalon, as ye know.
10064-8{_}2644{_}And this is a mighty man, who hath, within the week, broke ope my lord Duke Ivo's dungeon of Belsaye, slain divers of my lord Duke's good and loyal subjects, and burnt down the great gallows of my lord Duke."
10064-8{_}2645{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}2646{_}sighed the Duchess, her brows knit thoughtfully, "and what said Duke Ivo to this, Godric?"
10064-8{_}2647{_}"Smiled, lady, and begged instant speech with thee; and, when thou wert not to be found, then Duke Ivo smiled upon thy trembling counsellors.
10064-8{_}2648{_}'My lords,' said he, 'I ride south to hang certain rogues and fools.
10064-8{_}2649{_}But, when I have seen them dead, I shall come hither again to woo and wed the Duchess Helen.
10064-8{_}2650{_}See to it that ye find her, therefore, else will I myself seek her through the length and breadth of Mortain until I find her--aye, with lighted torches, if need be!"
10064-8{_}2651{_}"And dare he threaten us?"
10064-8{_}2652{_}cried the Duchess, white hands clenched.
10064-8{_}2653{_}"Aye, doth he, lady," nodded Godric, garrulous and grim.
10064-8{_}2654{_}"Thereafter away he rode, he and all his company, and after them, I grieving and alone, to seek thee, dear my lady.
10064-8{_}2655{_}And behold, I have found thee, the good Saint Martin be praised!"
10064-8{_}2656{_}"Verily thou hast found me, Godric!"
10064-8{_}2657{_}sighed the Duchess, looking upon Beltane very wistfully.
10064-8{_}2658{_}"So now will I guide thee back to thine own fair duchy, gentle mistress, for I do tell thee here in Pentavalon shall be woeful days anon.
10064-8{_}2659{_}Even as I came, with these two eyes did I behold the black ruin of Duke Ivo's goodly gallows--a woeful sight!
10064-8{_}2660{_}And divers tales have I heard of this gallows-burner, how that he did, unaided and alone, seize and bear off upon his shoulders one Sir Pertolepe--called the 'Red'-- Lord Warden of the Marches.
10064-8{_}2661{_}So hath Duke Ivo put a price upon his head and decreed that he shall forthright be hunted down, and thereto hath sent runners far and near with his exact description, the which have I heard and can most faithfully repeat an you so desire?"
10064-8{_}2662{_}"Aye me!"
10064-8{_}2663{_}sighed the Duchess, a little wearily.
10064-8{_}2664{_}"As thus, lady.
10064-8{_}2665{_}Item: calleth himself Beltane, son of Beltane, Duke of Pentavalon that was: Item--"  "Beltane!"
10064-8{_}2666{_}said the Duchess, and started.
10064-8{_}2667{_}"Item: he is very tall and marvellous strong.
10064-8{_}2668{_}Item: hath yellow hair--"  "Yellow hair!"
10064-8{_}2669{_}said the Duchess, and turned to look upon Beltane.
10064-8{_}2670{_}"Item: goeth in chain-mail, and about his middle a broad belt of gold and silver.
10064-8{_}2671{_}Item: beareth a great sword whereon is graven the legend-- lady, dost thou attend?--Ha!
10064-8{_}2672{_}Saint Martin aid us!"
10064-8{_}2673{_}cried Godric, for now, following the Duchess's glance, he beheld Beltane leaning upon his long sword.
10064-8{_}2674{_}Then, while Godric stared open-mouthed, the Duchess looked on Beltane, a new light in her eyes and with hands tight clasped, while Beltane looking upon her sighed amain.
10064-8{_}2675{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2676{_}he cried, "O Helen, 'tis true that I who am Beltane the Smith, am likewise son of Beltane, Duke of Pentavalon.
10064-8{_}2677{_}Behold, the sword I bear is the sword of the Duke my father, nor must I lay it by until wrong is vanquished and oppression driven hence.
10064-8{_}2678{_}Thus, see you, I may not stay to love, within my life it must not be--yet-a-while," and speaking, Beltane groaned and bowed his head.
10064-8{_}2679{_}So came she to him and looked on him with eyes of yearning, yet touched him not.
10064-8{_}2680{_}"Dear my lord," said she, tender-voiced, "thou should'st make a noble duke, methinks: and yet alas!
10064-8{_}2681{_}needs must I love my gentle Beltane the Smith.
10064-8{_}2682{_}And I did love him so!
10064-8{_}2683{_}Thou art a mighty man-at-arms, my lord, and terrible in war, meseemeth, O--methinks thou wilt make a goodly duke indeed!"
10064-8{_}2684{_}"Mayhap," he answered heavily, "mayhap, an God spare me long enough.
10064-8{_}2685{_}But now must I leave thee--"  "Aye, but wherefore?"
10064-8{_}2686{_}"Thou hast heard--I am a hunted man with a price upon my head, by my side goeth death--"  "So will I go also," she murmured, "ever and always beside thee."
10064-8{_}2687{_}"Thou?
10064-8{_}2688{_}Ah, not so, beloved.
10064-8{_}2689{_}I must tread me this path alone.
10064-8{_}2690{_}As for thee--haste, haste and get thee to Mortain and safety, and there wait for me--pray for me, O my love!"
10064-8{_}2691{_}"Beltane--Beltane," she sighed, "dost love me indeed--and yet would send me from thee?"
10064-8{_}2692{_}"Aye," he groaned, "needs must it be so."
10064-8{_}2693{_}"Beltane," she murmured, "Beltane, thou shalt be Duke within the week, despite Black Ivo."
10064-8{_}2694{_}"Duke--I?
10064-8{_}2695{_}Of Pentavalon?"
10064-8{_}2696{_}"Of Mortain!"
10064-8{_}2697{_}she whispered, "an thou wilt wed me, my lord."
10064-8{_}2698{_}"Nay," stammered Beltane, "nay, outcast am I, my friends very few--to wed thee thus, therefore, were shame--"  "To wed me thus," said she, "should be my joy, and thy joy, and Pentavalon's salvation, mayhap.
10064-8{_}2699{_}O, see you not, Beltane?
10064-8{_}2700{_}Thou should'st be henceforth my lord, my knight-at-arms to lead my powers 'gainst Duke Ivo, teaching Mortain to cringe no more to a usurper--to free Pentavalon from her sorrows--ah, see you not, Beltane?"
10064-8{_}2701{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2702{_}he murmured, "O Helen, poor am I--a beggar--"  "Beltane," she whispered, "an thou wed this lonely maid within the forest, then will I be beggar with thee; but, an thou take to wife the Duchess, then shalt thou be my Duke, lord of me and of Mortain, with her ten thousand lances in thy train."
10064-8{_}2703{_}"Thou would'st give me so much," he sighed at last, "so much, my Helen?"
10064-8{_}2704{_}"Nay," said she, with red lips curved and tender, "for this wide world to me is naught without thee, Beltane.
10064-8{_}2705{_}And I do need thy mighty arm--to shelter me, Beltane, since Ivo hath defied me, threatening Mortain with fire and sword.
10064-8{_}2706{_}So when he cometh, instead of a woman he shall find a man to withstand him, whose sword is swift and strong to smite and who doeth such deeds as no man ever did; so shalt thou be my love, my lord, my champion.
10064-8{_}2707{_}Wilt not refuse me the shelter of thy strength, Beltane?"
10064-8{_}2708{_}Now of a sudden Beltane lifted his head and seized her in his arms and held her close.
10064-8{_}2709{_}Quoth he:  "So be it, my Helen.
10064-8{_}2710{_}To wife will I take thee so soon as may be, to hold thee ever in love and reverence, to serve thee ever, to live for thee and for thee to die an needs be."
10064-8{_}2711{_}But now strode Godric forward, with hands outstretched in eager protest.
10064-8{_}2712{_}"Lady," he cried, "O dear lady bethink thee, now, bethink thee, thy choice is a perilous choice--"  "Yet is it my choice, Godric."
10064-8{_}2713{_}"But, O, dear my mistress--"  "O my faithful Godric, look now upon lord Beltane, my well-beloved who shall be Duke of Mortain ere the moon change.
10064-8{_}2714{_}Salute thy lord, Godric!"
10064-8{_}2715{_}So, perforce, came old Godric to fall upon his knee before Beltane, to take his hand and swear the oath of fealty.
10064-8{_}2716{_}"Lord Beltane," said he, "son art thou of a mighty Duke; God send Mortain find in thee such another!"
10064-8{_}2717{_}"Amen!"
10064-8{_}2718{_}said Beltane.
10064-8{_}2719{_}Thereafter Godric rose and pointed up to the zenith.
10064-8{_}2720{_}"Behold, my lady," said he, "it groweth to noon and there is danger hereabouts--more danger e'en than I had dreamed.
10064-8{_}2721{_}Let us therefore haste over into Mortain--to thy Manor of Blaen."
10064-8{_}2722{_}"But Godric, see you not my lord is faint of his wound, and Blaen is far, methinks."
10064-8{_}2723{_}"Not so, lady, 'tis scarce six hours' journey to the north, nay, I do know of lonely bridle-paths that shall bring us sooner."
10064-8{_}2724{_}"To Blaen?"
10064-8{_}2725{_}mused the Duchess.
10064-8{_}2726{_}"Winfrida is there--and yet--and yet-- aye, let us to Blaen, there will I nurse thee to thy strength again, my Beltane, and there shalt thou--wed with me--an it be so thy pleasure in sooth, my lord."
10064-8{_}2727{_}So, in a while, they set off through the forest, first Godric to guide them, then Beltane astride the great war-horse with the Duchess before him, she very anxious for his wound, yet speaking oft of the future with flushing cheek and eyes a-dream.
10064-8{_}2728{_}Thus, as the sun declined, they came forth of the forest-lands and beheld that broad sweep of hill and dale that was Mortain.
10064-8{_}2729{_}"O loved Mortain!"
10064-8{_}2730{_}she sighed, "O dear Mortain!
10064-8{_}2731{_}'Tis here there lived a smith, my Beltane, who sang of and loved but birds and trees and flowers.
10064-8{_}2732{_}'Tis here there lived a Duchess, proud and most disdainful, who yearned for love yet knew naught of it until--upon a day, these twain looked within each other's eyes--O day most blissful!
10064-8{_}2733{_}Ah, sweet Mortain!"
10064-8{_}2734{_}By pleasant ways they went, past smiling fields and sleepy villages bowered 'mid the green.
10064-8{_}2735{_}They rode ever by sequestered paths, skirting shady wood and coppice where birds sang soft a drowsy lullaby, wooing the world to forgetfulness and rest; fording prattling brook and whispering stream whose placid waters flamed to the glory of sunset.
10064-8{_}2736{_}And thus they came at last to Blaen, a cloistered hamlet beyond which rose the grey walls of the ancient manor itself.
10064-8{_}2737{_}Now as they drew near, being yet sheltered 'mid the green, old Godric halted in his stride and pointed to the highway that ran in the vale below.
10064-8{_}2738{_}"Lady," quoth he, "mine eyes be old, and yet methinks I should know yon horseman that rideth unhelmed so close beside the lady Winfrida--that breadth of shoulder!
10064-8{_}2739{_}that length of limb!
10064-8{_}2740{_}Lady, how think ye?"
10064-8{_}2741{_}"'Tis Duke Ivo!"
10064-8{_}2742{_}she whispered.
10064-8{_}2743{_}"Aye," nodded Godric, "armed, see you, yet with but two esquires--"  "And with Winfrida!"
10064-8{_}2744{_}said the Duchess, frowning.
10064-8{_}2745{_}"Can it indeed be as I have thought, betimes?
10064-8{_}2746{_}And Blaen is a very solitary place!"
10064-8{_}2747{_}"See!"
10064-8{_}2748{_}whispered Godric, "the Duke leaveth her.
10064-8{_}2749{_}Behold him kiss her hand!
10064-8{_}2750{_}Ha, he summoneth his esquires.
10064-8{_}2751{_}Hey now, see how they ride--sharp spur and loose bridle, 'tis ever Ivo's way!"
10064-8{_}2752{_}Now when the Duke and his esquires were vanished in the dusk and the sound of their galloping died away, the Duchess sprang lightly to the sward and bidding them wait until she summoned them, hasted on before.
10064-8{_}2753{_}Thus, in a while, as Winfrida the Fair paced slowly along upon her ambling palfrey, her blue eyes a-dream, she was suddenly aware of a rustling near by and, glancing swiftly up, beheld the Duchess Helen standing before her, tall and proud, her black brows wrinkled faintly, her eyes stern and challenging.
10064-8{_}2754{_}"Lady--dear my lady!"
10064-8{_}2755{_}stammered Winfrida--"is it thou indeed--"  "Since when," quoth the Duchess, soft-voiced yet menacing, "since when doth Winfrida hold sly meeting with one that is enemy to me and to Mortain?"
10064-8{_}2756{_}"Enemy?--nay, whom mean you--indeed I--O Helen, in sooth 'twas but by chance--"  "Is this treason, my lady Winfrida, or only foolish amourette?"
10064-8{_}2757{_}"Sweet lady--'twas but chance--an you mean Duke Ivo--he came--I saw--"  "My lady Winfrida, I pray you go before, we will speak of this anon.
10064-8{_}2758{_}Come, Godric!"
10064-8{_}2759{_}she called.
10064-8{_}2760{_}Then the lady Winfrida, her beauteous head a-droop, rode on before, sighing deep and oft yet nothing speaking, with the Duchess proud and stern beside her while Beltane and Godric followed after.
10064-8{_}2761{_}And so it was they came to the Manor of Blaen.
10064-8{_}2762{_}CHAPTER XXII  CONCERNING THE WILES OF WINFRIDA THE FAIR   Now in these days did my Beltane know more of joy and come more nigh to happiness than ever in his life before.
10064-8{_}2763{_}All day, from morn till eve, the Duchess was beside him; each hour her changing moods won him to deeper love, each day her glowing beauty enthralled him the more, so that as his strength grew so grew his love for her.
10064-8{_}2764{_}Oft would they sit together in her garden amid the flowers, and she, busied with her broidering needle, would question him of his doings, and betimes her breast would heave and her dexterous hand tremble and falter to hear of dangers past; or, talking of the future, her gracious head would droop with cheeks that flushed most maidenly, until Beltane, kneeling to her loveliness, would clasp her in his arms, while she, soft-voiced, would bid him beware her needle.
10064-8{_}2765{_}To him all tender sweetness, yet to all others within the manor was she the Duchess, proud and stately; moreover, when she met the lady Winfrida in hall or bower, her slender brows would wrinkle faintly and her voice sound cold and distant, whereat the fair Winfrida would bow her meek head, and sighing, wring her shapely fingers.
10064-8{_}2766{_}Now it befell upon a drowsy afternoon, that, waking from slumber within the garden, Beltane found himself alone.
10064-8{_}2767{_}So he arose and walked amid the flowers thinking of many things, but of the Duchess Helen most of all.
10064-8{_}2768{_}As he wandered slowly thus, his head bent and eyes a-dream, he came unto a certain shady arbour where fragrant herb and climbing blooms wrought a tender twilight apt to blissful musing.
10064-8{_}2769{_}Now standing within this perfumed shade he heard of a sudden a light step behind him, and turning swift about, his eager arms closed upon a soft and yielding form, and behold--it was Winfrida!
10064-8{_}2770{_}Then Beltane would have loosed his clasp, but her white hands reached up and clung upon his broad shoulders, yet when she spake her voice was low and humble.
10064-8{_}2771{_}"My lord Beltane," she sighed, "happy art thou to have won the love of our noble lady--aye, happy art thou!
10064-8{_}2772{_}But as for me, alas!
10064-8{_}2773{_}messire, meseemeth her heart is turned 'gainst me these days; I, who was her loved companion and childish play-fellow!
10064-8{_}2774{_}So now am I very desolate, wherefore I pray you speak with her on my behalf and win her to forgiveness.
10064-8{_}2775{_}Ah, messire, when thou shalt be Duke indeed, think kindly on the poor Winfrida, for as I most truly love the Duchess--" here needs must she sigh amain and turn aside her shapely head, and thereafter spake, clear and loud: "so will I love thee also!"
10064-8{_}2776{_}Then, while he yet stood abashed by the touch of her and the look in her eyes, she caught his hand to her lips and fled away out of the arbour.
10064-8{_}2777{_}But now as he stood staring after her beyond all thought amazed, a white hand parted the leafy screen and the Duchess stood before him.
10064-8{_}2778{_}And behold!
10064-8{_}2779{_}her slender brows were wrinkled faintly, and when she spake her voice was cold and distant.
10064-8{_}2780{_}"Saw you the lady Winfrida, my lord?"
10064-8{_}2781{_}"Why truly," stammered Beltane, "truly I--she was here but now--"  "Here, my lord?
10064-8{_}2782{_}Alone?"
10064-8{_}2783{_}"She besought me speak thee for her forgiveness; to remind thee of her love aforetime, to--"  "Would'st plead for her, in sooth?"
10064-8{_}2784{_}"I would but have thee do her justice, Helen--"  "Think you I am so unjust, my lord?"
10064-8{_}2785{_}"Not so indeed.
10064-8{_}2786{_}But she is so young--so fair--"  "Aye, she is very fair, my lord--there be--others think the same."
10064-8{_}2787{_}"Helen?"
10064-8{_}2788{_}said he, "O Helen!"
10064-8{_}2789{_}"And thou dost plead for her--and to me, my lord!
10064-8{_}2790{_}And with her kisses yet burning thee!"
10064-8{_}2791{_}"She did but kiss my hand--"  "Thy hand, my lord!
10064-8{_}2792{_}O aye, thy hand forsooth!"
10064-8{_}2793{_}"Aye, my hand, lady, and therewith named me 'Duke'!"
10064-8{_}2794{_}quoth Beltane, beginning to frown.
10064-8{_}2795{_}Whereat needs must the Duchess laugh, very soft and sweet yet with eyes aglow beneath her lashes.
10064-8{_}2796{_}"'Duke,' messire?
10064-8{_}2797{_}She names thee so betimes, meseemeth.
10064-8{_}2798{_}Thou art not Duke yet, nor can'st thou ever be but of my favour!"
10064-8{_}2799{_}"And the time flieth apace," sighed Beltane, "and I have mighty things to do.
10064-8{_}2800{_}O, methinks I have tarried here overlong!"
10064-8{_}2801{_}"Ah--and would'st be going, messire?"
10064-8{_}2802{_}"'Tis so methinks my duty."
10064-8{_}2803{_}"Go you alone, messire--or goeth she with thee?"
10064-8{_}2804{_}"Ah, God!
10064-8{_}2805{_}How dare ye so think?"
10064-8{_}2806{_}cried Beltane, in anger so fierce and sudden that though she fronted him yet smiling, she drew back a pace.
10064-8{_}2807{_}Whereat his anger fell from him and he reached out his hands.
10064-8{_}2808{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2809{_}said he, "O my Helen, what madness is this?
10064-8{_}2810{_}Thou art she I love--doth not thine heart tell thee so?"
10064-8{_}2811{_}and fain would he have caught her to him.
10064-8{_}2812{_}"Ah--touch me not!"
10064-8{_}2813{_}she cried, and steel flickered in her hand.
10064-8{_}2814{_}"This--to me?"
10064-8{_}2815{_}quoth he, and laughed short and bitter, and catching her wrist, shook the dagger from her grasp and set his foot upon it.
10064-8{_}2816{_}"And hath it come to this--'twixt thee and me?"
10064-8{_}2817{_}he sighed.
10064-8{_}2818{_}"O," she panted, "I have loved thee nor shamed to show thee my love.
10064-8{_}2819{_}Yet because my love is so great, so, methinks, an need be I might hate thee more than any man!"
10064-8{_}2820{_}Then, quick-breathing, flushed and trembling, she turned and sped away, leaving Beltane heavy-hearted, and with the dagger gleaming beneath his foot.
10064-8{_}2821{_}CHAPTER XXIII  OF THE HUMILITY OF HELEN THE PROUD   Beltane, leaning forth of his lattice, stared upon the moon with doleful eyes, heavy with sense of wrong and big with self-pity.
10064-8{_}2822{_}"I have dreamed a wondrous fair dream," said he within himself, "but all dreams must end, so is my dream vanished quite and I awake, and being awake, now will I arise and go upon my duty!"
10064-8{_}2823{_}Then turned he to his bed that stood beside the window and forthwith began to arm himself; but with every lace he drew, with every strap he buckled, he sighed amain and his self-pity waxed the mightier.
10064-8{_}2824{_}He bethought him of his father's sayings anent the love of women, and in his mind condemned them all as fickle and light-minded.
10064-8{_}2825{_}And in a while, being armed from head to foot, in glistening coif and hauberk and with sword girt about his middle, he came back to the lattice and leaned him there to stare again upon the moon, to wait until the manor should be wrapped in sleep and to grieve for himself with every breath he drew.
10064-8{_}2826{_}Being thus so profoundly occupied and, moreover, his head being thrust without the window, he heard nought of the tap upon his chamber door nor of the whispered sound of his name.
10064-8{_}2827{_}Thus he started to feel a touch upon his arm, and turning, beheld the Duchess.
10064-8{_}2828{_}She wore a simple robe that fell about her body's round loveliness in sweetly revealing folds; her hair, all unbraided, was caught up 'neath a jewelled fillet in careless fashion, but--O surely, surely, never had she looked so fair, so sweet and tender, so soft and desirable as now, the tear-drops yet agleam upon her drooping lashes and her bosom yet heaving with recent grief.
10064-8{_}2829{_}"And--thou art armed, my lord?"
10064-8{_}2830{_}"I ride for Thrasfordham-within-Bourne this night, my lady."
10064-8{_}2831{_}"But I am come to thee--humbly--craving thy forgiveness, Beltane."
10064-8{_}2832{_}"Nought have I to forgive thee, lady--save that thou art woman!"
10064-8{_}2833{_}"Thou would'st not have me--a man, messire?"
10064-8{_}2834{_}"'Twould be less hard to leave thee."
10064-8{_}2835{_}"Thou art--leaving me then, Beltane?"
10064-8{_}2836{_}"Yea, indeed, my lady.
10064-8{_}2837{_}The woes of Pentavalon call to me with a thousand tongues: I must away--pray God I have not tarried too long!"
10064-8{_}2838{_}"But art yet weak of thy wound, Beltane.
10064-8{_}2839{_}I pray thee tarry--a little longer.
10064-8{_}2840{_}Ah, my lord, let not two lives go empty because of the arts of a false friend, for well do I know that Winfrida, seeing me coming to thee in the garden, kissed thee of set purpose, that, beholding, I might grieve."
10064-8{_}2841{_}"Is this indeed so, my lady?"
10064-8{_}2842{_}"She did confess it but now."
10064-8{_}2843{_}"Said she so indeed?"
10064-8{_}2844{_}"Aye, my lord, after I had--pulled her hair--a little.
10064-8{_}2845{_}But O, my Beltane, even when I thought thee base, I loved thee!
10064-8{_}2846{_}Ah, go not from me, stay but until to-morrow, and then shalt thou wed me for thine own!
10064-8{_}2847{_}Leave me not, Beltane, for indeed--I cannot live--without thee!"
10064-8{_}2848{_}So saying, she sank down upon his couch, hiding her face in the pillow.
10064-8{_}2849{_}Now came Beltane and leaned above her.
10064-8{_}2850{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2851{_}he whispered; and falling upon his knees, he set his arms about her.
10064-8{_}2852{_}Then lifted she her tearful face and looked upon him in the moonlight; and lying thus, of a sudden reached out white arms to him: and in her eyes was love, and on her quivering lips and in all the yearning beauty of her, love called to him.
10064-8{_}2853{_}Close, close he caught her in his embrace, kissing her hard and fierce, and her long hair came down to veil them in its glory.
10064-8{_}2854{_}Then, trembling, he lifted her in his arms and bore her forth of his chamber out into the hall beyond, where lights flickered against arras-hung wall.
10064-8{_}2855{_}There, falling upon his knees before her, he hid his face within the folds of her habit.
10064-8{_}2856{_}"O Helen!"
10064-8{_}2857{_}he groaned, "thou art--so beautiful--so beautiful that I grow afraid of thee!
10064-8{_}2858{_}Wed me this night or in mercy let me begone!"
10064-8{_}2859{_}And now did the Duchess look down upon him with eyes of wonder changing to a great and tender joy, and stooping, put back his mail coif with reverent hand and laid her cheek upon that bowed and golden head.
10064-8{_}2860{_}"Beltane," she whispered, "O Beltane of mine, now do I know thee indeed for a true man and noble knight!
10064-8{_}2861{_}Such love as thine honoureth us both, so beloved, this night--within the hour, shalt thou wed with me, and I joy to hear thee call me--Wife!"
10064-8{_}2862{_}Therewith she turned and left him there upon his knees.
10064-8{_}2863{_}CHAPTER XXIV  OF WHAT BEFELL AT BLAEN   Late though the hour, full soon the manor was astir; lights glimmered in the great hall where were gathered all the household of the Duchess, her ladies, her tire-women, the porters and serving men, even to the scullions--all were there, staring in wonderment upon the Duchess, who stood before them upon the dais in a rich habit of blue and silver and with her golden fillet on her brow.
10064-8{_}2864{_}"Good friends," said she, looking round upon them happy-eyed, "hither have I summoned ye, for that this night, here before you all, 'tis my intent to wed this noble knight Beltane, son of Beltane Duke of Pentavalon aforetime, who shall henceforth be lord of me and of Mortain."
10064-8{_}2865{_}Now did Winfrida the Fair start and therewith clench pink palms and look quick-eyed upon my Beltane, noting in turn his golden hair, his belt of silver and the great sword he bore: and, biting her red lip, she stooped her beauteous head, frowning as one in sudden perplexity.
10064-8{_}2866{_}"So now," spake on the Duchess, "let us to the chapel where good Father Angelo shall give us heaven's blessing upon this our union."
10064-8{_}2867{_}"Lady," said Godric, "Friar Angelo was summoned to the village this night, nor is he come again yet."
10064-8{_}2868{_}"Then go fetch him," sighed the Duchess, "and O, Godric, hasten!"
10064-8{_}2869{_}Thereafter turned she to the assemblage, gentle-eyed.
10064-8{_}2870{_}"Friends," said she, "since I am greatly happy this night, so would I have ye happy likewise.
10064-8{_}2871{_}Therefore I decree that such as are serfs among ye shall go free henceforth, and to such as are free will I give grants of land that ye may come to bless this night and remember it ever."
10064-8{_}2872{_}But now, even as they fell on their knees, 'mid cries of gratitude and joyful acclaim, she, smiling and gracious, passed out of the hall: yet, as she went, beckoned the lady Winfrida to follow.
10064-8{_}2873{_}Being come into her chamber, all three, the Duchess sank down beside the open lattice and looked out upon the garden all bathed in the tender radiance of the moon.
10064-8{_}2874{_}Anon she sighed and spake:  "My lady Winfrida, on this my wedding night a new life dawns for Mortain and for me, wherein old harms shall be forgiven and forgot, so come--kiss me, Winfrida."
10064-8{_}2875{_}Then swiftly came the beauteous Winfrida to kneel at her lady's feet, to clasp her lady's slender hand, to kiss it oft and bathe it in her tears.
10064-8{_}2876{_}"O sweet my lady, am I indeed forgiven?"
10064-8{_}2877{_}"Aye, most truly."
10064-8{_}2878{_}"Am I again thy loved companion and thy friend?"
10064-8{_}2879{_}"So shall it be, Winfrida."
10064-8{_}2880{_}"Then, O dear Helen, as sign all is forgot and we lovers again, let us pledge each other, here and now--to thy future happiness and glory."
10064-8{_}2881{_}"Aye, be it so," sighed the Duchess, "bring wine, for I am athirst."
10064-8{_}2882{_}Then turned she to the lattice again and Winfrida went lightly on her errand.
10064-8{_}2883{_}Now, yet gazing upon the moon, the Duchess reached out and drew Beltane beside her.
10064-8{_}2884{_}"Dear my love," she whispered, "in but a little hour I shall be thine: art happy in the thought?
10064-8{_}2885{_}Nay," she sighed, white hands against his mailed breast, "beloved, wait--kiss me not again until the hour be passed.
10064-8{_}2886{_}Lean here thy golden head and look with me upon the splendour of the night.
10064-8{_}2887{_}See the pale moon, how placid and serene, how fair and stately she doth ride--"  "So may thy life be in coming years!"
10064-8{_}2888{_}said Beltane.
10064-8{_}2889{_}"And wilt love me ever, Beltane, no matter what betide?"
10064-8{_}2890{_}"Ever and always, so long as thou art Helen.
10064-8{_}2891{_}Nay, why dost tremble?"
10064-8{_}2892{_}"O my lord--see yonder--that cloud, how black--see how it doth furtive creep upon the gentle moon--"  "'Tis a long way hence, my Helen!"
10064-8{_}2893{_}"Yet will it come.
10064-8{_}2894{_}Ah, think you 'tis a portent?
10064-8{_}2895{_}O would the gentle Angelo were here--and yet, an he were come--methinks I might wish him hence--for that, loving thee so, yet am I a maid, and foolish--ah, who is here--not Angelo so soon?
10064-8{_}2896{_}What, 'tis thou, Winfrida?
10064-8{_}2897{_}Welcome--bring hither the goblet."
10064-8{_}2898{_}So came Winfrida, and falling on her knee gave the goblet into her lady's hand, who, rising, turned to Beltane looking on him soft-eyed across the brimming chalice.
10064-8{_}2899{_}"Lord and husband," she breathed--"now do I drink to thy glory in arms, to our future, and to our abiding love!"
10064-8{_}2900{_}So the Duchess raised the goblet to her lips.
10064-8{_}2901{_}But lo!
10064-8{_}2902{_}even as she drank, the thick, black cloud began to engulf the moon, quenching her radiant light in its murky gloom.
10064-8{_}2903{_}So the Duchess drank, and handed the goblet to Beltane.
10064-8{_}2904{_}"To thee, my Helen, whom only shall I love until death and beyond!"
10064-8{_}2905{_}Then Beltane drank also, and gave the cup to Winfrida: but, even as he did so, the Duchess uttered a cry and pointed with hand a-tremble:  "O Beltane, the moon--the moon that was so bright and glorious--'tis gone, the cloud hath blotted it out!
10064-8{_}2906{_}Ah, Beltane, what doth this portend?
10064-8{_}2907{_}Why do I tremble thus because the moon is gone?"
10064-8{_}2908{_}"Nay, my beloved," quoth Beltane, kissing those slender fingers that trembled upon his lip and were so cold--so deadly cold, "dear Helen, it will shine forth again bright and radiant as ever."
10064-8{_}2909{_}"Yet why is my heart so cold, Beltane, and wherefore do I tremble?"
10064-8{_}2910{_}"The night grows chill, mayhap."
10064-8{_}2911{_}"Nay, this cold is from within.
10064-8{_}2912{_}O, I would the moon would shine!"
10064-8{_}2913{_}"Nay, let us speak of our future, my Helen--"  "The future?"
10064-8{_}2914{_}she sighed, "what doth it hold?
10064-8{_}2915{_}Strife and bitter war for thee and a weary waiting for me, and should'st thou be slain--Ah, Beltane, forgive these fears and vain imaginings.
10064-8{_}2916{_}Indeed, 'tis most unlike me to fear and tremble thus.
10064-8{_}2917{_}I was ever accounted brave until now--is't love, think you, doth make me coward?
10064-8{_}2918{_}'Tis not death I fear-- save for thy dear sake.
10064-8{_}2919{_}Death?
10064-8{_}2920{_}Nay, what have we to do with such, thou and I--this is our wedding night, and yet--I feel as if this night--I were leading thee--to thy--death--.
10064-8{_}2921{_}O, am I mad, forsooth?
10064-8{_}2922{_}Hold me close, beloved, comfort me, Beltane, I--I am afraid."
10064-8{_}2923{_}Then Beltane lifted her in his arms and brought her to the hearth, and, setting her in the fireglow, kneeled there, seeking to comfort her.
10064-8{_}2924{_}And now he saw her very pale, sighing deep and oft and with eyes dilated and heavy.
10064-8{_}2925{_}"Beltane," said she slowly, "I grow a-weary, 'tis--the fire, methinks."
10064-8{_}2926{_}And smiling faintly she closed her eyes, yet sighed and gazed upon him as one new waked.
10064-8{_}2927{_}"Did I sleep?"
10064-8{_}2928{_}she questioned drowsily, "Beltane," she sighed, speaking low and thick--"I charge thee, whatsoe'er the future doth bring--yet love me alway--or I, methinks--shall--die!"
10064-8{_}2929{_}Awhile she lay against him breathing deep and slow, then started of a sudden, looking upon him vague-eyed.
10064-8{_}2930{_}"Beltane," she murmured, "art there, beloved?
10064-8{_}2931{_}'Tis dark, and my eyes-- heavy.
10064-8{_}2932{_}Methinks I--must sleep awhile.
10064-8{_}2933{_}Take me--to my women.
10064-8{_}2934{_}I must sleep--yet will I come to thee soon--soon, beloved."
10064-8{_}2935{_}So Beltane brought her to the door, but as he came thither the broidered curtain was lifted and he beheld Winfrida, who ran to her mistress, kissing her oft and sighing over her.
10064-8{_}2936{_}"Winfrida," sighed the Duchess, slumberous of voice, "I grow a-weary--I must sleep awhile--"  "Aye, thou'rt overwrought, dear lady.
10064-8{_}2937{_}Come, rest you until the holy Angelo be come, so shalt be thine own sweet self anon."
10064-8{_}2938{_}And when the Duchess was gone, Beltane sat and stared upon the fire and felt himself vaguely troubled, yet even so, as he watched the leaping flame, his head nodded and he slept, yet sleeping, dreamed he heard the Duchess calling him, and opening his eyes, found the fair Winfrida beside him:  "My lord Beltane," said she softly, "thy Duchess biddeth thee wait her in the chapel--follow me, messire!"
10064-8{_}2939{_}Now being yet heavy with sleep, Beltane arose and followed her through an opening in the arras near by, and down a narrow stair, stumbling often as he went and walking as one in a dream.
10064-8{_}2940{_}So by devious ways Winfrida brought him into a little chapel, where, upon the altar, was a crucifix with candles dim-burning in the gloom.
10064-8{_}2941{_}"Wait here, my lord," said Winfrida, "so will I go prepare my lady, Friar Angelo doth stay to do his holy office."
10064-8{_}2942{_}So speaking, Winfrida turned and was gone.
10064-8{_}2943{_}Then Beltane came unto the altar and, kneeling there, leaned his heavy head upon the fair white altar cloth, and kneeling thus, fell asleep--The altar beneath him seemed of a sudden riven and split asunder and, while he gazed, behold the fair white altar cloth grew fouled and stained with blood--new blood, that splashed down red upon the white even as he watched.
10064-8{_}2944{_}Then did Beltane seek to rise up from his knees, but a heavy weight bore him ever down, and hands huge and hairy gripped him fierce and strong.
10064-8{_}2945{_}But beholding these merciless hands, a sudden mighty rage came upon Beltane, and struggling up, he stood upon his feet and drew sword; but the fierce hands had crept up to his naked throat, cutting off his breath, the sword was dashed from his loosening grasp, the weight about him grew too much for his strength, it bore him down and down into a pitchy gloom where all was very still.
10064-8{_}2946{_}A wind, sweet and cool, breathed upon his cheek, grass was below and trees above him, shadowy trees beyond which a pallid moon rose high, very placid and serene.
10064-8{_}2947{_}Now as Beltane stared heavenward the moon was blotted out, a huge and hairy face looked down in his, and hairy hands lifted him with mighty strength.
10064-8{_}2948{_}Then Beltane thought to see the Duchess Helen standing by in her gown of blue and silver--  "Helen!"
10064-8{_}2949{_}he whispered.
10064-8{_}2950{_}But she paid no heed, busied in fastening about her the nun's long cloak that veiled her down from head to foot.
10064-8{_}2951{_}So the mighty arms that held Beltane bore him to a horse near by and across this horse he was flung; thereafter the monster mounted also, and they moved off amid the trees.
10064-8{_}2952{_}Thus was Beltane borne from Blaen upon his wedding night--dazed, bleeding and helpless in his bonds.
10064-8{_}2953{_}Yet even so, ever as they went he watched her who rode near by, now in moonlight, now in shadow, so youthful and shapely, but with hood drawn low as she had worn it when he bore her through the forest in his arms.
10064-8{_}2954{_}And ever as they went he watched the pale gleam of her hand upon the bridle, or her little foot in its embroidered shoe, or the fold of her blue gown with its silver needle-work.
10064-8{_}2955{_}And ever the trouble in his dazed brain grew the deeper; once, as they crossed a broad glade she rode up close beside him, and beneath her hood he saw a strand of her glorious hair, bright under the moon.
10064-8{_}2956{_}Then did he writhe and struggle in his bonds.
10064-8{_}2957{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2958{_}he cried, "O Helen!"
10064-8{_}2959{_}...
10064-8{_}2960{_}But a great hand, coarse and hairy, came upon his mouth, stopping the cry and choking him to silence.
10064-8{_}2961{_}So they bore my Beltane southwards through the misty woods, on and ever on, till with the dawn they were come to a castle great and very strong, where battlement and tower frowned upon the paling stars.
10064-8{_}2962{_}But with the dawn, 'mid the gloom of the little chapel of Blaen, came one who stood, haggard and pallid as the dawn, to stare wild-eyed upon a great sword and upon a torn and blood-stained altar-cloth; and so gazing, she shrank away back and back, crouching down amid the gloom.
10064-8{_}2963{_}When at last the sun arose, it glittered on a long broad blade, across which, upon the rough pavement, lay one very silent and very still, amid the tumbled glory of her hair.
10064-8{_}2964{_}CHAPTER XXV  HOW BELTANE BECAME CAPTIVE TO SIR PERTOLEPE   A horn, lustily winded, waked my Beltane from his swoon, waked him to a glimmering world vague and unreal, where lights flared and voices sounded, hoarse and faint, in question and answer.
10064-8{_}2965{_}Thereafter, down rattled drawbridge and up creaked portcullis, and so, riding 'neath a deep and gloomy arch they came out into a courtyard, where were many vague forms that flitted to and fro--and many more lights that glinted on steel bascinet and hauberk of mail.
10064-8{_}2966{_}Now as Beltane lay helpless in his bonds he felt a hand among his hair, a strong hand that lifted his heavy, drooping head and turned up his face to the glare of the torches.
10064-8{_}2967{_}"How now, Fool!"
10064-8{_}2968{_}cried a gruff voice, "here's not thy meat--ha, what would ye--what would ye, Fool?"
10064-8{_}2969{_}"Look upon another fool, for fool, forsooth, is he methinks that cometh so into Garthlaxton Keep."
10064-8{_}2970{_}Now hereupon, opening unwilling eyes, Beltane looked up into the face of Beda the Jester that bent above him with a ring of steel-begirt faces beyond.
10064-8{_}2971{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}2972{_}quoth the jester, clapping Beltane's pale and bloody cheek, "here is a fool indeed--forsooth, a very foolish fool, hither come through folly, for being great of body and small of wit, look you, his folly hath hither brought him in shape of a hairy, ape-like fool--"  "Ape!"
10064-8{_}2973{_}growled a voice, and the jester was seized in a hairy hand and shaken till his bells jingled; and now Beltane beheld his captor, a dwarf-like, gnarled and crooked creature, yet huge of head and with the mighty arms and shoulders of a giant; a fierce, hairy monster, whose hideousness was set off by the richness of his vesture.
10064-8{_}2974{_}"Ape, quotha!"
10064-8{_}2975{_}he growled.
10064-8{_}2976{_}"Dare ye name Ulf the Strong ape, forsooth?
10064-8{_}2977{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}2978{_}so will I shake the flesh from thy bones!"
10064-8{_}2979{_}But now, she who sat her horse near by so proud and stately, reached forth a white hand, touching Ulf the Strong upon the arm, and lo!
10064-8{_}2980{_}in that moment, he loosed the breathless jester and spake with bowed head: "Dear my lady, I forgot!"
10064-8{_}2981{_}Then turning to the grinning soldiery he scowled upon them.
10064-8{_}2982{_}"Dogs," quoth he, "go to your master and say Helen, Duchess of Mortain bringeth a wedding gift to Ivo, called the Black.
10064-8{_}2983{_}Behold here he that slew twenty within the green, that burned down Black Ivo's goodly gallows, that broke the dungeons of Belsaye and bore Red Pertolepe into the green, behold him ye seek--Beltane, son of Beltane the Strong, heretofore Duke of Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}2984{_}Now hereupon arose a mighty turmoil and excitement, all men striving to behold Beltane, to touch him and look upon his drooping face, but Ulf's mighty hand held them back, one and all.
10064-8{_}2985{_}And presently came hasting divers esquires and knights, who, beholding Beltane, his costly mail, his silver belt and golden hair, seized upon him right joyfully and bore him into an inner ward, and threw him down upon the floor, marvelling and rejoicing over him, while Beltane lay there fast bound and helpless, staring up with frowning brow as one that strives to think, yet cannot.
10064-8{_}2986{_}Now suddenly the noise about him ceased, all voices were hushed, and he was aware of one who stood near by, a doleful figure swathed in bandages, who leaned upon the arm of a tall esquire.
10064-8{_}2987{_}And looking upon this figure, he saw it was Sir Pertolepe the Red.
10064-8{_}2988{_}"Ha, by the eyes of God!"
10064-8{_}2989{_}quoth Sir Pertolepe, "'tis he himself--O sweet sight--see, I grow better already!
10064-8{_}2990{_}Who brought him, say you?"
10064-8{_}2991{_}"Lord, 'twas the Duchess Helen!"
10064-8{_}2992{_}said one.
10064-8{_}2993{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}2994{_}cried Sir Pertolepe, "Helen of Mortain?"
10064-8{_}2995{_}"Aye, lord, as her wedding gift to our lord Duke Ivo."
10064-8{_}2996{_}Now hereupon Beltane's staring eyes closed, the great muscles of his body twitched and writhed and stood out gnarled and rigid awhile, then he sighed, a slow, hissing breath, and lay there staring up wide-eyed at the vaulted roof again.
10064-8{_}2997{_}"Came she herself, Raoul?"
10064-8{_}2998{_}"Aye, good my lord."
10064-8{_}2999{_}"Why, then--admit her.
10064-8{_}3000{_}God's love, messires, would ye keep the glorious Helen without?"
10064-8{_}3001{_}"Lord, she is gone--she and her ape-man both."
10064-8{_}3002{_}"Gone?
10064-8{_}3003{_}Gone, forsooth?
10064-8{_}3004{_}'Tis strange, and yet 'tis like the wilful Helen.
10064-8{_}3005{_}Yet hath she left her wedding gift in my keeping.
10064-8{_}3006{_}O a rare gift, a worthy gift and most acceptable.
10064-8{_}3007{_}Strip me off his armour--yet no, as he came, so shall he bide until my lord Duke be come.
10064-8{_}3008{_}Bring now shackles, strong and heavy, bring fetters and rivets, so will I sit here and see him trussed."
10064-8{_}3009{_}And presently came two armourers with hammers and rivets, and shackled Beltane with heavy chains, the while Sir Pertolepe, sitting near, laughed and spake him right jovially.
10064-8{_}3010{_}But Beltane suffered it all, uttering no word and staring ever straight before him with wide, vague eyes, knitting his brow ever and anon in troubled amaze like a child that suffers unjustly; wherefore Sir Pertolepe, fondling his big chin, frowned.
10064-8{_}3011{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}3012{_}quoth he, "let our Duke that hath no duchy be lodged secure--to the dungeons, aye, he shall sleep with rats until my lord Duke Ivo come to see him die--yet stay!
10064-8{_}3013{_}The dungeons be apt to sap a man's strength and spirit, and to a weak man death cometh over soon and easy.
10064-8{_}3014{_}Let him lie soft, feed full and sleep sound--let him have air and light, so shall he wax fat and lusty against my lord Duke's coming.
10064-8{_}3015{_}See to it, Tristan!"
10064-8{_}3016{_}So they led Beltane away jangling in his fetters, across divers courtyards and up a narrow, winding stair and thrust him within a chamber where was a bed and above it a loop-hole that looked out across a stretch of rolling, wooded country.
10064-8{_}3017{_}Now being come to the bed, Beltane sank down thereon, and setting elbow to knee, rested his heavy head upon his hand as one that fain would think.
10064-8{_}3018{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}3019{_}he whispered, and so whispering, his strong fingers writhed and clenched themselves within his yellow hair.
10064-8{_}3020{_}And thus sat he all that day, bowed forward upon his hand, his fingers tight-clenched within his hair, staring ever at the square flagstone beneath his foot, heedless alike of the coming and going of his gaoler or of the food set out upon the bench hard by.
10064-8{_}3021{_}Day grew to evening and evening to night, yet still he sat there, mighty shoulders bowed forward, iron fingers clenched within his hair, like one that is dead; in so much that his gaoler, setting down food beside the other untasted dishes, looked upon him in amaze and touched him.
10064-8{_}3022{_}"Oho!"
10064-8{_}3023{_}said he, "wake up.
10064-8{_}3024{_}Here be food, look ye, and, by Saint Crispin, rich and dainty.
10064-8{_}3025{_}And drink--good wine, wake and eat!"
10064-8{_}3026{_}Then Beltane's clutching fingers relaxed and he raised his head, blinking in the rays of the lanthorn; and looking upon his rumpled hair, the gaoler stared and peered more close.
10064-8{_}3027{_}Quoth he:  "Methought thou wert a golden man, yet art silver also, meseemeth."
10064-8{_}3028{_}"Fellow," said Beltane harsh-voiced and slow, "Troy town was burned, and here was great pity, methinks, for 'twas a fair city.
10064-8{_}3029{_}Yet to weep o'er it these days were a fond madness.
10064-8{_}3030{_}Come, let us eat!"
10064-8{_}3031{_}But as Beltane uprose in his jangling fetters, the gaoler, beholding his face, backed to the door, and slamming it shut, barred and fast bolted it, yet cast full many a glance behind as he hasted down the winding stair.
10064-8{_}3032{_}Then Beltane ate and drank, and thereafter threw himself upon his narrow couch, but his fetters jangled often in the dark.
10064-8{_}3033{_}Thus as he lay, staring upwards into the gloom, he was aware of the opening of the iron-clamped door, and beheld his gaoler bearing a lanthorn and behind him Sir Pertolepe leaning on the arm of his favourite esquire, who, coming near, looked upon Beltane nodding right jovially.
10064-8{_}3034{_}"Messire Beltane," quoth he, "thou did'st dare set up thyself against Ivo our lord the Duke--O fool!
10064-8{_}3035{_}'Tis said thou hast sworn to drive him forth of Pentavalon--seeking her to wife, O fool of fools!
10064-8{_}3036{_}Did'st think, presumptuous rogue, that she--the glorious Helen--that Helen the Beautiful, whom all men desire, would stoop to thee, an outcast-- wolf's head and outlaw that thou art?
10064-8{_}3037{_}Did'st dare think so, forsooth?
10064-8{_}3038{_}To-morrow, belike, my lord Duke shall come, and mayhap shall bring the Duchess Helen in his train--to look upon the manner of thy dying--"  Now hereupon up started Beltane that his fetters clashed, and laughed so sudden, so fierce and harsh, that Raoul the esquire clapped hand to dagger and even Red Pertolepe started.
10064-8{_}3039{_}"Sweet lord," quoth Beltane, "noble messire Pertolepe, of thy boundless mercy--of thy tender ruth grant unto me this boon.
10064-8{_}3040{_}When ye shall have done me to death--cut off this head of mine and send it to Helen--to Helen the beautiful, the wilful--in memory of what befell at Blaen."
10064-8{_}3041{_}CHAPTER XXVI  OF THE HORRORS OF GARTHLAXTON KEEP, AND HOW A DEVIL ENTERED INTO BELTANE   Six days came and went, and during all this time Beltane spake word to no man.
10064-8{_}3042{_}Every evening came Sir Pertolepe leaning on the arm of Raoul the esquire, to view his prisoner with greedy eyes and ply him with jovial talk whiles Beltane would lie frowning up at the mighty roof-beams, or sit, elbows on knee, his fingers clenched upon that lock of hair that gleamed so strangely white amid the yellow.
10064-8{_}3043{_}Now upon the seventh evening as he sat thus, came Sir Pertolepe according to his wont, but to-night he leaned upon the shoulder of Beda the Jester, whose motley flared 'gainst rugged wall and dingy flagstone and whose bells rang loud and merry by contrast with the gloom.
10064-8{_}3044{_}Quoth Sir Pertolepe, seated upon the bench and smiling upon Beltane's grim figure:  "He groweth fat to the killing, seest thou, my Beda, a young man and hearty, very hale and strong--and therefore meet for death.
10064-8{_}3045{_}So strong a man should be long time a-dying--an death be coaxed and managed well.
10064-8{_}3046{_}And Tristan is more cunning and hath more love for his craft than ever had Black Roger.
10064-8{_}3047{_}With care, Beda--I say with care, messire Beltane should die from dawn to sundown."
10064-8{_}3048{_}"Alack!"
10064-8{_}3049{_}sighed the jester, "death shall take him over soon, as thou dost say--and there's the pity on't!"
10064-8{_}3050{_}"Soon, Fool--soon?
10064-8{_}3051{_}Now out upon thee for a fool ingrain--"  "Forsooth, sweet lord, fool am I--mark these bells!
10064-8{_}3052{_}Yet thou art a greater!"
10064-8{_}3053{_}"How, sirrah?"
10064-8{_}3054{_}"In that thou art a greater man, fair, sweet lord; greater in might, greater in body, and greater in folly."
10064-8{_}3055{_}"Ha, would'st mock me, knave?"
10064-8{_}3056{_}"For perceive me, fair and gentle lord, as this base body of ours being altogether thing material is also thing corruptible, so is it also a thing finite, and as it is a thing finite so are its sensations, be they of pleasure or pain, finite also--therefore soon must end.
10064-8{_}3057{_}Now upon the other hand--"  "How now?
10064-8{_}3058{_}What babbling folly is here?"
10064-8{_}3059{_}"As I say, most potent lord, upon the other hand--as the mind, being altogether thing transcendental, is also thing incorruptible, so is it also a thing infinite, and being a thing infinite so are its sensations infinite also--therefore everlasting."
10064-8{_}3060{_}"Ha, there's reason in thy folly, methinks.
10064-8{_}3061{_}What more?"
10064-8{_}3062{_}"Bethink thee, lord, there be divers rogues who, having provoked thy potent anger, do lie even now awaiting thy lordly pleasure.
10064-8{_}3063{_}E'en now irons be heating for them, moreover they are, by thy will, to suffer the grievous torment of the pulleys and the wheel, and these, as I do know, be sharp punishments and apt to cause prodigious outcry.
10064-8{_}3064{_}Now, to hear one cry out beneath the torture is an evil thing for youthful ears--and one not soon forgot."
10064-8{_}3065{_}"Aye, aye, forsooth, I begin to see thy meaning, good Fool--yet say on."
10064-8{_}3066{_}"Let this thy prisoner be set within the cell above the torture chamber, so, lying within the dark he must needs hear them cry below, and in his mind shall he suffer as they suffer, every pang of racking wheel and searing iron.
10064-8{_}3067{_}And, because the mind is thing infinite--"  "Enough--enough!
10064-8{_}3068{_}O most excellent Beda, 'tis well bethought.
10064-8{_}3069{_}O, rare Fool, so shall it be."
10064-8{_}3070{_}Forthwith Sir Pertolepe summoned certain of his guard, and, incontinent, Beltane was dragged a-down the winding stair and thereafter fast shut within a place of gloom, a narrow cell breathing an air close and heavy, and void of all light.
10064-8{_}3071{_}Therefore Beltane sat him down on the floor, his back to the wall, staring upon the dark, chin on fist.
10064-8{_}3072{_}Long he sat thus, stirring not, and in his heart a black void, deeper and more awful than the fetid gloom of any dungeon--a void wherein a new Beltane came into being.
10064-8{_}3073{_}Now presently, as he sat thus, upon the silence stole a sound, low and murmurous, that rose and fell yet never quite died away.
10064-8{_}3074{_}And Beltane, knowing what sound this was, clenched his hands and bowed his face upon his knees.
10064-8{_}3075{_}As he listened, this drone grew to a sudden squealing cry that rang and echoed from wall to wall, whiles Beltane, crouched in that place of horror, felt the sweat start out upon him, yet shivered as with deadly cold, and ever the cries thrilled within the dark or sank to whimpering moans and stifled supplications.
10064-8{_}3076{_}And ever Beltane hearkened to these fell sounds, staring blindly into the gloom, and ever the new Beltane grew the stronger within him.
10064-8{_}3077{_}Hour after hour he crouched thus, so very silent, so very quiet, so very still, but long after the groans and wailings had died to silence, Beltane stared grim-eyed into the gloom and gnawed upon his fingers.
10064-8{_}3078{_}Of a sudden he espied a glowing spark in the angle of the wall to the right--very small, yet very bright.
10064-8{_}3079{_}Now as he watched, behold the spark changed to a line of golden light, so that his eyes ached and he was fain to shade them in his shackled arm; and thus he beheld a flagstone that seemed to lift itself with infinite caution, and, thereafter, a voice breathed his name.
10064-8{_}3080{_}"Messire--messire Beltane!"
10064-8{_}3081{_}And now through the hole in the floor behold a hand bearing a lanthorn--an arm--a shoulder--a shrouded head; thus slowly a tall, cloaked figure rose up through the floor, and, setting down the lanthorn, leaned toward Beltane, putting back the hood of his mantle, and Beltane beheld Beda the Jester.
10064-8{_}3082{_}"Art awake, messire Beltane?"
10064-8{_}3083{_}"Aye!"
10064-8{_}3084{_}quoth Beltane, lifting his head.
10064-8{_}3085{_}"And I have used mine ears!
10064-8{_}3086{_}The wheel and the pulley are rare begetters of groans, as thou did'st foretell, Fool!
10064-8{_}3087{_}'Twas a good thought to drag me hither--it needed but this.
10064-8{_}3088{_}Now am I steel, without and--within.
10064-8{_}3089{_}O, 'tis a foul world!"
10064-8{_}3090{_}"Nay, messire--'tis a fair world wherein be foul things: they call them 'men.'
10064-8{_}3091{_}As to me, I am but a fool--mark this motley--yet hither I caused thee to be dragged that I might save those limbs o' thine from wheel and pulley, from flame and gibbet, and set thee free within a world which I do hold a fair world.
10064-8{_}3092{_}Yet first--those fetters--behold hammer and chisel!
10064-8{_}3093{_}Oswin, thy gaoler, sleepeth as sweet as a babe, and wherefore?
10064-8{_}3094{_}For that I decocted Lethe in his cup.
10064-8{_}3095{_}Likewise the guard below.
10064-8{_}3096{_}My father, that lived here before me (and died of a jest out of season), was skilled in herbs--and I am his son!
10064-8{_}3097{_}My father (that bled out his life 'neath my lord's supper table) knew divers secret ways within the thickness of these walls--so do I know more of Pertolepe's castle than doth Pertolepe himself.
10064-8{_}3098{_}Come, reach hither thy shackles and I will cut them off, a chisel is swifter than a file--"  "And why would'st give me life, Fool?"
10064-8{_}3099{_}"For that 'tis a useful thing, messire, and perchance as sweet to thee this night within thy dungeon as to me upon a certain day within the green that you may wot of?"
10064-8{_}3100{_}So speaking, Beda the Jester cut asunder the chain that bound the fetters, and Beltane arose and stretched himself and the manacles gleamed on each wide-sundered wrist.
10064-8{_}3101{_}Quoth he:  "What now?"
10064-8{_}3102{_}Whereat the jester, sitting cross-legged upon the floor, looked up at him and spake on this wise:  "Two days agone as I walked me in the green, dreaming such foolish dreams as a fool may, there came, very suddenly, a sorry wight--a wild man, very ragged--who set me his ragged arm about my neck and a sharp dagger to my throat; and thus, looking him within the eyes, I knew him for that same Roger from whose hand thou did'st save me aforetime.
10064-8{_}3103{_}'Beda,' says he, 'I am he that hanged and tortured men at my lord's bidding: I am Roger, and my sins be many.'
10064-8{_}3104{_}'Then prithee,' says I, 'prithee, Roger, add not another to thy sins by cutting the throat of a fool.'
10064-8{_}3105{_}'Needs must I,' says he, dolorous of voice, 'unless thou dost answer me two questions.'
10064-8{_}3106{_}'Nay, I will answer thee two hundred an thou leave my throat unslit,' says I.
10064-8{_}3107{_}'But two,' says Roger, sighing.
10064-8{_}3108{_}'First, doth Pertolepe hold him I seek?'
10064-8{_}3109{_}'Him?'
10064-8{_}3110{_}says I.
10064-8{_}3111{_}'Him they call Beltane?'
10064-8{_}3112{_}says Roger, 'doth he lie prisoned within Garthlaxton?'
10064-8{_}3113{_}'He doth,' quoth I.
10064-8{_}3114{_}Now for thine other question.
10064-8{_}3115{_}''Tis this,' says Roger, 'Wilt aid us to win him free?'
10064-8{_}3116{_}'Why look ye, Roger,' says I, ''Tis only a fool that seeketh aid of a fool--and fool am I.'
10064-8{_}3117{_}'Aye,' says Roger, 'but thou art a live fool; promise, therefore, or wilt be naught but a dead fool.'
10064-8{_}3118{_}'Roger,' says I, 'thou did'st once try to slay me in the green ere now.'
10064-8{_}3119{_}'Aye,' says Roger, 'and my lord Beltane saved thy carcass and my soul.'
10064-8{_}3120{_}'Aye,' quoth I, 'and e'en a fool can repay.
10064-8{_}3121{_}So was I but now dreaming here within this boskage how I might perchance win this same Beltane to life without thy scurvy aid, Black Roger.
10064-8{_}3122{_}Moreover, methinks I know a way--and thou spare me life to do it.'
10064-8{_}3123{_}'Aye, forsooth,' says Roger, putting away his dagger, 'thou wert ever a fool of thy word, Beda--so now do I spare thy life, and sparing it, I save it, and thus do I cut another accursed notch from my belt.'
10064-8{_}3124{_}'Why, then,' says I, 'to-morrow night be at the riven oak by Brankton Thicket an hour before dawn.'
10064-8{_}3125{_}'So be it, Beda,' says he, and so I left him cutting at his belt.
10064-8{_}3126{_}And lo, am I here, and within an hour it should be dawn.
10064-8{_}3127{_}Follow, messire!"
10064-8{_}3128{_}So saying, Beda rose, and taking the lanthorn, began to descend through the floor, having first shown how the flagstone must be lowered in place.
10064-8{_}3129{_}Thereafter, Beltane followed the jester down a narrow stair built in the thickness of the wall, and along a passage that ended abruptly, nor could Beltane see any sign of door in the solid masonry that barred their way.
10064-8{_}3130{_}Here Beda paused, finger on lip, and extinguished the lanthorn.
10064-8{_}3131{_}Then, in the dark a hinge creaked faintly, a quivering hand seized Beltane's manacled wrist, drawing him on and through a narrow opening that yawned suddenly before them.
10064-8{_}3132{_}Thereafter the hinge creaked again and they stood side by side within a small chamber where was a doorway hung across with heavy curtains beyond which a light burned.
10064-8{_}3133{_}Now even as Beltane looked thitherward, he heard the rattle of dice and a sleepy voice that cursed drowsily, and shaking off the clutching, desperate fingers that strove to stay him, he came, soft-treading, and peered through the curtains.
10064-8{_}3134{_}Thus he beheld two men that faced each other across a table whereon was wine, with dice and store of money, and as they played, these men yawned, leaning heavily upon the table.
10064-8{_}3135{_}Back swept the curtains and striding into the room Beltane stared upon these men, who, yet leaning upon the table, stared back at him open-mouthed.
10064-8{_}3136{_}But, beholding the look in his blue eyes and the smile that curled his mouth, they stumbled to their feet and sought to draw weapon--then Beltane sprang and caught them each about the neck, and, swinging them wide-armed, smote their heads together; and together these men sank in his grasp and lay in a twisted huddle across the table among the spilled wine.
10064-8{_}3137{_}A coin rang upon the stone floor, rolled into a distant corner and came to rest, the jester gasped in the shadow of the curtains; and so came silence, broke only by the soft drip, drip of the spilled wine.
10064-8{_}3138{_}"O, mercy of God!"
10064-8{_}3139{_}whispered the jester hoarsely at last, "what need was there for this--they would have slept--"  "Aye," smiled Beltane, "but not so soundly as now, methinks.
10064-8{_}3140{_}Come, let us go."
10064-8{_}3141{_}Silently the jester went on before, by narrow passage-ways that writhed and twisted in the thickness of the walls, up sudden flights of steps until at length they came out upon a parapet whose grim battlements scowled high in air.
10064-8{_}3142{_}But as they hasted on, flitting soft-footed 'neath pallid moon, the jester of a sudden stopped, and turning, dragged Beltane into the shadows, for upon the silence came the sound of mailed feet pacing near.
10064-8{_}3143{_}Now once again Beltane brake from the jester's clutching fingers and striding forward, came face to face with one that bare a pike on mailed shoulder, and who, beholding Beltane, halted to peer at him with head out-thrust; quoth he:  "Ha!
10064-8{_}3144{_}stand!
10064-8{_}3145{_}Stand, I say and speak me who thou art?"
10064-8{_}3146{_}Then Beltane laughed softly; said he:  "O fool, not to know--I am death!"
10064-8{_}3147{_}and with the word, he leapt.
10064-8{_}3148{_}Came a cry, muffled in a mighty hand, a grappling, fierce yet silent, and Beda, cowering back, beheld Beltane swing a writhing body high in air and hurl it far out over the battlements.
10064-8{_}3149{_}Thereafter, above the soft rustle of the night-wind, a sound far below--a faint splash, and Beda the Jester, shivering in the soft-stirring night wind, shrank deeper into the gloom and made a swift motion as though, for all his folly, he had crossed himself.
10064-8{_}3150{_}Then came Beltane, the smile still twisting his mouth; quoth he:  "Forsooth, my strength is come back again; be there any more that I may deal withal, good Fool?"
10064-8{_}3151{_}"Lord," whispered the shivering jester, "methinks I smell the dawn-- Come!"
10064-8{_}3152{_}So Beltane followed him from the battlements, down winding stairs, through halls that whispered in the dark; down more stairs, down and ever down 'twixt walls slimy to the touch, through a gloom heavy with mildew and decay.
10064-8{_}3153{_}On sped the jester, staying not to light the lanthorn, nor once touching, nor once turning with helping hand to guide Beltane stumbling after in the dark.
10064-8{_}3154{_}Then at last, deep in the clammy earth they reached a door, a small door whose rusted iron was handed with mighty clamps of rusted iron.
10064-8{_}3155{_}Here the jester paused to fit key to lock, to strain and pant awhile ere bolts shrieked and turned, and the door yawned open.
10064-8{_}3156{_}Then, stooping, he struck flint and steel and in a while had lit the lanthorn, and, looking upon Beltane with eyes that stared in the pallor of his face, he pointed toward the yawning tunnel.
10064-8{_}3157{_}"Messire," said he, "yonder lieth thy way to life and the world.
10064-8{_}3158{_}As thou did'st give me life so do I give thee thine.
10064-8{_}3159{_}Thou wert, as I remember thee, a very gentle, tender youth--to-night are three dead without reason--"  "Reason, good Fool," said Beltane, "thou did'st see me borne in a prisoner to Garthlaxton; now, tell me I pray, who was she that rode with us?"
10064-8{_}3160{_}"'Twas the Duchess Helen of Mortain, messire; I saw her hair, moreover--"  But lo, even as the jester spake, Beltane turned, and striding down the tunnel, was swallowed in the dark.
10064-8{_}3161{_}CHAPTER XXVII  HOW BELTANE TOOK TO THE WILD-WOOD   A faint glimmer growing ever brighter, a jagged patch of pale sky, a cleft in the rock o'er-grown with bush and creeping vines; this Beltane saw ere he stepped out into the cool, sweet air of dawn.
10064-8{_}3162{_}A while he stood to stare up at the sky where yet a few stars showed paling to the day, and to drink in mighty breaths of the fragrant air.
10064-8{_}3163{_}And thus, plain to his ears, stole the ripple of running water hard by, and going thitherward he stripped, and naked came down to the stream where was a misty pool and plunged him therein.
10064-8{_}3164{_}Now as he bathed him thus, gasping somewhat because of the cold, yet glorying in the rush and tingle of his blood, behold, the leaves parted near by, and uprising in his naked might, Beltane beheld the face of one that watched him intently.
10064-8{_}3165{_}"Master!"
10064-8{_}3166{_}cried a voice harsh but very joyful, "O dear, my lord!"
10064-8{_}3167{_}And Roger sprang down the bank and heedless of the water, plunged in to catch Beltane's hands and kiss them.
10064-8{_}3168{_}"Master!"
10064-8{_}3169{_}he cried.
10064-8{_}3170{_}And thus it was these two met again.
10064-8{_}3171{_}And presently, having donned clothes and harness, Beltane sat down him beside the brook, head upon hand, staring at the swift-running water, whiles Roger, sitting near, watched him in a silent ecstasy.
10064-8{_}3172{_}"Whence come ye, Roger?"
10064-8{_}3173{_}"From Thrasfordham-within-Bourne, lord.
10064-8{_}3174{_}Ho, a mighty place, great and strong as Sir Benedict himself.
10064-8{_}3175{_}And within Thrasfordham be many lusty fighting men who wait thy coming,--for, master, Bourne, aye and all the Duchy, doth ring with tales of thy deeds."
10064-8{_}3176{_}"Hath Sir Benedict many men?"
10064-8{_}3177{_}"Aye--within Thrasfordham five hundred and more."
10064-8{_}3178{_}"So few, Roger?"
10064-8{_}3179{_}"And mayhap as many again in Bourne.
10064-8{_}3180{_}But, for Sir Benedict--a right lusty knight in sooth, master!
10064-8{_}3181{_}and he doth hunger for sight of thee.
10064-8{_}3182{_}He hath had me, with Walkyn and the archer, speak full oft of how we fired the gibbet and roars mighty laughs to hear how thou didst bear off Sir Pertolepe in the green--aye, Sir Benedict doth love to hear tell of that."
10064-8{_}3183{_}"Aye; and what of Duke Ivo--where is he now, Roger?"
10064-8{_}3184{_}"He hath reinforced Belsaye garrison and all the coast towns and castles of the Marches, and lieth at Pentavalon, gathering his powers to attack Thrasfordham, so men say, and hath sworn to burn it within the year, and all therein save only Sir Benedict--him will he hang; 'tis so proclaimed far and wide."
10064-8{_}3185{_}"And do men yet come in to Sir Benedict?"
10064-8{_}3186{_}"Not so, master.
10064-8{_}3187{_}Since Duke Ivo came they are afraid."
10064-8{_}3188{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}3189{_}And what of the outlaws--there be many wild men within the forests."
10064-8{_}3190{_}"The outlaws--hey, that doth mind me.
10064-8{_}3191{_}I, with Giles and Walkyn and the young knight Sir Jocelyn brought down the outlaws upon Thornaby Mill.
10064-8{_}3192{_}But when we found thee not, we burned it, and thereafter the outlaws vanished all within the wild-wood; Sir Jocelyn rode away a-singing mighty doleful, and we three came to Thrasfordham according to thy word.
10064-8{_}3193{_}But when ye came not, master, by will of Sir Benedict we set out, all three, to find thee, and came to a cave of refuge Walkyn wots of: there do we sleep by night and by day search for thee.
10064-8{_}3194{_}And behold, I have found thee, and so is my tale ended.
10064-8{_}3195{_}But now, in an hour will be day, master, and with the day will be the hue and cry after thee.
10064-8{_}3196{_}Come, let us haste over into Bourne, there shall we be safe so long as Thrasfordham stands."
10064-8{_}3197{_}"True," nodded Beltane and rose to his feet.
10064-8{_}3198{_}"Go you to Thrasfordham, Roger, Sir Benedict shall need such lusty men as thou, meseemeth."
10064-8{_}3199{_}"Aye--but what of thee, master?"
10064-8{_}3200{_}"I?
10064-8{_}3201{_}O, I'm for the wild-wood, to a wild life and wilder doings, being myself a wild man, henceforth, lawful food for flame or gibbet, kin to every clapper-claw rogue and rascal 'twixt here and Mortain."
10064-8{_}3202{_}"Nay master, within Thrasfordham ye shall laugh at Black Ivo and all his powers--let us then to Thrasfordham, beseech thee!"
10064-8{_}3203{_}"Nay, I'm for the woods in faith, to seek me desperate rogues, wild men whose lives being forfeit, are void of all hope and fear.
10064-8{_}3204{_}So, get thee to Sir Benedict and speak him this from me, to wit: that while he holdeth Ivo in check before Thrasfordham, I will arise indeed and bring with me flame and steel from out the wild-wood.
10064-8{_}3205{_}When he shall see the night sky aflame, then shall he know I am at work, and when by day he heareth of death sudden and swift, then shall he know I am not idle.
10064-8{_}3206{_}Bid him rede me this riddle: That bringing from chaos order, so from order will I bring chaos, that order peradventure shall remain.
10064-8{_}3207{_}Haste you into Bourne, Roger, and so--fare thee well!"
10064-8{_}3208{_}Now as he spake, Beltane turned on his heel and strode along beside the brook, but even as he went, so went Roger, whereon Beltane turned frowning.
10064-8{_}3209{_}Quoth he:  "Roger--Thrasfordham lieth behind thee!"
10064-8{_}3210{_}"Aye, master, but death lieth before thee!"
10064-8{_}3211{_}"Why then, death will I face alone, Roger."
10064-8{_}3212{_}"Nay, master--not while Roger live.
10064-8{_}3213{_}Thy man am I--"  "Ha--wilt withstand me, Black Roger?"
10064-8{_}3214{_}"Thy man am I, to follow thee in life and go down with thee in death--"  Now hereupon Beltane came close, and in the dim light Black Roger beheld the new Beltane glaring down at him fierce-eyed and with great mailed fist clenched to smite; but even so Black Roger gave not back, only he drew dagger and strove to set it in Beltane's iron fingers.
10064-8{_}3215{_}"Take this," quoth he, "for, an ye would be free of Roger, first must ye slay him, master."
10064-8{_}3216{_}So Beltane took the dagger and fumbled with it awhile then gave it back to Roger's hand.
10064-8{_}3217{_}"Roger!"
10064-8{_}3218{_}muttered he, his hand upon his brow, "my faithful Roger!
10064-8{_}3219{_}So, men can be faithful--" saying which he sighed--a long, hissing breath, and hid his face within his mittened hand, and turning, strode swiftly upon his way.
10064-8{_}3220{_}Now in a while, they being come into the forest, Roger touched him on the arm.
10064-8{_}3221{_}"Master," said he, "whither do ye go?"
10064-8{_}3222{_}"Nay, it mattereth not so long as I can lie hid a while, for I must sleep, Roger."
10064-8{_}3223{_}"Then can I bring thee to a place where none shall ever find thee-- Come, master!"
10064-8{_}3224{_}So saying, Roger turned aside into the denser wood, bursting a way through a tangle of brush, plunging ever deeper into the wild until they came to a place where great rocks and boulders jutted up amid the green and the trees grew scant.
