10064-8{_}3225{_}Day was breaking, and before them in the pale light rose a steep cliff, whose jagged outline clothed here and there with brush and vines loomed up before them, barring their advance.
10064-8{_}3226{_}But at the foot of this cliff grew a tree, gnarled and stunted, the which, as Beltane watched, Black Roger began to climb, until, being some ten feet from the ground, he, reaching out and seizing a thick vine that grew upon the rock, stepped from the tree and vanished into the face of the cliff.
10064-8{_}3227{_}But in a moment the leaves were parted and Roger looked forth, beckoning Beltane to follow.
10064-8{_}3228{_}So, having climbed the tree, Beltane in turn seized hold upon the vine, and stumbling amid the leaves, found himself on his knees within a small cave, where Roger's hand met his.
10064-8{_}3229{_}Thereafter Roger led him to the end of the cavern where was a winding passage very rough and narrow, that brought them to a second and larger cave, as Beltane judged, for in the dark his hands could feel nought but space.
10064-8{_}3230{_}Here Roger halted and whistled three times, a melodious call that woke many a slumbering echo.
10064-8{_}3231{_}And in a while, behold a glow that grew ever brighter, until, of a sudden, a man appeared bearing a flaming pine-torch, that showed a wide cave whose rugged roof and walls glistened here and there, and whose rocky floor ended abruptly in a yawning gulf from whose black depths came soft murmurs and ripplings of water far below.
10064-8{_}3232{_}Now, halting on the opposite side of this chasm, the man lifted his flaming torch and lo!
10064-8{_}3233{_}it was Walkyn, who, beholding Beltane in his mail, uttered a hoarse shout of welcome, and stooping, thrust a plank across the gulf.
10064-8{_}3234{_}So Beltane crossed the plank and gave his hand to Walkyn's iron grip and thereafter followed him along winding, low-roofed passage-ways hollowed within the rock, until they came to a cavern where a fire blazed, whose red light danced upon battered bascinets and polished blades that hung against the wall, while in one corner, upon a bed of fern, Giles o' the Bow lay snoring right blissfully.
10064-8{_}3235{_}To him went Roger to shake him into groaning wakefulness and to point with eager finger to Beltane.
10064-8{_}3236{_}Whereat up sprang Giles and came running with hands outstretched in welcome, yet of a sudden, paused and stood staring upon Beltane, as did the others also, for the place was very bright and moreover Beltane's mail-coif was fallen back.
10064-8{_}3237{_}So they looked on him all three, yet spake no word.
10064-8{_}3238{_}Therefore Beltane sat him down beside the fire and rested his head upon his hands as one that is weary.
10064-8{_}3239{_}Sitting thus, he told them briefly what had chanced, but of the Duchess he said nothing.
10064-8{_}3240{_}And in a while, lifting his head he saw them watching him all three, and all three incontinent glanced otherwhere.
10064-8{_}3241{_}Quoth Beltane:  "Wherefore do ye stare upon me?"
10064-8{_}3242{_}"Why, as to that, good brother," said the archer, "'tis but that--that we do think thee something--changed of aspect."
10064-8{_}3243{_}"Changed!"
10064-8{_}3244{_}said Beltane, and laughed short and bitter, "aye, 'tis like I am."
10064-8{_}3245{_}"Lord," quoth Walkyn, clenching mighty fists, "have they tormented thee--was it the torture, lord?"
10064-8{_}3246{_}"Aye," nodded Beltane, "'twas the torture.
10064-8{_}3247{_}So now good comrades, here will I sleep awhile.
10064-8{_}3248{_}But first--go forth with the sun and question all ye may of Ivo and his doings--where he doth lie, and where his forces muster--hear all ye can and bring me word, for methinks we shall be busy again anon!"
10064-8{_}3249{_}Then, throwing himself upon the bed of fern that Roger had re-made, Beltane presently fell asleep.
10064-8{_}3250{_}And while he slept came the three, very silent and treading very soft, to look down upon his sleeping face and the manacles that gleamed upon his wrists; and behold, even as he slept, he groaned and writhed, his tender lips grown fierce, a relentless, down-curving line--his jaws grim set, and between his frowning brows a lock of silky hair that gleamed snow-white among the yellow.
10064-8{_}3251{_}"The torture!"
10064-8{_}3252{_}growled Roger, and so, soft as they came, the three turned and left him to his slumber.
10064-8{_}3253{_}But oft he moaned and once he spake a word, sudden and fierce 'twixt clenched teeth.
10064-8{_}3254{_}And the word was:  "Helen!"
10064-8{_}3255{_}CHAPTER XXVIII  OF THE PLACE OF REFUGE WITHIN THE GREEN   It was toward evening that Beltane awoke, and sitting up, looked about him.
10064-8{_}3256{_}He was in a chamber roughly square, a hollow within the rock part natural and part hewn by hand, a commodious chamber lighted by a jagged hole in the rock above, a fissure all o'er-grown with vines and creeping plants whose luxuriant foliage tempered the sun's rays to a tender green twilight very grateful and pleasant.
10064-8{_}3257{_}Now pendant from the opening was a ladder of cords, and upon this ladder, just beneath the cleft, Beltane beheld a pair of lusty, well-shaped legs in boots of untanned leather laced up with leathern thongs; as for their owner, he was hidden quite by reason of the leafy screen as he leaned forth of the fissure.
10064-8{_}3258{_}Looking upon these legs, Beltane knew them by their very attitude for the legs of one who watched intently, but while he looked, they stirred, shifted, and growing lax, became the legs of one who lounged; then, slow and lazily, they began to descend lower and lower until the brown, comely face of Giles Brabblecombe o' the Hills smiled down upon Beltane with a gleam of white teeth.
10064-8{_}3259{_}Cried he:  "Hail, noble brother, and likewise the good God bless thee!
10064-8{_}3260{_}Hast slept well, it lacketh scarce an hour to sundown, and therefore should'st eat well.
10064-8{_}3261{_}How say ye now to a toothsome haunch o' cold venison, in faith, cunningly cooked and sufficiently salted and seasoned--ha?
10064-8{_}3262{_}And mark me!
10064-8{_}3263{_}with a mouthful of malmsey, ripely rare?
10064-8{_}3264{_}Oho, rich wine that I filched from a fatuous friar jig-jogging within the green!
10064-8{_}3265{_}Forsooth, tall brother, 'tis a wondrous place, the greenwood, wherein a man shall come by all he doth need--an he seek far enough!
10064-8{_}3266{_}Thus, an my purse be empty, your beefy burgher shall, by dint of gentle coaxing, haste to fill me it with good, broad pieces.
10064-8{_}3267{_}But, an my emptiness be of the belly, then sweet Saint Giles send me some ambulating abbot or pensive-pacing prior; for your churchmen do ever ride with saddle-bags well lined, as I do know, having been bred a monk, and therefore with a rare lust to creature comforts."
10064-8{_}3268{_}Now while he spake thus, the archer was busily setting forth the viands upon a rough table that stood hard by, what time Beltane looked about him.
10064-8{_}3269{_}"'Tis a wondrous hiding-place, this, Giles!"
10064-8{_}3270{_}quoth he.
10064-8{_}3271{_}"Aye, verily, brother--a sweet place for hunted men such as we.
10064-8{_}3272{_}Here be caves and caverns enow to hide an army, and rocky passage-ways, narrow and winding i' the dark, where we four might hold all Black Ivo's powers at bay from now till Gabriel's trump--an we had food enow!"
10064-8{_}3273{_}Quoth Beltane:  "'Tis a fair thought that, and I've heard there be many outlaws in the woods hereabouts?"
10064-8{_}3274{_}"Yea, forsooth.
10064-8{_}3275{_}And each and every a clapper-claw, a rogue in faith.
10064-8{_}3276{_}O very lewd, bloody-minded knaves see ye now, that would have slain me three days agone but for my comrade Walkyn.
10064-8{_}3277{_}Scurvy dogs, fit for the halter they be, in faith!"
10064-8{_}3278{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}3279{_}quoth Beltane, thoughtful of brow.
10064-8{_}3280{_}"They be wild men, meseemeth?"
10064-8{_}3281{_}"Desperate knaves, one and all; and look ye, they would have slain--"  "Aye?"
10064-8{_}3282{_}nodded Beltane.
10064-8{_}3283{_}"All the off-scourings of town and village--and look ye, they would--"  "Aye," said Beltane.
10064-8{_}3284{_}"Thieves, rogues and murderers, branded felons, runaway serfs and villeins--"  "'Tis well," said Beltane, "so shall they be my comrades henceforth."
10064-8{_}3285{_}"Thy comrades!"
10064-8{_}3286{_}stammered the archer, staring in amaze--"thy comrades!
10064-8{_}3287{_}These base knaves that would have hanged me--me, that am free-born like my father before me--"  "So, peradventure, Giles, will we make them free men also.
10064-8{_}3288{_}Howbeit this day I seek them out--"  "Seek them--'tis death!"
10064-8{_}3289{_}"Death let it be, 'tis none so fearful!"
10064-8{_}3290{_}"They will slay thee out of hand--a wild rabblement, lawless and disordered!"
10064-8{_}3291{_}"So would I bring order among them, Giles.
10064-8{_}3292{_}And thou shalt aid me."
10064-8{_}3293{_}"I--aid thee?
10064-8{_}3294{_}How--would'st have me company with such vile carrion?
10064-8{_}3295{_}Not I, forsooth.
10064-8{_}3296{_}I am a soldier, free-born, and no serf like Walkyn or villein like Roger.
10064-8{_}3297{_}But sure you do but jest, brother, so will I laugh with thee--"  But now, very suddenly, Beltane reached out his long arm and seizing Giles in mighty hand, dragged him to his knees; and Giles, staring up in amaze, looked into the face of the new Beltane whose blue eyes glared 'neath frowning brows and whose lips curled back from gleaming teeth.
10064-8{_}3298{_}"Giles," said he softly, rocking the archer in his grasp, "O Giles Brabblecombe o' the Hills, did I not save thy roguish life for thee?
10064-8{_}3299{_}Did not Walkyn and Roger preserve it to thee?
10064-8{_}3300{_}So doth thy life belong to Walkyn and to Roger and to me.
10064-8{_}3301{_}Four men are we together, four brothers in arms, vowed to each other in the fulfilment of a purpose-- is it not so?"
10064-8{_}3302{_}"Yea, verily, lord.
10064-8{_}3303{_}Good men and true are we all, but see you not, lord, these outlaws be lewd fellows--base-born--"  "See you not, Giles, these outlaws be men, even as we, who, like us, can laugh and weep, can bleed and die--who can use their lives to purpose good or evil, even as we.
10064-8{_}3304{_}Therefore, since they are men, I will make of them our comrades also, an it may be."
10064-8{_}3305{_}Thus saying, Beltane loosed Giles and turning to the table, fell to eating again while the archer sat upon the floor nursing his bruised arm and staring open-mouthed.
10064-8{_}3306{_}Quoth Beltane at last:  "We will seek out and talk with these outlaws to-night, Giles!"
10064-8{_}3307{_}"Talk with a pack of--yea, forsooth!"
10064-8{_}3308{_}nodded Giles, rubbing his arm.
10064-8{_}3309{_}"I am minded to strike such a blow as shall hearten Sir Benedict for the siege and shake Black Ivo's confidence."
10064-8{_}3310{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}3311{_}cried Giles, springing up so that his link-mail jingled, "aha!
10064-8{_}3312{_}a sweet thought, tall brother!
10064-8{_}3313{_}Could we fire another gibbet now--"  "Know you where the outlaws lie hid, Giles?"
10064-8{_}3314{_}"Nay, lord, none save themselves and Walkyn know that.
10064-8{_}3315{_}Walkyn methinks, was great among them once."
10064-8{_}3316{_}"And where is Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}3317{_}"So soon as ye slept, lord, he and Roger went forth according to thy word.
10064-8{_}3318{_}As for me, I stayed here to watch.
10064-8{_}3319{_}From the spy-hole yonder you may command the road a-wind in the valley, and unseen, see you, may see.
10064-8{_}3320{_}But come, an thy hunger be allayed, reach me thy hand that I may file off those iron bracelets."
10064-8{_}3321{_}"Nay, let be, Giles.
10064-8{_}3322{_}I will wear them henceforth until my vow be accomplished."
10064-8{_}3323{_}Hereupon Beltane arose, and, climbing the ladder, looked forth through a screen of leaves and underbrush and saw that from the fissure the ground sloped steeply down, a boulder-strewn hill thick with gorse and bramble, at whose base the road led away north and south until it was lost in the green of the forest.
10064-8{_}3324{_}Now as Beltane stood thus, gazing down at the winding road whose white dust was already mellowing to evening, he beheld one who ran wondrous fleetly despite the ragged cloak that flapped about his long legs, and whose rough-shod feet spurned the dust beneath them so fast 'twas a marvel to behold; moreover as he ran, he bounded hither and thither, and with every bound an arrow sped by him from where, some distance behind, ran divers foresters bedight in a green livery Beltane thought he recognized; but even as Beltane grasped the branches that screened him, minded to swing himself up to the fellow's aid, the fugitive turned aside from the road and came leaping up the slope, but, of a sudden, uttered a loud cry and throwing up his hands fell face down upon the ling and so lay, what time came up one of the pursuers that had outstripped his fellows, but as he paused, his sword shortened for the thrust, up sprang the fugitive, a great axe flashed and whirled and fell, nor need was there for further stroke.
10064-8{_}3325{_}Then, while the rest of the pursuers were yet a great way off, Walkyn came leaping up the hill.
10064-8{_}3326{_}Back from the ladder Beltane leapt and down through the fissure came Walkyn to fall cat-like upon his feet, to shake free the ladder after him, and thereafter to sit panting upon a stool, his bloody axe betwixt his knees.
10064-8{_}3327{_}"Pertolepe's wolves!"
10064-8{_}3328{_}he panted, "two of them have I--slain--within the last mile," and grinning, he patted the haft of his axe.
10064-8{_}3329{_}"What news, Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}3330{_}"Death!"
10064-8{_}3331{_}panted Walkyn, "there be five dead men a-swing from the bartizan tower above Garthlaxton Keep, and one that dieth under the torture e'en now, for I heard grievous outcry, and all by reason of thy escape, lord."
10064-8{_}3332{_}"Come you then from Garthlaxton?"
10064-8{_}3333{_}quoth Beltane, frowning.
10064-8{_}3334{_}"Aye, lord.
10064-8{_}3335{_}For, see you, 'twas market day, so went I to one I know that is a swineherd, a trusty fellow that bringeth hogs each week unto Garthlaxton.
10064-8{_}3336{_}So did we change habits and went to Garthlaxton together, driving the hogs before us.
10064-8{_}3337{_}Thereafter, while he was away chaffering, I sat me down in the outer bailey tending my beasts, yet with eyes and ears wide and with my hand upon mine axe 'neath my cloak lest haply I might chance within striking distance of Red Pertolepe.
10064-8{_}3338{_}And, sitting thus, I heard tell that he had marched out with all his array to join Black Ivo's banner.
10064-8{_}3339{_}Whereupon was I mightily cast down.
10064-8{_}3340{_}But it chanced the wind lifted my cloak, and one of the warders, spying mine axe, must think to recognise me and gave the hue and cry; whereat I, incontinent, fled ere they could drop the portcullis--and divers rogues after me.
10064-8{_}3341{_}Aha!
10064-8{_}3342{_}then did I lead them a right merry dance by moor and moss, by briar and bog, and contrived to slay of them five in all.
10064-8{_}3343{_}But as to Pertolepe, a malison on him!
10064-8{_}3344{_}he is not yet to die, meseemeth.
10064-8{_}3345{_}But, some day--aye, some day!"
10064-8{_}3346{_}So saying he kissed the great axe and setting it by came to the table and fell to eating mightily while Giles sat hard by busied with certain arrows, yet betwixt whiles watching Beltane who, crossing to the bed of fern, laid him down thereon and closed his eyes.
10064-8{_}3347{_}But of a sudden he raised his head, hearkening to a whistle, soft and melodious, near at hand.
10064-8{_}3348{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}3349{_}exclaimed Giles, setting aside his arrows, "yonder should be Roger--a hungry Roger and therefore surly, and a surly Roger is rare sport to lighten a dull hour.
10064-8{_}3350{_}Heaven send our Roger be surly!"
10064-8{_}3351{_}So saying, the archer went forth and presently came hasting back with Roger at his heels scowling and in woeful plight.
10064-8{_}3352{_}Torn and stained and besprent with mud, his rawhide knee-boots sodden and oozing water, he stood glowering at Giles beneath the bloody clout that swathed his head, his brawny fist upon his dagger.
10064-8{_}3353{_}"No food left, say ye, Giles, no food, and I a-famishing?
10064-8{_}3354{_}You and Walkyn drunk up all the wine betwixt ye, and I a-perish--ha--so now will I let it out again--" and out flashed his dagger.
10064-8{_}3355{_}"Nay, 'tis but the archer's folly," quoth Walkyn--"sit, man, eat, drink, and speak us thy news."
10064-8{_}3356{_}"News," growled Roger, seating himself at table, "the woods be thick with Pertolepe's rogues seeking my master, rogues known to me each one, that ran to do my bidding aforetime--in especial one Ralpho--that was my assistant in the dungeons once.
10064-8{_}3357{_}Thrice did they beset me close, and once did I escape by running, once by standing up to my neck in a pool, and once lay I hid in a tree whiles they, below, ate and drank like ravening swine--and I a-famishing.
10064-8{_}3358{_}A murrain on 'em, one and all, say I--in especial Ralpho that was my comrade once--may he rot henceforth--"  "Content you, Roger, he doth so!"
10064-8{_}3359{_}laughed grim Walkyn and pointed to his axe.
10064-8{_}3360{_}"Forsooth, and is it so?"
10064-8{_}3361{_}growled Roger, his scowl relaxing--"now will I eat full and blithely, for Ralpho was an arrant knave."
10064-8{_}3362{_}Now when his hunger was somewhat assuaged, Roger turned and looked where Beltane lay.
10064-8{_}3363{_}"My master sleepeth?"
10064-8{_}3364{_}said he, his voice grown gentle.
10064-8{_}3365{_}"Nay, Roger, I lie and wait thy news," spake Beltane, his eyes yet closed.
10064-8{_}3366{_}"Why then, 'tis war, master--battle and siege.
10064-8{_}3367{_}The country is up as far as Winisfarne.
10064-8{_}3368{_}Black Ivo lieth at Barham Broom with a great company--I have seen their tents and pavilions like a town, and yet they come, for Ivo hath summoned all his powers to march against Thrasfordham.
10064-8{_}3369{_}'Twixt here and Pentavalon city, folk do say the roads be a-throng with bows and lances--lords and barons, knights and esquires, their pennons flutter everywhere."
10064-8{_}3370{_}"'Tis well!"
10064-8{_}3371{_}sighed Beltane.
10064-8{_}3372{_}"Well, master--nay, how mean you?"
10064-8{_}3373{_}"That being at Barham Broom, they cannot be otherwhere, Roger.
10064-8{_}3374{_}Saw you Pertolepe's banner among all these?"
10064-8{_}3375{_}"Aye, master; they have set up his pavilion beside the Duke's."
10064-8{_}3376{_}"Tell me now," said Beltane, coming to his elbow, "how many men should be left within Garthlaxton for garrison, think you?"
10064-8{_}3377{_}"An hundred, belike!"
10064-8{_}3378{_}said Walkyn.
10064-8{_}3379{_}"Less," quoth Roger; "Garthlaxton is so strong a score of men have held it ere now.
10064-8{_}3380{_}'Tis accounted the strongest castle in all the Duchy, save only Thrasfordham."
10064-8{_}3381{_}"Truly 'tis very strong!"
10064-8{_}3382{_}said Beltane thoughtfully, and lying down again he closed his eyes and spake slow and drowsily--"Aye, 'tis so strong, its garrison, being secure, should sleep sound o' nights.
10064-8{_}3383{_}So 'twould be no great matter to surprise and burn it ere the dawn, methinks!"
10064-8{_}3384{_}"Burn Garthlaxton!"
10064-8{_}3385{_}cried the archer, and sprang up, scattering the arrows right and left.
10064-8{_}3386{_}"Master!"
10064-8{_}3387{_}stammered Roger, "master--"  As for Walkyn, he, having his mouth full and striving to speak, choked instead.
10064-8{_}3388{_}"Lord--lord!"
10064-8{_}3389{_}he gasped at last, "to see Garthlaxton go up in flame--O blessed sight!
10064-8{_}3390{_}Its blood-soaked walls crumble to ruin--ah, sweet, rare sight!
10064-8{_}3391{_}But alas!
10064-8{_}3392{_}'tis a mighty place and strong, and we but four--"  "There be outlaws in the wild-wood!"
10064-8{_}3393{_}quoth Beltane.
10064-8{_}3394{_}"Ha!--the outlaws!"
10064-8{_}3395{_}cried Giles, and clapped hand to thigh.
10064-8{_}3396{_}"Aye," nodded Beltane, "bring me to the outlaws."
10064-8{_}3397{_}"But bethink thee, tall brother--of what avail a thousand such poor, ragged, ill-armed rogues 'gainst the walls of Garthlaxton?
10064-8{_}3398{_}They shall not tear you the stones with their finger-nails nor rend them with their teeth, see'st thou!"
10064-8{_}3399{_}"To burn Garthlaxton!"
10064-8{_}3400{_}growled Walkyn, biting at his fingers.
10064-8{_}3401{_}"Ha, to give it to the fire!
10064-8{_}3402{_}But the walls be mighty and strong and the outlaws scattered.
10064-8{_}3403{_}'Twould take a week to muster enough to attempt a storm, nor have they engines for battery--"  "Enough!"
10064-8{_}3404{_}said Beltane rising, his brows close drawn, "now hearken, and mark me well; the hole whereby one man came out may let a thousand in.
10064-8{_}3405{_}Give me but an hundred men at my back and Garthlaxton shall be aflame ere dawn.
10064-8{_}3406{_}So, come now, Walkyn--bring me to the outlaws."
10064-8{_}3407{_}"But lord, these be very wild men, obedient to no law save their own, and will follow none but their own; lawless men forsooth, governed only by the sword and made desperate by wrong and fear of the rope--"  "Then 'tis time one learned them other ways, Walkyn.
10064-8{_}3408{_}So now I command thee, bring me to them--'tis said thou wert great among them once."
10064-8{_}3409{_}Hereupon Walkyn rose and taking up his mighty axe twirled it lightly in his hand.
10064-8{_}3410{_}"Behold, lord," said he, "by virtue of this good axe am I free of the wild-wood; for, long since, when certain lords of Black Ivo burned our manor, and our mother and sister and father therein, my twin brother and I had fashioned two axes such as few men might wield--this and another--and thus armed, took to the green where other wronged men joined us till we counted many a score tall fellows, lusty fighters all.
10064-8{_}3411{_}And many of Ivo's rogues we slew until of those knights and men-at-arms that burned our home there none remained save Red Pertolepe and Gui of Allerdale.
10064-8{_}3412{_}But in the green--love came--even to me--so I laid by mine axe and vengeance likewise and came to know happiness until--upon a day--they hanged my brother, and thereafter they slew--her--my wife and child--e'en as ye saw.
10064-8{_}3413{_}Then would I have joined the outlaws again.
10064-8{_}3414{_}But in my place they had set up one Tostig, a sturdy rogue and foul, who ruleth by might of arm and liveth but for plunder--and worse.
10064-8{_}3415{_}Him I would have fought, but upon that night I fell in with thee.
10064-8{_}3416{_}Thus, see you, though I am free of the wild, power with these outlaws have I none.
10064-8{_}3417{_}So, an I should bring thee into their secret lurking-place, Tostig would assuredly give thee to swift death, nor could I save thee--"  "Yet must I go," said Beltane, "since, while I live, vowed am I to free Pentavalon.
10064-8{_}3418{_}And what, think you, is Pentavalon?
10064-8{_}3419{_}'Tis not her hills and valleys, her towns and cities, but the folk that dwell therein; they, each one, man and woman and child, the rich and poor, the high and low, the evil and the good, aye, all those that live in outlawry--these are Pentavalon.
10064-8{_}3420{_}So now will I go unto these wild men, and once they follow my call, ne'er will I rest until they be free men every one.
10064-8{_}3421{_}Each blow they strike, the wounds they suffer, shall win them back to honourable life, to hearth and home--and thus shall they be free indeed.
10064-8{_}3422{_}So, Walkyn, bring me to the outlaws!"
10064-8{_}3423{_}Then stood Walkyn and looked upon Beltane 'neath heavy brows, nothing speaking, and turned him of a sudden and, striding forth of the cave, came back bearing another great axe.
10064-8{_}3424{_}"Lord," said he, "thy long sword is missing, methinks.
10064-8{_}3425{_}Take now this axe in place of it--'twas my brother's once.
10064-8{_}3426{_}See, I have kept it bright, for I loved him.
10064-8{_}3427{_}He was a man.
10064-8{_}3428{_}Yet man art thou also, worthy, methinks, and able to wield it.
10064-8{_}3429{_}Take it therefore, lord Duke that art my brother-in-arms; mayhap it shall aid thee to bring order in the wild-wood and win Pentavalon to freedom.
10064-8{_}3430{_}Howbeit, wheresoe'er thou dost go, e'en though it be to shame and failure, I am with thee!"
10064-8{_}3431{_}"And I!"
10064-8{_}3432{_}cried Giles, reaching for his bow.
10064-8{_}3433{_}"And I also!"
10064-8{_}3434{_}quoth Roger.
10064-8{_}3435{_}CHAPTER XXIX  HOW BELTANE SLEW TOSTIG AND SPAKE WITH THE WILD MEN   The sun was down what time they left the hill country and came out upon a wide heath void of trees and desolate, where was a wind cold and clammy to chill the flesh, where rank-growing rush and reed stirred fitfully, filling the dark with stealthy rustlings.
10064-8{_}3436{_}"Master," quoth Roger, shivering and glancing about him, "here is Hangstone Waste, and yonder the swamps of Hundleby Fen--you can smell them from here!
10064-8{_}3437{_}And 'tis an evil place, this, for 'tis said the souls of murdered folk do meet here betimes, and hold high revel when the moon be full.
10064-8{_}3438{_}Here, on wild nights witches and warlocks ride shrieking upon the wind, with goblins damned--"  "Ha, say ye so, good Roger?"
10064-8{_}3439{_}quoth the archer, "now the sweet Saint Giles go with us--amen!"
10064-8{_}3440{_}and he crossed himself devoutly.
10064-8{_}3441{_}So went they in silence awhile until they were come where the sedge grew thick and high above whispering ooze, and where trees, stunted and misshapen, lifted knotted arms in the gloom.
10064-8{_}3442{_}"Lord," spake Walkyn, his voice low and awe-struck, "here is the marsh, a place of death for them that know it not, where, an a man tread awry, is a quaking slime to suck him under.
10064-8{_}3443{_}Full many a man lieth 'neath the reeds yonder, for there is but one path, very narrow and winding-- follow close then, and step where I shall step."
10064-8{_}3444{_}"Aye, master," whispered Roger, "and look ye touch no tree as ye go; 'tis said they do grow from the bones of perished men, so touch them not lest some foul goblin blast thee."
10064-8{_}3445{_}So went they, following a narrow track that wound betwixt slow-stirring sedge, past trees huddled and distorted that seemed to writhe and shiver in the clammy air until, beyond the swamp, they came to a place of rocks where ragged crags loomed high and vague before them.
10064-8{_}3446{_}Now, all at once, Walkyn raised a warning hand, as from the shadow of those rocks, a hoarse voice challenged:  "Stand!"
10064-8{_}3447{_}cried the voice, "who goes?"
10064-8{_}3448{_}"What, and is it thou, rogue Perkyn?"
10064-8{_}3449{_}cried Walkyn, "art blind not to know me?"
10064-8{_}3450{_}"Aye," growled the voice, "but blind or no, I see others with thee."
10064-8{_}3451{_}"Good friends all!"
10064-8{_}3452{_}quoth Walkyn.
10064-8{_}3453{_}"Stand forth that I may see these friends o' thine!"
10064-8{_}3454{_}Drawing near, Beltane beheld a man in filthy rags who held a long bow in his hand with an arrow on the string, at sight of whom Roger muttered and Giles held his nose and spat.
10064-8{_}3455{_}"Aha," growled the man Perkyn, peering under his matted hair, "I like not the looks o' these friends o' thine--"  "Nor we thine, foul fellow," quoth Giles, and spat again whole-heartedly.
10064-8{_}3456{_}"How!"
10064-8{_}3457{_}cried Walkyn fiercely, "d'ye dare bid Walkyn stand, thou dog's meat?
10064-8{_}3458{_}Must I flesh mine axe on thy vile carcase?"
10064-8{_}3459{_}"Not till I feather a shaft in thee," growled Perkyn, "what would ye?"
10064-8{_}3460{_}"Speak with Eric o' the Noose."
10064-8{_}3461{_}"Aha, and what would ye with half-hung Eric, forsooth?
10064-8{_}3462{_}Tostig's our chief, and Tostig's man am I.
10064-8{_}3463{_}As for Eric--"  "Aye--aye, and what of Eric?"
10064-8{_}3464{_}spake a third voice--a soft voice and liquid, and a man stepped forth of the rocks with two other men at his heels.
10064-8{_}3465{_}"Now well met, Eric o' the Noose," quoth Walkyn.
10064-8{_}3466{_}"I bring promise of more booty, and mark this, Eric--I bring also him that you wot of."
10064-8{_}3467{_}Now hereupon the man Eric drew near, a broad-set man clad in skins and rusty mail who looked upon Beltane with head strangely askew, and touched a furtive hand to his battered head-piece.
10064-8{_}3468{_}"Ye come at an evil hour," said he, speaking low-voiced.
10064-8{_}3469{_}"Tostig holdeth high feast and revel, for to-day we took a rich booty at the ford beyond Bassingthorp--merchants out of Winisfarne, with pack-horses well laden--and there were women also--in especial, one very fair.
10064-8{_}3470{_}Her, Tostig bore hither.
10064-8{_}3471{_}But a while since, when he bade them bring her to him, behold she had stabbed herself with her bodkin.
10064-8{_}3472{_}So is she dead and Tostig raging.
10064-8{_}3473{_}Thus I say, ye come in an evil hour."
10064-8{_}3474{_}"Not so," answered Beltane.
10064-8{_}3475{_}"Methinks we come in good hour.
10064-8{_}3476{_}I am fain to speak with Tostig--come!"
10064-8{_}3477{_}and he stepped forward, but Eric caught him by the arm:  "Messire," said he soft-voiced, "yonder be over five score lusty fellows, fierce and doughty fighters all, that live but to do the will of Tostig and do proclaim him chief since he hath proved himself full oft mightiest of all--"  "Ah," nodded Beltane, "a strong man!"
10064-8{_}3478{_}"Beyond equal.
10064-8{_}3479{_}A fierce man that knoweth not mercy, swift to anger and joyful to slay at all times--"  "Why, look you," sighed Beltane, "neither am I a lamb.
10064-8{_}3480{_}Come, fain am I to speak with this Tostig."
10064-8{_}3481{_}A while stood Eric, head aslant, peering at Beltane, then, at a muttered word from Walkyn, he shook his head and beckoning the man Perkyn aside, led the way through a cleft in the rocks and up a precipitous path beyond; and as he went, Beltane saw him loosen sword in scabbard.
10064-8{_}3482{_}Ever as they clomb, the path grew more difficult, until at last they were come to a parapet or outwork with mantelets of osiers beyond, cunningly wrought, above which a pike-head glimmered and from beyond which a voice challenged them; but at a word from Eric the sentinel stood aside and behold, a narrow opening in the parapet through which they passed and so up another path defended by yet another parapet of osiers.
10064-8{_}3483{_}Now of a sudden, having climbed the ascent, Beltane paused and stood leaning upon his axe, for, from where he now stood, he looked down into a great hollow, green and rock-begirt, whose steep sides were shaded by trees and dense-growing bushes.
10064-8{_}3484{_}In the midst of this hollow a fire burned whose blaze showed many wild figures that sprawled round about in garments of leather and garments of skins; its ruddy light showed faces fierce and hairy; it glinted on rusty mail and flashed back from many a dinted head-piece and broad spear-head; and upon the air was the sound of noisy talk and boisterous laughter.
10064-8{_}3485{_}Through the midst of this great green hollow a stream wound that broadened out in one place into a still and sleepy pool upon whose placid surface stars seemed to float, a deep pool whereby was a tall tree.
10064-8{_}3486{_}Now beneath this tree, far removed from the fire, sat a great swarthy fellow, chin on fist, scowling down at that which lay at his feet, and of a sudden he spurned this still and silent shape with savage foot.
10064-8{_}3487{_}"Oswin!"
10064-8{_}3488{_}he cried, "Walcher!
10064-8{_}3489{_}Throw me this useless carrion into the pool!"
10064-8{_}3490{_}Hereupon came two sturdy rogues who, lifting the dead betwixt them, bore her to the edge of the silent pool.
10064-8{_}3491{_}Once they swung and twice, and lo, the floating stars shivered to a sullen splash, and subsiding, rippled softly to the reedy banks.
10064-8{_}3492{_}Slowly the swarthy giant rose and stood upon his legs, and Beltane knew him for the tallest man he had ever seen.
10064-8{_}3493{_}"Oswin," quoth he, and beckoned with his finger, "Oswin, did I not bid thee keep watch upon yon dainty light o' love?"
10064-8{_}3494{_}Now meeting the speaker's baleful eye, the man Oswin sprang back, striving to draw sword, but even so an iron hand was about his throat, he was lifted by a mighty arm that held him a while choking and kicking above the silent pool until he had gasped and kicked his life out 'midst shouts and gibes and hoarse laughter; thereafter again the sullen waters quivered, were still, and Tostig stood, empty-handed, frowning down at those floating stars.
10064-8{_}3495{_}Then Beltane leapt down into the hollow and strode swift-footed, nor stayed until he stood face to face with Tostig beside the sullen pool.
10064-8{_}3496{_}But swift as he had come, Roger had followed, and now stood to his back, hand on sword.
10064-8{_}3497{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}3498{_}quoth Tostig in staring amaze, and stood a while eying Beltane with hungry gaze.
10064-8{_}3499{_}"By Thor!"
10064-8{_}3500{_}said he, "but 'tis a good armour and should fit me well.
10064-8{_}3501{_}Off with it--off, I am Tostig!"
10064-8{_}3502{_}So saying, he drew a slow pace nearer, his teeth agleam, his great hands opening and shutting, whereat out leapt Roger's blade; but now the outlaws came running to throng about them, shouting and jostling one another, and brandishing their weapons yet striking no blow, waiting gleefully for what might befall; and ever Beltane looked upon Tostig, and Tostig, assured and confident, smiled grimly upon Beltane until the ragged throng about them, watching eager-eyed, grew hushed and still.
10064-8{_}3503{_}Then Beltane spake:  "Put up thy sword, Roger," said he, "in very truth this Tostig is a foul thing and should not die by thy good steel--so put up thy sword, Roger."
10064-8{_}3504{_}And now, no man spake or moved, but all stood rigid and scarce breathing, waiting for the end.
10064-8{_}3505{_}For Tostig, smiling no more, stood agape as one that doubts his senses, then laughed he loud and long, and turned as if to reach his sword that leaned against the tree and, in that instant, sprang straight for Beltane's throat, his griping hands outstretched; but swift as he, Beltane, letting fall his axe, slipped aside and smote with mailed fist, and as Tostig reeled from the blow, closed with and caught him in a deadly wrestling hold, for all men might see Beltane had locked one arm 'neath Tostig's bearded chin and that Tostig's shaggy head was bending slowly backwards.
10064-8{_}3506{_}Then the outlaws surged closer, a dark, menacing ring where steel flickered; but lo!
10064-8{_}3507{_}to Roger's right hand sprang Walkyn, gripping his axe, and upon his left came Giles, his long-bow poised, a shaft upon the string; so stood the three alert and watchful, eager for fight, what time the struggle waxed ever more fierce and deadly.
10064-8{_}3508{_}To and fro the wrestlers swayed, locked in vicious grapple, grimly silent save for the dull trampling of their feet upon the moss and the gasp and hiss of panting breaths; writhing and twisting, stumbling and slipping, or suddenly still with feet that gripped the sod, with bulging muscles, swelled and rigid, that cracked beneath the strain, while eye glared death to eye.
10064-8{_}3509{_}But Beltane's iron fingers were fast locked, and little by little, slow but sure, Tostig's swart head was tilting up and back, further and further, until his forked beard pointed upwards--until, of a sudden, there brake from his writhen lips a cry, loud and shrill that sank to groan and ended in a sound--a faint sound, soft and sudden.
10064-8{_}3510{_}But now, behold, Tostig's head swayed loosely backwards behind his shoulders, his knees sagged, his great arms loosed their hold: then, or he could fall, Beltane stooped beneath and putting forth all his strength, raised him high above his head, and panting, groaning with the strain, turned and hurled dead Tostig down into the pool whose sullen waters leapt to a mighty splash, and presently subsiding, whispered softly in the reeds; and for a while no man stirred or spoke, only Beltane stood upon the marge and panted.
10064-8{_}3511{_}Then turned he to the outlaws, and catching up his axe therewith pointed downwards to that stilly pool whose placid waters seemed to hold nought but a glory of floating stars.
10064-8{_}3512{_}"Behold," he panted, "here was an evil man--a menace to well-being, wherefore is he dead.
10064-8{_}3513{_}But as for ye, come tell me--how long will ye be slaves?"
10064-8{_}3514{_}Hereupon rose a hoarse murmur that grew and grew--Then stood the man Perkyn forward, and scowling, pointed at Beltane with his spear.
10064-8{_}3515{_}"Comrades!"
10064-8{_}3516{_}he cried, "he hath slain Tostig!
10064-8{_}3517{_}He hath murdered our leader--come now, let us slay him!"
10064-8{_}3518{_}and speaking, he leapt at Beltane with levelled spear, but quick as he leapt, so leapt Walkyn, his long arms rose and fell, and thereafter, setting his foot upon Perkyn's body, he shook his bloody axe in the scowling faces of the outlaws.
10064-8{_}3519{_}"Back, fools!"
10064-8{_}3520{_}he cried, "have ye no eyes?
10064-8{_}3521{_}See ye not 'tis he of whom I spake--he that burned Belsaye gallows and brake ope the dungeon of Belsaye--that is friend to all distressed folk and broken men; know ye not Beltane the Duke?
10064-8{_}3522{_}Hear him, ye fools, hear him!"
10064-8{_}3523{_}Hereupon the outlaws stared upon Beltane and upon each other, and fumbled with their weapons as men that knew not their own minds, while Beltane, wiping sweat from him, leaned upon his axe and panted, with the three at his elbow alert and watchful, eager for fight; but Perkyn lay where he had fallen, very still and with his face hidden in the grass.
10064-8{_}3524{_}Of a sudden, Beltane laid by his axe and reached out his hands.
10064-8{_}3525{_}"Brothers," said he, "how long will ye be slaves?"
10064-8{_}3526{_}"Slaves, forsooth?"
10064-8{_}3527{_}cried one, "slaves are we to no man--here within the green none dare gainsay us--we be free men, one and all.
10064-8{_}3528{_}Is't not so, comrades?"
10064-8{_}3529{_}"Aye!
10064-8{_}3530{_}Aye!"
10064-8{_}3531{_}roared a hundred voices.
10064-8{_}3532{_}"Free?"
10064-8{_}3533{_}quoth Beltane, "free?
10064-8{_}3534{_}Aye, free to wander hither and thither, hiding forever within the wilderness, living ever in awe and dread lest ye die in a noose.
10064-8{_}3535{_}Free to go in rags, to live like beasts, to die unpitied and be thrown into a hole, or left to rot i' the sun--call ye this freedom, forsooth?
10064-8{_}3536{_}Hath none among ye desire for hearth and home, for wife and child--are ye become so akin to beasts indeed?"
10064-8{_}3537{_}Now hereupon, divers muttered in their beards and others looked askance on one another.
10064-8{_}3538{_}Then spake the man Eric, of the wry neck.

10064-8{_}3540{_}Say now?"
10064-8{_}3541{_}Then spake Beltane on this wise:  "All ye that have suffered wrong, all ye that be broken men--hearken!
10064-8{_}3542{_}Life is short and quick to escape a man, yet do all men cherish it, and to what end?
10064-8{_}3543{_}What seek ye of life--is it arms, is it riches?
10064-8{_}3544{_}Go with me and I will teach ye how they shall be come by.
10064-8{_}3545{_}Are ye heavy-hearted by reason of your wrongs--of bitter shame wrought upon the weak and innocent?
10064-8{_}3546{_}Seek ye vengeance?--would ye see tyrants die?--seek ye their blood, forsooth?
10064-8{_}3547{_}Then follow me!"
10064-8{_}3548{_}Now at this the outlaws began to murmur among themselves, wagging their heads one to another and voicing their grievances thus:  "They cut off mine ears for resisting my lord's taxes, and for this I would have justice!"
10064-8{_}3549{_}"They burned me in the hand for striking my lord's hunting dog!"
10064-8{_}3550{_}"I had a wife once, and she was young and fair; so my lord's son took her and thereafter gave her for sport among his huntsmen, whereof she died--and for this would I have vengeance!"
10064-8{_}3551{_}"They burned my home, and therein wife and child--and for this would I have vengeance!"
10064-8{_}3552{_}"They cut off my brother's hands!"
10064-8{_}3553{_}"They put out my father's eyes!"
10064-8{_}3554{_}Quoth Eric:  "And me they sought to hang to mine own roof-tree!--behold this crooked neck o' mine--so am I Eric o' the Noose.
10064-8{_}3555{_}Each one of us hath suffered wrong, great or little, so live we outlaws in the green, lawless men in lawless times, seeking ever vengeance for our wrongs.
10064-8{_}3556{_}Who then shall bring us to our desire, how shall our grievous wrongs be righted?
10064-8{_}3557{_}An we follow, whither would'st thou lead us?"
10064-8{_}3558{_}"By dangerous ways," answered Beltane, "through fire and battle.
10064-8{_}3559{_}But by fire men are purged, and by battle wrongs may be done away.
10064-8{_}3560{_}An ye follow, 'tis like some of us shall die, but by such death our brethren shall win to honour, and home, and happiness, for happiness is all men's birthright.
10064-8{_}3561{_}Ye are but a wild, unordered rabble, yet are ye men!
10064-8{_}3562{_}'Tis true ye are ill-armed and ragged, yet is your cause a just one.
10064-8{_}3563{_}Ye bear weapons and have arms to smite--why then lurk ye here within the wild-wood?
10064-8{_}3564{_}Will not fire burn?
10064-8{_}3565{_}Will not steel cut?
10064-8{_}3566{_}He that is not coward, let him follow me!"
10064-8{_}3567{_}"Aye," cried a score of harsh voices, "but whither--whither?"
10064-8{_}3568{_}Quoth Beltane:  "Be there many among ye that know Sir Pertolepe the Red?"

10064-8{_}3570{_}"Ah--we know him--the Red Wolf--we know him--ah!"

10064-8{_}3572{_}Will not fire burn?
10064-8{_}3573{_}Arise, I say, rise up and follow me.
10064-8{_}3574{_}So will we smite Tyranny this night and ere the dawn Garthlaxton shall be ablaze!"
10064-8{_}3575{_}"Garthlaxton!"
10064-8{_}3576{_}cried Eric, "Garthlaxton!"
10064-8{_}3577{_}and thereafter all men stared on Beltane as one that is mad.
10064-8{_}3578{_}"Look now," said Beltane, "Sir Pertolepe hath ridden forth with all his company to join Black Ivo's banner.
10064-8{_}3579{_}Thus, within Garthlaxton his men be few; moreover I know a secret way beneath the wall.
10064-8{_}3580{_}Well, is't enough?
10064-8{_}3581{_}Who among ye will follow, and smite for freedom and Pentavalon?"
10064-8{_}3582{_}"That will I!"
10064-8{_}3583{_}cried Eric, falling upon his knee.
10064-8{_}3584{_}"And I!
10064-8{_}3585{_}And I!"
10064-8{_}3586{_}cried others, and so came they to crowd eagerly about Beltane, to touch his hand or the links of his bright mail.
10064-8{_}3587{_}"Lead us!"
10064-8{_}3588{_}they cried, "come--lead us!"
10064-8{_}3589{_}"Nay first--hearken!
10064-8{_}3590{_}From henceforth outlaws are ye none.
10064-8{_}3591{_}Come now, one and all, draw, and swear me on your swords:--To make your strength a shelter to the weak; to smite henceforth but in honourable cause for freedom, for justice and Pentavalon--swear me upon your swords to abide by this oath, and to him that breaks it--Death.
10064-8{_}3592{_}Swear!"
10064-8{_}3593{_}So there upon their knees with gleaming swords uplifted, these wild men swore the oath.
10064-8{_}3594{_}Then up sprang Walkyn, pointing to Beltane with his axe.
10064-8{_}3595{_}"Brothers!"
10064-8{_}3596{_}he cried, "behold a man that doeth such deeds as no man ever did--that burned the gallows--burst ope the dungeon of Belsaye and slew Tostig the mighty with naked hands!
10064-8{_}3597{_}Behold Beltane the Duke!
10064-8{_}3598{_}Is he not worthy to be our leader--shall we not follow him?"
10064-8{_}3599{_}Then came a roar of voices:  "Aye--let us follow--let us follow!"
10064-8{_}3600{_}"On, then!"
10064-8{_}3601{_}cried Walkyn, his glittering axe aloft.
10064-8{_}3602{_}"To Garthlaxton!"
10064-8{_}3603{_}Then from an hundred brawny throats a roar went up to heaven, a cry that hissed through clenched teeth and rang from eager lips, wilder, fiercer than before.
10064-8{_}3604{_}And the cry was:--  "Garthlaxton!"
10064-8{_}3605{_}CHAPTER XXX  HOW THEY SMOTE GARTHLAXTON   It was in the cold, still hour 'twixt night and dawn that Beltane halted his wild company upon the edge of the forest where ran a water-brook gurgling softly in the dark; here did he set divers eager fellows to fell a tree and thereafter to lop away branch and twig, and so, bidding them wait, stole forward alone.
10064-8{_}3606{_}Soon before him rose Garthlaxton, frowning blacker than the night, a gloom of tower and turret, of massy wall and battlement, its mighty keep rising stark and grim against a faint light of stars.
10064-8{_}3607{_}Now as he stood to scan with purposeful eye donjon and bartizan, merlon and arrow-slit for gleam of light, for glint of mail or pike-head, he grew aware of a sound hard by, yet very faint and sweet, that came and went--a small and silvery chime he could by no means account for.
10064-8{_}3608{_}So crept he near and nearer, quick-eyed and with ears on the stretch till he was stayed by the broad, sluggish waters of the moat; and thus, he presently espied something that moved in the gloom high above the great gateway, something that stirred, pendulous, in the cold-breathing air of coming dawn.
10064-8{_}3609{_}Now as he peered upward through the gloom, came the wind, colder, stronger than before--a chill and ghostly wind that flapped the heavy folds of his mantle, that sighed forlornly in the woods afar, and softly smote the misty, jingling thing above--swayed it--swung it out from the denser shadows of scowling battlement so that Beltane could see at last, and seeing--started back faint and sick, his flesh a-creep, his breath in check 'twixt pale and rigid lips.
10064-8{_}3610{_}And beholding what manner of thing this was, he fell upon his knees with head bowed low yet spake no prayer, only his hands gripped fiercely upon his axe; while to and fro in the dark above, that awful shape turned and swung-- its flaunting cock's-comb dreadfully awry, its motley stained and rent --a wretched thing, twisted and torn, a thing of blasting horror.
10064-8{_}3611{_}And ever as it swung upon the air, it rang a chime upon its little, silver bells; a merry chime and mocking, that seemed to gibe at coming day.
10064-8{_}3612{_}Now in a while, looking upon that awful, dim-seen shape, Beltane spake low-voiced.
10064-8{_}3613{_}"O Beda!"
10064-8{_}3614{_}he whispered, "O manly heart hid 'neath a Fool's disguise!
10064-8{_}3615{_}O Fool, that now art wiser than the wisest!
10064-8{_}3616{_}Thy pains and sorrows have lifted thee to heaven, methinks, and freed now of thy foolish clay thou dost walk with angels and look within the face of God!
10064-8{_}3617{_}But, by thine agonies endured, now do I swear this night to raise to thy poor Fool's body a pyre fit for the flesh of kings!"
10064-8{_}3618{_}Then Beltane arose and lifting high his axe, shook it against Garthlaxton's frowning might, where was neither glint of armour nor gleam of pike-head, and turning, hasted back to that dark and silent company which, at his word, rose up from brake and fern and thicket, and followed whither he led, a long line, soundless and phantom-like within a phantom world, where a grey mist swirled and drifted in the death-cold air of dawn.
10064-8{_}3619{_}Swift and silent they followed him, these wild men, with fierce eyes and scowling faces all set toward that mighty keep that loomed high against the glimmering stars.
10064-8{_}3620{_}Axe and bow, sword and pike and gisarm, in rusty mail, in rags of leather and skins, they crept from bush to bush, from tree to tree, till they were come to that little pool wherein Beltane had bathed him aforetime in the dawn.
10064-8{_}3621{_}Here they halted what time Beltane sought to and fro along the bank of the stream, until at last, within a screen of leaves and vines he found the narrow opening he sought.
10064-8{_}3622{_}Then turned he and beckoned those ghostly, silent shapes about him, and speaking quick and low, counselled them thus:  "Look now, this secret burrow leadeth under the foundations of the keep; thus, so soon as we be in, let Walkyn and Giles with fifty men haste to smite all within the gate-house, then up with portcullis and down with drawbridge and over into the barbican there to lie in ambush, what time Roger and I, with Eric here and the fifty and five, shall fire the keep and, hid within the dark, raise a mighty outcry, that those within the keep and they that garrison the castle, roused by the fire and our shout, shall issue out amazed.
10064-8{_}3623{_}So will we fall upon them and they, taken by surprise, shall seek to escape us by the gate.
10064-8{_}3624{_}Then, Walkyn, sally ye out of the barbican and smite them at the drawbridge, so shall we have them front and rear.
10064-8{_}3625{_}How think you?
10064-8{_}3626{_}Is it agreed?"
10064-8{_}3627{_}"Agreed!
10064-8{_}3628{_}agreed!"
10064-8{_}3629{_}came the gruff and whispered chorus.
10064-8{_}3630{_}"Then last--and mark this well each one--till that I give the word, let no man speak!
10064-8{_}3631{_}Let death be swift, but let it be silent."
10064-8{_}3632{_}Then, having drawn his mail-hood about his face and laced it close, Beltane caught up his axe and stepped into the tunnel.
10064-8{_}3633{_}There he kindled a torch of pine and stooping 'neath the low roof, went on before.
10064-8{_}3634{_}One by one the others followed, Roger and Giles, Walkyn and Eric bearing the heavy log upon their shoulders, and behind them axe and bow, sword and pike and gisarm, a wild company in garments of leather and garments of skins, soft-treading and silent as ghosts--yet purposeful ghosts withal.
10064-8{_}3635{_}Soon came they to the iron door and Beltane stood aside, whereon the mighty four, bending brawny shoulders, swung the log crashing against the iron; thrice and four times smote they, might and main, ere rusted bolt and rivet gave beneath the battery and the door swung wide.
10064-8{_}3636{_}Down went the log, and ready steel flashed as Beltane strode on, his torch aflare, 'twixt oozing walls, up steps of stone that yet were slimy to the tread, on and up by winding passage and steep-climbing stairway, until they came where was a parting of the ways--the first still ascending, the second leading off at a sharp angle.
10064-8{_}3637{_}Here Beltane paused in doubt, and bidding the others halt, followed the second passage until he was come to a narrow flight of steps that rose to the stone roof above.
10064-8{_}3638{_}But here, in the wall beside the steps, he beheld a rusty iron lever, and reaching up, he bore upon the lever and lo!
10064-8{_}3639{_}the flagstone above the steps reared itself on end and showed a square of gloom beyond.
10064-8{_}3640{_}Then went Beltane and signalled to the others; so, one by one, they followed him up through the opening into that same gloomy chamber where he had lain in bonds and hearkened to wails of torment; but now the place was bare and empty and the door stood ajar.
10064-8{_}3641{_}So came Beltane thither, bearing the torch, and stepped softly into the room beyond, a wide room, arras-hung and richly furnished, and looking around upon the voluptuous luxury of gilded couch and wide, soft bed, Beltane frowned suddenly upon a woman's dainty, broidered shoe.
10064-8{_}3642{_}"Roger," he whispered, "what place is this?"
10064-8{_}3643{_}"'Tis Red Pertolepe's bed-chamber, master."
10064-8{_}3644{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}3645{_}sighed Beltane, "'tis rank of him, methinks--lead on, Roger, go you and Walkyn before them in the dark, and wait for me in the bailey."
10064-8{_}3646{_}One by one, the wild company went by Beltane, fierce-eyed and stealthy, until there none remained save Giles, who, leaning upon his bow, looked with yearning eyes upon the costly splendour.
10064-8{_}3647{_}"Aha," he whispered, "a pretty nest, tall brother.
10064-8{_}3648{_}I'll warrant ye full many a fair white dove hath beat her tender pinions--"  "Come!"
10064-8{_}3649{_}said Beltane, and speaking, reached out his torch to bed-alcove and tapestried wall; and immediately silk and arras went up in a puff of flame--a leaping fire, yellow-tongued, that licked at gilded roof-beam and carven screen and panel.
10064-8{_}3650{_}"Brother!"
10064-8{_}3651{_}whispered Giles, "O brother, 'tis a sin, methinks, to lose so much good booty.
10064-8{_}3652{_}That coffer, now--Ha!"
10064-8{_}3653{_}With the cry the archer leapt out through the tapestried doorway.
10064-8{_}3654{_}Came the ring of steel, a heavy fall, and thereafter a shriek that rang and echoed far and near ere it sank to a silence wherein a voice whispered:  "Quick, brother--the besotted fools stir at last--away!"
10064-8{_}3655{_}Then, o'erleaping that which sprawled behind the curtain, Beltane sped along a passage and down a winding stair, yet pausing, ever and anon, with flaring torch: and ever small fires waxed behind him.
10064-8{_}3656{_}So came he at last to the sally-port and hurling the blazing torch behind him, closed the heavy door.
10064-8{_}3657{_}And now, standing upon the platform, he looked down into the inner bailey.
10064-8{_}3658{_}Dawn was at hand, a glimmering mist wherein vague forms moved, what time Walkyn, looming ghostly and gigantic in the mist, mustered his silent, ghostly company ere, lifting his axe, he turned and vanished, his fifty phantoms at his heels.
10064-8{_}3659{_}Now glancing upward at the rugged face of the keep, Beltane beheld thin wisps of smoke that curled from every arrow-slit, slow-wreathing spirals growing ever denser ere they vanished in the clammy mists of dawn, while from within a muffled clamour rose--low and inarticulate yet full of terror.
10064-8{_}3660{_}Then Beltane strode down the zig-zag stair and came forthright upon Roger, pale and anxious, who yet greeted him in joyous whisper:  "Master, I began to fear for thee.
10064-8{_}3661{_}What now?"
10064-8{_}3662{_}"To the arch of the parapet yonder.
10064-8{_}3663{_}Let each man crouch there in the gloom, nor stir until I give word."
10064-8{_}3664{_}Now as they crouched thus, with weapons tight-gripped and eyes that glared upon the coming day, a sudden trumpet brayed alarm upon the battlements--shouts were heard far and near, and a running of mailed feet; steel clashed, the great castle, waking at last, was all astir about them and full of sudden bustle and tumult.
10064-8{_}3665{_}And ever the clamour of voices waxed upon the misty air from hurrying groups dim-seen that flitted by, arming as they ran, and ever the fifty and five, crouching in the dark, impatient for the sign, watched Beltane--his firm-set lip, his frowning brow; and ever from belching arrow-slit the curling smoke-wreaths waxed blacker and more dense.
10064-8{_}3666{_}Of a sudden, out from the narrow sally-port burst a huddle of choking men, whose gasping cries pierced high above the clamour:  "Fire!
10064-8{_}3667{_}Fire!
10064-8{_}3668{_}Sir Fulk is slain!
10064-8{_}3669{_}Sir Fulk lieth death-smitten!
10064-8{_}3670{_}Fire!"
10064-8{_}3671{_}From near and far men came running--men affrighted and dazed with sleep, a pushing, jostling, unordered throng, and the air hummed with the babel of their voices.
10064-8{_}3672{_}And now at last--up sprang Beltane, his mittened hand aloft.
10064-8{_}3673{_}"Arise!"
10064-8{_}3674{_}he cried, "Arise and smite for Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}3675{_}And from the gloom behind him a hoarse roar went up: "Arise!
10064-8{_}3676{_}Arise--Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}3677{_}Then, while yet the war-cry thundered in the air, they swept down on that disordered press, and the bailey rang and echoed with the fell sounds of a close-locked, reeling battle; a hateful din of hoarse shouting, of shrieks and cries and clashing steel.
10064-8{_}3678{_}Axe and spear, sword and pike and gisarm smote and thrust and swayed; stumbling feet spurned and trampled yielding forms that writhed, groaning, beneath the press; faces glared at faces haggard with the dawn, while to and fro, through swirling mist and acrid smoke, the battle rocked and swayed.
10064-8{_}3679{_}But now the press thinned out, broke and yielded before Beltane's whirling axe, and turning, he found Roger beside him all a-sweat and direfully besplashed, his mailed breast heaving as he leaned gasping upon a broadsword red from point to hilt.
10064-8{_}3680{_}"Ha, master!"
10064-8{_}3681{_}he panted,--"'tis done already--see, they break and fly!"
10064-8{_}3682{_}"On!"
10064-8{_}3683{_}cried Beltane, "on--pursue!
10064-8{_}3684{_}pursue!
10064-8{_}3685{_}after them to the gate!"
10064-8{_}3686{_}With axe and spear, with sword and pike and gisarm they smote the fugitives across the wide space of the outer bailey, under the narrow arch of the gate-house and out upon the drawbridge beyond.
10064-8{_}3687{_}But here, of a sudden, the fugitives checked their flight as out from the barbican Walkyn leapt, brandishing his axe, and with the fifty at his back.
10064-8{_}3688{_}So there, upon the bridge, the fight raged fiercer than before; men smote and died, until of Sir Pertolepe's garrison there none remained save they that littered that narrow causeway.
10064-8{_}3689{_}"Now by the good Saint Giles--my patron saint," gasped Giles, wiping the sweat from him, "here was a good and sweet affray, tall brother--a very proper fight, _pugnus et calcibus_--while it lasted--"  "Aye," growled Walkyn, spurning a smitten wretch down into the moat, "'twas ended too soon!
10064-8{_}3690{_}Be these all in faith, lord?"
10064-8{_}3691{_}But now upon the air rose shrill cries and piercing screams that seemed to split the dawn.
10064-8{_}3692{_}"O--women!"
10064-8{_}3693{_}cried Giles, and forthwith cleansed and sheathed his sword and fell to twirling his beard.
10064-8{_}3694{_}"Aha, the women!"
10064-8{_}3695{_}cried a ragged fellow, turning about, "'tis their turn--let us to the women--" But a strong hand caught and set him aside and Beltane strode on before them all, treading swift and light until he was come to the chapel that stood beside the banqueting hall.
10064-8{_}3696{_}And here he beheld many women, young and fair for the most part, huddled about the high altar or struggling in the ragged arms that grasped them.
10064-8{_}3697{_}Now did they (these poor souls) looking up, behold one in knightly mail stained and foul with battle, yet very young and comely of face, who leaned him upon a mighty, blood-stained axe and scowled 'neath frowning brows.
10064-8{_}3698{_}Yet his frown was not for them, nor did his blue eyes pause at any one of them, whereat hope grew within them and with white hands outstretched they implored his pity.
10064-8{_}3699{_}"Men of Pentavalon," said he, "as men this night have ye fought in goodly cause.
10064-8{_}3700{_}Will ye now forget your manhood and new-found honour, ye that did swear to me upon your swords?
10064-8{_}3701{_}Come, loose me these women!"
10064-8{_}3702{_}"Not so," cried one, a great, red-headed rogue, "we have fought to pleasure thee--now is our turn--"  "Loose me these women!"
10064-8{_}3703{_}cried Beltane, his blue eyes fierce.
10064-8{_}3704{_}"Nay, these be our booty, and no man shall gainsay us.
10064-8{_}3705{_}How think ye, comrades?"
10064-8{_}3706{_}Now Beltane smiled upon this red-haired knave and, smiling, drew a slow pace nearer, the great axe a-swing in his mailed hand.
10064-8{_}3707{_}"Fellow," quoth he, kind-voiced, "get thee out now, lest I slay thee!"
10064-8{_}3708{_}Awhile the fellow glared upon Beltane, beheld his smiling look and deadly eye, and slowly loosing his trembling captive, turned and strode out, muttering as he went.
10064-8{_}3709{_}Then spake Beltane to the shrinking women, yet even so his blue eyes looked upon none of them.
10064-8{_}3710{_}Quoth he:  "Ye are free to go whither ye will.
10064-8{_}3711{_}Take what ye will, none shall gainsay you, but get you gone within this hour, for in the hour Garthlaxton shall be no more."
10064-8{_}3712{_}Then beckoning Walkyn he bade him choose six men, and turning to the women--  "These honourable men shall bring you safe upon your way--haste you to be gone.
10064-8{_}3713{_}And should any ask how Garthlaxton fell, say, 'twas by the hand of God, as a sure and certain sign that Pentavalon shall yet arise to smite evil from her borders.
10064-8{_}3714{_}Say also that he that spake you this was one Beltane, son of Beltane the Strong, heretofore Duke of Pentavalon."
10064-8{_}3715{_}Thus said Beltane unto these women, his brows knit, and with eyes that looked aside from each and every, and so went forth of the chapel.
10064-8{_}3716{_}CHAPTER XXXI  HOW GILES MADE A MERRY SONG   Morning, young and fragrant, bedecked and brave with gems of dewy fire; a blithe morning, wherein trees stirred whispering and new-waked birds piped joyous welcome to the sun, whose level, far-flung beams filled the world with glory save where, far to the south, a pillar of smoke rose upon the stilly air, huge, awful, and black as sin--a writhing column shot with flame that went up high as heaven.
10064-8{_}3717{_}"O merry, aye merry, right merry I'll be,    To live and to love 'neath the merry green tree,    Nor the rain, nor the sleet,    Nor the cold, nor the heat,    I'll mind, if my love will come thither to me."
10064-8{_}3718{_}Sang Giles, a sprig of wild flowers a-dance in his new-gotten, gleaming bascinet, his long-bow upon his mailed shoulder, and, strapped to his wide back, a misshapen bundle that clinked melodiously with every swinging stride; and, while he sang, the ragged rogues about him ceased their noise and ribaldry to hearken in delight, and when he paused, cried out amain for more.
10064-8{_}3719{_}Whereupon Giles, nothing loth, brake forth afresh:    "O when is the time a maid to kiss,    Tell me this, ah, tell me this?
10064-8{_}3720{_}'Tis when the day is new begun,    'Tis to the setting of the sun,    Is time for kissing ever done?
10064-8{_}3721{_}Tell me this, ah, tell me this?"
10064-8{_}3722{_}Thus blithely sang Giles the Archer, above the tramp and jingle of the many pack-horses, until, being come to the top of a hill, he stood aside to let the ragged files swing by and stayed to look back at Garthlaxton Keep.
10064-8{_}3723{_}Now as he stood thus, beholding that mighty flame, Walkyn and Roger paused beside him, and stood to scowl upon the fire with never a word betwixt them.
10064-8{_}3724{_}"How now," cried Giles, "art in the doleful dumps forsooth on so blithe a morn, with two-score pack-horses heavy with booty--and Garthlaxton aflame yonder?
10064-8{_}3725{_}Aha, 'tis a rare blaze yon, a fire shall warm the heart of many a sorry wretch, methinks."
10064-8{_}3726{_}"Truly," nodded Roger, "I have seen yon flaming keep hung round with hanged men ere now--and in the dungeons beneath--I have seen--God forgive me, what I have seen!
10064-8{_}3727{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}3728{_}Burn, accursed walls, burn!
10064-8{_}3729{_}Full many shall rejoice in thy ruin, as I do--lorn women and fatherless children--fair women ravished of life and honour!"
10064-8{_}3730{_}"Aye," cried Giles, "and lovely ladies brought to shame!
10064-8{_}3731{_}So, Garthlaxton--smoke!"
10064-8{_}3732{_}"And," quoth frowning Walkyn, "I would that Pertolepe's rank carcass smoked with thee!"
10064-8{_}3733{_}"Content you, my gentle Walkyn," nodded the archer, "hell-fire shall have him yet, and groweth ever hotter against the day--content you.
10064-8{_}3734{_}So away with melancholy, be blithe and merry as I am and the sweet-voiced throstles yonder--the wanton rogues!
10064-8{_}3735{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}3736{_}by Saint Giles!
10064-8{_}3737{_}See where our youthful, god-like brother rideth, his brow as gloomy as his hair is bright--"  "Ah," muttered Roger, "he grieveth yet for Beda the Jester--and he but a Fool!"
10064-8{_}3738{_}"Yet a man-like fool, methinks!"
10064-8{_}3739{_}quoth the archer.
10064-8{_}3740{_}"But for our tall brother now, he is changed these latter days: he groweth harsh, methinks, and something ungentle at times."
10064-8{_}3741{_}And Giles thoughtfully touched his arm with tentative fingers.
10064-8{_}3742{_}"Why, the torment is apt to change a man," said Walkyn, grim-smiling.
10064-8{_}3743{_}"I have tried it and I know."
10064-8{_}3744{_}Now hereupon Giles fell to whistling, Walkyn to silence and Roger to scowling; oft looking back, jealous-eyed, to where Beltane rode a black war-horse, his mail-coif thrown back, his chin upon his breast, his eyes gloomy and wistful; and as often as he looked, Roger sighed amain.
10064-8{_}3745{_}Whereat at last the archer cried:  "Good lack, Roger, and wherefore puff ye so?
10064-8{_}3746{_}Why glower ye, man, and snort?"
10064-8{_}3747{_}"Snort thyself!"
10064-8{_}3748{_}growled Roger.
10064-8{_}3749{_}"Nay, I had rather talk."
10064-8{_}3750{_}"I had rather be silent."
10064-8{_}3751{_}"Excellent, Roger; so will I talk for thee and me.
10064-8{_}3752{_}First will I show three excellent reasons for happiness--_videlicit:_ the birds sing, I talk, and Garthlaxton burns.--"  "I would thou did'st burn with it," growled Roger.
10064-8{_}3753{_}"But here is a deed shall live when thou and I are dust, archer!"
10064-8{_}3754{_}"Verily, good Roger, for here and now will I make a song on't for souls unborn to sing--a good song with a lilt to trip it lightly on the tongue, as thus:    "How Beltane burned Garthlaxton low    With lusty Giles, whose good yew bow    Sped many a caitiff rogue, I trow,       _Dixit_!"
10064-8{_}3755{_}"How!"
10064-8{_}3756{_}exclaimed Roger, "here be two whole lines to thy knavish self and but one to our master?"
10064-8{_}3757{_}"Aye," grumbled Walkyn, "and what of Roger?--what of me?--we were there also, methinks?"
10064-8{_}3758{_}"Nay, show patience," said Giles, "we will amend that in the next triplet, thus:    "There Roger fought, and Walkyn too,    And Giles that bare the bow of yew;    O swift and strong his arrows flew,       _Dixit_!"
10064-8{_}3759{_}"How think ye of that, now?"
10064-8{_}3760{_}"I think, here is too much Giles," said Roger.
10064-8{_}3761{_}"Forsooth, and say ye so indeed?
10064-8{_}3762{_}Let us then to another verse:    "Walkyn a mighty axe did sway,    Black Roger's sword some few did slay,    Yet Giles slew many more than they,       _Dixit_!"
10064-8{_}3763{_}"Here now, we have each one his line apiece, which is fair--and the lines trip it commendingly, how think ye?"
10064-8{_}3764{_}"I think it a lie!"
10064-8{_}3765{_}growled Roger.
10064-8{_}3766{_}"Aye me!"
10064-8{_}3767{_}sighed the archer, "thou'rt fasting, Rogerkin, and an empty belly ever giveth thee an ill tongue.
10064-8{_}3768{_}Yet for thy behoof my song shall be ended, thus:    "They gave Garthlaxton to the flame,    Be glory to Duke Beltane's name,    And unto lusty Giles the same,       _Dixit_!"
10064-8{_}3769{_}"_Par Dex!_" he broke off, "here is a right good song for thee, trolled forth upon this balmy-breathing morn sweet as any merle; a song for thee and me to sing to our children one day, mayhap--so come, rejoice, my rueful Rogerkin--smile, for to-day I sing and Garthlaxton is ablaze."
10064-8{_}3770{_}"And my master grieveth for a Fool!"
10064-8{_}3771{_}growled sulky Roger, "and twenty and two good men slain."
10064-8{_}3772{_}"Why, see you, Roger, here is good cause for rejoicing also, for, our youthful Ajax grieving for a dead Fool, it standeth to reason he shall better love a live one--and thou wert ever a fool, Roger--so born and so bred.
10064-8{_}3773{_}As for our comrades slain, take ye comfort in this, we shall divide their share of plunder, and in this thought is a world of solace.
10064-8{_}3774{_}Remembering the which, I gathered unto myself divers pretty toys--you shall hear them sweetly a-jingle in my fardel here.
10064-8{_}3775{_}As, item: a silver crucifix, very artificially wrought and set with divers gems-- a pretty piece!
10064-8{_}3776{_}Item: a golden girdle from the East--very sweet and rare.
10064-8{_}3777{_}Item: four silver candlesticks--heavy, Roger!
10064-8{_}3778{_}Item: a gold hilted dagger--a notable trinket.
10064-8{_}3779{_}Item--"  A sudden shout from the vanward, a crashing in the underbrush beside the way, a shrill cry, and three or four of Eric's ragged rogues appeared dragging a woman betwixt them, at sight of whom the air was filled with fierce shouts and cries.
10064-8{_}3780{_}"The witch!
10064-8{_}3781{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}3782{_}'Tis the witch of Hangstone Waste!
10064-8{_}3783{_}To the water with the hag!
10064-8{_}3784{_}Nay, burn her!
10064-8{_}3785{_}Burn her!"
10064-8{_}3786{_}"Aye," cried Roger, pushing forward, "there's nought like the fire for your devils or demons!"
10064-8{_}3787{_}Quoth the archer:  "_In nomen Dominum_--Holy Saint Giles, 'tis a comely maid!"
10064-8{_}3788{_}"Foul daughter of an accursed dam!"
10064-8{_}3789{_}quoth Roger, spitting and drawing a cross in the dust with his bow-stave.
10064-8{_}3790{_}"With the eyes of an angel!"
10064-8{_}3791{_}said Giles, pushing nearer where stood a maid young and shapely, trembling in the close grasp of one Gurth, a ragged, red-haired giant, whose glowing eyes stared lustfully upon her ripe young beauty.
10064-8{_}3792{_}"'Tis Mellent!"
10064-8{_}3793{_}cried the fellow.
10064-8{_}3794{_}"'Tis the witch's daughter that hath escaped me thrice by deviltry and witchcraft--"  "Nay--nay," panted the maid 'twixt pallid lips, "nought am I but a poor maid gathering herbs and simples for my mother.
10064-8{_}3795{_}Ah, show pity--"  "Witch!"
10064-8{_}3796{_}roared a score of voices, "Witch!"
10064-8{_}3797{_}"Not so, in sooth--in very sooth," she gasped 'twixt sobs of terror, "nought but a poor maid am I--and the man thrice sought me out and would have shamed me but that I escaped, for that I am very swift of foot--"  "She lured me into the bog with devil-fires!"
10064-8{_}3798{_}cried Gurth.
10064-8{_}3799{_}"And would thou had'st rotted there!"
10064-8{_}3800{_}quoth Giles o' the Bow, edging nearer.
10064-8{_}3801{_}Now hereupon the maid turned and looked at Giles through the silken curtain of her black and glossy hair, and beholding the entreaty of that look, the virginal purity of those wide blue eyes, the archer stood awed and silent, his comely face grew red, grew pale--then, out flashed his dagger and he crouched to spring on Gurth; but, of a sudden, Beltane rode in between, at whose coming a shout went up and thereafter a silence fell.
10064-8{_}3802{_}But now at sight of Beltane, the witch-maid uttered a strange cry, and shrinking beneath his look, crouched upon her knees and spake in strange, hushed accents.
10064-8{_}3803{_}"Messire," she whispered, "mine eyes do tell me thou art the lord Beltane!"
10064-8{_}3804{_}"Aye, 'tis so."
10064-8{_}3805{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}3806{_}she cried, "now glory be and thanks to God that I do see thee hale and well!"
10064-8{_}3807{_}So saying, she shivered and covered her face.
10064-8{_}3808{_}Now while Beltane yet stared, amazed by her saying, the bushes parted near by and a hooded figure stepped forth silent and soft of foot, at sight of whom all men gave back a pace, and Roger, trembling, drew a second cross in the dust with his bow-stave, what time a shout went up:  "Ha!--the Witch--'tis the witch of Hangstone Waste herself!"
10064-8{_}3809{_}Very still she stood, looking round upon them all with eyes that glittered 'neath the shadow of her hood; and when at last she spake, her voice was rich and sweet to hear.
10064-8{_}3810{_}"Liar!"
10064-8{_}3811{_}she said, and pointed at Gurth a long, white finger, "unhand her, liar, lest thou wither, flesh and bone, body and soul!"
10064-8{_}3812{_}Now here, once again, men gave back cowering 'neath her glance, while Roger crossed himself devoutly.
10064-8{_}3813{_}"The evil eye!"
10064-8{_}3814{_}he muttered 'twixt chattering teeth, "cross thy fingers, Giles, lest she blast thee!"
10064-8{_}3815{_}But Gurth shook his head and laughed aloud.
10064-8{_}3816{_}"Fools!"
10064-8{_}3817{_}he cried, "do ye forget?
10064-8{_}3818{_}No witch hath power i' the sun!
10064-8{_}3819{_}She can work no evil i' the sunshine.
10064-8{_}3820{_}Seize her!--'tis an accursed hag-- seize her!
10064-8{_}3821{_}Bring her to the water and see an she can swim with a stone at her hag's neck.
10064-8{_}3822{_}All witches are powerless by day.
10064-8{_}3823{_}See, thus I spit upon and defy her!"
10064-8{_}3824{_}Now hereupon a roar of anger went up and, for that they had feared her before, so now grew they more fierce; a score of eager hands dragged at her, hands that rent her cloak, that grasped with cruel fingers at her long grey hair, bending her this way and that; but she uttered no groan nor complaint, only the maid cried aloud most pitiful to hear, whereat Giles, dagger in hand, pushed and strove to come at Gurth.
10064-8{_}3825{_}Then Beltane alighted from his horse and parting the throng with mailed hands, stood within the circle and looking round upon them laughed, and his laugh was harsh and bitter.
10064-8{_}3826{_}"Forsooth, and must ye war with helpless women, O men of Pentavalon?"
10064-8{_}3827{_}quoth he, and laughed again right scornfully; whereat those that held the witch relaxed their hold and fain would justify themselves.
10064-8{_}3828{_}"She is a witch--a cursed witch!"
10064-8{_}3829{_}they cried.
10064-8{_}3830{_}"She is a woman," says Beltane.
10064-8{_}3831{_}"Aye--a devil-woman--a notable witch--we know her of old!"
10064-8{_}3832{_}"Verily," cried one, "'tis but a sennight since she plagued me with aching teeth--"  "And me with an ague!"
10064-8{_}3833{_}cried another.
10064-8{_}3834{_}"She bewitched my shafts that they all flew wide o' the mark!"
10064-8{_}3835{_}cried a third.
10064-8{_}3836{_}"She cast on me a spell whereby I nigh did perish i' the fen--"  "She is a hag--she's demon-rid and shall to the fire!"
10064-8{_}3837{_}they shouted amain.
10064-8{_}3838{_}"Ha!--witch!--witch!"
10064-8{_}3839{_}"That doeth no man harm by day," said Beltane, "so by day shall no man harm her--"  "Aye, lord," quoth Roger, "but how by night?
10064-8{_}3840{_}'tis by night she may work her spells and blast any that she will, or haunt them with goblins damned that they do run mad, or--"  "Enough!"
10064-8{_}3841{_}cried Beltane frowning, "on me let her bewitchments fall; thus, see you, an I within this next week wither and languish 'neath her spells, then let her burn an ye will: but until this flesh doth shrivel on these my bones, no man shall do her hurt.
10064-8{_}3842{_}So now let there be an end--free these women, let your ranks be ordered, and march--"  "Comrades all!"
10064-8{_}3843{_}cried red-haired Gurth, "will ye be slaves henceforth to this girl-faced youth?
10064-8{_}3844{_}We have arms now and rich booty.
10064-8{_}3845{_}Let us back to the merry greenwood, where all men are equal--come, let us be gone, and take these witches with us to our sport--"  But in this moment Beltane turned.
10064-8{_}3846{_}"Girl-faced, quotha?"
10064-8{_}3847{_}he cried; and beholding his look, Gurth of a sudden loosed the swooning maid and, drawing sword, leapt and smote at Beltane's golden head; but Beltane caught the blow in his mailed hand, and snapped the blade in sunder, and, seizing Gurth about the loins, whirled him high in air; then, while all men blenched and held their breath waiting the thud of his broken body in the dust, Beltane stayed and set him down upon his feet.
10064-8{_}3848{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}3849{_}Gurth's cheek was pale, his eye wide and vacant, and his soul sat numbed within him.
10064-8{_}3850{_}So Beltane took him by the throat, and, laughing fierce, shook him to and fro.
10064-8{_}3851{_}"Beast!"
10064-8{_}3852{_}said he, "unfit art thou to march with these my comrades.
10064-8{_}3853{_}Now therefore do I cast thee out.
10064-8{_}3854{_}Take thy life and go, and let any follow thee that will--Pentavalon needeth not thy kind.
10064-8{_}3855{_}Get thee from among us, empty-handed as I found thee--thy share of treasure shall go to better men!"
10064-8{_}3856{_}Now even as Beltane spake, Gurth's red head sank until his face was hidden within his hands; strong hands, that slowly clenched themselves into anger-trembling fists.
10064-8{_}3857{_}And ever as Beltane spake, the witch, tossing back her long grey hair, looked and looked on him with bright and eager eyes; a wondering look, quick to note his shape and goodly size, his wide blue eyes, his long and golden hair and the proud, high carriage of his head: and slowly, to her wonderment came awe and growing joy.
10064-8{_}3858{_}But Beltane spake on unheeding:  "Thou dost know me for a hunted man with a price upon my head, but thou art thing so poor thy death can pleasure no man.
10064-8{_}3859{_}So take thy life and get thee hence, but come not again, for in that same hour will I hang thee in a halter--go!"
10064-8{_}3860{_}So, with drooping head, Gurth of the red hair turned him about, and plunging into the green, was gone; then Beltane looked awhile upon the others that stood shifting on their feet, and with never a word betwixt them.
10064-8{_}3861{_}"Comrades," quoth he, "mighty deeds do lie before us--such works as only true men may achieve.
10064-8{_}3862{_}And what is a man?
10064-8{_}3863{_}A man, methinks, is he, that, when he speaketh, speaketh ever from his heart; that, being quick to hate all evil actions, is quicker to forgive, and who, fearing neither ghost nor devil, spells nor witchcraft, dreadeth only dishonour, and thus, living without fear, he without fear may die.
10064-8{_}3864{_}So now God send we all be men, my brothers.
10064-8{_}3865{_}To your files there--pikes to the front and rear, bows to the flanks--forward!"
10064-8{_}3866{_}But now, as with a ring and clash and tramp of feet the ragged company fell into rank and order, the witch-woman came swiftly beside Beltane and, touching him not, spake softly in his ear.
10064-8{_}3867{_}"Beltane--Beltane, lord Duke of Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}3868{_}Now hereupon Beltane started, and turning, looked upon her grave-eyed.
10064-8{_}3869{_}"What would ye, woman?"
10064-8{_}3870{_}he questioned.
10064-8{_}3871{_}"Born wert thou of a mother chaste as fair, true wife unto the Duke thy father--a woman sweet and holy who liveth but to the good of others: yet was brother slain by brother, and thou baptised in blood ere now!"
10064-8{_}3872{_}"Woman," quoth he, his strong hands a-tremble, "who art thou--what knowest thou of my--mother?
10064-8{_}3873{_}Speak!"
10064-8{_}3874{_}"Not here, my lord--but, an thou would'st learn more, come unto Hangstone Waste at the full o' the moon, stand you where the death-stone stands, that some do call the White Morte-stone.
10064-8{_}3875{_}There shalt thou learn many things, perchance.
10064-8{_}3876{_}Thou hast this day saved a witch from cruel death and a lowly beggar-maid from shame.
10064-8{_}3877{_}A witch!
10064-8{_}3878{_}A beggar-maid!
10064-8{_}3879{_}The times be out a joint, methinks.
10064-8{_}3880{_}Yet, witch and beggar, do we thank thee, lord Duke.
10064-8{_}3881{_}Fare thee well--until the full o' the moon!"
10064-8{_}3882{_}So spake she, and clasping the young maid within her arm they passed into the brush and so were gone.
10064-8{_}3883{_}Now while Beltane stood yet pondering her words, came Roger to his side, to touch him humbly on the arm.
