10064-8{_}6501{_}'Tis Prat who alone stood off a score what time I lay wounded and pinned beneath my charger.
10064-8{_}6502{_}Mark ye yon lusty fellow beside him?
10064-8{_}6503{_}'Tis Cnut that, single-handed, hewed him a path through Ivo's battle and bare away his own banner, the which doth grace my hall at Thrasfordham e'en now.
10064-8{_}6504{_}And yonder is Dirk that was a slave, yet fighteth like a paladin.
10064-8{_}6505{_}And there again is Siward, that with his brother maintained the sallyport 'gainst Ivo's van what time they drave us from the outer bailey.
10064-8{_}6506{_}And yonder Cedric--but so could I name them each and every--ha!
10064-8{_}6507{_}there sounds the welcome tucket!
10064-8{_}6508{_}Come, let us break our fast, and there be many knights and esquires and gentles of degree do wait to pay thee homage."
10064-8{_}6509{_}So presently came they into the midst of the camp, where, seated on the mossy ling, hungry and expectant, were many noble lords and gentle knights and esquires of degree, who, beholding Sir Benedict with Beltane, rose up with one accord.
10064-8{_}6510{_}Young men were these for the most part, yet were there many grizzled heads and wrinkled brows among them-- grim lords of the old Duke's following much versed in war, calm of judgment and wise in council; but one and all did they stare upon my Beltane in wonder at his youth because of his so famous deeds.
10064-8{_}6511{_}Now spake to them Sir Benedict, short and soldier-like:  "My lords, this is he of whom ye all have heard, Beltane hight, son of Beltane our Duke, for whom we together have held Thrasfordham so long and painfully.
10064-8{_}6512{_}My lord Beltane, of all the knights and nobles of the Duke thy father's days, here do stand, sire or son, all that have withstood Black Ivo.
10064-8{_}6513{_}Behold here Sir Bertrand, that was thy father's seneschal of Pentavalon City.
10064-8{_}6514{_}Here, Sir John of Griswold whose sire bare thy father's banner, wherefore Griswold is ashes long since.
10064-8{_}6515{_}Here Hubert of Erdington, that was thy father's marshal-of-the-field.
10064-8{_}6516{_}Here, Hacon of Trant, that was wont to lead thy father's vanward, and here, Sir Brian of Hartismere, brother to Eric, called the Wry-neck.
10064-8{_}6517{_}So now, all's said, my lord, wherefore I pray, let us eat."
10064-8{_}6518{_}Forthwith down they sat together on the grass, all and sundry, and ate and drank and laughed and talked, insomuch that in brake and thicket near and far the birds carolled and chattered in pretty mockery.
10064-8{_}6519{_}"Lord Beltane," quoth Sir Benedict when the meal was ended, "ere I met thee, 'twas my intent this hour to march on Winisfarne, according to my promise to Waldron of Brand, how say you?"
10064-8{_}6520{_}"Forsooth," nodded Beltane, "as soon as ye will."
10064-8{_}6521{_}Thus, within the hour, the trumpets brayed 'to horse' and all was seeming hurry and confusion; yet a confusion, this, governed by soldierly method, so that, ere long, horsemen were mounted and footmen in array what time Beltane, bedight in goodly vizored casque, with lance and shield borne behind him, came where stood Sir Benedict beside a great and noble war-horse.
10064-8{_}6522{_}Forthwith Beltane mounted, and forthwith from these well-ordered ranks a great shout arose:  "Beltane--the Duke--the Duke!"
10064-8{_}6523{_}Now, reining in his eager beast, Beltane looked upon that stern array, and as he looked his eye kindled and his heart swelled within him.
10064-8{_}6524{_}"O men!"
10064-8{_}6525{_}said he, "I that ye do acclaim am but a man even as ye are men, to bear with ye the heat and labour of the day.
10064-8{_}6526{_}What ye must endure that will I endure with you.
10064-8{_}6527{_}Here stand I, ready to spill my blood that Wrong may cease.
10064-8{_}6528{_}Even as ye, I am prepared to adventure me, life and limb, that Lust and Murder may cease to be and Innocence and Truth may walk again all unashamed.
10064-8{_}6529{_}So shall I lead ye into battles and affrays desperate and bloody, where foes shall be a-many and we, few.
10064-8{_}6530{_}But we do fight for hearth and home, and the thought of this, methinks, shall nerve us strong as giants.
10064-8{_}6531{_}Yet is our way a perilous way, and some of us, belike, must die.
10064-8{_}6532{_}But, by the blood of such, this our country is hallowed unto those that shall come after us, so shall our memories teach others how to die--and better--how to live that this our country may stand, hereafter, for all things great and noble.
10064-8{_}6533{_}He that dieth for home and children shall, mayhap, from the floor of heaven, look down upon a great and happy people whose freedom he--by weary marches, by pain of wounds, by sharp and sudden death--he himself hath helped to purchase, and, in their peace and happiness, find an added joy.
10064-8{_}6534{_}"O men!
10064-8{_}6535{_}who would not be a man to fight in such just cause?
10064-8{_}6536{_}Who would not cherish life that he might lose it to such noble purpose?
10064-8{_}6537{_}"Now therefore, all ye that do love Pentavalon--follow!"
10064-8{_}6538{_}Thus saying, my Beltane wheeled his horse; and with rhythmic ring and clash, together, rank on rank, horsemen and footmen, they followed hard behind, a silent, grim array, with eyes that gleamed 'neath helm and bascinet, and purposeful hands that griped full strong on lance and spear-shaft, as, coming to the forest-road, they swung away northwards towards Winisfarne.
10064-8{_}6539{_}CHAPTER LVI  WHAT THEY FOUND AT WINISFARNE   Two and two they rode--for the way was oft-times narrow--their flanks well covered by light-armed archers who marched within the green, with mounted archers far in their van and others in their rear.
10064-8{_}6540{_}A glory of sun dappled their way with dancing shadows, flowers were a-bloom in bank and hedgerow, and birds carolled blithe in the fragrant air, what time Sir Benedict rode beside Beltane, his ponderous casque a-swing at saddle-bow; and oft he turned his grizzled head to view my thoughtful Beltane as one might look upon a son, new-found.
10064-8{_}6541{_}Now in a while Beltane turned and meeting his look reached out to him his hand.
10064-8{_}6542{_}"Dear Benedict," said he, "how much--how very much I owe to thee.
10064-8{_}6543{_}Thou art methinks the greatest knight that e'er couched lance--"  "Save thy noble father!"
10064-8{_}6544{_}quoth Sir Benedict with solemn nod.
10064-8{_}6545{_}"My father--you were his esquire and much-loved comrade, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}6546{_}"I was, Beltane."
10064-8{_}6547{_}"Knew you my mother well, also?"
10064-8{_}6548{_}"Thy mother?
10064-8{_}6549{_}Why--aye, forsooth, I--knew thy mother--very well, Beltane."
10064-8{_}6550{_}"What manner of woman was she, I pray?"
10064-8{_}6551{_}"The fairest and noblest these eyes have e'er beheld!"
10064-8{_}6552{_}"The--noblest?"
10064-8{_}6553{_}"And purest!
10064-8{_}6554{_}Hark ye, Beltane, and mark me well--there ne'er lived wife of so stainless honour as the noble woman that bare thee!"
10064-8{_}6555{_}"And yet," sighed Beltane, with wrinkled brow, "within the garden of Pentavalon--my father--"  "Thy father was a sick man, faint with wounds and spent with hardship.
10064-8{_}6556{_}All that day, as we rode unto Pentavalon City, he and I, his mind oft wandered and he held wild talk in his fever.
10064-8{_}6557{_}But hale was I, mind and body, and I do know the Duke thy father fell to strange and sudden madness upon that dreadful day, whereby came woe to Pentavalon, and bitter remorse to him.
10064-8{_}6558{_}This do I swear, thy mother was noble wife and saintly woman!"
10064-8{_}6559{_}"Loved she my father?"
10064-8{_}6560{_}"Aye, verily--she was his wife!
10064-8{_}6561{_}Thy father was a noble knight and peerless--and oft warring on the marches, but methinks--she was something lonely--at times, Beltane."
10064-8{_}6562{_}"Alas!"
10064-8{_}6563{_}sighed Beltane, and again "Alas!"
10064-8{_}6564{_}So fell they incontinent to deep thought and rode full long in silence.
10064-8{_}6565{_}But ever and anon as they paced along together thus, Sir Benedict must needs lift his head to gaze upon my Beltane, and his grim lips curved to smile infinite tender, and in his eyes was growing wonder.
10064-8{_}6566{_}Quoth he at last:  "Beltane, d'ye mark this our silent company, not a stave have they carolled since we set forth!
10064-8{_}6567{_}But how shall a man sing and jest whose heart is set on great emprise?
10064-8{_}6568{_}Verily thy words have fired e'en this shrivelled heart o' mine till I, even as they, methinks, do burn to fight Pentavalon's cause, to shield her from woeful shame and--ha!-- such vile sights as yon!"
10064-8{_}6569{_}Now looking where Sir Benedict pointed, Beltane beheld a thing, crookedly contorted, a-dangle from a knotted branch that jutted athwart the way, insomuch that the must needs stoop, cowering in his saddle, lest he touch the twisted feet of it.
10064-8{_}6570{_}"Dead three days I judge!"
10064-8{_}6571{_}mused Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}6572{_}"Much is possible to the Red Pertolepe in three days.
10064-8{_}6573{_}And he hath a great and powerful following, 'tis said!"
10064-8{_}6574{_}Quoth Beltane, pale-cheeked and frowning a little:  "So would I have it, Benedict--they shall be the more for us to smite!"
10064-8{_}6575{_}"I've heard he musters full three thousand, Beltane."
10064-8{_}6576{_}"What then, good Benedict?
10064-8{_}6577{_}Yon poor, dead thing we passed but now was worth a score of men to us--and there will be others--Sir Pertolepe loveth to see men hang!
10064-8{_}6578{_}So perchance, ere we come to Winisfarne, the strength of thousands shall lie within these arms of ours."
10064-8{_}6579{_}"'Tis a fair thought, lad--aye, 'tis a right fair thought!
10064-8{_}6580{_}May all the poor souls done thus to sudden, cruel death, march within our slender ranks and smite with us, shoulder to shoulder, henceforth!"
10064-8{_}6581{_}And now as they went, came they on many and divers signs of the Red Pertolepe's passing; here a smouldering heap of ruin whereby lay pale, stiff shapes half hidden in the grass--yonder a little child outstretched as though asleep, save for wide eyes that looked so blindly on the sun: and there, beyond, upon the white dust of the road, great gouts and pools that had trickled from something sprawled among the underbrush.
10064-8{_}6582{_}And the soft wind crooned and whispered in the leaves--leaves that parting, showed other shapes swung high in air, whose pallid faces looked down on them, awful-eyed, from the tender green, faces drawn and haggard, with teeth agleam or open mouths whence screams had come, but very silent now until the Day of Judgment.
10064-8{_}6583{_}So rode they, with death above them and around, death in many hateful shapes; and oft Sir Benedict bowed his head as one that prayed, the while his strong hands knit themselves to iron fists; and oft from those grim ranks behind a sound went up to heaven, a sound ominous and low, that was like unto a moan.
10064-8{_}6584{_}Thus marched they, through heat and dust, through cool, green shadow, splashing through noisy brook and shallow ford, until, as the sun reached the zenith, they came to the brow of a hill and saw afar the walls and roofs of the prosperous town of Winisfarne.
10064-8{_}6585{_}And ever as they drew nearer.
10064-8{_}6586{_}Sir Benedict stared on it, his black brows close-knit, and fingered his square chin as one puzzled.
10064-8{_}6587{_}"Beltane," quoth he at last, "'tis full ten years since I saw Winisfarne, and yet--meseemeth--it looked not so!
10064-8{_}6588{_}'Tis as though I missed somewhat, and yet--"  But now came Roger, a dusty figure, spurring from the rear:  "Master," he cried, pointing with eager finger, "O master, the keep-- where is the great keep that stood yonder?"
10064-8{_}6589{_}"Aye, verily--the keep!"
10064-8{_}6590{_}nodded Sir Benedict, clapping mailed hand to thigh, "and 'twas a great and mighty hold as I do mind me!"
10064-8{_}6591{_}Now looked they gloomily on each other and halted their array what time Sir Benedict passed word for bows to be strung and every eye and every ear to be strained right needfully; then moved they on again.
10064-8{_}6592{_}Betimes they reached the outskirts of the town, for defences it had none, but no man moved therein and no sound reached them but the noise of their own going.
10064-8{_}6593{_}Thus, in a while, with hands tight-clenched and lips firm-set they rode into the desolation of the market-place befouled by signs of battle fierce and fell, while beyond, a mass of charred ruin, lay all that was left of Winisfarne's once great and famous keep.
10064-8{_}6594{_}Now above this ruin divers gibbets had been set up, and behold!
10064-8{_}6595{_}these gibbets each bore a heavy burden.
10064-8{_}6596{_}Then Beltane lighted from his horse, and going apart, laid by his casque and sat him down, his head bowed betwixt his hands as one that is direly sick.
10064-8{_}6597{_}In a while as he sat thus, heedless of all things, cometh Roger.
10064-8{_}6598{_}"Master," said he, "saw ye the gibbets yonder?"
10064-8{_}6599{_}"I saw them, Roger."
10064-8{_}6600{_}"Upon those gibbets be divers of our good fellows, master.
10064-8{_}6601{_}There is Diccon and Peter of my company of pikes, and Gregory that was a fair good bowman, and there be others also--and master, these be not hanged men!"
10064-8{_}6602{_}"Not hanged--?"
10064-8{_}6603{_}"No, master!
10064-8{_}6604{_}All these our men died in battle, as their wounds do testify--they were dead men already when Pertolepe hanged them on his gibbets.
10064-8{_}6605{_}And Walkyn is not here, wherefore, methinks, he liveth yet.
10064-8{_}6606{_}And Pertolepe is not here, yet where Pertolepe is, there shall we surely find Walkyn, for Walkyn hath sworn full oft--ha!
10064-8{_}6607{_}master-- master, behold what cometh here--see, yonder!"
10064-8{_}6608{_}Then Beltane arose, and looking where Roger pointed, beheld a strange, misshapen thing, half beast, half man, that ran wondrous fleetly towards them, and, as it ran, flourished aloft a broken sword; now was he lost to sight behind some bush or quick-set, now he bounded high over stream or stone or fallen tree--nought was there could let or stay him--until he came where stood Sir Benedict's outposts, to whose conduct he yielded him forthwith and so was presently brought into the market-square.
10064-8{_}6609{_}A wild figure this, great and hairy of head and with the arms and shoulders of a very giant; bedight was he in good link-mail, yet foul with dirt and mire and spattered with blood from heel to head, and in one great hand he griped still the fragment of a reddened sword.
10064-8{_}6610{_}All a-sweat was he, and bleeding from the hair, while his mighty chest heaved and laboured with his running.
10064-8{_}6611{_}So stood he betwixt his brawny captors what time he panted hoarse and loud, and stared about him fierce-eyed 'neath beetling brows.
10064-8{_}6612{_}Thus, of a sudden he espied my Beltane standing bare-headed in his youthful might, whereon this monstrous man forthwith dashed aside his stalwart guards as they had been babes, and ran towards Beltane with hairy hands outstretched, whereon sprang Roger to front him, dagger a-gleam; but lo!
10064-8{_}6613{_}Roger was caught up in those mighty arms and shaken helplessly.
10064-8{_}6614{_}"Fool!"
10064-8{_}6615{_}cried this grim fellow, "think ye I would harm Beltane that is my most loved lord henceforth?
10064-8{_}6616{_}I am Ulf, called the Strong, and, as this my hateful body is strong, so is my love--lie there!"
10064-8{_}6617{_}So saying, Ulf laid Roger upon his back, and coming to Beltane, fell upon his face before him and caught his mailed feet and kissed them.
10064-8{_}6618{_}"Lord Beltane," he cried, harsh-voiced, "thou seest I do love thee--yet 'twas I did bear thee captive to thy foe by command of one I love beyond all others.
10064-8{_}6619{_}But thou, lord Beltane, thou at peril of thy life did save her from shame and fiery death when Ulf could not--so do I love thee, lord Beltane, and will be thy slave henceforth, to love and serve thee till I die--an thou wilt take me.
10064-8{_}6620{_}Misshapen and unlovely ye behold me--a vile thing that men would jeer at but that they fear to die, for God who hath denied me all else, hath given me strength beyond all men.
10064-8{_}6621{_}Yet do I hate myself and do hide me from the eyes of my fellows: but, an thou canst bear with me, canst suffer me beside thee and be not ashamed of my unloveliness, then will I front all eyes right boldly.
10064-8{_}6622{_}Now lord, an thou wilt take Ulf for thy man, reach down to me thy hand."
10064-8{_}6623{_}Then Beltane reached down and took Ulf's hairy hand in his.
10064-8{_}6624{_}"Ulf," said he, "thou that God hath blessed with such noble strength, methinks 'neath thy grim shape thy heart is noble also, and thy soul, mayhap, straight and lovely.
10064-8{_}6625{_}So will I make thee brother in arms to my faithful Roger, that ye two shall ride ever near me when the battle joins."
10064-8{_}6626{_}Now Ulf the strong stood up erect upon his feet, and on his swart cheeks great tears rolled, glistening.
10064-8{_}6627{_}"Lord!"
10064-8{_}6628{_}said he, "O Beltane, my lord and master--" and bowed grim head with sudden sob, whereat Beltane questioned him full hastily, as thus:  "Art wounded, Ulf!
10064-8{_}6629{_}And whence come ye in such guise?"
10064-8{_}6630{_}"Lord," says Ulf, wiping off his tears and choking upon a sob, "I came through Bloody Pertolepe's array."
10064-8{_}6631{_}"Through?--nay, how mean you?"
10064-8{_}6632{_}questioned Beltane, the while Sir Benedict and many wondering knights and esquires pressed round them in a ring.
10064-8{_}6633{_}"I mean through, lord, for Walkyn's need is dire.
10064-8{_}6634{_}So burst I through them--I had an axe but it brake in my hold, see you, even as this my sword--alack, there is no weapon that I do not break!
10064-8{_}6635{_}Howbeit here am I, lord, hither come with word for one Sir Benedict of Bourne that did covenant to meet with Walkyn here at Winisfarne!"
10064-8{_}6636{_}"Behold us here--speak on!"
10064-8{_}6637{_}quoth Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}6638{_}"Thus, then, saith Walkyn o' the Dene: That scarce had he stormed and set fire to yonder prison-keep, than from the south cometh a great company, the which he at the first did take for ye.
10064-8{_}6639{_}But, in a while, behold Sir Pertolepe's accursed Raven banner, the which giveth Walkyn much to think.
10064-8{_}6640{_}Now cometh to him one beyond all women noble and gracious and holy (as I do know) the fair and stately Abbess Veronica, who, years agone, did build and endow yon great and goodly abbey, wherein all poor desolate souls should be cherished and comforted by her and her saintly nuns, and where the stricken fugitive might find sanctuary and peace and moreover be healed of his hurts.
10064-8{_}6641{_}(All this know I since I was fugitive, hurt and very woeful and found me solace there.)
10064-8{_}6642{_}So cometh this noble lady to Walkyn (and with her, I) and speaketh him calm and sweetly, thus: 'Yonder rideth Sir Pertolepe that is knight of noble birth, yet the rather would I trust myself and these my good sisters in thy hands, O man!
10064-8{_}6643{_}So do I pray thee when thou goest hence, yield us the protection of thy strength, so shall heaven bless thee!'
10064-8{_}6644{_}Hereon Walkyn frowned and plucked his beard awhile, but thereafter, came he to kneel and kiss her hand and swear to aid her the while life him lasted.
10064-8{_}6645{_}Then summoned he his company (lusty fellows all) and called for thirty men that would remain to hold Red Pertolepe in play what time he seeketh place of greater vantage well beknown to him.
10064-8{_}6646{_}Forthwith stood out one Tall Orson hight (a doughty fellow) and with him nine and twenty other lusty fellows, right willing (and with them, I) and thereafter Walkyn formeth his company (the nuns in the midst) and marched in haste for Brand that is a lonely tower.
10064-8{_}6647{_}Then did these thirty (and with them I) shoot arrows amain on Pertolepe's vanguard from every place of vantage hereabouts, and met them with right lusty hand-strokes and stayed thus their advance until of the thirty there none remained alive save seven (and of these, I).
10064-8{_}6648{_}And, since we could do no more, I (that do know this country from my misshapen youth) brought these men by secret ways unto the Tower of Brand that is desolate and a ruin, yet strong withal.
10064-8{_}6649{_}And there lay Walkyn (that is a notable fighter) keeping watch and ward within the tower what time he waited thy succour.
10064-8{_}6650{_}Now who so skilful and tender with our wounded as this sweet and gracious lady Abbess!
10064-8{_}6651{_}Next day, sure enough, cometh Pertolepe with brave show of horse and foot (above three thousand, lords) and straightway sendeth he a haughty fellow to demand incontinent surrender--a loud-voiced knight whom Walkyn forthwith shot and slew with his own hand.
10064-8{_}6652{_}Whereat Sir Pertolepe waxed exceeding wroth and came on amain and beset the tower on all sides, whereby they lost others of their men, for Walkyn's fellows shot exceeding strong and true (and with them, I).
10064-8{_}6653{_}Then, O my lords, in all that fierce debate, who so brave and calm, heartening wearied and wounded with gentle voice and gentler hand, than this same noble lady Abbess!
10064-8{_}6654{_}For two days lay we besieged whereby our food and drink began to fail (for the well within the tower is well-nigh dried up) yet none did eat or drink so sparingly as this same holy Abbess.
10064-8{_}6655{_}Now on this (the second day, lords) cometh Pertolepe himself (under flag of truce, lords) and demands we yield to him the body of this same lady Abbess (to our ransom) swearing on his knightly word he then will march away forthwith, and seek our hurt no more.
10064-8{_}6656{_}And, to save our lives, fain would this brave lady have yielded her to Pertolepe's hands.
10064-8{_}6657{_}But Walkyn (mindful of his oath, lords), leaning him from the battlement, spake Red Pertolepe defiantly, calling him knave and liar, and therewith spat upon him, very fairly.
10064-8{_}6658{_}Whereat Pertolepe sware to hang us one and all and the battle joined again fiercer than before.
10064-8{_}6659{_}Therefore, on this the third day, seeing no hope of succour, Walkyn made him ready to sally out (a right desperate venture because of the women).
10064-8{_}6660{_}Then spake I before them all, saying I doubted not I might win through, and bring thee to their aid (an ye had kept the tryst) would they but ply their shafts amain to cover me.
10064-8{_}6661{_}The which was so agreed.
10064-8{_}6662{_}Then did this saintly lady Abbess set her white hand on this my hateful head and prayed the sweet Christ to shield this my monstrous body, and I thereafter being bedight in right good mail (as thou seest) issued suddenly out of the tower whiles our foemen sat at meat, and ran among them roaring dreadfully and smote amain full many until my axe brake and I betook me to my sword and smote them as I ran what time Walkyn's archers shot right furiously and well.
10064-8{_}6663{_}Thus came I through Bloody Pertolepe's array, and thus, lords, ye do behold a something weary man and a mighty hungry one withal!"
10064-8{_}6664{_}Now came Sir Benedict to grasp Ulf's great hand.
10064-8{_}6665{_}"Forsooth, hast done a great and noble thing!"
10064-8{_}6666{_}quoth he.
10064-8{_}6667{_}"Thy twisted body doth hide a great and manly soul, meseemeth, so ne'er shalt lack for friend whiles Benedict doth live!"
10064-8{_}6668{_}And after Sir Benedict came many other knights and esquires of degree, to bring him of their own viands and press upon him rich and goodly wine.
10064-8{_}6669{_}In so much that Ulf grew hot and awkward, and presently stole away to eat with Roger in a quiet corner.
10064-8{_}6670{_}But now within the market-place was sound of song, of jest and laughter, where bow-strings were looked to heedfully, sword-belts buckled tighter, mail-coifs laced the closer, stirrup-chain and saddle-girth carefully regarded, whiles ever and anon all eyes turned where Beltane sat among the older knights, Sir Benedict beside him, hearkening to their counsel.
10064-8{_}6671{_}And presently he rose and lifted his hand, whereat the trumpets blared and, thereafter, with ring of hoof and tramp of foot, marched they forth of Winisfarne, the sun bright on helm and shield, a right gallant array.
10064-8{_}6672{_}And at their head rode Ulf the Strong.
10064-8{_}6673{_}CHAPTER LVII  TELLETH OF THE ONFALL AT BRAND   By wild and lonely ways Ulf led them, through mazy thicket, o'er murmurous rill, through fragrant bracken that, sweeping to their saddle-girths, whispered as they passed; now rode they by darkling wood, now crossed they open heath; all unerring rode Ulf the Strong, now wheeling sharp and sudden to skirt treacherous marsh or swamp, now plunging into the gloom of desolate woods, on and on past lonely pools where doleful curlews piped, nor faltered he nor stayed until, as the sun grew low, they climbed a sloping upland crowned by mighty trees and thick with underbrush; here Ulf checked his horse and lifted long arm in warning, whereon the company halted, hard-breathing, yet very orderly and silent.
10064-8{_}6674{_}Forthwith down lighted Beltane with Sir Benedict and Ulf who pointed before them with his finger.
10064-8{_}6675{_}"Lords," said he, "beyond yon trees is a valley and in the valley the tower of Brand, the which you may see from the brush yonder--aha!
10064-8{_}6676{_}and hear also, methinks!"
10064-8{_}6677{_}And indeed the air was full of a strange droning sound that rose and fell unceasing, a drowsy, ominous hum.
10064-8{_}6678{_}"Ah, Benedict," said Beltane, frowning a little, "I like not that sound!
10064-8{_}6679{_}Summon we our wisest heads, for here is matter for thought and sudden action methinks!"
10064-8{_}6680{_}Hereupon Sir Benedict beckoned to his five chiefest knights and they together followed Ulf's broad back up the slope until they were come within the little wood; and ever as they advanced the strange hum grew louder, hoarser--a distant roar, pierced, ever and anon, by sharper sound, a confused din that was the voice of desperate conflict.
10064-8{_}6681{_}Presently Ulf brought them to the edge of the little wood and, parting twig and leaf, they looked forth and down.
10064-8{_}6682{_}And what they saw was this:  A little valley, wondrous green but very desolate-seeming, for here and there stood ruined walls and charred timbers that once had been fair dwellings; and in the midst of this small and ruined hamlet, a mighty tower uprose, hoary and weather-beaten, yet stark and grim against the sunset.
10064-8{_}6683{_}All about this tower a great camp lay, set well out of bow-shot, and 'twixt camp and tower were many men whose armour flashed, rank on rank, and archers who, kneeling behind mantlets, shot amain at battlement and loophole.
10064-8{_}6684{_}Against the tower were two great ladders, roughly fashioned and a-swarm with men; but ever as they strove to reach the battlement a mighty axe whirled and swung and a long sword flashed, and ever as they fell, so fell one of the besiegers.
10064-8{_}6685{_}"There stand Walkyn and Tall Orson!"
10064-8{_}6686{_}quoth Ulf, biting his nails.
10064-8{_}6687{_}"Ha!-- they be dour fighters--would I stood with them!"
10064-8{_}6688{_}"We come in due season, methinks!"
10064-8{_}6689{_}said Sir Benedict, stroking his square chin, "what is your counsel, my lords?"
10064-8{_}6690{_}Quoth young Sir John of Griswold:  "Let us to horse and sally out on them, the hill is with us and we shall--"  "Slay and be slain!"
10064-8{_}6691{_}quoth Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}6692{_}"Verily!"
10064-8{_}6693{_}nodded grim Sir Bertrand, "dost speak like a very youth, John!"
10064-8{_}6694{_}"Here, methinks," said Sir Benedict, "is work for pike and bow-string.
10064-8{_}6695{_}First break we their charge, then down on them in flank with shock and might of all our lances."
10064-8{_}6696{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}6697{_}'tis well be-thought, Benedict!"
10064-8{_}6698{_}growled old Hubert of Erdington, "so let me march with the pikes."
10064-8{_}6699{_}"Art silent, lord Beltane," quoth Sir Hacon, "dost agree?"
10064-8{_}6700{_}"Aye, truly," answered Beltane, rising, "but let our pikes march in V formation, our mightiest men at the point of the V, and with archers behind.
10064-8{_}6701{_}Then, ere the foe do engage, let the V become an L, so shall we oppose them two faces.
10064-8{_}6702{_}Now, when Sir Pertolepe's chivalry charge, let Sir Benedict with two hundred knights and men-at-arms spur in upon their flank, driving them confused upon their main battle, what time I, yet hid within the green, will sound my rallying note that Walkyn knoweth of old, whereat he shall sally out upon their further flank.
10064-8{_}6703{_}Then will I, with my hundred horse, charge down upon their rear, so should we have them, methinks?
10064-8{_}6704{_}How say you, my lords?"
10064-8{_}6705{_}"Truly," quoth Sir Bertrand, closing his vizor, "thy father liveth again in thee, methinks!"
10064-8{_}6706{_}Forthwith, pikemen and archers fell into array with Cnut at their head, while behind the spreading ranks of pikes Prat and his archers were ranged, bows strung and quivers slung before; and presently, at Beltane's word, they swung forth of the sheltering green, fierce-eyed, grim-lipped, bascinet and pike-head a-twinkle.
10064-8{_}6707{_}Away they swung down the slope, a stalwart company swift-treading and light, and in their midst old Hubert of Erdington in his heavy armour, whose long sword flashed as he flourished his farewell.
10064-8{_}6708{_}With rhythmic step and swing of broad mailed shoulders they marched until they were come down into the valley.
10064-8{_}6709{_}And now, as they advanced swift and steady, rose shouts from besieged and besiegers; Sir Pertolepe's trumpets brayed defiance and alarm, and of a sudden, forth of his camp mailed horsemen rode rank upon rank, pennons a-flutter and armour flashing in the sunset glare.
10064-8{_}6710{_}But, as they mustered to the charge, as shields flashed and lances sank, Sir Benedict's pikemen wheeled, their ranks swung wide, and lo!
10064-8{_}6711{_}the V was become an L. Now from this L bows twanged and arrows flew amain above the kneeling pikemen, what time Sir Pertolepe's trumpets blared the charge, and down upon those slender ranks his heavy-armed chivalry thundered; horses reared and fell, screaming, beneath the whistling arrow-shower, but on swept the charge; those thin ranks bent and swayed 'neath the shock as lance crossed pike, but these pike-butts rested on firm ground and upon their deadly points, horses, smitten low, reared transfixed, and above these rocking pikes steel flashed and flickered where the stout archers plied their heavy broadswords, while, loud above the din, Sir Hubert's voice boomed hoarse encouragement what time he thrust and smote above the kneeling pikemen.
10064-8{_}6712{_}Now out from the green Sir Benedict paced astride his great black charger, and behind him his two hundred steel-girt knights and men-at-arms, their vizors closed, their shields slung before, the points of their long and ponderous lances agleam high in air.
10064-8{_}6713{_}Then turned Sir Benedict and looked on their grimly ranks, glad-eyed:  "O sirs," quoth he, "who would not be a man to fight in such just cause!"
10064-8{_}6714{_}So saying, he smiled his wry and twisted smile and closed his vizor: then, with shield addressed and feet thrust far within the stirrups he lightly feutred his deadly lance; and behold!
10064-8{_}6715{_}down swept every lance behind him as, leaning low behind his shield, he shouted right joyously:  "Come ye, messires--lay on this day for Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}6716{_}Forward bounded the great horses a-down the slope--away, away, gathering speed with every stride--away, away, across the level with flying rein and busy spur; and now a loud shouting and dire amaze among Sir Pertolepe's battle with desperate wheeling of ranks and spurring of rearing horses, while Sir Benedict's riders swept down on them, grim and voiceless, fast and faster.
10064-8{_}6717{_}Came a roaring crash beneath whose dire shock Sir Pertolepe's ranks were riven and rent asunder, and over and through their red confusion Sir Benedict rode in thunderous, resistless might, straight for where, above their mid-most, close-set ranks, fluttered and flew Sir Pertolepe's Raven banner.
10064-8{_}6718{_}Now, in hot haste, Sir Pertolepe launched another charge to check that furious onset, what time he reformed and strengthened his main battle; but, with speed unchecked, Sir Benedict's mighty ranks met them in full career--broke them, flung them reeling back on Sir Pertolepe's staggering van and all was wild disorder, above which roaring tumult the Raven banner reeled and swayed and the fray waxed ever fiercer.
10064-8{_}6719{_}Now ran Beltane where stood Roger to hold his horse, with Ulf who leaned upon a goodly axe and young Sir John of Griswold, who clenched and wrung his mailed hands and bit upon his boyish lip and stamped in his impatience.
10064-8{_}6720{_}"My lord," he cried, "my lord, suffer us to charge--ah!
10064-8{_}6721{_}see--our good Sir Benedict will be surrounded--cut off--"  "Nay, methinks he is too wise in war, he fighteth ever with calm head, Sir John."
10064-8{_}6722{_}"But, messire, do but see--his charge is checked--see--see, he yieldeth ground--he giveth back!"
10064-8{_}6723{_}"Aye, verily!"
10064-8{_}6724{_}quoth Beltane, springing to saddle, "but behold how he orders his line!
10064-8{_}6725{_}O lovely knight!
10064-8{_}6726{_}O wise Benedict!
10064-8{_}6727{_}See you not his wisdom now, Sir John?
10064-8{_}6728{_}In his retreat he draweth Sir Pertolepe's main battle athwart our line of charge, their flank exposed and open--to horse, Sir John, to horse!
10064-8{_}6729{_}Yet stir not until I give the word."
10064-8{_}6730{_}Forthwith sprang Sir John to saddle and Roger and Ulf also, what time Beltane sat, his gaze upon the conflict, his bugle-horn in his hand; of a sudden he clapped it to lip and sounded the old fierce rallying note.
10064-8{_}6731{_}High and shrill and loud it rang above the roar of battle, and lo!
10064-8{_}6732{_}distant and far, like an answer to the call, from the grim and battered tower of Brand a mighty shout went up--"Arise!
10064-8{_}6733{_}Arise!--Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}6734{_}"Oho!"
10064-8{_}6735{_}cried Roger, sitting close on Beltane's left, "list ye to that, now!
10064-8{_}6736{_}And see--ha!
10064-8{_}6737{_}there cometh our long-legged Walkyn, first of them all!
10064-8{_}6738{_}See how they order their pikes--O master, they be sweet and doughty fellows!
10064-8{_}6739{_}See how Jenkyn's archers shoot--each man to the ear!"
10064-8{_}6740{_}Awhile sat Beltane watching, wide-eyed, while Sir Benedict, fighting sword in hand, fell back and back before the furious onset of Sir Pertolepe's main battle until he had drawn the fight mid-way.
10064-8{_}6741{_}Then, quick-breathing, my Beltane closed his vizor.
10064-8{_}6742{_}"Now!"
10064-8{_}6743{_}cried he, "now, good comrades all, God willing, we have them.
10064-8{_}6744{_}Let each man choose his foe and smite this day for Liberty and Justice!"
10064-8{_}6745{_}So saying, he levelled his lance, and a hundred lances sank behind him.
10064-8{_}6746{_}Spurs struck deep, horses reared, plunged, and sped away.
10064-8{_}6747{_}Before their galloping line rode Sir John of Griswold with Roger and Ulf: and before these, Beltane.
10064-8{_}6748{_}He felt the wind a-whistle through the eye-vents of his casque, heard the muffled thunder of the galloping hoofs behind mingled with the growing din of battle; heard a shout--a roar of anger and dismay, saw a confusion of rearing horses as Sir Pertolepe swung about to meet this new attack, steadied his aim, and with his hundred lances thundering close behind, drove in upon those bristling ranks to meet them shield to shield with desperate shock of onset--felt his tough lance go home with jarring crash--saw horses that reared high and were gone, lost beneath the trampling fray, and found his lance shivered to the very grip.
10064-8{_}6749{_}Out flashed his sword, for all about him was a staggering press of horses that neighed and screamed, and men who smote, shouting, and were smitten; unseen blows battered him while he thrust and hewed, and wondered to see his long blade so dimmed and bloody.
10064-8{_}6750{_}And ever as he fought, through the narrow vent of his casque he caught small and sudden visions of this close-locked, desperate fray; of Ulf standing in his stirrups to ply his whirling axe whose mighty, crashing blows no armour might withstand; of grim Roger, scowling and fierce, wielding ponderous broad-sword; of young Sir John of Griswold, reeling in his saddle, his helpless arms wide-flung.
10064-8{_}6751{_}So cut they bloody path through Pertolepe's deep array, on and forward with darting point and deep-biting edge, unheeding wounds or shock of blows, until Beltane beheld the press yield, thin out, and melt away, thereupon shouted he hoarse and loud, rode down a knight who sought to bar his way, unhorsed a second, and wheeling his snorting charger, wondered at the seeming quiet; then lifting his vizor, looked about him.
10064-8{_}6752{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}6753{_}wheresoever his glance fell were men that crawled groaning, or lay very mute and still amid a huddle of fallen horses, and, beyond these again, were other men, a-horse and a-foot, that galloped and ran amain for the shelter of the green.
10064-8{_}6754{_}Sir Pertolepe's array was scattered up and down the valley--the battle was lost and won.
10064-8{_}6755{_}Now while he yet sat thus, dazed by the shock of blows and breathing deep of the sweet, cool air, he beheld one rise up from where the battle-wrack lay thickest, an awful figure that limped towards him, holding aloft the broken shaft of an axe.
10064-8{_}6756{_}"Aha, lord Beltane!"
10064-8{_}6757{_}cried Ulf, wiping sweat and blood from him, "there be no more--left to smite, see you.
10064-8{_}6758{_}The which--is well, for weapon-- have I none.
10064-8{_}6759{_}This axe was the third this day--broken, see you!
10064-8{_}6760{_}Alas!
10064-8{_}6761{_}there is no weapon I may use.
10064-8{_}6762{_}Saw you Roger, lord, that is my comrade?"
10064-8{_}6763{_}"Nay, good Ulf--ha, what of him?"
10064-8{_}6764{_}"His horse was slain, lord.
10064-8{_}6765{_}So fought he afoot, since when I saw him not."
10064-8{_}6766{_}"And where is Sir Benedict and Walkyn--O see you not Sir Benedict?
10064-8{_}6767{_}mine eyes are dazzled with the sun."
10064-8{_}6768{_}But now Ulf uttered a joyful cry and pointed with his axe-shaft.
10064-8{_}6769{_}"Yonder cometh Roger, lord, and with him the little archer, but whom bring they?"
10064-8{_}6770{_}Very slowly they came, Roger and Prat the archer, up-bearing betwixt them good Sir Hubert of Erdington, his harness hacked and broken, his battered helm a-swing upon its thongs, his eyes a-swoon in the pallor of his face.
10064-8{_}6771{_}Down sprang Beltane and ran to greet him and to catch his nerveless hands:  "Lord Beltane," quoth he, faintly, "full oft have I shed my blood for-- Pentavalon--to-day I die, messire.
10064-8{_}6772{_}But, as thou didst say--'tis well to die--in cause so noble!
10064-8{_}6773{_}My lord, farewell to thee!"
10064-8{_}6774{_}And with the word, even as he stood 'twixt Roger and the archer, the stout old knight was dead.
10064-8{_}6775{_}So they laid Hubert of Erdington very reverently upon that trampled field he had maintained so well.
10064-8{_}6776{_}"A right noble knight, my lord," quoth Prat, shaking gloomy head, "but for him, methinks our pikemen would have broke to their third onset!"
10064-8{_}6777{_}"There is no man of you hath not fought like ten men this day!"
10064-8{_}6778{_}said Beltane, leaning on his sword and with head a-droop.
10064-8{_}6779{_}"Have we lost many, know ye?"
10064-8{_}6780{_}"A fair good number, master, as was to be expected," quoth Roger, cleansing his sword on a tuft of grass, "Sir John of Griswold fell beside me deep-smitten through the helm."
10064-8{_}6781{_}"And what of Sir Benedict?"
10064-8{_}6782{_}"See yonder--yonder he rides, my lord!"
10064-8{_}6783{_}cried Prat, "though methinks you scarce shall know him."
10064-8{_}6784{_}And he pointed where, on spent and weary charger, one rode, a drooping, languid figure, his bright armour bespattered and dim, his dinted casque smitten awry; slowly he rode before his weary company until of a sudden espying Beltane, he uttered a great and glad cry, his drooping shoulders straightened, and he rode forward with mailed arms outstretched.
10064-8{_}6785{_}"Beltane!"
10064-8{_}6786{_}he cried, "praise be to God!
10064-8{_}6787{_}One told me thou wert down--art well, sweet lad, and all unharmed?
10064-8{_}6788{_}God is merciful!"
10064-8{_}6789{_}And he patted Beltane's mailed shoulder, what time blood oozed from his steel gauntlet and his sobbing charger hung weary head and snorted purple foam.
10064-8{_}6790{_}"O lad," quoth he, smiling his wry smile, "here was an hour worth living for--though Sir Bertrand is sore hurt and many do lie dead of my company."
10064-8{_}6791{_}"And here," sighed Beltane, "brave Hubert of Erdington--behold!"
10064-8{_}6792{_}"A gallant knight, Beltane!
10064-8{_}6793{_}May I so valiantly die when that my time be come.
10064-8{_}6794{_}Truly 'twas a sharp debate what time it lasted, there be many that will ride with us no more."
10064-8{_}6795{_}"And thou, my lord?"
10064-8{_}6796{_}cried Beltane suddenly, "thy cheek so pale-- thou'rt hurt, Benedict!"
10064-8{_}6797{_}"Nought to matter, lad, save that it is my sword-arm: nay indeed, my Beltane, 'twas but an axe bit through my vanbrace, 'twill heal within the week.
10064-8{_}6798{_}But take now my horn and summon ye our scattered company, for I do lack the wind."
10064-8{_}6799{_}Knight and man-at-arms, limping and afoot, on horses weary and blown, they came at the summons--archer and pike-man they came, a blood be-spattered company; many were they that staggered, faint with wounds, and many that sank upon the trampled grass a-swoon with weariness, but in the eyes of each and every was the look of men that triumph.
10064-8{_}6800{_}Cnut was there, his bascinet gone, his fiery hair betousled: Tall Orson was there, leaning on a bent and battered pike, and there his comrade, Jenkyn o' the Ford, with many others that Beltane well remembered and others whose faces he knew not.
10064-8{_}6801{_}So formed they their battle-scarred array what time Beltane viewed them with glowing eye and heart swelling within him.
10064-8{_}6802{_}"Master!"
10064-8{_}6803{_}cried Tall Orson of a sudden, "O master, us do be clean men and goodly fighters as us did promise thee time 'gone i' the Hollow, master, ye'll mind us as did promise so to be--I and Jenkyn as be my comrade?"
10064-8{_}6804{_}"Aye, master!"
10064-8{_}6805{_}cried Jenkyn o' the Ford, "aye, look'ee, we ha' kept our word to thee as we did promise, look'ee master!
10064-8{_}6806{_}So now, speak word to us master, look'ee!"
10064-8{_}6807{_}"Ye men!"
10064-8{_}6808{_}quoth Beltane, hoarse-voiced, "O my good comrades all, your deeds this day shall speak when we are dust, methinks!
10064-8{_}6809{_}Your foes this day did muster three thousand strong, and ye do number scarce a thousand--yet have ye scattered them, for that your cause is just--'tis thus ye shall lift Pentavalon from shame and give to her peace at last!"
10064-8{_}6810{_}Then Tall Orson shook aloft his battered pike and shouted amain, and on the instant, others took up the cry--a hoarse roar that rolled from rank to rank; lance and sword, axe and pike were flourished high in air, and from these men who had marched so grimly silent all the day a great and mighty shout went up:  "Arise, Pentavalon!
10064-8{_}6811{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}6812{_}Beltane--Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}6813{_}Now even as they shouted, upon this thunderous roar there stole another sound, high and clear and very sweet, that rose and swelled upon the air like the voices of quiring angels; and of a sudden the shouting was hushed, as, forth of the tower's gloomy portal the lady Abbess came, tall and fair and saintly in her white habit, her nuns behind her, two and two, their hands clasped, their eyes upraised to heaven, chanting to God a hymn of praise and thanksgiving.
10064-8{_}6814{_}Slow paced they thus, the stately Abbess with head low-bended and slim hands clasped upon her silver crucifix until, the chant being ended, she raised her head and beheld straightway Sir Benedict unhelmed and yet astride his great charger.
10064-8{_}6815{_}The silver crucifix fell, the slim hands clasped themselves upon her bosom and the eyes of the tall, white Abbess grew suddenly wide and dark: and even as she gazed on him, so gazed Sir Benedict on her.
10064-8{_}6816{_}"Yolande!"
10064-8{_}6817{_}said he, hoarse-voiced and low.
10064-8{_}6818{_}"Benedict!"
10064-8{_}6819{_}she murmured.
10064-8{_}6820{_}Slowly Sir Benedict bowed his head, and turning, laid his hand on Beltane's mailed shoulder.
10064-8{_}6821{_}"Lady," said he, "behold here Beltane--that is son to Beltane heretofore Duke and Lord of Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}6822{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}6823{_}she whispered, "Beltane!"
10064-8{_}6824{_}and of a sudden stretched out her arms in passionate yearning gesture, then, covering her face, sank upon her knees, "God pity me!"
10064-8{_}6825{_}she sighed, "God pity me!"
10064-8{_}6826{_}Thereafter she rose to her stately height and looked on Beltane, gentle and calm-eyed.
10064-8{_}6827{_}"My lord Beltane," said she, "I have heard tell thou art a noble knight, strong yet gentle--so should thy father be greatly blessed in thee--and thy--mother also.
10064-8{_}6828{_}God have thee ever in His keeping-- Beltane!"
10064-8{_}6829{_}Now as she spake the name her soft voice brake, and turning, she stood with head bowed upon her hands, and standing thus, spake again, deep-voiced and soft:  "Sir Benedict, we are come to minister to the hurt, all is prepared within the tower, let them be brought to us I pray, and--my lord, forget not the sacred oath thou didst swear me--long years agone!"
10064-8{_}6830{_}CHAPTER LVIII  HOW BELTANE HAD SPEECH WITH THE ABBESS   They found rich booty in Pertolepe's camp, with store of arms and armour and many goodly horses, and thither Sir Benedict's wearied followers betook them as night fell and knew blessed rest and sleep.
10064-8{_}6831{_}But in the tower of Brand lights gleamed where the Abbess and her gentle nuns went to and fro among the wounded, ministering to their wants; and far beyond the camp, armour glinted ever and anon against the blackness of the surrounding woods, where outpost and sentinel kept vigilant watch and ward.
10064-8{_}6832{_}Though late the hour Beltane sat wakeful, chin on fist, beside a glimmering watch-fire, oft turning his glance towards the massy, weather-beaten tower, bethinking him of the noble lady Abbess, of her strange looks and words, and so fell to brooding thought.
10064-8{_}6833{_}High overhead the moon rode, obscured by flying clouds, a wild wrack up-whirling from the south: at fitful intervals was a wind that moaned drearily 'mid the gloom of distant woods, a desolate sound that sobbed upon the air, and dying to a wail, was gone.
10064-8{_}6834{_}Now becoming aware of this, Beltane raised his head, and looked up at the ominous heavens and round about him.
10064-8{_}6835{_}And thus he espied a light that hovered hither and thither above the distant battle-field, a small light whose red flame flashed back from cloven casque and riven shield, where eyes glared unseeing and mouths gaped mute and dumb from a dark confusion whence mailed arms stiffly rose with hands tight-clenched that seemed to menace heaven, and rigid feet whose spurred heels yet gored the flanks of rigid, fallen chargers; to and fro and up and down this small flame leaped merrily, dancing from dead face to dead face but staying never, a fiendish fire that seemed to mock the horror of wounds and gibe at solemn death.
10064-8{_}6836{_}Now as he watched this devilish light, Beltane arose and reaching for his sword went soft-footed to meet it, then paused, for the light was moving towards him.
10064-8{_}6837{_}Near and nearer it came, until, into the glow of the fire, his betousled head wild and bare, his link-mail yet befouled with battle, Walkyn strode, and hurling his torch upon the grass, crushed it out 'neath his heel.
10064-8{_}6838{_}Then came he to the fire and stood there, arms crossed, frowning down at the flame.
10064-8{_}6839{_}"Greeting to thee, Waldron of Brand!"
10064-8{_}6840{_}Swift turned Walkyn, his gloomy scowl relaxed at Beltane's voice, and stooping, he took and kissed my Beltane's hand.
10064-8{_}6841{_}"Whence come ye, Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}6842{_}"From going to and fro among the dead, seeking Pertolepe, master.
10064-8{_}6843{_}Ha!
10064-8{_}6844{_}they do lie thick yonder, five hundred and twenty and three I counted of Bloody Pertolepe's following.
10064-8{_}6845{_}And in the woods do lie certain others, that I, with divers of our company, pursued and cut off."
10064-8{_}6846{_}"And what of their wounded?"
10064-8{_}6847{_}"I saw none, master--nor have I seen Pertolepe.
10064-8{_}6848{_}I have viewed all the slain, but Pertolepe is not there, yet have I smitten and slain three Pertolepes this day--hawks, see you, in eagle's feathers!
10064-8{_}6849{_}So is my work yet to do, and I grieve still for Pertolepe's head."
10064-8{_}6850{_}"Sit ye down, Walkyn, here with me beside the fire."
10064-8{_}6851{_}Forthwith Walkyn obeyed and stretching himself on the grass fell to toying with the haft of his axe and scowling at the fire again.
10064-8{_}6852{_}"This was, methinks, thy father's tower and demesne of Brand, Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}6853{_}"Aye, lord, here was I born--yon ruined walls did hear my father's groans--the screams of my mother and sister amid the flame.
10064-8{_}6854{_}And Red Pertolepe was there, and Gui of Allerdale and Roger and young Gilles of Brandonmere--all were there with six other noble knights; but these six we slew long since, my brother and I.
10064-8{_}6855{_}All these were here that day--and Sir Pertolepe--laughed--full loud, 'twas told me.
10064-8{_}6856{_}So 'twere just he should have died here to-day, methinks?
10064-8{_}6857{_}'Twas for this I lured him hither--and he liveth yet!"
10064-8{_}6858{_}"But God is a just God, Walkyn!
10064-8{_}6859{_}Now therefore leave him to God henceforth--!"
10064-8{_}6860{_}"To God!"
10064-8{_}6861{_}cried Walkyn, his eyes wild, his hands tight-clenched, "to God!--ha!
10064-8{_}6862{_}master, ye left him to God on a time and because of thee, I-- I that had my dagger at his rogue's throat--I, yearning to slay him, did but mark him i' the brow--aye, forsooth, we left him to God and lo!
10064-8{_}6863{_}to-day he burneth, he slayeth and hangeth as was ever his wont--"  "God's time is not ours, Walkyn, but for the evil wrought by Sir Pertolepe, Sir Pertolepe needs must answer when God so wills.
10064-8{_}6864{_}So leave him to the vengeance of God--lest the fire of thy vengeance consume thee quite.
10064-8{_}6865{_}Thou art strong, and few may cope with thee in fight, yet hath vengeance fettered and made thee bond-slave.
10064-8{_}6866{_}Forego thy vengeance then, and be free, good comrade."
10064-8{_}6867{_}"Nay master, an I so do, what is left me?"
10064-8{_}6868{_}"The love of thy fellows, Walkyn.
10064-8{_}6869{_}Thou art, forsooth, a man, so do I love thee, and perchance within a new Pentavalon thou may'st come to new fortune and honour.
10064-8{_}6870{_}Thou shalt hold again thy father's lands--"  "To what end, lord?
10064-8{_}6871{_}As ye do know, my wife and child do lie in nameless grave, done to cruel death by dogs of Pertolepe: my brother rotted in a noose--set there by Pertolepe.
10064-8{_}6872{_}So am I a lonely man henceforth; one thing only seek I of life, master."
10064-8{_}6873{_}"And that, Walkyn?"
10064-8{_}6874{_}"The head of Bloody Pertolepe!"
10064-8{_}6875{_}So saying, Walkyn rose, and stood scowling down at the fire again, whose glow shone ominous and red upon the broad blade of the mighty axe that lay on the grass at his feet.
10064-8{_}6876{_}Now of a sudden forth from the shadows, swift and silent on his long legs came crooked Ulf, and stooping, would have lifted the weapon, but in that moment Walkyn snarled, and set his foot upon it.
10064-8{_}6877{_}"Off!"
10064-8{_}6878{_}he growled, "touch not mine axe, thou vile mannikin--lest I tread on thee!"
10064-8{_}6879{_}But scarce were the words spoken, than, with great back low-crouched, Ulf sprang, and whirling mighty Walkyn aloft, mailed feet on high, held him writhing above the fire: then, swinging about, hurled him, rolling over and over, upon the ling; so lay Walkyn awhile propped on an elbow, staring on Ulf with wide eyes and mouth agape what time, strung for sudden action, Beltane sat cross-legged upon the green, looking from one to the other.
10064-8{_}6880{_}"Mannikin?"
10064-8{_}6881{_}roared Ulf, great hands opening and shutting, "unworthy to touch axe of thine, thou pestilent beast!
10064-8{_}6882{_}Dare ye so say to one gently born, base fellow?
10064-8{_}6883{_}Now will I break thee thine accursed axe--and thee thereafter, an ye will!"
10064-8{_}6884{_}So saying, Ulf the Mighty caught up the axe and wheeling it full-armed, smote and buried it in a young tree close by--wrenched it free and smote again.
10064-8{_}6885{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}6886{_}with prodigious crack and rending of fibres the tall tree swayed, crashing to earth.
10064-8{_}6887{_}Now while Ulf yet stood to stare amazed upon this wondrous axe, upon its sharp-glittering, flawless edge, Walkyn had risen, dagger in hand; but even as he crouched to spring, a voice spake--a gentle voice but commanding; and in the fire-glow stood the white Abbess, tall and gracious, the silver crucifix agleam upon her bosom.
10064-8{_}6888{_}"Children!"
10064-8{_}6889{_}she sighed; and looking from scowling Walkyn to frowning Ulf she reached a slim hand to each.
10064-8{_}6890{_}"O children," said she, "lay by your steel and give to me your hands!"
10064-8{_}6891{_}Fumbling and awkward, Walkyn sheathed his dagger while Ulf laid the mighty axe upon the grass very tenderly, as it had been a sleeping child; so came they both, shame-faced, unto the lady Abbess and gave her each a hand.
10064-8{_}6892{_}Holding them thus she looked with sad, sweet eyes from one grim face to the other, and drew them nearer the fire.
10064-8{_}6893{_}"Walkyn, son of God," said she, "behold here Ulf whose valiant heart and mighty strength have been our salvation!
10064-8{_}6894{_}Ulf, child of Heaven, whom God hath made so mighty, behold here brave Walkyn who did protect the weak and helpless and fighteth for the right!
10064-8{_}6895{_}Come then, as ye are children of God, go ye in brotherly love together henceforth, and may heaven bless ye, valiant sons!"
10064-8{_}6896{_}Thus saying, she set their hands one in another, and these hands gripped and held.
10064-8{_}6897{_}Quoth Ulf, sighing:  "Forsooth, I did but mean to try the balance of thine axe, Walkyn.
10064-8{_}6898{_}And truly it is a mighty weapon and a peerless--one that even my strength cannot break!"
10064-8{_}6899{_}Quoth Walkyn, grim-smiling:  "There is in this world no axe like unto it save one that was my brother's--and shall be thine henceforth, Ulf the Strong.
10064-8{_}6900{_}Come now, and I will give it unto thee."
10064-8{_}6901{_}Then bent they reverently before the Abbess, saluted Beltane and, side by side, strode away together.
10064-8{_}6902{_}"Would all feuds might so end, sweet son," sighed the Abbess, her wistful eyes down-bent upon the fire.
10064-8{_}6903{_}"Would there were more sweet souls abroad to teach men reason!"
10064-8{_}6904{_}quoth Beltane.
10064-8{_}6905{_}"Why sit you here, my son, wakeful and alone and the hour so late?"
10064-8{_}6906{_}"For that sleep doth fly my wooing, holy mother."
10064-8{_}6907{_}"Then fain would I share thy vigil awhile."
10064-8{_}6908{_}Forthwith Beltane brought her a stool, rough and rudely fashioned, and while she sat, he lay beside her in the firelight; and thus, despite her hood and wimple, he saw her face was of a calm and noble beauty, smooth and unwrinkled despite the silver hair that peeped forth of her loosened hood.
10064-8{_}6909{_}A while they sat thus, nothing speaking, he viewing her, she gazing ever on the fire; at last:  "Thou'rt young, messire," she said wistfully, "yet in thy life hath been much of strife, I've heard.
10064-8{_}6910{_}Thou hast known much of hardship, my son, and sorrow methinks?"
10064-8{_}6911{_}"So do I live for that fair day when Peace shall come again, noble lady."
10064-8{_}6912{_}"Full oft have I heard tell of thee, my son, strange tales and marvellous.
10064-8{_}6913{_}Some do liken thee to a demon joying in slaughter, and some to an archangel bearing the sword of God."
10064-8{_}6914{_}"And how think you, reverend mother?"
10064-8{_}6915{_}"I think of thee as a man, my son.
10064-8{_}6916{_}I have heard thee named 'outlaw' and 'lawless ravener,' and some do call thee 'Beltane the Smith.'
10064-8{_}6917{_}Now wherefore smith?"
10064-8{_}6918{_}"For that smith was I bred, lady."
10064-8{_}6919{_}"But thou'rt of noble blood, lord Beltane."
10064-8{_}6920{_}"Yet knew I nought of it until I was man grown."
10064-8{_}6921{_}"Thy youth--they tell me--hath been very lonely, my son--and desolate."
10064-8{_}6922{_}"Not desolate, for in my loneliness was the hermit Ambrose who taught me many things and most of all, how to love him.
10064-8{_}6923{_}So lived I in the greenwood, happy and content, until on a day this saintly Ambrose told me a woeful tale--so did I know this humble hermit for the noble Duke, my father."
10064-8{_}6924{_}"Thy father!
10064-8{_}6925{_}The Duke!
10064-8{_}6926{_}A hermit!
10064-8{_}6927{_}Told he of--all his sorrows, my son?"
10064-8{_}6928{_}"All, reverend mother, and thereafter bade me beware the falsity of women."
10064-8{_}6929{_}The pale cheek of the Abbess grew suddenly suffused, the slim hand clenched rigid upon the crucifix at her bosom, but she stirred not nor lifted her sad gaze from the fire.
10064-8{_}6930{_}"Liveth thy father yet, my son?"
10064-8{_}6931{_}"'Tis so I pray God, lady."
10064-8{_}6932{_}"And--thy mother?"
10064-8{_}6933{_}"'Tis so I've heard."
10064-8{_}6934{_}"Pray you not for--for her also?"
10064-8{_}6935{_}"I never knew my mother, lady."
10064-8{_}6936{_}"Alas!
10064-8{_}6937{_}poor lonely mother!
10064-8{_}6938{_}So doth she need thy prayers the more.
10064-8{_}6939{_}Ah, think you she hath not perchance yearned with breaking heart for her babe?
10064-8{_}6940{_}To have kissed him into rosy slumber!
10064-8{_}6941{_}To have cherished his boyish hurts and sorrows!
10064-8{_}6942{_}To have gloried in his youthful might and manhood!
10064-8{_}6943{_}O sure there is no sorrow like the loneliness of desolate motherhood.
10064-8{_}6944{_}Would'st seek this unknown mother, lord Beltane?"
10064-8{_}6945{_}"Truly there be times when I do yearn to find her--and there be times when I do fear--"  "Fear, my lord?"
10064-8{_}6946{_}"Holy mother, I learned of her first as one false to her vows, light-minded and fickle from her youth--"  "O hath there been none to speak thee good of her--in all these years?"
10064-8{_}6947{_}"There was Jolette, that folk did call a witch, and there is Sir Benedict that doth paint her pure and noble as I would have her.
10064-8{_}6948{_}Yet would I know for myself, fain would I be sure ere we do meet, if she is but the woman who bore me, or the proud and noble mother I fain would love."
10064-8{_}6949{_}"Could'st not love her first and judge her after, my son?
10064-8{_}6950{_}Could not her very motherhood plead her cause with thee?
10064-8{_}6951{_}Must she be weighed in the balance ere thou yield her a son's respect and love?
10064-8{_}6952{_}So many weary years--'tis something hard, methinks!
10064-8{_}6953{_}Nay, heed me not, my lord--seek out thy mother, unbeknown--prove for thyself her worthiness or falsity, prove for thyself her honour or her shame--'tis but just, aye, 'tis but just in very truth.
10064-8{_}6954{_}But I, beholding things with woman's eyes, know only that a mother's love shrinketh not for any sin, but reacheth down through shame and evil with sheltering arms outstretched--a holy thing, fearless of sin, more lasting than shame and stronger than death itself."
10064-8{_}6955{_}So saying, the lady Abbess rose and turned to look up at the lights that burned within the tower.
10064-8{_}6956{_}"'Tis late, my lord," she sighed, "get thee now to thy rest, for I must begone to my duty till the dawn.
10064-8{_}6957{_}There be many sick, and good Sir Bertrand lieth very nigh to death--he ne'er will see another dawn, methinks, so needs must I away.
10064-8{_}6958{_}Good night, sweet son, and in thy prayers forget not thy--thy most unhappy mother!"
10064-8{_}6959{_}Then she lifted her hand and blessed him, and, ere he rose up from his knees she set that white hand upon his bowed head and touched his yellow hair--a light touch, furtive and shy, but a touch that was like to a caress.
10064-8{_}6960{_}Thereafter, Beltane, coming into his hut of woven wattle, rolled himself in his weather-worn mantle and presently fell to slumber.
10064-8{_}6961{_}CHAPTER LIX  TELLETH HOW SIR BENEDICT WENT A-FISHING   Next day Sir Bertrand died of his hurts, so they buried him beside young Sir John of Griswold and sturdy old Hubert of Erdington and a hundred and twenty and five others of their company who had fallen in that desperate affray; therefore tarried they a while what time their sick and wounded grew towards health and strength by reason of the skill and tender care of the lady Abbess and her nuns.
10064-8{_}6962{_}Now on the afternoon of this day.
10064-8{_}6963{_}Sir Benedict being sick a-bed of his wound, Beltane sat in council among the oldest and wisest of the knights, and presently summoned Walkyn and Ulf, Roger and Jenkyn o' the Ford, speaking them on this wise:  "Good comrades, list ye now!
10064-8{_}6964{_}These noble knights and I have hither summoned ye for that ye are of good and approved courage and moreover foresters born and cunning in wood-lore.
10064-8{_}6965{_}As ye do know, 'tis our intent to march for Belsaye so soon as our wounded be fit.
10064-8{_}6966{_}But first must we be 'ware if our road be open or no.
10064-8{_}6967{_}Therefore, Walkyn, do ye and Ulf take ten men and haste to Winisfarne and the forest-road that runneth north and south: be ye wary of surprise and heedful of all things.
10064-8{_}6968{_}You, Roger and Jenkyn, with other ten, shall seek the road that runneth east and west; marching due south you shall come to the northern road where ye shall wait two hours (but no longer) for Walkyn.
10064-8{_}6969{_}Ye are woodsmen!
10064-8{_}6970{_}Heed ye the brush and lower branches of the trees if any be broken, mark well the track in dusty places and seek ye the print of feet in marshy places, learn all ye may from whomsoever ye may and haste ye hot-foot back with tidings good or ill. Is it understood?"
10064-8{_}6971{_}"Aye, lord!"
10064-8{_}6972{_}quoth the four.
10064-8{_}6973{_}"And look'ee master," said Jenkyn, "there be my comrade Orson the Tall, look'ee.
10064-8{_}6974{_}His hurt is nigh healed and to go wi' us shall be his cure--now, look'ee lord, shall he go wi' us?"
10064-8{_}6975{_}"Nay, Roger shall answer thee this, Jenkyn.
10064-8{_}6976{_}So now begone and God speed ye, good comrades all!"
10064-8{_}6977{_}Hereupon the mighty four made their obeisance and hasted away, rejoicing.
10064-8{_}6978{_}Now Sir Benedict's hurt had proved an evil one and deep, wherefore the Abbess, in accent soft and tender, had, incontinent, ordered him to bed, and there, within the silken tent that had been Sir Pertolepe's, Beltane oft sat by, the while she, with slim and dexterous fingers, washed and anointed and bound the ugly wound: many times came she, soft-treading, gentle and gracious ever; and at such times Beltane noticed that full often he would find her deep, sad gaze bent upon him; he noticed also that though her voice was low and gentle, yet she spake ever as one 'customed to obedience.
10064-8{_}6979{_}Thus it was, that Sir Benedict being ordered to his couch, obeyed the soft-spoke command, but being kept there all day, grumbled (albeit to Beltane): being kept there the second day he fell to muttered oaths and cursing (albeit to Beltane): but at sunset he became unruly, in so much that he ventured to remonstrate with the lady Abbess (albeit humbly), whereon she smiled, and bidding Beltane reach her cup and spoon, forthwith mixed a decoction and dosed Sir Benedict that he fell asleep and slumbered amain.
10064-8{_}6980{_}Thus, during this time, Beltane saw and talked much with the lady Abbess: oft went he to watch her among the sick and to aid her when he might; saw how fierce faces softened when she bent to touch fevered brow or speak them cheerily with smiling lip despite the deep and haunting sadness of her eyes; saw how eagerly rough hands were stretched forth to furtive touch her white habit as she passed; heard harsh voices grow sudden soft and all unfamiliar--voices that broke in murmurous gratitude.
10064-8{_}6981{_}All this saw and heard he and failed not, morn and eve, to kneel him at her feet to hear her bless him and to feel that soft, shy touch among his hair.
10064-8{_}6982{_}So passed two days, but neither Roger, nor Walkyn, nor Ulf, nor indeed any of the twenty chosen men had yet returned or sent word or sign, wherefore Beltane began to wax moody and anxious.
10064-8{_}6983{_}Thus it was that upon a sunny afternoon he wandered beside a little rivulet, bowered in alder and willow: here, a merry brook that prattled over pebbly bed and laughed among stones and mossy boulders, there a drowsy stream that, widening to dreamy pool, stayed its haste to woo down-bending branches with soft, kissing noises.
10064-8{_}6984{_}Now as Beltane walked beside the stream, head a-droop and very thoughtful, he paused of a sudden to behold one richly dight in gambeson of fair-wrought leather artificially quilted and pinked, who sat ensconced within this greeny bower, his back to a tree, one bandaged arm slung about his neck and in the other hand a long hazel-branch trimmed with infinite care, whereunto a line was tied.
10064-8{_}6985{_}"Sir Benedict!"
10064-8{_}6986{_}cried Beltane, "methought thee asleep: what do ye so far from camp and bed?"
10064-8{_}6987{_}"I fish, lad, I fish--I ply a tentative angle.
10064-8{_}6988{_}Nay--save thy breath, I have caught me nothing yet, save thoughts.
10064-8{_}6989{_}Thoughts do flock a many, but as to fish--they do but sniff my bait and flirt it with their wanton tails, plague take 'em!
10064-8{_}6990{_}But what o' fish?
10064-8{_}6991{_}'Tis not for fish alone that man fisheth, for fishing begetteth thought and thought, dreams--and to dream is oft-times sweet!"
10064-8{_}6992{_}"But--Benedict, what of the Abbess?"
10064-8{_}6993{_}"The Abbess?
10064-8{_}6994{_}Ha, the Abbess, Beltane!
10064-8{_}6995{_}Sweet soul, she sleepeth.
10064-8{_}6996{_}At noon each day needs must she sleep since even she is mortal and mortals must sleep now and then.
10064-8{_}6997{_}The Abbess?
10064-8{_}6998{_}Come sit ye, lad, what time I tickle the noses of these pestilent fish.
10064-8{_}6999{_}Sit ye here beside me and tell me, how think ye of this noble and most sweet lady?"
10064-8{_}7000{_}"That, for thy truancy, she will incontinent mix thee another sleeping draught, Benedict."
10064-8{_}7001{_}"Ha--then I'll never drink it!"
10064-8{_}7002{_}quoth Sir Benedict, settling his shoulder against Beltane and frowning at his line.
10064-8{_}7003{_}"Am I a babe, forsooth, to be dosed to slumber?
10064-8{_}7004{_}Ha, by the foul fiend his black dam, ne'er will I drink it, lad!"
10064-8{_}7005{_}"Then will she smile on thee, sad-eyed, and set it to thy lip, and woo thee soft-voiced, so shalt thou swallow it every drop--"  "Not so--dear blood of all the saints!
10064-8{_}7006{_}Must I be mewed up within an accursed bed on such a day and all by reason of a small axe-stroke?
10064-8{_}7007{_}Malediction, no!"
10064-8{_}7008{_}"She is wondrous gentle with the sick, Benedict--"  "She is a very woman, Beltane, and therefore gentle, a noble lady sweet of soul and body!
10064-8{_}7009{_}To die for such were joyful privilege, methinks, aye, verily!"
10064-8{_}7010{_}and Sir Benedict, forgetful of his line, drooped his head and sighed.
10064-8{_}7011{_}"And thou didst know her well--long years agone, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7012{_}"Aye, long--years--agone!"
10064-8{_}7013{_}"Very well, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7014{_}"Very well."
10064-8{_}7015{_}"She was 'Yolande' then, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7016{_}"Aye," quoth Sir Benedict, lifting his head with a start and looking at Beltane askance, "and to-day she is the lady Abbess Veronica!"
10064-8{_}7017{_}"That shall surely dose thee again and--"  "Ha!
10064-8{_}7018{_}bones and body o' me, not so!
10064-8{_}7019{_}For here sit I, and here angle I, fish or no fish, thunder o' God, yes!
10064-8{_}7020{_}Aye, verily, here will I sit till I have caught me a fish, or weary and go o' my own free will--by Beelzebub I vow, by Bel and the Dragon I swear it!
10064-8{_}7021{_}And furthermore--"  Sir Benedict paused, tilted his head and glancing up, beheld the lady Abbess within a yard of them.
10064-8{_}7022{_}Gracious she stood in her long white habit and shook her stately head in grave rebuke, but beholding his abashed look and how the rod sagged in his loosened hold, her lips parted of a sudden and her teeth gleamed in a smile wondrous young and pleasant to see.
10064-8{_}7023{_}"O Benedict!"
10064-8{_}7024{_}said she, "O child most disobedient!
10064-8{_}7025{_}O sir knight!
10064-8{_}7026{_}Is this thy chivalry, noble lord--to steal away for that a poor soul must needs sleep, being, alas!
10064-8{_}7027{_}so very mortal?"
10064-8{_}7028{_}"Forsooth and indeed, dear my lady," quoth Sir Benedict, fumbling with his angle, "the sun did woo me forth--and the wind, see you--the wind--"  "Nay, I see it not, my lord, but I did hear something of thy fearsome, great oaths as I came hither."
10064-8{_}7029{_}"Oaths, lady?"
10064-8{_}7030{_}said Sir Benedict, fingering his chin, "Forsooth and did I so?
10064-8{_}7031{_}Mayhap 'twas by reason that the fish, see you, the pestilent fish--Ha!
10064-8{_}7032{_}Saint Benedict!
10064-8{_}7033{_}I have a bite!"
10064-8{_}7034{_}Up sprang Sir Benedict, quite forgetting his wounded arm, capering lightly to and fro, now in the water, now out, with prodigious stir and splash and swearing oaths galore, until, his pallid cheek flushed and bright eyes a-dance, he had won the fish into the shallows and thence landed it right skilfully, where it thrashed and leapt, flashing in the sun.
10064-8{_}7035{_}"Ha, Yolande!"
10064-8{_}7036{_}he cried, "in the golden days thou wert ever fond of a goodly trout fresh caught and broiled upon a fire of--"  "Benedict!"
10064-8{_}7037{_}cried the Abbess, and, all forgetful of his hurt, caught him by his wounded arm, "O Sir Benedict!"
10064-8{_}7038{_}Now, man of iron though he seemed, Sir Benedict must needs start and flinch beneath her hold and grow livid by reason of the sharp pain of it; whereat she loosed him of a sudden and fell away, white hands tight clasped together.
10064-8{_}7039{_}"Ah Benedict!--I have hurt thee--again!"
10064-8{_}7040{_}she panted.
10064-8{_}7041{_}"Not so, 'twas when I landed the fish--my lady Abbess!"
10064-8{_}7042{_}Now at this she turned away and standing thus awhile very silent, presently raised her hand, whereat came two of her gentle nuns.
10064-8{_}7043{_}"Dear my daughters," said she, "take now Sir Benedict unto the camp and look to his hurt, anoint it as ye have seen me do.
10064-8{_}7044{_}Go!"
10064-8{_}7045{_}Nothing speaking, Sir Benedict bowed him humbly to the stately Abbess and went away between the two white-robed sisters and so was gone.
10064-8{_}7046{_}Slowly the Abbess turned to Beltane who had risen and was regarding her with a new and strange intensity, and meeting that look, her own glance wavered, sank, and she stood awhile gazing down into the murmurous waters; and as she stood thus, aware of his deep-searching eyes, into her pale cheek crept a flush that deepened and ever deepened.
10064-8{_}7047{_}"My lord," said she, very low and placid-seeming, "why dost thou look on me so?"
10064-8{_}7048{_}And for all her stately calm, her hand, which had clenched itself upon the silver crucifix, was woefully a-tremble.
10064-8{_}7049{_}"What--is it--my lord Beltane?"
10064-8{_}7050{_}"A thought, noble lady."
10064-8{_}7051{_}"What is thy thought?"
10064-8{_}7052{_}"Lady, 'tis this--that, an I might find a mother such as thee, then would I pay her homage on my knees, and love her and honour her for what I do know her, praying God to make me worthy--!"
10064-8{_}7053{_}So saying, he came a step towards her, faltered, stopped, and reached out appealing hands to her.
10064-8{_}7054{_}From red to white and from white to red again the colour flushed in cheek and brow while the Abbess hearkened to his words; then she looked on him with proud head uplifted and in her eyes a great and wondrous light, quick and passionate her slim hands came out to meet his--  A sudden clamour in the air!
10064-8{_}7055{_}A clash of arms!
10064-8{_}7056{_}A running of swift feet and Walkyn sprang betwixt them, his face grimed with dust and sweat, his armour gone, his great axe all bloody in his hand: "Master!"
10064-8{_}7057{_}he cried, "in Winisfarne lieth Pertolepe with over a thousand of his company, I judge--and in the woods 'twixt here and Winisfarne is Hollo of Revelsthorne marching on us through the woods with full five thousand of Ivo's picked levies, new come from Barham Broom!"
10064-8{_}7058{_}CHAPTER LX  TELLETH HOW THEY MARCHED FROM THE VALLEY OF BRAND   Within the camp was prodigious stir, a fanfare of trumpets and hoarse commands, where archers and pikemen, knights and men-at-arms were mustering; but nowhere was hurry or confusion, wherefore Beltane's heart rejoiced and he smiled glad-eyed as he came where, before Sir Benedict and the assembled council, stood Roger and Ulf with fifteen of their twenty men.
10064-8{_}7059{_}"Walkyn," said Sir Benedict, what time his esquire strapped and buckled him into his bright armour, "where-abouts do they hold their march?"
10064-8{_}7060{_}"Scarce twenty miles from here due west, lord."
10064-8{_}7061{_}"Ha, and they come through the forest, ye say?"
10064-8{_}7062{_}questioned Sir Brian, "so shall they move more slowly, methinks."
10064-8{_}7063{_}"Why see you, messire," said Walkyn, "they march by way of Felindre that was once a fair town, and from Felindre is a road that leadeth through the wild unto this valley of Brand."
10064-8{_}7064{_}"So have we, I judge, 'twixt six and seven hours," quoth Hacon of Trant.
10064-8{_}7065{_}"Less, Hacon, less!"
10064-8{_}7066{_}said Sir Benedict, beginning to stride up and down in his clanking armour, "Sir Rollo ever rideth with busy spur, and he will doubtless push on amain nor spare his men that he may take us unprepared.
10064-8{_}7067{_}Put it at five hours, Hacon, mayhap less!"
10064-8{_}7068{_}"'Tis so I pray!"
10064-8{_}7069{_}said Beltane, glancing towards the glowing west, "and in two hours it will be dark, my lords!
10064-8{_}7070{_}Walkyn, thy company doth lack for five, meseemeth?"
10064-8{_}7071{_}"Aye, master--for five; two fell in Winisfarne where I lay in bonds; other three were slain in the pursuit."
10064-8{_}7072{_}"Saw Sir Rollo aught of thee?"
10064-8{_}7073{_}"Nay, lord, we lay well hid."
10064-8{_}7074{_}"'Tis very well.
10064-8{_}7075{_}Are they many?"
10064-8{_}7076{_}"Of horsemen I counted full three thousand, master."
10064-8{_}7077{_}"And I, lord," quoth Ulf, "did reckon over two thousand foot."
10064-8{_}7078{_}"'Tis a fairish company!"
10064-8{_}7079{_}said Sir Brian.
10064-8{_}7080{_}"And I do lack my sword-arm!"
10064-8{_}7081{_}sighed Sir Benedict, "but my left hath served me well ere now."
10064-8{_}7082{_}"And Sir Pertolepe lieth yet in Winisfarne!"
10064-8{_}7083{_}said Beltane thoughtfully.
10064-8{_}7084{_}"Aye," nodded Sir Benedict, "and shall march south to cut off our retreat if haply any of us escape Sir Rollo's onfall."
10064-8{_}7085{_}"So should we strike camp and march forthright," said Sir Brian.
10064-8{_}7086{_}"March--aye, but whither?"
10064-8{_}7087{_}questioned Sir Hacon.
10064-8{_}7088{_}"We are threatened on two fronts and for the rest, we have the trackless wilderness!
10064-8{_}7089{_}Whither would'st march, Brian?"
10064-8{_}7090{_}"South to Belsaye," answered Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7091{_}"South through the wild until we strike the western road by Thornaby.
10064-8{_}7092{_}I with certain others will form a rear-guard and hold Sir Rollo in play what time our main body presses on at speed."
10064-8{_}7093{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}7094{_}quoth Sir Hacon, "and what of Red Pertolepe?
10064-8{_}7095{_}Truly our case is desperate methinks, old comrade!"
10064-8{_}7096{_}"Why, 'tis not the first time we have out-faced desperate odds, Hacon!"
10064-8{_}7097{_}"Aye, verily, Benedict--thy cool head and cunning strategy have saved us from dungeon and death a score of times, but then were we a chosen company, swift at onfall or retreat, well mounted and equipped-- to-night we go hampered with our wounded and these lady nuns.
10064-8{_}7098{_}So is our case desperate, Benedict, and needeth desperate remedy--"  "And that, methinks, I've found, messire!"
10064-8{_}7099{_}quoth Beltane, and rising up he looked upon them all, his eye bright with sudden purpose.
10064-8{_}7100{_}"Hark ye, my lords!
10064-8{_}7101{_}Great and valiant knights do I know ye, one and all--wise in experience of battle and much versed in warlike stratagem beyond my understanding; but this is the wild-wood where only wood-craft shall advantage us.
10064-8{_}7102{_}Within these wilds your tactics shall avail nothing nor all your trampling chivalry--here must be foresters that may go silent and unseen amid the leaves, 'neath whose trained feet no twig shall snap, who smite unseen from brush and thicket and being wise in wood-craft thus make the forest their ally.
10064-8{_}7103{_}And, lords, I am a forester; all my days the greenwood hath been my home, and in my loneliness I made the trees my friends.
10064-8{_}7104{_}So, I pray you, let me with three hundred chosen foresters keep our rear to-night, and this night the forest shall fight for us and Sir Rollo rue the hour he dared adventure him within the green.
10064-8{_}7105{_}Messires, how say you?"
10064-8{_}7106{_}"Why my lord, 'tis very well!"
10064-8{_}7107{_}sighed Sir Benedict, glancing down at his wounded arm, "I, for one, do agree right heartily."
10064-8{_}7108{_}"And I!"
10064-8{_}7109{_}nodded Sir Brian.
10064-8{_}7110{_}"And I also!"
10064-8{_}7111{_}quoth Sir Hacon, "though 'tis a far cry to Belsaye and I love not to be pent within walls, and with Red Pertolepe threatening our flank 'tis a very parlous case, methinks."
