10064-8{_}7112{_}"And thou art ever at thy best where danger is, Hacon," said Sir Benedict, "so will I give thee charge of our van-ward!"
10064-8{_}7113{_}Now hereupon Sir Hacon's gloom vanished and rising up, he smiled and forthwith did on his great war-helm.
10064-8{_}7114{_}"Then it is agreed!"
10064-8{_}7115{_}said Beltane and beckoned to Roger and Walkyn; quoth he:  "Good friends, go now and choose three hundred trusty fellows, skilled foresters all; look that each doth bear flint and steel for by yon clouds I judge 'twill be a dark night.
10064-8{_}7116{_}Let every fire within the camp be quenched and the ground well cooled with water, that by the feel of it none may know how long we have removed--see you to this, Ulf."
10064-8{_}7117{_}Now when the mighty three were gone about the business, their fifteen lusty fellows at their heels, Beltane turned and pointed westward, and lo!
10064-8{_}7118{_}the sun was set.
10064-8{_}7119{_}"Messires," said he, "you were wise, methinks, to mount and away ere the night fall.
10064-8{_}7120{_}To-night, since the moon is hid, 'twill be very dark amid the trees, therefore let Orson guide you--he is forest-bred and well knoweth the way to Thornaby.
10064-8{_}7121{_}Heaven prosper you, for in your valiant keeping is the safety of--of our noble lady Abbess--and her ladies.
10064-8{_}7122{_}So mount, my lords, press on with what speed ye may, and God aid us this night each and every--fare ye well!"
10064-8{_}7123{_}Presently the trumpets sounded and forthwith armour was buckled on, horses saddled, while everywhere was stir and bustle of departure, what time, within his osier hut, my Beltane was busily doing on his armour, and, being in haste, making slow business of it; thrice he essayed to buckle a certain strap and thrice it escaped him, when lo!
10064-8{_}7124{_}came a slim white hand to do it for him, and turning, he beheld the lady Abbess.
10064-8{_}7125{_}And in her eyes was yet that soft and radiant look, but nought said she until Beltane stood armed from head to heel, until she had girt the great sword about him; then she set her hands upon his shoulders:  "Beltane," said she soft-voiced, "thou didst yearn for thy mother, so is she come to thee at last, dear son!"
10064-8{_}7126{_}So saying, she drew him down into her embrace.
10064-8{_}7127{_}"O Beltane, son of mine, long, long have I waited-- aye, bitter, weary years, and oft-times in my sorrow I have dreamed of this hour--the arms about thee are thy mother's arms!"
10064-8{_}7128{_}Now fell Beltane upon his knees and caught those white and gentle hands and kissed them; quoth he:  "Mother--O dear my mother, ne'er did I know how deep had been my need of thee until now.
10064-8{_}7129{_}And yet, all unknowing, I have yearned for thee; in my youth I did love all sweet and gentle things in thy stead--the trees, the tender flowers, the murmurous brooks--these did I love in place of thee for that mine heart did yearn and hunger for a mother's tender love--" Here needs must she stoop, all soft whispers and tender mother-cries, to kiss him oft, to lay her cheek upon his golden head and murmur over him.
10064-8{_}7130{_}"And thou wilt love thy mother, Beltane--thou wilt love thy unknown mother--now and always, for that she is thy mother?"
10064-8{_}7131{_}"I will love her and honour her now and always, for that my mother is a sweet and noble woman!"
10064-8{_}7132{_}"And thou didst need me, Beltane, in thy lonely childhood thou didst need me, and I--O God pity me--I was far from thee!
10064-8{_}7133{_}But, dear my son, because I could not cherish thee within these arms I strove to love and cherish all motherless children for thy dear sake and to grieve for all sorrowing mothers.
10064-8{_}7134{_}So builded I the nunnery at Winisfarne and there sought to bring solace and comfort to desolate hearts because my heart was so desolate for thee, my babe, my Beltane.
10064-8{_}7135{_}And I have prayed unceasing unto God, and He, in His infinite mercy, hath given thee to my arms again--"  A trumpet brayed harsh and loud near by, whereat those tender mother-arms drew him closer yet within their sheltering embrace.
10064-8{_}7136{_}"Sweet son," she sighed, "methinks death is very near each one of us to-night--but I have held thee to my heart, have felt thy kisses and heard thy loving words--now if death come how shall it avail 'gainst such love as ours?
10064-8{_}7137{_}Sir Benedict telleth me thou hast chosen the post of danger--'tis so I would have it, dear my son, and thy proud mother's prayers go with thee--God keep thee--O God keep thee, my Beltane--ah, there sounds again the clarion bidding me from thee!
10064-8{_}7138{_}Kiss now thy mother farewell, for alas!
10064-8{_}7139{_}I must be gone!"
10064-8{_}7140{_}So presently Beltane brought the Abbess where stood Sir Benedict with an easy-paced jennet for her use and his company formed up in column beyond the camp.
10064-8{_}7141{_}Then Beltane lifted the lady Abbess to the saddle and with her hand yet clasped in his, reached the other to Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7142{_}"My lord of Bourne," said he, "dear my friend, to thy care I give this lady Abbess, Duchess of Pentavalon--my well-beloved and noble mother.
10064-8{_}7143{_}O Benedict, no prouder son than I in all the world, methinks--nor one so humble!
10064-8{_}7144{_}God send we meet again anon, but now--fare ye well!"
10064-8{_}7145{_}Saying the which, Beltane caught his mother's hand to his lips, and turning him suddenly about, hasted to Roger and Walkyn and the chosen three hundred.
10064-8{_}7146{_}And in a while, the nuns and wounded in their midst, Sir Benedict's steel-clad column moved forward up the slope.
10064-8{_}7147{_}First rode Sir Hacon and his knights in the van and last Sir Benedict with his grim men-at-arms to form a rear-ward, while archers and pikemen marched upon their flanks.
10064-8{_}7148{_}With ring of steel, with jingle of stirrup and bridle-chain they swung away up the slope and plunging into the gloom of the forest were gone; only Sir Benedict paused to turn in his saddle and lift unwounded arm in salutation ere he too vanished into the shadows of the wild-wood.
10064-8{_}7149{_}Awhile stood Beltane before the three hundred, his head bowed as one in meditation until the sound of voices, the ring and clash of their companions' going was died away; then looked he at the cloudy sky already deepening to evening, and round about upon the encircling woods.
10064-8{_}7150{_}"The wind is from the south, methinks!"
10064-8{_}7151{_}said he.
10064-8{_}7152{_}"Aye, master," nodded Walkyn.
10064-8{_}7153{_}"South-westerly!"
10064-8{_}7154{_}quoth Roger.
10064-8{_}7155{_}Now came Beltane and looked upon his company, tall, lusty fellows they, whose bold, sun-tanned faces proclaimed them free men of the forest-lands; and beholding their hardy look Beltane's eye brightened.
10064-8{_}7156{_}"Comrades," quoth he, "we be foresters all, and the wild-wood our home and playground.
10064-8{_}7157{_}But yonder from the west do march full five thousand of Duke Ivo's knights and soldiery-men, they, of courts, of town and city, so now will we teach them 'tis an ill thing to adventure them 'gainst trained foresters within the green.
10064-8{_}7158{_}List now--and mark me well, for, an our plan do fail, there shall few of us live to see to-morrow's sun."
10064-8{_}7159{_}Then Beltane spake them plain and to the point, insomuch that when all was said, these hardy foresters stood mute awhile, desperate fellows though they were; then laughed they fierce and loud, and flourished sword and bow-stave and so fell to clamourous talk.
10064-8{_}7160{_}Now did Beltane divide the three hundred into five companies of sixty; over the first company he set Walkyn, over the second, Roger, over the third, Ulf, over the fourth Jenkyn o' the Ford.
10064-8{_}7161{_}Then spake he on this wise:  "Walkyn, take now these sixty good fellows and march you north-westerly yonder across the valley; let your men lie well hid a bow-shot within the forest, but do you stay upon the verge of the forest and watch for the coming of our foes.
10064-8{_}7162{_}And when they be come, 'tis sure they will plant outposts and sentinels within the green, so be ye wary to smite outpost and sentinel suddenly and that none may hear within the camp nor take alarm; when 'tis done, cry you thrice like unto a curlew that we may know.
10064-8{_}7163{_}Are all things understood?"
10064-8{_}7164{_}"Aye, lord!"
10064-8{_}7165{_}they cried, one and all.
10064-8{_}7166{_}"Why then, be ye cautious each and every, for, an our foes do take alarm, so shall it be our death.
10064-8{_}7167{_}March, Walkyn--away!"
10064-8{_}7168{_}Forthwith Walkyn lifted his axe and strode off up the slope until he and his sixty men had vanished quite into the glooming woods to the north-west.
10064-8{_}7169{_}"Jenkyn, didst hear my commands to Walkyn, so shalt thou do also--your post doth lie to the east, yonder."
10064-8{_}7170{_}"Aye, master, and look'ee now--my signal shall be three owl-hoots, master, look'ee!"
10064-8{_}7171{_}So saying, Jenkyn turned, his sixty at his heels, and swung away until they were lost to sight in the woods to the east.
10064-8{_}7172{_}"Ulf the Strong, thy post doth lie south-westerly, and Roger's south-easterly; thus I, lying south, shall have ye on my left and right: go get ye to your places, watch ye, and wait in patience for the signals, and when time for action cometh, be swift and sure."
10064-8{_}7173{_}Away marched Roger and Ulf with their companies, and presently were gone, and there remained within the little valley only Beltane and his sixty men.
10064-8{_}7174{_}Awhile he stood to look to the north and east and west but nought saw he save the dense gloom of forest growing dark and ever darker with evening.
10064-8{_}7175{_}Then of a sudden turned he, and summoning his company, strode away into the forest to the south.
10064-8{_}7176{_}Thus, as night fell, the valley of Brand lay deserted quite, and no sound brake the pervading quiet save the wind that moaned feebly through those dark and solitary woods wherein Death lay hid, so very silent--so very patient, but Death in grim and awful shape.
10064-8{_}7177{_}CHAPTER LXI  HOW THE FOREST FOUGHT FOR THEM   A hum upon the night-wind, lost, ever and anon, in wailing gust, yet a hum that never ceased; a sound that grew and grew, loud and ever more loud until it seemed to fill the very night, a dreadful sound, ominous and threatening, a sound to shake the boldest heart--the ring and tramp of an armed, oncoming multitude.
10064-8{_}7178{_}Now, lying amid the leaves and fern with Cnut and the small man Prat beside him.
10064-8{_}7179{_}Beltane presently espied certain figures moving in the valley below, stealthy figures that were men of Sir Rollo's van-ward.
10064-8{_}7180{_}Soft-creeping they approached the deserted camp, soft-creeping they entered it; and suddenly their trumpets brayed loud and long, and, dying away, gave place to the ring and trampling thunder of the advancing host.
10064-8{_}7181{_}On they came, knights and men-at-arms, rank upon rank, company by company, until the valley seemed full of the dull gleam of their armour and the air rang loud with clash and jingle and the trample of countless hooves.
10064-8{_}7182{_}Yet still they came, horsemen and foot-men, and ever the sound of them waxed upon the air, a harsh, confused din--and ever, from the glooming woods above, Death stared down on them.
10064-8{_}7183{_}And now the trumpets blew amain, lights flickered and flared, as one by one, fires were lighted whose red glow flashed back from many a helm and shield and breast-plate, from broad gisarm and twinkling lance-point, what time, above the confused hum, above stamping hooves and clashing armour, voices shouted hoarse commands.
10064-8{_}7184{_}So, little by little, from chaos order was wrought, pack-horse and charger were led away to be watered and picketed and gleaming figures sank wearily about the many camp-fires where food was already preparing.
10064-8{_}7185{_}In a while, from the stir of the camp, bright with its many watch-fires, divers small groups of men were detached, and, pike and gisarm on shoulder, began to mount toward the forest at varying points.
10064-8{_}7186{_}Hereupon, Beltane reached out in the dark and touched the small man Prat the Archer.
10064-8{_}7187{_}Quoth he:  "Hither come their outposts, go now and bring up my company,--and bid them come silently!"
10064-8{_}7188{_}Forthwith Prat sank down among the fern and was gone, while Beltane watched, keen-eyed, where four men of Sir Hollo's outposts climbed the slope hard by.
10064-8{_}7189{_}And one was singing, and one was cursing, and two were quarrelling, and all four, Beltane judged, were men aweary with long marching.
10064-8{_}7190{_}Thus, singing, cursing, quarrelling, came they to keep their ward within these dark and silent woods, crashing through the underbrush careless of their going and all unheeding the sombre, stealthy forms that rose up so silently behind them and before from brush and brake and thicket, creeping figures that moved only when the night-wind moaned in the shivering leaves.
10064-8{_}7191{_}Beltane's dagger was out and he rose up from the fern, crouched and strung for action--but from the gloom near by rose a sudden, strange flurry amid the leaves, a whimpering sound evil to hear and swiftly ended, a groan, a cry choked to strangling gasp and thereafter-- silence, save for the fitful wailing of the wind--a long, breathless pause; then, high and clear rose the cry of an owl thrice repeated, and presently small Prat was beside him in the fern again.
10064-8{_}7192{_}"Lord," said he softly, albeit panting a little, "these men were fools!
10064-8{_}7193{_}We do but wait our comrades' signals now."
10064-8{_}7194{_}And he fell to cleansing his dagger-blade carefully with a handful of bracken.
10064-8{_}7195{_}"Ha--list ye!"
10064-8{_}7196{_}whispered Cnut, "there sounds Ulf's warning, methinks!"
10064-8{_}7197{_}And from the gloom on their left a frog croaked hoarsely.
10064-8{_}7198{_}A hundred watch-fires blazed in the valley below and around each fire armour glittered; little by little the great camp grew to silence and rest until nought was heard but the stamp and snorting of the many horses and the cries of the sentinels below.
10064-8{_}7199{_}But ever dagger in hand Beltane strained eyes and ears northward across the valley, while big Cnut bit his nails and wriggled beside him in the bracken, and small Prat softly snapped his fingers; so waited they with ears on the stretch and eyes that glared ever to the north.
10064-8{_}7200{_}At last, faint and far across the valley, rose the doleful cry of a curlew thrice repeated, the which was answered from the east by the hooting of an owl, which again was caught up like an echo, and repeated thrice upon their right.
10064-8{_}7201{_}Then Beltane sheathed his dagger.
10064-8{_}7202{_}"Look," said he, "Cnut--Prat, look north and tell me what ye see!"
10064-8{_}7203{_}"Fire, my lord!"
10064-8{_}7204{_}quoth Prat.
10064-8{_}7205{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}7206{_}it burneth well--see, see how it spreads!"
10064-8{_}7207{_}"And there again--in the east," said Cnut, "Oho!
10064-8{_}7208{_}Jenkyn is busy--look, master!"
10064-8{_}7209{_}"Aye, and Roger too!"
10064-8{_}7210{_}said Beltane, grim-lipped, "our ring of fire is well-nigh complete--it lacketh but for us and Ulf--to work, then!"
10064-8{_}7211{_}Came the sound of flint meeting steel--a sound that spread along the ranks that lay unseen beyond Prat and Cnut.
10064-8{_}7212{_}And behold--a spark!
10064-8{_}7213{_}a glow!
10064-8{_}7214{_}a little flame that died down, leapt up, caught upon dry grass and bracken, seized upon crackling twigs, flared up high and ever fiercer--a devouring flame, hungry and yellow-tongued that licked along the earth--a vengeful flame, pitiless and unrelenting--a host of fiery demons that leapt and danced with crackling laughter changing little by little to an angry roar that was the voice of awful doom.
10064-8{_}7215{_}Now of a sudden above the hiss of flame, from the valley of Brand a cry went up--a shout--a roar of fear and amaze and thereafter rose a wild clamour; a babel inarticulate, split, ever and anon, by frantic trumpet-blast.
10064-8{_}7216{_}But ever the dreadful hubbub waxed and grew, shrieks and cries and the screaming of maddened horses with the awful, rolling thunder of their fierce-galloping hooves!
10064-8{_}7217{_}Within that valley of doom Death was abroad already, Death in many dire shapes.
10064-8{_}7218{_}Proud knights, doughty archers and men-at-arms who had fronted death unmoved on many a stricken field, wept aloud and crouched upon their knees and screamed--but not so loud as those wild and maddened horses, that, bursting all bonds asunder, reared and leapt with lashing hooves, and, choked with rolling smoke-clouds, blinded by flame, plunged headlong through and over the doomed camp, wave upon wave of wild-flung heads and tossing manes.
10064-8{_}7219{_}On they came, with nought to let or stay them, their wild hooves trampling down hut of osier and silken tent, spurning the trembling earth and filling the air with flying clods; and wheresoever they galloped there was flame to meet them, so swerved they, screaming their terror and fled round and round within the valley.
10064-8{_}7220{_}So raced they blindly to and fro and back and forth, trampling down, maiming and mangling 'neath reddened, cruel hooves all and every that chanced to lie athwart their wild career: on and ever on they galloped until sobbing, panting, they fell, to be crushed 'neath the thundering hooves behind.
10064-8{_}7221{_}Within the little valley of Brand Death was rife in many and awful shapes that no eye might see, for the many watch-fires were scattered and trampled out; but up from that pit of doom rose shrieks and cries and many hateful sounds--sounds to pierce the brain and ring there everlastingly.
10064-8{_}7222{_}Thus Beltane, marching swift to the south at the head of his three hundred foresters, heard nought of their joyful acclaim, heeded not their triumph, saw nought of watchful Roger's troubled glances, but went with head bowed low, with pallid cheek and eyes wide-staring, for he saw yet again the fierce leap of those merciless flames and in his ears rang the screams and cries of Sir Rollo's proud chivalry.
10064-8{_}7223{_}CHAPTER LXII  HOW THEY CAME TO BELSAYE FOR THE THIRD TIME   The sun was high as they came to the western road that led to the ford at Thornaby, but upon the edge of the forest Beltane stopped of a sudden to stare up at an adjacent tree.
10064-8{_}7224{_}"What is't, master?"
10064-8{_}7225{_}questioned Roger, halting beside him.
10064-8{_}7226{_}"An arrow--and new-shot by the look of it!"
10064-8{_}7227{_}said Beltane, gloomily.
10064-8{_}7228{_}"Aye master, and it hath travelled far--see, it hath scarce pierced the bark!"
10064-8{_}7229{_}"'Twas shot from the brush yonder, methinks," said Beltane, pointing to the dense underwood that skirted the opposite side of the dusty highway.
10064-8{_}7230{_}"Reach me it down, Roger!"
10064-8{_}7231{_}so saying Beltane stooped and hove Roger aloft until he could grasp and draw the arrow from the tree.
10064-8{_}7232{_}"Here is no woodsman's shaft, master!"
10064-8{_}7233{_}quoth Roger, turning the missile over in his hand ere he gave it to Beltane, "no forester doth wing his shafts so."
10064-8{_}7234{_}"True!"
10064-8{_}7235{_}nodded Beltane, frowning at the arrow.
10064-8{_}7236{_}"Walkyn, Ulf!
10064-8{_}7237{_}here hath been an ambushment, methinks--'tis a likely place for such.
10064-8{_}7238{_}Let our company scatter and search amid the fern hereabouts--"  But even as he spake came a cry, a clamour of voices, and Prat the archer came frowning and snapping his restless fingers.
10064-8{_}7239{_}"My lord," said he, "yonder doth lie my good comrade Martin and three other fellows of my archer-company that marched with Sir Benedict, and all dead, lord, slain by arrows all four."
10064-8{_}7240{_}"Show me!"
10064-8{_}7241{_}said Beltane.
10064-8{_}7242{_}And when he had viewed and touched those stark and pallid forms that lay scattered here and there amid the bracken, his anxious frown deepened.
10064-8{_}7243{_}"These have been dead men full six hours!"
10064-8{_}7244{_}quoth he.
10064-8{_}7245{_}"Aye, lord," says Prat, "and 'tis unmeet such good fellows should lie here for beasts to tear; shall we bury them?"
10064-8{_}7246{_}"Not so!"
10064-8{_}7247{_}answered Beltane, turning away.
10064-8{_}7248{_}"Take their shafts and fall to your ranks--we must march forthright!"
10064-8{_}7249{_}Thus soon the three hundred were striding fast behind Beltane, keeping ever to the forest yet well within bow-shot of the road, and, though they travelled at speed they went very silently, as only foresters might.
10064-8{_}7250{_}In a while Beltane brought them to those high wooded banks betwixt which the road ran winding down to Thornaby Ford--that self-same hilly road where, upon a time, the Red Pertolepe had surprised the lawless company of Gilles of Brandonmere; and, now as then, the dark defile was littered with the wrack of fight, fallen charges that kicked and snorted in their pain or lay mute and still, men in battered harness that stared up from the dust, all unseeing, upon the new day.
10064-8{_}7251{_}They lay thick within the sunken road but thicker beside the ford, and they dotted the white road beyond, grim signs of Sir Benedict's stubborn retreat.
10064-8{_}7252{_}Hereupon Beltane halted his hard-breathing foresters and bidding them rest awhile and break their fast, hasted down into the roadway with Walkyn and Cnut and Black Roger.
10064-8{_}7253{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}7254{_}cried Walkyn, pointing to divers of the slain that hampered their going, "these be Pertolepe's rogues--"  "Aye," quoth Roger, throwing back his mail-coif, "and yonder lie four, five--six of Sir Benedict's good fellows!
10064-8{_}7255{_}It hath been a dour fight hereabouts--they have fought every yard of the way!"
10064-8{_}7256{_}"Forsooth," nodded Cnut, "Sir Benedict is ever most fierce when he retreats, look you."
10064-8{_}7257{_}A while stood Beltane in that dark defile, the which, untouched as jet by the sun's level beams, struck dank and chill, a place of gloom and awful silence--so stood he, glancing from one still form to another, twice he knelt to look more closely on the dead and each time he rose thereafter, his brow was blacker and he shivered, despite his mantle.
10064-8{_}7258{_}"'Tis strange," said he, "and passing strange that they should all lie dead--not a living man among them!
10064-8{_}7259{_}How think you Roger?"
10064-8{_}7260{_}"I think, lord, others have been here afore us.
10064-8{_}7261{_}See you this knight now, his gorget loosed off--"  "O messire!"
10064-8{_}7262{_}said a faint voice hard by, "if ye have any pity save me from the crone--for the love of Christ let not the hag slay me as she hath so many--save me!"
10064-8{_}7263{_}Starting round, Beltane espied a pale face that glared up at him from a thick furze-bush beside the way, a youthful face albeit haggard and drawn.
10064-8{_}7264{_}"Fear not!"
10064-8{_}7265{_}said Beltane, kneeling beside the wounded youth, "thy life is safe from us.
10064-8{_}7266{_}But what mean you by talk of hag and crone?"
10064-8{_}7267{_}"Ah, messire, to-day, ere the dawn, we fell upon Sir Benedict of Bourne--a seditious lord who hath long withstood Duke Ivo.
10064-8{_}7268{_}But though his men were few they fought hard and gained the ford ahead of us.
10064-8{_}7269{_}And in the fight I, with many others as ye see, was smitten down and the fight rolled on and left us here in the dust.
10064-8{_}7270{_}As I lay, striving to tend my hurt and hearkening to the sighs and groans of the stricken, I heard a scream, and looking about, beheld an ancient woman--busied with her knife--slaying--slaying and robbing the dead--ah, behold her--with the black-haired archer--yonder!"
10064-8{_}7271{_}And verily Roger stepped forth of the underwood that clothed the steep, dragging a thing of rags and tatters, a wretched creature, bent and wrinkled, that mopped and mowed with toothless chaps and clutched a misshapen bundle in yellow, talon-like fingers, and these yellow fingers were splotched horribly with dark stains even as were the rags that covered her.
10064-8{_}7272{_}She whined and whimpered querulously, mouthing inarticulate plaints and prayers as Roger haled her along, with Cnut and Walkyn, fierce and scowling, behind.
10064-8{_}7273{_}Having brought her to Beltane, Roger loosed her, and wrenching away her bundle, opened it, and lo!
10064-8{_}7274{_}a yellow-gleaming hoard of golden neck-chains, of rings and armlets, of golden spurs and belt-buckles, the which he incontinent scattered at Beltane's feet; whereon the gibbering creature screamed in high-pitched, cracked and ancient voice, and, screeching, threw herself upon the gold and fell to scrabbling among the dust with her gnarled and bony fingers; and ever as she raked and raked, she screeched harsh and high--a hateful noise that ended, of a sudden, in a wheezing sob, and sinking down, she lay outstretched and silent, her wrinkled face in the dust and a cloth-yard shaft transfixing her yellow throat.
10064-8{_}7275{_}So swift had death been dealt that all men fell back a pace and were yet staring down at this awful dead thing when forth from the brush an archer crawled painfully, his bow yet in his hand, and so lay, panting loud and hoarse.
10064-8{_}7276{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}7277{_}cried Cnut, "'tis lusty Siward of our archers!
10064-8{_}7278{_}How now, Siward?"
10064-8{_}7279{_}"I'm sped, Cnut!"
10064-8{_}7280{_}groaned Siward, "but yon hag lieth dead, so am I-- content.
10064-8{_}7281{_}I've watched her slay John that was my comrade, you'll mind-- for his armlet.
10064-8{_}7282{_}And--good Sir Hugh she stabbed,--yonder he lieth--him she slew for--spurs and chain.
10064-8{_}7283{_}When I fell I--dropped my bow--in the brush, yonder--I have been two hours creeping--a dozen yards to--reach my bow but--I got it at last--Aha!"
10064-8{_}7284{_}And Siward, feebly pointing to the ancient, dead woman, strove to laugh and so--died.
10064-8{_}7285{_}Then Beltane turned, and coming beside the wounded youth spake him tender and compassionate.
10064-8{_}7286{_}"Young sir, we must hence, but first can I do aught forthee?"
10064-8{_}7287{_}"O messire, an I might--come to the river--water!"
10064-8{_}7288{_}Saying no word, Beltane stooped and lifting the young knight very carefully, bore him down toward the ford.
10064-8{_}7289{_}"Messire," quoth the young knight, stifling his groans, "art very strong and wondrous gentle withal!"
10064-8{_}7290{_}Presently Beltane brought him beside the river, and while the youth drank, laid bare an ugly wound above the knee and bathed it with his hand, and, thereafter, tearing a strip from his ragged cloak, he bound it tight above the hurt, (even as he had seen Sir Fidelis do) and thus stayed the bleeding.
10064-8{_}7291{_}Now while this was a-doing, the young knight must needs talk.
10064-8{_}7292{_}"Ho!"
10064-8{_}7293{_}cried he, "'twas a good fight, messire, and he who gave me this was none other than Benedict of Bourne himself--whom our good Duke doth fondly imagine pent up within Thrasfordham!
10064-8{_}7294{_}O indeed 'twas Sir Benedict, I saw his hawk-face plain ere he closed his vizor, and he fought left-handed.
10064-8{_}7295{_}Moreover, beside him I recognised the leaping dog blazoned on the shield of Hacon of Trant--Oho, this shall be wondrous news for Duke Ivo, methinks.
10064-8{_}7296{_}But, faith, 'tis wonder how he escaped Sir Rollo, and as for the outlaw Beltane we saw nought of him--Sir Pertolepe vows he was not of this company--mayhap Sir Rollo hath him, 'tis so I pray--so, peradventure I shall see him hang yet!
10064-8{_}7297{_}My grateful thanks, messire, for thy tender care of me.
10064-8{_}7298{_}At home I have a mother that watcheth and prayeth for me--prithee tell me thy name that she may remember it in her prayers?"
10064-8{_}7299{_}"I am called Beltane the Outlaw, sir knight--and I charge thee to heed that thy bandage slip not, lest the bleeding start afresh--fare thee well!"
10064-8{_}7300{_}So saying, Beltane turned and went on across the ford what time the young knight, propped upon weak elbow, stared after him wide of eye and mouth.
10064-8{_}7301{_}Forthwith Beltane, setting horn to lip, sounded the rally, and very soon the three hundred crossed the ford and swung off to the left into the green.
10064-8{_}7302{_}Thus, heartened and refreshed by food and rest, they pressed on amain southward through the forest with eyes and ears alert and on the strain; what time grim Sir Benedict, riding with his rearguard, peered through the dust of battle but saw only the threatening column of the foe upon the forest road behind, rank upon rank far as the eye could reach, and the dense green of the adjacent woods on either flank whence unseen arrows whizzed ever and anon to glance from his heavy armour.
10064-8{_}7303{_}"Ha, Benedict!"
10064-8{_}7304{_}quoth Sir Brian, "they do know thee, methinks, 'spite thy plain armour--'tis the third shaft hath struck thee in as many minutes!"
10064-8{_}7305{_}"So needs must I stifle and sweat within closed casque!"
10064-8{_}7306{_}Sir Benedict groaned.
10064-8{_}7307{_}Upon his right hand Sir Brian rode and upon his left his chiefest esquire, and oft needs must they wheel their chargers to front the thunderous onset of Red Pertolepe's fierce van, at the which times Sir Benedict laughed and gibed through his vizor as he thrust and smote left-armed, parrying sword and lance-point right skilfully nevertheless, since shield he bare none.
10064-8{_}7308{_}Time and again they beat back their assailants thus, until spent and short of wind they gave place to three fresh knights.
10064-8{_}7309{_}"By Our Lady of Hartismere!"
10064-8{_}7310{_}panted Sir Brian, "but thy left arm serves thee well, Benedict!"
10064-8{_}7311{_}"'Tis fair, Brian, 'tis fair, God be thanked!"
10064-8{_}7312{_}sighed Sir Benedict, eyeing his reeking blade, "though I missed my thrust 'neath yon gentle knight's gorget--"  "Yet shore clean through his helm, my lord!"
10064-8{_}7313{_}quoth young Walter the esquire.
10064-8{_}7314{_}"Why truly, 'tis a good blade, this of mine," said Sir Benedict, and sighed again.
10064-8{_}7315{_}"Art doleful, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7316{_}questioned Sir Brian, "'tis not like thee when steel is ringing, man."
10064-8{_}7317{_}"In very sooth, Brian, I hanker for knowledge of our Beltane--ha, Walter!"
10064-8{_}7318{_}he cried suddenly, "lower thy vizor, boy--down with it, I say!"
10064-8{_}7319{_}"Nay, dear my lord, fain would I breathe the sweet, cool air--but a moment and--"  The young esquire rose up stiffly in his stirrups, threw up gauntleted hands and swaying from the high saddle, pitched down crashing into the dust.
10064-8{_}7320{_}"Alas!
10064-8{_}7321{_}there endeth my poor Walter!"
10064-8{_}7322{_}sighed Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7323{_}"Aye, a shaft between the eyes, poor lad!
10064-8{_}7324{_}A curse on these unseen archers!"
10064-8{_}7325{_}quoth Sir Brian, beckoning a pikeman to lead forward the riderless horse.
10064-8{_}7326{_}"Ha--look yonder, Benedict--we are beset in flank, and by dismounted knights from the underwood.
10064-8{_}7327{_}See, as I live 'tis the nuns they make for!"
10064-8{_}7328{_}Nothing saying, Sir Benedict spurred forward beside his hard-pressed company; in the midst of the column was dire tumult and shouting, where, from the dense woods upon their left a body of knights sheathed in steel from head to foot were cutting their way toward the lady Abbess, who, conspicuous in her white habit, was soothing her frightened palfrey.
10064-8{_}7329{_}All about her a shouting, reeling press of Sir Benedict's light-armed footmen were giving back and back before the swing of ponderous axe and mace and sword, were smitten down and trampled 'neath those resistless, steel-clad ranks.
10064-8{_}7330{_}"Ha!
10064-8{_}7331{_}the Abbess!"
10064-8{_}7332{_}they cried, "yield us the lady Abbess!"
10064-8{_}7333{_}Into this close and desperate affray Sir Benedict spurred, striving with voice and hand to re-form his broken ranks, hewing him a path by dint of sword until he had won beside the Abbess.
10064-8{_}7334{_}"Yolande!"
10064-8{_}7335{_}he shouted above the din, "keep thou beside me close--close, Yolande--stoop--ah, stoop thy head that I may cover thee--the debate waxeth a little sharp hereabouts!"
10064-8{_}7336{_}Even as he spake he reeled 'neath the blow of a heavy mace, steadied himself, cut down his smiter, and thrust and smote amain until the grim, fierce-shouting ranks gave back before the sweep of that long sword.
10064-8{_}7337{_}"See, Yolande!"
10064-8{_}7338{_}he panted, hard-breathing, "see yonder where my good Hacon spurs in to our relief--ha, mighty lance!"
10064-8{_}7339{_}"Ah, Benedict," cried the Abbess, pale-lipped but calm of eye, "of what avail?
10064-8{_}7340{_}'Tis me they seek, though wherefore I know not, so--dear Benedict--let me go.

10064-8{_}7343{_}I must go--I will go!
10064-8{_}7344{_}My lord, let me pass-- loose my bridle--"  A hunting horn fiercely winded among the woods hard by!
10064-8{_}7345{_}A confused roar of harsh voices and forth of the green four terrible figures sprang, two that smote with long-shafted axes and two that plied ponderous broadswords; and behind these men were others, lean and brown-faced-- the very woods seemed alive with them.
10064-8{_}7346{_}And from these fierce ranks a mighty shout rent the air:  "Arise!
10064-8{_}7347{_}Arise!
10064-8{_}7348{_}Ha, Beltane--Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}7349{_}Then did Sir Benedict, laughing loud and joyous, haste to re-form his swaying ranks, the bloody gap in his column closed up and Sir Pertolepe's knights, hemmed in thus, smote and were smitten and but scant few were they that won them free.
10064-8{_}7350{_}And presently, through that red confusion brake Beltane with Roger and Ulf and Walkyn at his heels, and, sword in hand, he sprang and caught the Abbess in a close embrace.
10064-8{_}7351{_}"Mother!"
10064-8{_}7352{_}he cried.

10064-8{_}7360{_}So shouting, he drave back into the confusion of the staggering rear-guard with Sir Benedict spurring behind.
10064-8{_}7361{_}But, as Sir Benedict rode, pushing past the files of his halted company, he felt hands that gripped either stirrup and glancing down beheld Ulf the Strong on his one flank and grim Walkyn upon the other.
10064-8{_}7362{_}So came they where the road broadened out and where the battle raged swaying and surging above the form of Sir Brian prostrate in the dust where horsemen and footmen strove together in desperate grapple, where knightly shields, aflare with proud devices, rang 'neath the blows of Beltane's lusty foresters and Sir Benedict's veteran pikemen.
10064-8{_}7363{_}Then of a sudden Walkyn shouted fierce and loud, and sprang forward with mighty axe whirled aloft.
10064-8{_}7364{_}"Ha--Pertolepe, turn!"
10064-8{_}7365{_}he roared, "Ho, Bloody Pertolepe--turn, thou dog!
10064-8{_}7366{_}'Tis I--'tis Waldron of Brand!"
10064-8{_}7367{_}So cried he, and, plunging into the thick of the affray, smote aside all such as barred his way until he fronted Sir Pertolepe, who, astride a powerful mailed charger, wielded a bloody mace, and who, hearing that hoarse cry, turned and met the shearing axe with blazoned shield--and behold!
10064-8{_}7368{_}the gorgeous shield was split in twain; but even so, he smote in turn and mighty Walkyn was beaten to his knee.
10064-8{_}7369{_}Forth sprang Ulf, swift and eager, but Walkyn, bounding up, shouldered him aside--his axe whirled and fell once, and Sir Pertolepe's mace was dashed from his loosened hold--whirled and fell again, and Sir Pertolepe's great casque was beaten from his head and all men might see the ghastly, jagged cross that scarred his brow beneath his fiery hair--whirled again, but, ere it could fall, knights and esquires mounted and afoot, had burst 'twixt Walkyn and their reeling lord, and Walkyn was dashed aside, shouting, cursing, foaming with rage, what time Sir Pertolepe was borne out of the fight.
10064-8{_}7370{_}But the rear-guard was saved, and, with a hedge of bristling pikes behind, Sir Benedict's sore-battered company marched on along the forest-road and breathed again, the while their pursuers, staggered in their onset, paused to re-form ere they thundered down upon that devoted rear-guard once more.
10064-8{_}7371{_}But Sir Benedict was there, loud-voiced and cheery still despite fatigue, and Sir Hacon was there, his wonted gloom forgotten quite, and Beltane was there, equipped with shield and vizored war-helm and astride a noble horse, and there, too, was Roger, grim and silent, and fierce Ulf, and Walkyn in black and evil temper; quoth he:  "Ha--'tis ever so, his life within my very grasp, yet doth he escape me!
10064-8{_}7372{_}But one more blow and the Red Pertolepe had been in hell--"  "Yet, forsooth, didst save our rear-guard, comrade!"
10064-8{_}7373{_}said Ulf.
10064-8{_}7374{_}"Aye--and what o' that?
10064-8{_}7375{_}'Twas Pertolepe's foul life I sought--"  "And there," quoth Beltane, "there spake Vengeance, and vengeance is ever a foul thing and very selfish!"
10064-8{_}7376{_}Now hereupon Walkyn's scowl deepened, and, falling further to the rear, he spake no more.
10064-8{_}7377{_}"Beltane, dear my lad," said Sir Benedict as they rode together, "hast told me nought of thy doings last night--what of Sir Rollo?"
10064-8{_}7378{_}"Nay, Benedict, ask me not yet, only rest ye assured Sir Rollo shall not trouble us this side Belsaye.
10064-8{_}7379{_}But pray, how doth our brave Sir Brian?"
10064-8{_}7380{_}"Well enough, Beltane; he lieth in a litter, being tended by thy noble lady mother.
10064-8{_}7381{_}A small lance-thrust 'neath the gorget, see'st thou, 'twill be healed--Ha, they charge us again--stand firm, pikes!"
10064-8{_}7382{_}So shouting, Sir Benedict wheeled his horse and Beltane with him, and once again the road echoed to the din of battle.
10064-8{_}7383{_}Thus all day long they fought their way south along the forest-road, as, time and again, Sir Pertolepe's heavy chivalry thundered down upon them, to check and break before that hedge of deadly pikes.
10064-8{_}7384{_}So marched this valiant rear-guard, parched with thirst, choked with dust, grim with blood and wounds, until, as the sun sank westwards, the woods thinned away and they beheld at last, glad-eyed and joyful, the walls and towers of fair Belsaye town.
10064-8{_}7385{_}Now just beyond the edge of the woods, Sir Benedict halted his shrunken column, his dusty pikemen drawn up across the narrow road with archers behind supported by his cavalry to hold Sir Pertolepe's powers in check amid the woods what time the nuns with the spent and wounded hasted on towards the city.
10064-8{_}7386{_}Hereupon Beltane raised his vizor and setting horn to lip, sounded the rally.
10064-8{_}7387{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}7388{_}from the city a glad and mighty shout went up, the while above the square and frowning keep a great standard arose and flapping out upon the soft air, discovered a red lion on a white field.
10064-8{_}7389{_}"Aha, Beltane!"
10064-8{_}7390{_}quoth Sir Benedict, "yon is a rare-sweet sight--behold thy father's Lion banner that hath not felt the breeze this many a year--"  "Aye, lords," growled Walkyn, "and yonder cometh yet another lion--a black lion on red!"
10064-8{_}7391{_}and he pointed where, far to their left, a red standard flaunted above the distant glitter of a wide-flung battle line.
10064-8{_}7392{_}"Hast good eyes, Walkyn!"
10064-8{_}7393{_}said Sir Benedict, peering 'neath his hand toward the advancing host, "aye, verily--'tis Ivo himself.
10064-8{_}7394{_}Sir Pertolepe must have warned him of our coming."
10064-8{_}7395{_}"So are we like to be crushed 'twixt hammer and anvil," quoth Sir Hacon, tightening the lacing of his battered casque.
10064-8{_}7396{_}"So will I give thee charge of our knights and men-at-arms--what is left of them, alas!--to meet Black Ivo's banner, my doleful Hacon!"
10064-8{_}7397{_}spake Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7398{_}"Nay, Benedict," said Sir Hacon, grim-smiling, "my dole is but caution!"
10064-8{_}7399{_}So saying, he closed his vizor and rode away to muster his chivalry to meet their new assailants the while Sir Benedict fell to re-forming his scanty ranks of pikemen and archers.
10064-8{_}7400{_}Meantime Beltane, sitting his weary charger, glanced from Sir Pertolepe's deep array of knights and men-at-arms that thronged and jostled each other in the narrow forest-road to the distant flash and glitter of Duke Ivo's mighty van-ward, and from these again to the walls of Belsaye.
10064-8{_}7401{_}And as he looked thither he saw the great drawbridge fall, the portcullis raised, and the gates flung wide to admit the fugitives; even at that distance he thought to recognise the Abbess, who paused to turn and gaze towards him, as, last of all, she rode to safety into the city.
10064-8{_}7402{_}Then my Beltane sighed, and, closing his vizor, turned to find Ulf beside him with Roger and Walkyn, who stood to watch the while Sir Benedict rode to and fro, ordering his company for their perilous retreat across the plain.
10064-8{_}7403{_}Swift and silent his war-worn veterans fell to their appointed ranks; his trumpets blew and they began to fall back on Belsaye town.
10064-8{_}7404{_}Grimly silent they marched, and ever Beltane gazed where, near and ever more near, flashed and flickered Duke Ivo's hard-riding van-ward.
10064-8{_}7405{_}And now from the forest-road Sir Pertolepe's company marched, and forming in the open, spurred down upon them.
10064-8{_}7406{_}"Stand firm, pikes!"
10064-8{_}7407{_}roared Cnut.
10064-8{_}7408{_}"Aim low, archers!"
10064-8{_}7409{_}squealed small Prat, and forthwith the battle joined.
10064-8{_}7410{_}The weary rear-guard rocked and swayed beneath the onset, but Prat and his archers shot amain, arrows whistled while pike and gisarm thrust and smote, as, encompassed now on three sides, they fell back and back towards the yawning gates of Belsaye; and ever as he fought, Beltane by times turned to watch where Duke Ivo's threatening van-ward galloped--a long line of gleaming shields and levelled lances gay with the glitter of pennon and banderol.
10064-8{_}7411{_}Back and back the rear-guard staggered, hewing and smiting; twice Beltane reeled 'neath unseen blows and with eyes a-swim beheld Roger and Ulf, who fought at either stirrup: heard of a sudden shrieks and cries and the thunder of galloping hooves; was aware of the flash of bright armour to his left, rank upon rank, where charged Duke Ivo's van-ward before whose furious onset Sir Benedict's weary pikemen were hurled back--their centre swayed, broke, and immediately all was dire uproar and confusion.
10064-8{_}7412{_}"Ah, Beltane--these be fresh men on fresh horses," cried Sir Benedict, "but hey--body o' me--all's not lost yet--malediction, no!
10064-8{_}7413{_}And 'tis scarce half a mile to the gates.
10064-8{_}7414{_}Ha--yonder rides lusty Hacon to stay their rush--in upon them.

10064-8{_}7416{_}Shouting thus, Sir Benedict plunged headlong into the raging fury of the battle; but, as Beltane spurred in after him, his weary charger, smitten by an arrow, reared up, screaming, yet ere he fell, Beltane, kicking free of the stirrups, rolled clear; a mighty hand plucked him to his feet and Ulf, roaring in his ear, pointed with his dripping axe.
10064-8{_}7417{_}And, looking whither he pointed, Beltane beheld Sir Benedict borne down beneath a press of knights, but as he lay, pinned beneath his squealing charger, Beltane leapt and bestrode him, sword in hand.
10064-8{_}7418{_}"Roger!"
10064-8{_}7419{_}he shouted, "Ulf--Walkyn--to me!"
10064-8{_}7420{_}All about him was a swaying trample of horses and men, an iron ring that hemmed him in, blows dinted his long shield, they rang upon his helmet, they battered his triple mail, they split his shield in sunder; and 'neath this hail of blows Beltane staggered, thrice he was smitten to his knees and thrice he arose, and ever his long blade whirled and darted.
10064-8{_}7421{_}"Yield thee, sir knight--yield thee!"
10064-8{_}7422{_}was the cry.
10064-8{_}7423{_}"Ho, Roger!"

10064-8{_}7425{_}An axe bit through his great helm, a sword bent against his stout mail, a knight spurred in upon him, blade levelled to thrust again, but Beltane's deadly point darted upward and the snorting charger plunged away--riderless.
10064-8{_}7426{_}But now, as he fought on with failing arm, came a joyous roar on his right where Ulf smote direly with bloody axe, upon his left hand a broad-sword flickered where Roger fought silent and grim, beyond him again, Walkyn's long arms rose and fell as he whirled his axe, and hard by Tall Orson plied goring pike.
10064-8{_}7427{_}So fought these mighty four until the press thinned out and they had cleared them a space amid the battle, the while Beltane leaned him, spent and panting, upon his reeking sword.
10064-8{_}7428{_}Now, as he stood thus, from a tangle of the fallen near by a bent and battered helm was lifted and Sir Benedict spake, faint and short of breath:  "'Twas nobly done--sweet lad!
10064-8{_}7429{_}'Tis enough, methinks--there be few of us left, I fear me, so--get thee hence--with such as be alive--hence, Beltane, for--thy sweet mother's sake.
10064-8{_}7430{_}Nay, heed not--old Benedict, I did my best and--'tis a fitting couch, this--farewell to thee, my Beltane--" So saying, Sir Benedict sank weakly to an elbow and from elbow upon his face, and lay there, very still and mute.
10064-8{_}7431{_}"Master--master!"
10064-8{_}7432{_}cried Roger, "we shall win to Belsaye yet, see--see, Giles hath out-flanked them with his pikes and archers, and--ha!

10064-8{_}7434{_}But Beltane leaned him upon his sword very spent and sick, and stared ever upon Sir Benedict's motionless form, his harness bent and hacked, his proud helm prone in the trampled ling.
10064-8{_}7435{_}Slowly, and with fumbling hands, Beltane sheathed his sword, and stooping, raised Sir Benedict upon his shoulder and strove to bear him out of the fight, but twice he staggered in his going and would have fallen but for Roger's ready arm.
10064-8{_}7436{_}"Master," quoth he, "master, let me aid thee with him!"
10064-8{_}7437{_}But nothing saying, Beltane stumbled on until they came where stood Ulf holding a riderless horse, on the which he made shift to mount with Roger's aid; thereafter Ulf lifted Sir Benedict to his hold.
10064-8{_}7438{_}"And, pray you," said Beltane, slow and blurred of speech, "pray you what of noble Sir Hacon?"
10064-8{_}7439{_}"Alack, lord," growled Ulf, "yonder is he where they lie so thick, and slain, methinks,--yet will I bring him off--"  "Aye, lord," cried Tall Orson, great tears furrowing the grime of his cheeks, "and little Prat do be killed--and lusty Cnut do be killed wi' him--and my good comrade Jenkyn do lie smitten to death--O there do be none of us left, methinks, lord!"
10064-8{_}7440{_}So, faint and heart-sick, with Sir Benedict limp across his saddle bow, Beltane rode from that place of death; beside him went Roger, stumbling and weary, and behind them strode mighty Ulf with Sir Hacon upon his shoulder.
10064-8{_}7441{_}In a while, as they went thus, Beltane, glancing back at the fight, beheld stout Eric with the men of Belsaye, well mounted and equipped, at fierce grapple with Duke Ivo's van-ward, what time Giles and his archers supported by lusty pikemen, plied Sir Pertolepe's weary forces with whizzing shafts, drawing and loosing marvellous fast.
10064-8{_}7442{_}So came they at last unto the gates of Belsaye town that were already a-throng with many wounded and divers others of Sir Benedict's company that had won out of the affray; now upon the drawbridge Beltane paused and gave Sir Benedict and brave Hacon into kindly, eager hands, then, wheeling, with Ulf and Roger beside him, rode back toward the battle.
10064-8{_}7443{_}And ever as they went came scattered groups of Sir Benedict's stout rear-guard, staggering with weariness and limping with wounds, the while, upon the plain beyond, Eric with his men-at-arms and Walkyn with the survivors of the foresters and Giles with his archers and pikemen, holding the foe in play, fell back upon the town, compact and orderly.
10064-8{_}7444{_}Thus, they in turn began to cross the drawbridge, archers and pikemen, and last of all, the men-at-arms, until only Eric o' the Noose and a handful of his horsemen, with Beltane, Roger and Ulf remained beyond the drawbridge, whereon the enemy came on amain and 'neath their furious onset brave Eric was unhorsed; then Beltane drew sword and with Roger and Ulf running at either stirrup, spurred in to the rescue.
10064-8{_}7445{_}A shock of hard-smitten steel--a whirl and flurry of blows--a shout of triumph, and, reeling in his saddle, dazed and sick, Beltane found himself alone, fronting a bristling line of feutred lances; he heard Roger shout to him wild and fearful, heard Walkyn roar at him--felt a sudden shock, and was down, unhelmed, and pinned beneath his stricken charger.
10064-8{_}7446{_}Half a-swoon he lay thus, seeing dimly the line of on-rushing lance-points, while on his failing senses a fierce cry smote:  "'Tis Beltane--the Outlaw!
10064-8{_}7447{_}Slay him!
10064-8{_}7448{_}Slay him!"
10064-8{_}7449{_}But now of a sudden and as one that dreamed, he beheld a tender face above him with sad-sweet eyes and lips that bent to kiss his brow, felt soft arms about him--tender arms that drew his weary head upon a gentle bosom to hide and pillow it there; felt that enfolding embrace tighten and tighten in sudden shuddering spasm, as, sighing, the lady Abbess's white-clad arms fell away and her proud head sank beside his in the dust.
10064-8{_}7450{_}And now was a rush and roar of fierce voices as over them sprang Roger and Giles with Ulf and Eric, and, amid the eddying dust, axe and sword swung and smote, while came hands strong yet tender, that bare Beltane into the city.
10064-8{_}7451{_}Now beyond the gate of the city was a well and beside the well they laid Beltane and bathed him with the sweet cool water, until at length the mist vanished from his sight and thus he beheld the White Abbess who lay upon a pile of cloaks hard by.
10064-8{_}7452{_}And beholding the deadly pallor of lip and cheek, the awful stains that spotted her white robe and the fading light in those sad-sweet eyes, Beltane cried aloud--a great and bitter cry, and fell before her on his knees.
10064-8{_}7453{_}"Mother!"
10064-8{_}7454{_}he groaned, "O my mother!"
10064-8{_}7455{_}"Dear my Beltane," she whispered faintly, striving to kiss his hand, "death is none so--painful, so grieve not thine heart for me, sweet son.
10064-8{_}7456{_}And how may a mother--die better than for her own--beloved son?
10064-8{_}7457{_}Beltane, if God--O if God in His infinite mercy--shall think me worthy --to be--one of His holy angels, then will I be ever near thee when thy way proveth dark--to comfort thee--to aid thee.
10064-8{_}7458{_}O dear my son--I sought thee so long--so long--'tis a little hard to leave thee--so soon.
10064-8{_}7459{_}But--God's will--fare thee well, I die--aye--this is death, methinks.
10064-8{_}7460{_}Beltane, tell thy father that I--O--dear my--my Beltane--"  So died the gracious lady Abbess that had been the proud Yolande, Duchess of Pentavalon, wept and bemoaned by full many who had known her tender care; and, in due season, she was laid to rest within the fair Minster of Belsaye.
10064-8{_}7461{_}And thereafter, Beltane took to his bed and abode there many days because of his wounds and by reason of his so great sorrow and heart-break.
10064-8{_}7462{_}But, that night, through the dark hours was strange stir and hum beyond the walls of Belsaye, and, when the dawn broke, many a stout heart quailed and many a cheek blanched to see a great camp whose fortified lines encompassed the city on all sides, where lay Ivo the Black Duke to besiege them.
10064-8{_}7463{_}CHAPTER LXIII  TELLETH SOMEWHAT OF THE WOES OF GILES O' THE BOW   Six days and nights my Beltane kept his bed, seeing and speaking to no man; and it is like he would have died but for the fostering care of the good Friar Martin who came and went softly about him, who watched and tended and prayed over him long and silently but who, perceiving his heart-sickness, spake him not at all.
10064-8{_}7464{_}Day in and day out Beltane lay there, heedless of all but his great sorrow, sleeping little and eating less, his face hid in his pillow or turned to the wall, and in all this time he uttered no word nor shed a single tear.
10064-8{_}7465{_}His wounds healed apace but his soul had taken a deeper hurt, and day and night he sorrowed fiercely for his noble mother, wherefore he lay thus, heeding nought but his great grief.
10064-8{_}7466{_}But upon the seventh night, he dreamed she stood beside his couch, tall and fair and gracious, and looked down on him, the mother-love alight within her sweet, sad eyes.
10064-8{_}7467{_}Now within her hand she bare his sword and showed him the legend graven upon the bright steel:  RESURGAM  And therewith she smiled wondrous tender and put the great weapon into his grasp; then stooped and kissed him, and, pointing upward with her finger, was gone.
10064-8{_}7468{_}And now within his sleep his anguished heart found solacement in slow and burning tears, and, sleeping yet, he wept full bitterly, insomuch that, sobbing, he awoke.
10064-8{_}7469{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}7470{_}beneath his right hand was the touch of cold steel and his fingers clenched tight upon the hilt of his great sword.
10064-8{_}7471{_}Then my Beltane arose forthwith, and finding his clothes near by, clad himself and did on his mail, and, soft-treading, went forth of his narrow chamber.
10064-8{_}7472{_}Thus came he where Friar Martin lay, deep-breathing in his slumber, and waking him not, he passed out into the dawn.
10064-8{_}7473{_}And in the dawn was a gentle wind, very cool and grateful, that touched his burning brow and eyes like a caress; now looking up to heaven, where stars were paling to the dawn, Beltane raised the hilt of his sword and pressed it to his lips.
10064-8{_}7474{_}"O blessed mother!"
10064-8{_}7475{_}he whispered, "God hath surely found thee worthy to be one of His holy angels, so hast thou stooped from heaven to teach to me my duty.
10064-8{_}7476{_}Thus now will I set by my idle grieving for thee, sweet saint, and strive to live thy worthy son--O dear my mother, who, being dead, yet liveth!"
10064-8{_}7477{_}Then Beltane sheathed his sword and went softly up the narrow stair that led to the battlements.
10064-8{_}7478{_}It was a bleak dawn, full of a thick, low-lying mist beyond the walls, but within this mist, to north and south and east and west, was a faint stir, while, ever and anon, rose the distant cry of some sentinel within Duke Ivo's sleeping camp, a mighty camp whose unseen powers held the fair city in deadly grip.
10064-8{_}7479{_}In Belsaye nothing stirred and none waked at this dead hour save where, high on the bartizan above the square and mighty keep, the watchman paced to and fro, while here and there from curtain wall and massy tower, spear-head and bascinet gleamed.
10064-8{_}7480{_}Slow and light of foot Beltane climbed the narrow stair that led up to one of the two square towers that flanked the main gate, but, being come thither, he paused to behold Giles, who chancing to be captain of the watch, sat upon a pile of great stones beside a powerful mangonel or catapult and stared him dolefully upon the lightening east: full oft sighed he, and therewith shook despondent head and even thus fell he to soft and doleful singing, groaning to himself 'twixt each verse, on this wise:    "She will not heed her lover's moan,    His mopd tear, his deep-fetched groan,    So doth he sit, and here alone       Sing willow!
10064-8{_}7481{_}("With three curses on this foul mist!)
10064-8{_}7482{_}"The little fishes fishes woo,    Birds blithe on bough do bill and coo,    But lonely I, with sad ado       Sing willow!"
10064-8{_}7483{_}("And may Saint Anthony's fire consume Bernard, the merchant's round, plump son!)
10064-8{_}7484{_}"'Tis sure a maid was made for man,    'Twas e'en so since the world began,    Yet doleful here, I only can       Sing willow!"
10064-8{_}7485{_}("And may the blessed saints have an eye upon her tender slumbers!")
10064-8{_}7486{_}Here Giles paused to sigh amain, to fold his arms, to cross his legs, to frown and shake gloomy head; having done the which, he took breath and sang again as followeth:--    "Alack-a-day, alas and woe!
10064-8{_}7487{_}Would that Genevra fair might know    'Tis for her love Giles of the Bow       Sings willow!"
10064-8{_}7488{_}But now, chancing to turn and espy Beltane, Giles fell suddenly abashed, his comely face grew ruddy 'neath its tan and he sprang very nimbly to his feet:  "Ha, tall brother--good brother," he stammered, "noble lord, God den to ye--hail and good morrow!
10064-8{_}7489{_}Verily and in faith, by Saint Giles (my patron saint, brother) I do rejoice to see thee abroad again, as will our surly Rogerkin that doth gloom and glower for thee and hath hung about thy chamber door morn and noon and night, and our noble Sir Benedict and Walkyn--but none more unfeignedly than Giles that doth grow glad because of thee--"  "That is well," quoth Beltane, seating himself upon the battlement, "for verily thy song was vastly doleful, Giles!"
10064-8{_}7490{_}"My song, lord, my song?
10064-8{_}7491{_}Ha--hum!
10064-8{_}7492{_}O verily, my song is a foolish song or the song of a fool, for fool am I, forsooth--a love-lorn fool; a doleful fool, a very fool of fools, that in my foolish folly hath set his foolish heart on thing beyond reach of such base fool as I.
10064-8{_}7493{_}In a word, tall brother, I'm a fool, _videlicet_--a lover!"
10064-8{_}7494{_}"Truly, hast the speech and outward seeming of your approved lover, Giles," nodded Beltane.
10064-8{_}7495{_}"Aye, verily!"
10064-8{_}7496{_}sighed Giles, "aye, verily--behold my beard, I have had no heart to trim it this sennight!
10064-8{_}7497{_}Alack, I--I that was so point-de-vice am like to become a second Diogenes (a filthy fellow that never washed and lived in a foul tub!).
10064-8{_}7498{_}As for food, I eat no more than the chameleon that doth fill its belly with air and nought else, foolish beast!
10064-8{_}7499{_}I, that was wont to be a fair figure of a man do fall away to skin and bone, daily, hourly, minute by minute--behold this leg, tall brother!"
10064-8{_}7500{_}And Giles thrust out a lusty, mailed limb.
10064-8{_}7501{_}"Here was a leg once--a proper shapely leg to catch a woman's eye--see how it hath shrunk, nay, faith, 'tis hidden in mine armour!
10064-8{_}7502{_}But verily, my shanks will soon be no thicker than my bowstave!
10064-8{_}7503{_}Lastly I--I that loved company and good cheer do find therein abomination these days, so do I creep, like moulting fowl, brother, to corners dark and dismal and there make much ado--and such is love, O me!"
10064-8{_}7504{_}"Doth the maid know of thy love?"
10064-8{_}7505{_}"Nay lord, good lack, how should she?--who am I to speak of it?
10064-8{_}7506{_}She is a fair lady and noble, a peerless virgin, while I--I am only Giles-- poor Giles o' the Bow, after all!"
10064-8{_}7507{_}"Truly, love is teaching thee wisdom, Giles," said Beltane, smiling.
10064-8{_}7508{_}"Indeed, my lord, my wisdom teacheth me this--that were I the proudest and noblest in the land yet should I be unworthy!"
10064-8{_}7509{_}and Giles shook miserable head and sighed again full deep.
10064-8{_}7510{_}"Who is she, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7511{_}"She is Genevra, daughter to the Reeve!
10064-8{_}7512{_}And the Reeve is a great man in Belsaye and gently born, alas!
10064-8{_}7513{_}And with coffers full of good broad pieces.
10064-8{_}7514{_}O would she were a beggar-maid, the poorest, the meanest, then might I woo her for mine own.
10064-8{_}7515{_}As it is, I can but look and sigh--for speak me her I dare not--ha, and there is a plump fellow!"
10064-8{_}7516{_}Here Giles clenched bronzed fist.
10064-8{_}7517{_}"A round and buxom fellow he, a rich merchant's son doth woo her boldly, may speak with her, may touch her hand!
10064-8{_}7518{_}So do I ofttimes keep him shooting at the butts by the hour together and therein do make me some small amend.
10064-8{_}7519{_}Yet daily do I mope and pine, and pine and mope--O tall brother, a most accursed thing is this love--and dearer than my life, heigho!"
10064-8{_}7520{_}"Nay, pluck up thy heart, thou'rt a man, Giles."
10064-8{_}7521{_}"Aye, verily, but she is a maid, brother, therein lieth vasty difference, and therefore do I fear her for her very sweetness and purity--fear her?
10064-8{_}7522{_}Faith, my knees do knock at sound of her voice, her very step doth set me direly a-tremble.
10064-8{_}7523{_}For she is so fair--so pure and nigh the angels, that I--alack!
10064-8{_}7524{_}I have ever been a something light fellow in matters of love--forget not I was bred a monk, noble brother!
10064-8{_}7525{_}Thus, brother, a moping owl, I--a very curst fellow, gloomy and silent as the grave, saving my breath for sighs and groans and curses fell, wherefore I have builded me a 'mockery' above the wall and there-from do curse our foes, as only a churchman may, brother."
10064-8{_}7526{_}"Nay, how mean you, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7527{_}questioned Beltane, staring.
10064-8{_}7528{_}"Follow me, lord, and I will show thee!"
10064-8{_}7529{_}So saying, Giles led the way down to the battlement above the great gates, where was a thing like unto a rough pulpit, builded of massy timbers, very stout and strong, and in these timbers stood many arrows and cross-bow bolts.
10064-8{_}7530{_}"Here, lord," quoth Giles, "behold my 'mockery' wherefrom it is my wont and custom to curse our foes thrice daily.
10064-8{_}7531{_}The which is a right good strategy, brother, in that my amorous anguish findeth easement and I do draw the enemy's shafts, for there is no man that heareth my contumacious dictums but he forthwith falleth into rageful fury, and an angry fellow shooteth ever wide o' the mark, brother.
10064-8{_}7532{_}Thus, thrice daily do we gather a full sheaf of their ill-sped shafts, whereby we shall not lack for arrows an they besiege us till Gabriel's trump-- heigho!
10064-8{_}7533{_}Thus do I live by curses, for, an I could not curse, then would my surcharged heart assuredly in sunder burst--aye me!"
10064-8{_}7534{_}Now whiles they sat thus in talk, up rose the sun, before whose joyous beams the stealthy mists slunk away little by little, until Beltane beheld Duke Ivo's mighty camp--long lines of tents gay with fluttering pennon and gonfalon, of huts and booths set well out of bowshot behind the works of contravallation--stout palisades and barriers with earthworks very goodly and strong.
10064-8{_}7535{_}And presently from among these booths and tents was the gleam and glitter of armour, what time from the waking host a hum and stir arose, with blare and fanfare of trumpet to usher in the day: and in a while from the midst of the camp came the faint ring and tap of many hammers.
10064-8{_}7536{_}Now as the mists cleared, looking thitherward, Beltane stared wide-eyed to behold wooden towers in course of building, with the grim shapes of many powerful war-engines whose mighty flying-beams and massy supporting-timbers filled him with great awe and wonderment.
10064-8{_}7537{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}7538{_}quoth Giles, "they work apace yonder, and by Saint Giles they lack not for engines; verily Black Ivo is a master of siege tactics-- but so is Giles, brother!
10064-8{_}7539{_}See where he setteth up his mangonels, trebuchets, perriers and balistae, with bossons or rams, towers and cats, in the use of the which he is right cunning--but so also is Giles, brother!
10064-8{_}7540{_}And verily, though your mangonels and trebuchets are well enough, yet for defence the balista is weapon more apt, methinks, as being more accurate in the shooting and therefore more deadly--how think you, lord?"
10064-8{_}7541{_}"Indeed Giles, being a forester I could scarce tell you one from another."
10064-8{_}7542{_}"Ha--then you'll know nought of their nature and use, lord?"
10064-8{_}7543{_}"Nought, Giles.
10064-8{_}7544{_}Ne'er have I seen their like until now."
10064-8{_}7545{_}"Say ye so, brother?"
10064-8{_}7546{_}cried Giles full eager, his brown eyes a-kindle, "say ye so in very truth?
10064-8{_}7547{_}Then--an it be so thy wish--I might instruct thee vastly, for there is no man in the world to-day shall discourse you more fluent and learned upon siege-craft, engines and various tormenta than I.
10064-8{_}7548{_}So--an it be thy wish, lord--?"
10064-8{_}7549{_}"It is my wish: say on, Giles."
10064-8{_}7550{_}"Why then firstly, lord, firstly we have the great Mangon or mangonel, _fundis fundibula_, that some do also term _catapultum_, the which worketh by torsion and shall heave you great stones of the bigness of a man fully two hundred yards an it be dry weather; next is the Trebuchet, like to the mangon save that it swingeth by counterpoise; next cometh the Balista or Springald that worketh by tension--a pretty weapon!
10064-8{_}7551{_}and shall shoot you dart or javelin so strong as shall transpierce you six lusty fellows at a time, hauberk and shield, like so many fowl upon a spit--very sweet to behold, brother!
10064-8{_}7552{_}Then have we the Bore or Cat that some again do name _musculus_ or mouse for that it gnaweth through thick walls--and some do call this hog, sow, _scrofa_ or _sus_, brother, and some again, _vulpes_.
10064-8{_}7553{_}"And this Cat is a massy pole that beareth a great and sharp steel point, the which, being mounted within a pent-house, swingeth merrily to and fro, much like to a ram, brother, and shall blithely pick you a hole through stone and mortar very pleasing to behold.
10064-8{_}7554{_}Then we have the Ram, _cancer testudo_, that battereth; next we have the Tower or Beffroi that goeth on wheels--yonder you shall see them a-building.
10064-8{_}7555{_}And these towers, moving forward against your city, shall o'ertop the walls and from them archers and cross-bowmen may shoot into your town what time their comrades fill up and dam your moat until the tower may come close unto your walls.
10064-8{_}7556{_}And these towers, being come against the wall, do let fall drawbridges over which the besiegers may rush amain and carry your walls by assault.
10064-8{_}7557{_}Lastly, there be Mantlets--stakes wattled together and covered with raw-hide--by the which means the besiegers make their first approaches.
10064-8{_}7558{_}Then might I descant at goodly length upon the Mine and Furnace, with divers and sundry other stratagems, devices, engines and tormenta, but methinks this shall mayhap suffice thee for the nonce?"
10064-8{_}7559{_}"Aye, verily--'twill suffice!"
10064-8{_}7560{_}said Beltane, rising.
10064-8{_}7561{_}"Truly war is even more terrible than I had thought."
10064-8{_}7562{_}"Why lord, 'tis an art--a notable art and--ha!
10064-8{_}7563{_}this doth mind me of my heart, heigho!
10064-8{_}7564{_}And of all terrible things, of all the woes and ills man-hearts may know is--love.
10064-8{_}7565{_}O me, alack and woe!"
10064-8{_}7566{_}"When doth thy watch end, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7567{_}"It ended an hour agone, but to what end?
10064-8{_}7568{_}Being a lover I sleep little and pine much, and this is a fair good place and solitary, so will I pine awhile and likewise mope and languish, alack!"
10064-8{_}7569{_}So presently, as Beltane descended the stair, he heard the archer break forth again in doleful song.
10064-8{_}7570{_}Across the wide market-square went Beltane, with brow o'ercast and head low-bowed until he came to one of the many doors of the great minster; there paused he to remove bascinet and mail-coif, and thus bareheaded, entered the cathedral's echoing dimness.
10064-8{_}7571{_}The new-risen sun made a glory of the great east window, and with his eyes uplifted to this many-coloured glory, Beltane, soft-treading, crossed dim aisle and whispering transept; but, as he mounted the broad steps of the sanctuary he paused with breath in check, for he heard a sound--a soft sound like the flutter of wings or the rustle of silken draperies.
10064-8{_}7572{_}Now as he stood thus, his broad, mail-clad shoulders and golden hair bathed in the refulgence of the great window, it seemed to him that from somewhere near there breathed a sigh, tremulous and very soft, and thereafter was the quick, light tread of feet, and silence.
10064-8{_}7573{_}A while stood Beltane scarce breathing, then, slow and reverent, he approached the high altar; and ever as he went was a fragrance, wonder-sweet, that grew stronger and stronger until he was come behind the high altar where was his mother's grave.
10064-8{_}7574{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}7575{_}upon that long, white stone lay flowers a-bloom, roses and lilies whose dewy loveliness filled the place with their pure and fragrant sweetness.
10064-8{_}7576{_}So looked he round about and upon these flowers with grateful wonder, and sinking to his knees, bowed his head and folded his hands in prayer.
10064-8{_}7577{_}But presently, as he knelt thus, he was roused by the clank of steel and a shuffling step, wherefore he arose and crossing to the shadows of the choir, sat him down within the deeper gloom to wait until his disturber should be gone.
10064-8{_}7578{_}Slowly these halting steps advanced, feet that stumbled oft; near they came and nearer, until Beltane perceived a tall figure whose armour gleamed dully and whose shoulders were bowed like one that is feeble or very weary.
10064-8{_}7579{_}"Yolande!"
10064-8{_}7580{_}said a voice, a hoarse voice but very tender, "Yolande, beloved!"
10064-8{_}7581{_}And on the word the voice broke and ended upon a great sob, swift followed by another and yet another, the fierce sobbing of a man.
10064-8{_}7582{_}Then Beltane clenched his hands and rose up, for behold!
10064-8{_}7583{_}this man was Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7584{_}But now, and very suddenly, Sir Benedict was upon his knees, and bent and kissed that white, smooth stone whereon as yet was no inscription.
10064-8{_}7585{_}"Yolande!"
10064-8{_}7586{_}he whispered, "now thou art one among the holy angels, O forget not thy most unworthy Benedict.
10064-8{_}7587{_}God--O God!
10064-8{_}7588{_}Father to whom all hearts are open, Thou dost know how as child and maid I loved her, how as a wife I loved her still--how, in my madness, I spake my love--and she, being saint and woman, bade me to my duty.
10064-8{_}7589{_}So, by her purity, kept she my honour unstained--"  Beltane's long scabbard struck the carven panelling, a soft blow that yet echoed and re-echoed in vaulted arch and dim roof, and, glancing swiftly up, Sir Benedict beheld him.
10064-8{_}7590{_}And kneeling thus beside the grave of the woman he had loved, Sir Benedict looked up into Beltane's face with eyes wide, eyes unflinching but dimmed with great grief and pain.
10064-8{_}7591{_}Quoth he, firm-voiced:  "My lord, thou hast learned my life's secret, but, ere thou dost judge me, hear this!
10064-8{_}7592{_}Long ere thy princely father met thy mother, we loved, she and I, and in our love grew up together.
10064-8{_}7593{_}Then came the Duke thy father, a mighty lord; and her mother was ambitious and very guileful-- and she--but a maid.
10064-8{_}7594{_}Thus was she wed. Then rode I to the foreign wars seeking death--but death took me not.
10064-8{_}7595{_}So, the wars ended, came I home again, burning ever with my love, and sought her out, and beholding the sadness in her eyes I spake my love; and forgetful of honour and all save her sweet soul and the glory of her beauty, I tempted her--aye, many times!--tempted her in fashion merciless and cruel insomuch that she wept many bitter tears, and, upon a day, spake me thus: 'Benedict, 'tis true I loved thee, for thou wert a noble knight--but now, an thy love for me be so small that thou canst bring me to this shame, then-- take me where thou wilt--but--ne'er shall all thy love nor all my tears thereafter cleanse us from the shame of it.'
10064-8{_}7596{_}Thus went I from her, nor have I looked on woman since.
10064-8{_}7597{_}So followed I thy father in all his warring and all my days have I fought much--fierce foes within me and without, and lived--a very solitary life.
10064-8{_}7598{_}And to-day she lieth dead--and I am here, old and worn, a lonely man and sinful, to be judged of as ye will."
10064-8{_}7599{_}Then came Beltane and looked down into Sir Benedict's pale, sad face.
10064-8{_}7600{_}And beholding him thus in his abasement, haggard with wounds and bowed with grief, needs must Beltane kneel also and thereafter spake thus:  "Sir Benedict, who am I, to judge of such as thou?"
10064-8{_}7601{_}"I tempted her--I wooed her to shame, I that loved her beyond life--did cause her many bitter tears--alas!"
10064-8{_}7602{_}"Yet in the end, Sir Benedict, because thy love was a great and noble love, thou didst triumph over base self.
10064-8{_}7603{_}So do I honour thee and pray that I, in like case, may act as nobly."
10064-8{_}7604{_}"And now--she lieth dead!
10064-8{_}7605{_}So for me is life ended also, methinks!"
10064-8{_}7606{_}"She is a saint in heaven, Benedict, living forever.
10064-8{_}7607{_}As to thee, on whose skill and valiance the safety of this fair city doth hang--so hath God need of thee here, methinks.
10064-8{_}7608{_}So now for thy sake and for her sake needs must I love thee ever and always, thou noble knight.
10064-8{_}7609{_}She, being dead, yet liveth and shall go betwixt us henceforth, drawing us together in closer bonds of love and amity--is it not so, dear my friend?"
10064-8{_}7610{_}And speaking, Beltane reached out his hands across his mother's narrow grave, and straightway came Sir Benedict's hands, swift and eager, to meet and clasp them.
10064-8{_}7611{_}For a while knelt they thus, hand clasping hand above that long, white stone whence stole to them the mingled fragrance of the flowers, like a silent benediction.
10064-8{_}7612{_}And presently, together they arose and went their way; but now, seeing how Sir Benedict limped by reason of his wounds, Beltane set an arm about him.
10064-8{_}7613{_}So came they together out of the shadows into the glory of the morning.
10064-8{_}7614{_}Now as they came forth of the minster, the tocsin rang loud in sudden alarm.
10064-8{_}7615{_}CHAPTER LXIV  HOW GILES CURSED BELSAYE OUT OF HER FEAR   Within the market-place all was dire confusion; men hasted hither and thither, buckling on armour as they went, women wept and children wailed, while ever the bell clashed out its fierce summons.
10064-8{_}7616{_}Presently, through the populace cometh Sir Brian of Hartismere, equipped in his armour and leaning on the mailed arm of his brother Eric of the wry neck, but perceiving Sir Benedict and Beltane, they turned and came up forthwith.
10064-8{_}7617{_}"Eric--Brian, what meaneth the tumult?"
10064-8{_}7618{_}questioned Sir Benedict, his eye kindling, "are we attacked--so soon?"
10064-8{_}7619{_}"Not so," answered Sir Brian, "at the least--not by Ivo's men."
10064-8{_}7620{_}"'Tis worse than that," sighed Eric, shaking his head, "yonder cometh a churchman, borne on the shoulders of his monks, and with choristers and acolytes attendant."
10064-8{_}7621{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}7622{_}said Sir Benedict, frowning and rubbing his chin, "I had dreaded this!
10064-8{_}7623{_}The citizens do shake and shiver already, I'll warrant me!
10064-8{_}7624{_}There is nought like a cowl with bell, book and candle to sap the courage of your citizen soldier.
10064-8{_}7625{_}Let us to the walls!"
10064-8{_}7626{_}In a corner hard by the main gate they beheld Giles, holding forth to Roger and Walkyn and Ulf, but perceiving Sir Benedict he ceased abruptly, and advancing, saluted the noble company each in turn, but addressed himself to Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7627{_}"My lord," quoth he, eyes a-dance, "yonder cometh a pompous prior that was, not very long since, nought but massy monk that did upon a time (though by dint of some small persuasion) bestow on me a goodly ass.
10064-8{_}7628{_}My lord, I was bred a monk, so do I know, by divers signs and portents, he cometh here to ban the city with book, bell and candle, wherefore the townsfolk, fearing greatly, do shiver and shake, especially the women and maids--sweet souls!
10064-8{_}7629{_}And, lord, by reason of the matter of the ass, I do know this priest prolific of damnatory pronouncements and curses contumacious (O verily).
10064-8{_}7630{_}Yet I, messire (having been bred a monk) shall blithely him out-curse, an the joy be permitted me, thus turning tears to laughter and gloomy fear to loud-voiced merriment--my lord, messires, how say you?"
10064-8{_}7631{_}"'Tis blasphemy unheard!"
10064-8{_}7632{_}quoth Sir Brian.
10064-8{_}7633{_}"Save in the greenwood where men do breathe God's sweet air and live free!"
10064-8{_}7634{_}said wry-necked Eric.
10064-8{_}7635{_}"And," spake Sir Benedict, stroking his square chin, "there is a fear can be quelled but by ridicule, so may thy wit, sir archer, avail more than our wisdom--an thou canst make these pale-cheeked townsfolk laugh indeed.
10064-8{_}7636{_}How think you, my Beltane?"
10064-8{_}7637{_}"That being the wise and valiant knight thou art, Sir Benedict, thy will during the siege is law in Belsaye, henceforth."
10064-8{_}7638{_}Now hereupon Giles made his obeisance, and together with Roger and Walkyn and Ulf, hasted up to the battlement above the gateway.
10064-8{_}7639{_}"Benedict," said Sir Brian as they climbed the turret stair, "blasphemy is a dread and awful thing.
10064-8{_}7640{_}We shall be excommunicate one and all-- better methinks to let the populace yield up the city and die the death, than perish everlastingly!"
10064-8{_}7641{_}"Brian," quoth Sir Benedict pausing, something breathless by reason of his recent sickness, "I tell thee fire and pillage and ravishment of women is a thing more dread and awful--better, methinks, to keep Innocence pure and unspotted while we may, and leave hereafter in the hands of God and His holy angels!"
10064-8{_}7642{_}Upon the tower there met them the Reeve, anxious of brow, who pointed where the townsfolk talked together in fearful undertones or clustered, mute and trembling, while every eye was turned where, in the open, 'twixt town and camp, a procession of black-robed priests advanced, chanting very solemn and sweet.
10064-8{_}7643{_}"My lords," said the Reeve, looking round with haggard eyes, "an these priests do come to pronounce the Church's awful malediction upon the city--then woe betide!
10064-8{_}7644{_}Already there be many--aye, some of our chiefest citizens do fear the curse of Holy Church more than the rapine of Ivo's vile soldiery, fair women shamed, O Christ!
10064-8{_}7645{_}Lords--ha, messires, there is talk afoot of seizing the gates, of opening to this churchman and praying his intercession to Ivo's mercy--to Ivo the Black, that knoweth nought of mercy.
10064-8{_}7646{_}Alas, my lords, once they do ope the gates--"  "That can they in nowise do!"
10064-8{_}7647{_}said Sir Benedict gently, but with face grim and hawk-like.
