10064-8{_}7648{_}"Every gate is held by stout fellows of my own following, moreover I have good hope yon churchman may leave us yet uncursed."
10064-8{_}7649{_}And Sir Benedict smiled his wry and twisted smile.
10064-8{_}7650{_}"Be you our tongue, good Reeve, and speak this churchman as thy bold heart dictateth."
10064-8{_}7651{_}Solemn and sweet rose the chanting voices growing ever more loud, where paced the black-robed priests.
10064-8{_}7652{_}First came acolytes swinging censers, and next, others bearing divers symbolic flags and standards, and after these again, in goodly chair borne on the shoulders of brawny monks, a portly figure rode, bedight in full canonicals, a very solid cleric he, and mightily round; moreover his nose was bulbous and he had a drooping lip.
10064-8{_}7653{_}Slow and solemn the procession advanced, and ever as they came the choristers chanted full melodiously what time the white-robed acolytes swung their censers to and fro; and ever as they came, the folk of Belsaye, from wall and turret, eyed these slow-pacing, sweet-singing monks with fearful looks and hearts cold and full of dire misgiving.
10064-8{_}7654{_}Beyond the moat over against the main gate, the procession halted, the chair with its portly burden was set down, and lifting up a white, be-ringed hand, the haughty cleric spake thus, in voice high-pitched, mellifluous and sweet:  "Whereas it hath pleased ye, O rebellious people of Belsaye, to deny, to cast off and wantonly repudiate your rightful allegiance to your most just, most merciful and most august lord--Ivo, Duke of Pentavalon (whom God and the saints defend--amen!)
10064-8{_}7655{_}and whereas ye have moreover made captive and most barbarously entreated certain of your lord Duke his ambassadors unto you sent; now therefore--and let all ears be opened to my pronouncements, since Holy Church doth speak ye, one and all, each and every through humble avenue of these my lips--list, list, O list, rebellious people, and mark me well.
10064-8{_}7656{_}For inasmuch as I, Prior of Holy Cross within Pentavalon City, do voice unto ye, one and all, each and every, the most sacred charge of Holy Church, her strict command or enactment, mandate or caveat, her holy decree, _senatus consultum_, her writ, edict, precept or decretal, namely and to wit: That ye shall one and all, each and every, return to your rightful allegiance, bowing humbly, each and every, to the will of your lawful lord the Duke (whom God and the saints defend) and shall forthwith make full and instant surrender of this his ancient city of Belsaye unto your lord the Duke (whom God and the saints defend--amen!)
10064-8{_}7657{_}Failing the which, I, in the name of Holy Church, by power of papal bull new come from Rome--will, here and now, pronounce this most rebellious city (and all that therein be) damned and excommunicate!"
10064-8{_}7658{_}Now hereupon, from all the townsfolk crowding wall and turret a groan went up and full many a ruddy cheek grew pale at this dire threat.
10064-8{_}7659{_}Whereupon the Prior, having drawn breath, spake on in voice more stern and more peremptory:  "Let now your gates unbar!
10064-8{_}7660{_}Yield ye unto your lord Duke his mercy!
10064-8{_}7661{_}Let the gates unbar, I say, lest I blast this wicked city with the most dread and awful ban and curse of Holy Church--woe, woe in this life, and, in the life to come, torment and everlasting fire!
10064-8{_}7662{_}Let the gates unbar!"
10064-8{_}7663{_}Now once again the men of Belsaye sighed and groaned and trembled in their armour, while from crowded street and market-square rose buzz of fearful voices.
10064-8{_}7664{_}Then spake the Reeve in troubled tones, his white head low-stooped above the battlement.
10064-8{_}7665{_}"Good Prior, I pray you an we unbar, what surety have we that this our city shall not be given over to fire and pillage and ravishment?"
10064-8{_}7666{_}Quoth the Prior:  "Your lives are your lord's, in his hand resteth life and death, justice and mercy.
10064-8{_}7667{_}So for the last time I charge ye--set wide your rebellious gates!"
10064-8{_}7668{_}"Not so!"
10064-8{_}7669{_}cried the Reeve, "in the name of Justice and Mercy ne'er will we yield this our city until in Belsaye no man is left to strike for maid and wife and child!"
10064-8{_}7670{_}At the which bold words some few men shouted in acclaim, but for the most part the citizens were mumchance, their hearts cold within them, while all eyes stared fearfully upon the Prior, who, lifting white hand again, rose up from cushioned chair and spake him loud and clear:  "Then, upon this rebellious city and all that therein is, on babe, on child, on youth, on maid, on man, on wife, on the hale, the sick, the stricken in years, on beast, on bird, and on all that hath life and being I do pronounce the church's dread curse and awful ban:--ex--"  The Prior's mellifluous voice was of a sudden lost and drowned in another, a rich voice, strong and full and merry:  "Quit--quit thy foolish babblement, thou fat and naughty friar; too plump art thou, too round and buxom to curse a curse as curses should be cursed, so shall thy curses avail nothing, for who doth heed the fatuous fulminations of a fat man?
10064-8{_}7671{_}But as to me, I could have out-cursed thee in my cradle, thou big-bellied thing of emptiness--go to for a sounding brass and tinkling cymbal!"
10064-8{_}7672{_}Thus, from his "mockery" perched high above the battlement, spake Giles, with many and divers knowing gestures of arm, waggings of the head, rollings of the eyes and the like, what time Roger and Walkyn and Ulf, their heads bent close together, busied themselves above a great and bulging wine-skin.
10064-8{_}7673{_}And now on wall and tower and market-square a great silence had fallen, yet a silence broken now and then by sound of stifled laughter, while the Prior, staring in wonder and amaze, suddenly clenched white fist, and, albeit very red and fiery of visage, strove whole-heartedly to curse on:  "Ha--now upon the lewd populace of this most accursed and rebellious city do I call down the--"  "Upon thy round and barrel-like paunch," cried Giles, "do I pronounce this dire and dreadful ban, _videlicet_, Sir Fatness, _nota bene_ and to wit: may the fiend rend it with gruesome gripings--aye, rend it with claws and beak, _unguibus et rostro_, most mountainous monk!"
10064-8{_}7674{_}Here, once again came sounds of stifled merriment, what time the Prior, puffing out his fat cheeks, fell to his curses full-tongued:  "Upon this evil city be the malison of Holy Church, her maledictions bitter, her imprecation and anathema.
10064-8{_}7675{_}I do pronounce all within this city ex--"  "Abate thee, friar, abate!"
10064-8{_}7676{_}roared Giles, "cease thy rumbling, thou empty wine-butt.
10064-8{_}7677{_}An thou must deal in curses, leave them to one more apt and better schooled--to Giles, in faith, who shall forthwith curse thee sweet and trippingly as thus--now mark me, monk!
10064-8{_}7678{_}Aroint, aroint thee to Acheron dark and dismal, there may the foul fiend seize and plague thee with seven and seventy plaguey sorrows!
10064-8{_}7679{_}May Saint Anthony's fire frizzle and fry thee--woe, woe betide thee everlastingly--(bate thy babble, Prior, I am not ended yet!)
10064-8{_}7680{_}In life may thou be accursed from heel to head, within thee and without--(save thy wind, Prior, no man doth hear or heed thee!)
10064-8{_}7681{_}Be thou accursed in father and in mother, in sister and in brother, in oxen and in asses--especially in asses!
10064-8{_}7682{_}Be thou accursed in sleeping and in waking, eating and drinking, standing, sitting, lying--O be thou accursed completely and consumedly!
10064-8{_}7683{_}Here now, methinks, Sir Monkish Tunbelly, is cursing as it should be cursed.
10064-8{_}7684{_}But now--(hush thy vain babbling, heed and mark me well!)
10064-8{_}7685{_}--now will I to dictums contumacious, from cursing thee I will to song of thee, of thy plump and pertinacious person--a song wherein shall pleasant mention be o' thy round and goodly paunch, a song that shall be sung, mayhap, when thee and it are dusty dust, O shaveling--to wit:    "O frater fat and flatulent, full foolish, fatuous Friar    A prime plump priest in passion seen, such pleasure doth inspire,    That sober souls, 'spite sorrows sad, shall sudden, shout and sing    Because thy belly big belittleth baleful ban ye bring.
10064-8{_}7686{_}Wherefore with wondrous wit withal, with waggish wanton wiles,    I joyful chant to glorify the just and gentle Giles."
10064-8{_}7687{_}And now behold!
10064-8{_}7688{_}fear and dread were forgotten quite, and wheresoever Beltane looked were men who bent and contorted themselves in their merriment, and who held their laughter yet in check to catch the archer's final words.
10064-8{_}7689{_}"Thus, thou poor and pitiful Prior, for thy rude speech and curses canonical we do requite thee with song sweet-sung and of notable rhyme and metre.
10064-8{_}7690{_}Curse, and Belsaye shall out-curse thee; laugh, and Belsaye laugheth at thee--"  "Sacrilege!"
10064-8{_}7691{_}gasped the Prior, "O 'tis base sacrilege!
10064-8{_}7692{_}'Tis a vile, unhallowed city and shall go up in flame--"  "And thou," cried Giles, "thou art a fiery churchman and shall be cooled.
10064-8{_}7693{_}Ho, Rogerkin--loose off!"
10064-8{_}7694{_}Came the thudding crash of a powerful mangonel, whose mighty beam, swinging high, hurled aloft the bulging wine-skin, the which, bursting in mid-air, deluged with water all below--prior and monk, acolyte and chorister; whereat from all Belsaye a shout went up, that swelled to peal on peal of mighty laughter, the while, in stumbling haste, the dripping Prior was borne by dripping monks back to Duke Ivo's mighty camp.
10064-8{_}7695{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}7696{_}from this great camp another sound arose, a roar of anger, fierce and terrible to hear, that smote Belsaye to silence.
10064-8{_}7697{_}But, out upon the battlement, plain for all folk to see, sprang Giles flourishing his six-foot bow.
10064-8{_}7698{_}"Archers!"
10064-8{_}7699{_}he cried, "archers, ye hear the dogs bay yonder--fling back their challenge!
10064-8{_}7700{_}"Ho, archers!
10064-8{_}7701{_}shout and rend the skies,    Bold archers shout amain    Belsaye, Belsaye--arise, arise!
10064-8{_}7702{_}Pentavalon--Beltane!"
10064-8{_}7703{_}Then from tower and turret, from wall and keep and market-square a great and joyous shout was raised--a cry fierce and loud and very purposeful, that rolled afar:  "Arise, arise!--ha, Beltane--Pentavalon!"
10064-8{_}7704{_}"Beltane," quoth Sir Benedict, smiling his wry smile as he turned to descend the tower, "methinks yon roguish archer's wit hath served us better than all our wisdom.
10064-8{_}7705{_}Belsaye hath frighted away fear with laughter, and her men, methinks, will fight marvellous well!"
10064-8{_}7706{_}CHAPTER LXV  TELLETH OF ROSES   A fair and strong city was Belsaye, for (as hath been said) to north and east of it the river flowed, a broad stream and deep, while south and west it was fortified by a goodly moat; wherefore it was to south and west that the besiegers mustered their chief force and set up their mightiest engines and towers.
10064-8{_}7707{_}Day in, day out, mangonel, trebuchet and balista whirred and crashed from keep and tower and curtain-wall, while from every loophole and crenelle long-bows twanged and arrows flew; yet with each succeeding dawn the besiegers' fence-works crept nearer, closing in upon the city until, within close bowshot of the walls, they set up earthworks and stockades and from these strong barriers plied the defenders with cloth-yard shaft and cross-bow bolt what time their mighty engines advanced, perriers and rams wherewith to batter and breach the city's massy walls.
10064-8{_}7708{_}So day in, day out, Eric's chosen men plied trebuchet and balista, and Beltane, beholding the dire havoc wrought by heavy stone and whizzing javelin among the dense ranks of the besiegers despite their mantlets and stout palisades, grew sick at times and was fain to look otherwhere.
10064-8{_}7709{_}But the besiegers were many and Duke Ivo had sworn swift destruction on Belsaye; thus, heedless of all else, he pushed on the attack until, despite their heavy losses, his men were firmly established close beyond the moat; wherefore my Beltane waxed full anxious and was for sallying out to destroy their works: at the which, gloomy Sir Hacon, limping in his many bandages, grew suddenly jovial and fain was to call for horse and lance forthwith.
10064-8{_}7710{_}Quoth Sir Benedict placidly:  "Nay, let them come, messires; they are a sea, but Belsaye is a rock.
10064-8{_}7711{_}Duke Ivo is cunning in war, but is, mark me!
10064-8{_}7712{_}a passionate man, and he who fighteth in blind anger, fighteth ill.
10064-8{_}7713{_}So let them come, I say the time for us to beware is when Ivo's hot temper shall have cooled.
10064-8{_}7714{_}Ha, look yonder!"
10064-8{_}7715{_}and Sir Benedict pointed where a great wooden tower, urged forward by rope and pulley and winch, was creeping near and nearer the walls, now stopping jerkily, now advancing, its massy timbers protected from fire by raw hides, its summit bristling with archers and cross-bow men, who from their lofty post began to sweep wall and turret with their whizzing shafts.
10064-8{_}7716{_}"Now mark yon tower," said Sir Benedict, closing his vizor, "here shall be good sport for Eric's perriers--watch now!"
10064-8{_}7717{_}and he nodded where on the battlement below, crouched Eric with Walkyn and Roger who laboured at the winches of a great trebuchet hard by.
10064-8{_}7718{_}To left and right on wall and turret, Eric glanced, then blew a blast upon the horn he carried; and immediately, from wall and turret mangonels, trebuchets and balistae unknown of until now crashed and whirred, and the tall tower shook and quivered 'neath the shock of great stones and heavy bolts, its massy timbers were split and rent, insomuch that it was fain to be withdrawn.
10064-8{_}7719{_}Thereafter the besiegers brought up a long pent-house or cat unto the edge of the moat, and sheltered within this cat were many men who fell to work filling up the moat with bags of earth and stone werewith to form a causeway across which they might assault the wall with bore and ram; and because this cat was builded very strong, Eric's engines battered it in vain, wherefore he presently desisted; thus, hour by hour the causeway grew and lengthened.
10064-8{_}7720{_}So needs must Beltane seek Sir Benedict and point this out with anxious finger.
10064-8{_}7721{_}"Let them come, Beltane!"
10064-8{_}7722{_}quoth Sir Benedict, placid as was his wont, "once they are close against the wall with ram a-swing, I will make their labour of no avail; you shall see me burn them with a devil's brew I learned of in the foreign wars.
10064-8{_}7723{_}So, let them come.
10064-8{_}7724{_}Beltane!"
10064-8{_}7725{_}Thus, day in, day out, was roar of conflict about the walls of Belsaye town, and ever Sir Benedict, with Beltane beside him, went to and fro, quick of eye and hand, swift to foresee and counteract the tactics of the besiegers, meeting cunning artifice with crafty strategem; wheresoever was panic or pressing need there was Sir Benedict, calm-voiced and serene.
10064-8{_}7726{_}And Beltane, watching him thus, came to understand why this man had withstood the powers of Duke Ivo all these years, and why all men trusted to his judgment.
10064-8{_}7727{_}Thus, all day was rage of battle, but with the night peace came, since in the dark men might not see to aim and slay each other.
10064-8{_}7728{_}And by night the folk of Belsaye made good their battered walls what time the besiegers prepared fresh devices of attack.
10064-8{_}7729{_}Every morning at sunrise it was Beltane's custom to steal to the great minster and, soft-treading despite his armour, come to his mother's grave to hold communion with her in his prayers.
10064-8{_}7730{_}And lo!
10064-8{_}7731{_}upon that hallowed stone there always he found fragrant flowers, roses and lilies, new-gathered, upon whose sweet petals the dew yet sparkled, and ever his wonder grew.
10064-8{_}7732{_}More than once he had thought to hear again that indefinable stir and whisper the which had thrilled him on that first morning, and, starting up, he would peer into the vague shadows.
10064-8{_}7733{_}Twice he had thought to see a draped figure bending above that long, white stone, a veiled figure slender and graceful, that upon his approach, soft though it was, flitted swiftly into the dark recesses of the choir.
10064-8{_}7734{_}Once he had followed, and stood amazed to see it vanish through the carven panelling, though door could he find none.
10064-8{_}7735{_}Therefore was he sore perplexed and oft would touch the dewy flowers as half expecting they should vanish also.
10064-8{_}7736{_}Now upon a certain dawn he had hid himself within the shadows and waited with bated breath and heart strangely a-throb.
10064-8{_}7737{_}And with the day-spring she came again, tall and gracious in her clinging draperies and long green veil.
10064-8{_}7738{_}Then, even as she bent to lay the flowers upon the grave came Beltane, soft of foot, and spake ere she was 'ware of him.
10064-8{_}7739{_}"Lady--!"
10064-8{_}7740{_}now though his voice was very low and gentle she started, the flowers fell from her loosened clasp, and, after a moment, she turned and fronted him, proud head up-flung beneath her veil.
10064-8{_}7741{_}So stood they within that place of silence, while high above, the great window grew luminous with coming day.
10064-8{_}7742{_}"Lady," said he again, "for thy sweet flowers, for thy sweeter thought for one that is--gone, fain would I thank thee, for she who lieth here I found, and loved, and have lost again a while.
10064-8{_}7743{_}She did love all fair things, so loved she the flowers, methinks; yet I, who have grieved for my noble mother, ne'er thought to bring her flowers--this did need a woman's gentle soul.
10064-8{_}7744{_}So, for thy flowers, I do most truly thank thee."
10064-8{_}7745{_}Very still she stood, nor spake nor moved, save for the sweet hurry of her breathing; and beholding her thus, of a sudden Beltane's heart leapt and he fell a-trembling though wherefore he knew not, only yearned he mightily to look beneath her veil.
10064-8{_}7746{_}And now it seemed to him that, in the stillness, she must needs hear the passionate throbbing of his heart; twice would he have spoken yet could not; at last:  "Beseech thee," he whispered, "O beseech thee unveil, that I may behold the face of one so tender to her that was my dear-loved mother--O beseech thee!"
10064-8{_}7747{_}As he spake, he drew a swift pace nearer, hand outstretched in supplication, but, because this hand shook and quivered so, he clenched it, whereat the unknown shrank back and back and, turning swift and sudden, was gone.
10064-8{_}7748{_}A while stood my Beltane, his head a-droop, and fell to wonderment because of the so painful throbbing of his heart.
10064-8{_}7749{_}Then knelt he above his mother's grave with hands tight-clasped.
10064-8{_}7750{_}"Dear mother in heaven," he sighed, "being an angel, thou dost know all my heart, its hopes and fears--thou hast seen me tremble--thou dost know wherefore this my heart doth yearn so bitterly.
10064-8{_}7751{_}O sweet mother with God, plead thou on my behalf that I may be worthy her love--meet to her embracements--fit for so great happiness.
10064-8{_}7752{_}Angel of God, thou dost know how great is my desire--how empty life without her--O mother--aid me!"
10064-8{_}7753{_}In a while he arose and immediately beheld that which lay beyond his mother's grave full in the radiance of the great east window--a thing small and slender and daintily wrought; and stooping, he picked up a little shoe.
10064-8{_}7754{_}Of soft leather it was fashioned, cunningly pinked, and sewn, here and there, with coloured silks; and as he stared down at it, so small-seeming in his mailed hand, his heart leapt again, and again his strong hand fell a-trembling.
10064-8{_}7755{_}Of a sudden he raised his eyes to heaven, then, coming to his mother's grave, very reverently took thence a single great bloom and thrusting the shoe in the wallet at his girdle (that same wallet Sir Fidelis had borne) went out into the golden dawn.
10064-8{_}7756{_}Like one in a dream went Beltane, heedless of his going; by silent street and lane where none stirred at this early hour, thus he wandered on until he was stayed by a high wall wherein was set a small, green door.
10064-8{_}7757{_}As he stood, staring down at the rose he held and lost in pleasant dream, he was aroused by a scrambling sound near by, and, glancing up, beheld a mailed head and shoulders rise suddenly above the wall and so looked into the face of Giles o' the Bow.
10064-8{_}7758{_}Now in his teeth Giles bare a great red rose--even as that which Beltane held.
10064-8{_}7759{_}"Giles," quoth he, sharp and stern, "whence had ye that flower?"
10064-8{_}7760{_}For answer, Giles, straddling the wall, laid finger to lip, then dropping cat-like to his feet, drew Beltane down an adjacent lane.
10064-8{_}7761{_}"Lord," said he, "yonder is the Reeve's garden and in the Reeve's garden cometh the Reeve to taste the sweet dawn, wherefore Giles doth incontinent vanish him over the Reeve's wall because of the Reeve; nevertheless needs must I bless the Reeve because of the Reeve's daughter--though verily, both in my speech and in the Reeve's garden is too much Reeve, methinks.
10064-8{_}7762{_}As to this rose, now--ha!"
10064-8{_}7763{_}"How came you by the rose, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7764{_}"Why, in the first place, tall brother, I stole it--"  "Stole it!"
10064-8{_}7765{_}repeated Beltane, and behold!
10064-8{_}7766{_}his frown was gone completely.
10064-8{_}7767{_}"But, in the second place, brother, 'twas given to me--"  "Given to thee--by whom?"
10064-8{_}7768{_}and immediately Beltane's frown was back again.
10064-8{_}7769{_}"And therefore, in the third place, brother, Giles this day would not change skins with any lord, duke, archduke, pope or potentate that e'er went in skin--"  "Who gave it thee?--speak, man!"
10064-8{_}7770{_}"Faith, lord, I had it from one as pure, as fair, as--"  "Aye, but what like is she?"
10064-8{_}7771{_}"Like unto this flower for sweetness, lord, and--ha, saints and martyrs!
10064-8{_}7772{_}whence had ye that bloom, tall brother--speak!"
10064-8{_}7773{_}and Giles pointed to the rose in Beltane's fingers.
10064-8{_}7774{_}"What like is she--answer me!"
10064-8{_}7775{_}"Alack!"
10064-8{_}7776{_}sighed Giles, shaking gloomy head, "she is very like a woman, after all, methinks--"  "Mean ye the Reeve's daughter?"
10064-8{_}7777{_}"Even so, lord!"
10064-8{_}7778{_}"Doth she wear ever a--a green veil, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7779{_}"Verily, lord, and with a most sweet grace--"  "And her shoes--"  "Her shoes, tall brother, O methinks her sweet shoe doth kiss the earth so sweet and light poor earth must needs love and languish as doth poor Giles!
10064-8{_}7780{_}Her shoe--"  "Is it aught like to this, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7781{_}and forthwith Beltane took out the little shoe.
10064-8{_}7782{_}"Aye, 'tis her very own, master!"
10064-8{_}7783{_}groaned Giles.
10064-8{_}7784{_}"Ah, woe is me, for if she hath given to thee rose and therewith her pretty shoe--thou hast, belike, her heart also, and with her heart--"  "Nay, take it, Giles,--take it!"
10064-8{_}7785{_}quoth Beltane, sighing.
10064-8{_}7786{_}"I did but find it in my going, and this rose--I found also, but this will I keep.
10064-8{_}7787{_}Methinks thy love is what thy heart telleth thee--a maid very gentle and sweet--so God prosper thy wooing, Giles!"
10064-8{_}7788{_}So saying, Beltane thrust the shoe upon bewildered Giles and, turning swiftly about, hasted away.
10064-8{_}7789{_}But even then, while the archer yet stared after him, Beltane turned and came striding back.
10064-8{_}7790{_}"Giles," quoth he, "how tall is the Reeve's daughter?"
10064-8{_}7791{_}"Lord, she is better than tall--"  "Ha--is she short of stature, good Giles?"
10064-8{_}7792{_}"Messire, God hath shaped her lovely body no higher and no lower than my heart.
10064-8{_}7793{_}Small is she and slender, yet in her sweet and slender shapeliness is all the beauty of all the women that all men have ever loved--"  "Small, say you, Giles--small?
10064-8{_}7794{_}Then give me back yon lovely thing!"
10064-8{_}7795{_}Saying the which, Beltane caught the shoe from Giles's hold and strode away blithe and debonair, leaving the garrulous archer dumb for once and beyond all words amazed.
10064-8{_}7796{_}Now as Beltane went very deep in thought there met him Friar Martin, who bore upon his arm a great basket full of green vegetables and sweet herbs.
10064-8{_}7797{_}Quoth Beltane:  "Good friar, what do ye abroad so early?"
10064-8{_}7798{_}"Sweet son, I praise the good God for His mercies and pant by reason of this my weighty basket."
10064-8{_}7799{_}"Indeed 'tis a something well-laden basket," said Beltane, relieving the friar of his burden with gentle force.
10064-8{_}7800{_}"Why, verily, my children are hungry children and clamour to be filled.
10064-8{_}7801{_}And see you, my son, I have a secret of a certain broth whereof these lentils and these sweet herbs do so tickle their palates that to satisfy them is a hard matter--more especially Orson and Jenkyn--who being nigh cured of their hurts do eat like four men and vaunt my cooking full-mouthed, insomuch that I must needs grow heedful of vain pride."
10064-8{_}7802{_}"Fain would I see these children of thine an I may, good friar, so will I bear thy burden for thee."
10064-8{_}7803{_}"Verily they shall rejoice to see thee," quoth the friar, "but for my basket, methinks 'tis better suited to my habit than thy knightly mail--"  For answer Beltane slipped the basket on his arm and they went on together talking whole-heartedly of many things.
10064-8{_}7804{_}Thus the gentle friar brought him at last to a low-arched portal within a narrow lane, and pushing open the door, ushered him into the great refectory of the abbey, where Beltane set down the basket, and Friar Martin, rolling up his sleeves, brought pot and pannikin but paused to smile and shake his head, as from a stone-flagged passage hard by came the sound of voices raised in altercation.
10064-8{_}7805{_}"My children do grow a little fractious at times," quoth he, "as is but natural, methinks.
10064-8{_}7806{_}Yonder you shall hear Orson and Jenkyn, who having saved each other's life in battle and loving like brothers, do oft contend together with tongues most ungentle; go you, my son, and quiet me the naughty rogues."
10064-8{_}7807{_}So saying, Friar Martin fell to washing and preparing his herbs and vegetables whiles Beltane, hasting down the passage, opened a certain door and entered a cool and airy dormitory, where upon pallets neat and orderly lay divers fellows whose hurts were swathed in fair white linen, and who, despite their bandages, started up on hand or elbow to greet Beltane right gladly.
10064-8{_}7808{_}And behold!
10064-8{_}7809{_}beside each man's couch was a bowl wherein roses bloomed.
10064-8{_}7810{_}"Master," quoth Tall Orson, "us do be glad to see thee--in especial me-- and Jenkyn that I did save the carcase of and as do be a liar as do say my roses do be a-fading, master, and as his roses do bloom fairer than my roses and--"  "And look'ee master, so they be, for I ha' watered mine wi' Orson's drinking-water, while he snored, look'ee--" "So Jenkyn do be thief as well, master--"  "Nay," said Beltane smiling, and seating himself on Orson's bed, "stint now your angers and tell me who gave ye flowers so fair?"
10064-8{_}7811{_}"Master, she do be an angel!"
10064-8{_}7812{_}"Heed him not, lord, for look'ee, she is a fair and lovely woman, and look'ee, a good woman is better than an angel, look'ee!"
10064-8{_}7813{_}"And what like is she?"
10064-8{_}7814{_}questioned Beltane.
10064-8{_}7815{_}"She do be like to a stag for grace o' body, and wi' the eyes of a stag--"  "Nay, master, her eyes do be maid's eyes, look'ee, very soft and sweet, and her hair, look'ee--"  "Her hair do be like a forest-pool brim-full o' sunset--"  "Not so, master, her hair is red, look'ee--"  "And each day she do bring us flowers, master--"  "And suckets, look'ee, very sweet and delicate, master."
10064-8{_}7816{_}In a while Beltane arose and going from bed to bed spake with each and every, and went his way, leaving Orson and Jenkyn to their recriminations.
10064-8{_}7817{_}Being come back into the refectory, he found Friar Martin yet busied with the preparations of his cooking, and seating himself upon the great table hard by, fell to a profound meditation, watched ever and anon by the friar's kindly eyes: so very silent and thoughtful was he that the friar presently looked up from slicing and cutting his vegetables and spake with smile wondrous tender:  "Wherefore so pensive, my son?"
10064-8{_}7818{_}"Good father, I think and dream of--red roses!"
10064-8{_}7819{_}Friar Martin cut and trimmed a leek with great care, yet surely here was no reason for his eyes to twinkle within the shadow of his white cowl.
10064-8{_}7820{_}"A sweet and fragrant thought, my son!"
10064-8{_}7821{_}quoth he.
10064-8{_}7822{_}"As sweet, methinks, holy father, as pure and fragrant as she herself!"
10064-8{_}7823{_}"'She,' my son?"
10064-8{_}7824{_}"As Helen, good friar, as Helen the Beautiful, Duchess of Mortain!"
10064-8{_}7825{_}"Ah!"
10064-8{_}7826{_}sighed the friar, and forthwith popped the leek into the pot.
10064-8{_}7827{_}"I prithee, noble son, reach me the salt-box yonder!"
10064-8{_}7828{_}CHAPTER LXVI  CONCERNING A BLUE CAMLET CLOAK   Next morning, ere the sun was up, came Beltane into the minster and hiding within the deeper gloom of the choir, sat there hushing his breath to listen, trembling in eager anticipation.
10064-8{_}7829{_}Slowly amid the dimness above came a glimmer from the great window, a pale beam that grew with dawn until up rose the sun and the window glowed in many-hued splendour.
10064-8{_}7830{_}And in a while to Beltane's straining senses came the faint creak of a door, a soft rustle, the swift light tread of feet, and starting forth of his lurking place he stepped forward with yearning arms outstretched--then paused of a sudden beholding her who stood at gaze, one slender foot advanced and white hands full of roses and lilies, one as fair, as sweet and pure as the fragrant blooms she bore.
10064-8{_}7831{_}Small was she and slender, and of a radiant loveliness, red of lip and grey-eyed: now beholding Beltane thus suddenly, she shrank and uttered a soft cry.
10064-8{_}7832{_}"Nay," quoth he, "fear me not, sweet maid, methought thee other than thou art--I grieve that I did fright thee--forgive me, I pray," so saying, he sighed and bowing full humbly, turned, but even so paused again: "Thou art methinks the Reeve's fair daughter--thou art the lady Genevra?"
10064-8{_}7833{_}he questioned.
10064-8{_}7834{_}"Aye, my lord."
10064-8{_}7835{_}"Then, an thou dost love, gentle maid, heaven send thee happier in thy love than I."
10064-8{_}7836{_}At the which Genevra's gentle eyes grew softer yet and her sweet mouth full pitiful and tender.
10064-8{_}7837{_}"Art thou so unhappy, lord Beltane?"
10064-8{_}7838{_}"Aye, truly!"
10064-8{_}7839{_}he sighed, and drooped mournful head.
10064-8{_}7840{_}"Ah, messire, then fain would I aid thee an I might!"
10064-8{_}7841{_}said she, soft-voiced.
10064-8{_}7842{_}"Then where, I pray you, is she that came here yesterday?"
10064-8{_}7843{_}"Nay, lord, how may I tell thee this?
10064-8{_}7844{_}There be many women in Belsaye town."
10064-8{_}7845{_}"For me," quoth Beltane, "in all the world there is but one and to this one, alas!
10064-8{_}7846{_}thou canst not aid me, yet for thy kind intent I thank thee, and so farewell, sweet maid."
10064-8{_}7847{_}Thus saying, he took three steps away from her, then turning, came back in two.
10064-8{_}7848{_}"Stay," quoth he, slipping hand in wallet, "know you this shoe?"
10064-8{_}7849{_}Now beholding this, Genevra's red lips quivered roguishly, and she bowed her little, shapely head:  "Indeed, my lord, 'tis mine!"
10064-8{_}7850{_}said she.
10064-8{_}7851{_}"Then pray you, who was she did wear it yesterday--?"
10064-8{_}7852{_}"Aye, messire, 'twas yesterday I--missed it, wilt not give it me therefore?
10064-8{_}7853{_}One shoe can avail thee nothing and--and 'tis too small for thee to wear methinks--"  "Did she--she that lost this yesterday, send thee to-day in her stead?"
10064-8{_}7854{_}"Wilt not give a poor maid her shoe again, messire?"
10064-8{_}7855{_}"O Genevra, beseech thee, who was she did wear it yesterday--speak!"
10064-8{_}7856{_}"Nay, this--this I may not tell thee, lord Beltane."
10064-8{_}7857{_}"And wherefore?"
10064-8{_}7858{_}"For that I did so promise--and yet--what seek you of her, my lord?"
10064-8{_}7859{_}"Forgiveness," said Beltane, hot and eager, "I would woo her sweet clemency on one that hath wrought her grievous wrong.
10064-8{_}7860{_}O sweet Genevra, wilt not say where I may find her?"
10064-8{_}7861{_}A while stood the maid Genevra with bowed head as one in doubt, then looked on him with sweet maiden eyes and of a sudden smiled compassionate and tender.
10064-8{_}7862{_}"Ah, messire," said she, "surely thine are the eyes of one who loveth greatly and well!
10064-8{_}7863{_}And I do so love her that fain would I have her greatly loved--so will I tell thee despite my word--hearken!"
10064-8{_}7864{_}And drawing him near she laid white finger to rosy lip and thereafter spake in whispers.
10064-8{_}7865{_}"Go you to the green door where yesterday thou didst meet with Gi--with the captain of the archers--O verily we--she and I, my lord, did see and hear all that passed betwixt you--and upon this door knock you softly three times.
10064-8{_}7866{_}Go--yet, O prithee say not 'twas Genevra told thee this!"
10064-8{_}7867{_}and again she laid white finger to roguish, pouting lip.
10064-8{_}7868{_}Then Beltane stooped, and catching that little hand kissed it, and thereafter hasted blithely on his way.
10064-8{_}7869{_}Swift of foot went he and with eyes a-dance, nor paused in his long stride until he was come to a certain high wall wherein was set the small, green door, whereon he knocked three times.
10064-8{_}7870{_}And presently he heard the bar softly raised, the door was opened slow and cautiously, and stooping, Beltane stepped beneath the lintel and stood suddenly still, staring into the face of Black Roger.
10064-8{_}7871{_}And even as Beltane stared thus amazed, so stared Roger.
10064-8{_}7872{_}"Why, master--" quoth he, pushing back his mail-coif to rumple his black hair, "why, master, you--you be early abroad--though forsooth 'tis a fair morning and--"  "Roger," quoth Beltane, looking round upon a fair garden a-bloom with flowers, "Roger, where is the Duchess Helen?"
10064-8{_}7873{_}"Ha, so ye do know, master--who hath discovered it--?"
10064-8{_}7874{_}"Where is she, Roger?"
10064-8{_}7875{_}"Lord," quoth Roger, giving a sudden sideways jerk of his head, "how should Roger tell thee this?"
10064-8{_}7876{_}Now even as he spake, Roger must needs gesture again with his head and therewith close one bright, black eye, and with stealthy finger point to a certain tall hedge hard by; all of which was seen by one who stood beyond the hedge, watching Beltane with eyes that missed nought of him, from golden spur to golden head; quick to note his flushing cheek, his parted lips and the eager light of his blue eyes; one who perceiving him turn whither Roger's sly finger pointed, gathered up her flowing robe in both white hands that she might flee the faster, and who, speeding swift and light, came to a certain leafy bower where stood a tambour frame, and sitting there, with draperies well ordered, caught up silk and needle, yet paused to close her eyes and set one hand upon rounded bosom what time a quick, firm step drew near and ever nearer with clash and ring of heavy mail until Beltane stood before her.
10064-8{_}7877{_}And how was he to know of the eyes that had watched him through the hedge, or that the hand that held the needle had paused lest he should see how direfully it trembled: how should my Beltane know all this, who was but a very man?
10064-8{_}7878{_}A while stood he, viewing her with eyes aglow with yearning tenderness, and she, knowing this, kept her face down-bent, therefore.
10064-8{_}7879{_}Now beholding all the beauty of her, because of her gracious loveliness, his breath caught, then hurried thick and fast, insomuch that when he would have spoken he could not; thus he worshipped her in a look and she, content to be so worshipped, sat with head down-bent, as sweetly demure, as proud and stately as if--as if she ne'er in all her days had fled with hampering draperies caught up so high!
10064-8{_}7880{_}So Beltane stood worshipping her as she had been some young goddess in whose immortal beauty all beauty was embodied.
10064-8{_}7881{_}At last he spake, hoarse and low and passionate:  "Helen!"
10064-8{_}7882{_}said he, "O Helen!"
10064-8{_}7883{_}Slowly, slowly the Duchess lifted stately head and looked on him: but now, behold!
10064-8{_}7884{_}her glance was high and proud, her scarlet mouth firm-set like the white and dimpled chin below and her eyes swept him with look calm and most dispassionate.
10064-8{_}7885{_}"Ah, my lord Beltane," she said, sweet-voiced, "what do you here within the privacy of Genevra's garden?"
10064-8{_}7886{_}Now because of the sweet serenity of her speech, because of the calm, unswerving directness of her gaze, my Beltane felt at sudden loss, his outstretched arms sank helplessly and he fell a-stammering.
10064-8{_}7887{_}"Helen, I--I--O Helen, I have dreamed of, yearned for this hour!
10064-8{_}7888{_}To see thee again--to hear thy voice, and yet--and yet--"  "Well, my lord?"
10064-8{_}7889{_}Now stood Beltane very still, staring on her in dumb amaze, and the pain in his eyes smote her, insomuch that she bent to her embroidery and sewed three stitches woefully askew.
10064-8{_}7890{_}"O surely, surely I am mad," quoth he wondering, "or I do dream.
10064-8{_}7891{_}For she I seek is a woman, gentle and prone to forgiveness, one beyond all women fair and brave and noble, in whose pure heart can nothing evil be, in whose gentle eyes her gentle soul lieth mirrored, whose tender lips be apt and swift to speak mercy and forgiveness.
10064-8{_}7892{_}Even as her soft, kind hands did bind up my wounds, so methought she with gentle sayings might heal my grieving heart--and now--now--"  "O my lord," she sighed, bending over idle fingers, "methinks you came seeking an angel of heaven and find here--only a woman."
10064-8{_}7893{_}"Yet 'tis this woman I do love and ever must--'tis this woman I did know as Fidelis--"  "Alas!"
10064-8{_}7894{_}she sighed again, "alas, poor Fidelis, thou didst drive him from thee into the solitary wild-wood.
10064-8{_}7895{_}So is poor Fidelis lost to thee, methinks--"  "Nay, Helen--O Helen, be just to me--thou dost know I loved Fidelis--"  "Yet thou didst spurn and name him traitor and drave him from thee!"
10064-8{_}7896{_}Now of a sudden he strode towards her, and as he came her bosom swelled, her lashes drooped, for it seemed he meant to clasp her to his heart.
10064-8{_}7897{_}But lo!
10064-8{_}7898{_}being only man, my Beltane paused and trembled, and dared not touch her, and sinking before her on his knees, spake very humbly and with head low-bowed.
10064-8{_}7899{_}"Helen--show me a little mercy!"
10064-8{_}7900{_}he pleaded.
10064-8{_}7901{_}"Would'st that I abase myself?
10064-8{_}7902{_}Then here--here behold me at thy feet, fearing thee because of my unworthiness.
10064-8{_}7903{_}But O believe--believe, for every base doubt of thee this heart hath known, now doth it grieve remorseful.
10064-8{_}7904{_}For every harsh and bitter word this tongue hath spoke thee, now doth it humbly crave thy pitiful forgiveness!
10064-8{_}7905{_}But know you this, that from the evil hour I drave thee from me, I have known abiding sorrow and remorse, for without thee life is indeed but an empty thing and I a creature lost and desolate--O Helen, pity me!"
10064-8{_}7906{_}Thus spake he, humble and broken, and she, beholding him thus, sighed (though wondrous softly) and 'neath her long lashes tears glittered (though swift dashed away) but--slowly, very slowly, one white hand came out to him, faltered, stopped, and glancing up she rose in haste and shrank away.
10064-8{_}7907{_}Now Beltane, perceiving only this last gesture, sprang up, fierce-eyed:  "How?"
10064-8{_}7908{_}quoth he, "am I then become a thing so base my presence doth offend thee--then, as God liveth, ne'er shalt see me more until thou thyself do summon me!"
10064-8{_}7909{_}Even as he spake thus, swift and passionate, Giles clambered the adjacent wall and dropping softly within the garden, stared to behold Beltane striding towards him fierce-eyed, who, catching him by the arm yet viewing him not, spun him from his path, and coming to the green door, sped out and away.
10064-8{_}7910{_}Now as Giles stood to rub his arm and gape in wonderment, he started to find the Duchess beside him; and her eyes were very bright and her cheeks very red, and, meeting her look, poor Giles fell suddenly abashed.
10064-8{_}7911{_}"Noble lady--" he faltered.
10064-8{_}7912{_}"Foolish Giles!"
10064-8{_}7913{_}said she, "go, summon me my faithful Roger."
10064-8{_}7914{_}But as she spake, behold Roger himself hasting to her through the roses.
10064-8{_}7915{_}"Roger," said she, frowning a little, "saw you my lord go but now?"
10064-8{_}7916{_}"Aye, verily, dear my lady," quoth he, ruffling up his hair, "but wherefore--"  "And I," said Giles, cherishing his arm, "both saw and felt him--"  "Ha," quoth Roger, "would'st have him back, sweet mistress?"
10064-8{_}7917{_}"Why truly I would, Roger--"  "Then forsooth will I go fetch him."
10064-8{_}7918{_}"Nay--rather would I die, Roger."
10064-8{_}7919{_}"But--dear lady--an thou dost want him--"  "I will bring him by other means!"
10064-8{_}7920{_}said the Duchess, "aye, he shall come despite himself," and her red lips curved to sudden roguish smile, as smiling thus, she brought them to a certain arbour very shady and remote, and, seating herself, looked from one tanned face to the other and spake them certain matters, whereat the archer's merry eyes grew merrier yet, but Roger sighed and shook his head; said he:  "Lady, here is tale shall wring his noble heart, methinks, wherefore the telling shall wring mine also--"  "Then speak not of it, Roger.
10064-8{_}7921{_}Be this Giles's mission."
10064-8{_}7922{_}"Aye, Rogerkin, leave it to me.
10064-8{_}7923{_}In faith, noble lady, I will with suggestion soft and subtle, with knowing look and wily wag of head, so work upon my lord that he shall hither hot-foot haste--"  "At moonrise," said the Duchess softly, "this evening at moonrise!"
10064-8{_}7924{_}"Verily, lady, at moonrise!
10064-8{_}7925{_}And a blue camlet cloak, say you?"
10064-8{_}7926{_}"Come, Giles, and I will give it thee."
10064-8{_}7927{_}Meanwhile, Beltane, hurt and angry, betook him to the walls where bow and perrier had already begun their deadly morning's work; and coming to a quiet corner of the battlement, he leaned him there to watch where the besiegers, under cover of the cat that hourly crept more nigh, worked amain to dam the moat.
10064-8{_}7928{_}Now as he leaned thus, a hand slipped within his arm, and turning, he beheld Sir Benedict.
10064-8{_}7929{_}"A right fair morning, my Beltane," quoth he.
10064-8{_}7930{_}"Aye, truly, Benedict," sighed Beltane, "though there be clouds to the west.
10064-8{_}7931{_}And the causeway across the moat groweth apace; I have watched yon cat creep a full yard--"  "Aye, verily, by mid-day, Beltane, 'twill reach our wall, then will they advance their ram to the battery, methinks."
10064-8{_}7932{_}"And what then, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7933{_}"Then shall we destroy their ram forthwith with devil-fire, dear lad!"
10064-8{_}7934{_}"Aye, and how then, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7935{_}"Then, belike will they plant ladders on the causeway and attempt the wall by storm, so shall we come to handstrokes at last and beset them with pitch and boiling oil and hew their ladders in sunder."
10064-8{_}7936{_}"And after, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7937{_}"Hey-day, Beltane, here be a many questions--"  "Aye, Benedict, 'tis that I do look into the future.
10064-8{_}7938{_}And what future can there be?
10064-8{_}7939{_}Though we maintain our walls a year, or two, or three, yet in the end Belsaye must fall."
10064-8{_}7940{_}"And I tell thee, Beltane, were Ivo twice as strong Belsaye should yet withstand him.
10064-8{_}7941{_}So gloom not, lad, Belsaye is safe, the sun shineth and behold my arm--'tis well-nigh healed, thanks to--to skilful nursing--"  "Of the Duchess Helen, Benedict?"
10064-8{_}7942{_}"Ha--so hast found it out--at last, lad--"  "Knew you she was here?"
10064-8{_}7943{_}"Aye, verily."
10064-8{_}7944{_}"And told me not?"
10064-8{_}7945{_}"For that she did so command, Beltane."
10064-8{_}7946{_}"And wherefore came she hither?"
10064-8{_}7947{_}"For thy dear sake in the first place, and--"  "Nay, mock me not, friend, for I do know myself of none account."
10064-8{_}7948{_}"And in the second place, Beltane, to save this fair city of Belsaye."
10064-8{_}7949{_}"Nay, how mean you?"
10064-8{_}7950{_}"I mean that Belsaye cannot fall whiles it holdeth Helen the Proud.
10064-8{_}7951{_}And the reason this--now mark me, Beltane!
10064-8{_}7952{_}Since her father's death Duke Ivo hath had his glutton eye on fair Mortain, whereof her counsellors did ken, yet, being old men and averse to war, would fain have had her wed with him.
10064-8{_}7953{_}Now upon a day word reached me in Thrasfordham bidding me come to her and Waldron of Brand at Winisfarne.
10064-8{_}7954{_}So, as thou dost know, stole I from my goodly castle and marched north.
10064-8{_}7955{_}But on the way she came to me bedight in mail, and she and I took counsel together.
10064-8{_}7956{_}Wherefore came she hither to Belsaye and sent speedy messengers to Sir Jocelyn of Alain and others of her greatest lords and knights, bidding them come down with all their powers--nay, why shake ye gloomy head, fond boy?
10064-8{_}7957{_}Body o' me, Beltane, I tell thee this--to-day she--"  "To-day," sighed Beltane, frowning, "to-day she spurneth me!
10064-8{_}7958{_}Kneeling at her feet e'en as I was she shrank away as I had leprous been!"
10064-8{_}7959{_}"Aye, lad, and then--didst woo as well as kneel to her, didst clasp her to thee, lift her proud head that needs must she give to thine her eyes--she is in sooth very woman--did you this, my Beltane?"
10064-8{_}7960{_}"Ah, dear Benedict, she that I love was not wont to shrink from me thus!
10064-8{_}7961{_}'Tis true I am unworthy--and yet, she spurned me--so is her love dead, methinks!"
10064-8{_}7962{_}"So art thou but youth, and foolish youth, and belike, foolish, hungry youth--so come, let us break our fast together."
10064-8{_}7963{_}"Not I, Benedict, for if love be dead, no mind have I to food."
10064-8{_}7964{_}"O lad--lad!"
10064-8{_}7965{_}sighed Sir Benedict, "would I had one as fair and noble to love me in such sort!"
10064-8{_}7966{_}And turning, he gazed sad-eyed towards Belsaye's great minster, and sighing, went his way.
10064-8{_}7967{_}And presently, as Beltane leaned thus, grieving and alone, cometh Giles that way, who, pausing beside him, peered down where the besiegers, but ill-sheltered by battered mantlet and palisades, strove amain to bring up one of their rams, since the causeway across the moat was well-nigh complete.
10064-8{_}7968{_}"Holy saints!"
10064-8{_}7969{_}quoth Giles, "the rogues grow bold and venturesome, methinks!"
10064-8{_}7970{_}So saying, he strung his powerful bow, and laying arrows to his hand fell to drawing and loosing amain.
10064-8{_}7971{_}So swift shot he and with aim so true, that in a while the enemy gave over their attempt and betook them to cover what time their archers and cross-bowmen plied the wall with a storm of shafts and bolts.
10064-8{_}7972{_}Upon this Giles, laying by his bow, seated himself in corner well screened from harm, beckoning Beltane to do the like, since the enemy's missiles whizzed and whistled perilously near.
10064-8{_}7973{_}But sighing, Beltane closed his vizor and heedless of flying bolt and arrow strode to the narrow stair that led up to the gate-tower and being come there sat him down beside the great mangonel.
10064-8{_}7974{_}But lo!
10064-8{_}7975{_}very soon Giles was there also and even as Beltane sighed, so sighed Giles.
10064-8{_}7976{_}"Heigho--a sorry world, brother!"
10064-8{_}7977{_}quoth he, "a sorry world!"
10064-8{_}7978{_}and forthwith fell to his archery, yet now, though his aim was true as ever, he sighed and murmured plaintively 'twixt every shot: "Alack, a sorry world!"
10064-8{_}7979{_}So deep and oft were his sighs, so plaintive his groans, that Beltane, though plunged in bitter thought, must needs at length take heed of him.
10064-8{_}7980{_}"Giles," quoth he, looking up, "a heaven's name, what aileth thee, man?"
10064-8{_}7981{_}"'Tis my eyes, lord."
10064-8{_}7982{_}"Thine eyes are well enough, Giles, and see wondrous well to judge by thy shooting."
10064-8{_}7983{_}"Wondrous well--aye, there it is, tall brother, mine eyes do see wondrous well, mine eyes do see so much, see you, that they do see over-much, over-much, aye--too, too much.
10064-8{_}7984{_}Alack, 'tis a sorry and woeful world, brother!
10064-8{_}7985{_}beshrew my eyes, I say!"
10064-8{_}7986{_}"And wherefore, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7987{_}"For that these eyes do see what other eyes see not--thine, methinks, saw nought of a fine, lusty and up-standing fellow in a camlet cloak within the Reeve's garden this morning, I'll warrant me now?
10064-8{_}7988{_}A tall, shapely rogue, well be-seen, see you, soft-voiced and very debonair?"
10064-8{_}7989{_}"Nay, not I," said Beltane, and sighing he arose and descended to the battlement above the gates.
10064-8{_}7990{_}And presently, behold Giles was there also!
10064-8{_}7991{_}"Brother," quoth he, selecting an arrow with portentous care, "'tis an ill thing to be cursed with eyes such as mine, I tell thee!"
10064-8{_}7992{_}"Aye, and wherefore, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7993{_}said Beltane, yet intent on his own thoughts.
10064-8{_}7994{_}"For that they do see more than is good for this heart o' mine--as this fellow in the blue camlet cloak--"  "What fellow, Giles?"
10064-8{_}7995{_}"The buxom fellow that was in the Reeve's garden this morning."
10064-8{_}7996{_}"Why then," quoth Beltane, turning away, "go you not to the Reeve's garden, Giles."
10064-8{_}7997{_}All day long Beltane kept the wall, eating not at all, wherefore his gloom waxed the more profound; so spake he to few men and oft exposed himself to shaft and missile.
10064-8{_}7998{_}And so, all day long, wheresoever he came, on tower or keep, in corners most remote, there sure was Giles to come also, sighing amain and with brow of heavy portent, who, so oft as he met Beltane's gloomy eye, would shake his head in sad yet knowing fashion.
10064-8{_}7999{_}Thus, as evening fell, Beltane finding him at his elbow yet despondent, betook him to speech at last; quoth he:  "Giles, art thou sick?"
10064-8{_}8000{_}"Aye, lord, by reason of this fellow in the blue camlet--"  "What fellow?"
10064-8{_}8001{_}"The tall and buxom fellow in the Reeve's garden."
10064-8{_}8002{_}"Ha!"
10064-8{_}8003{_}quoth Beltane, frowning.
10064-8{_}8004{_}"In the garden, say you--what manner of man is this?"
10064-8{_}8005{_}"O brother--a shapely man, a comely man--a man of words and cunning phrases--a man shall sing you sweet and melodious as any bird--why, I myself can sing no sweeter!"
10064-8{_}8006{_}"Cometh he there often, Giles?"
10064-8{_}8007{_}"Why lord, he cometh and he goeth--I saw him there this morning!"
10064-8{_}8008{_}"What doeth he there?"
10064-8{_}8009{_}"Nay, who shall say--Genevra is wondrous fair, yet so is she that is Genevra's friend, so do I hope belike 'tis she--"  "Hold thy peace, Giles!"
10064-8{_}8010{_}Now beholding Beltane's fierce eye and how his strong hands clenched themselves, Giles incontinent moved further off and spake in accents soft and soothing:  "And yet, tall brother, and yet 'tis belike but some gentle troubadour that singeth songs to their delectation, and 'tis meet to hark to songs sweet-sung--at moonrise, lord!"
10064-8{_}8011{_}"And wherefore at moonrise?"
10064-8{_}8012{_}"'Tis at this sweet hour your minstrel singeth best.
10064-8{_}8013{_}Aye me, and to-night there is a moon!"
10064-8{_}8014{_}Hereupon Beltane must needs turn to scowl upon the moon just topping the distant woods.
10064-8{_}8015{_}Now as they sat thus, cometh Roger with bread and meat for his lord's acceptance; but Beltane, setting it aside, stared on Roger with baleful eye.
10064-8{_}8016{_}"Roger," said he, "wherefore hast avoided me this day?"
10064-8{_}8017{_}"Avoided thee, master--I?"
10064-8{_}8018{_}"And what did you this morning in the Reeve's garden?"
10064-8{_}8019{_}"Master, in this big world are two beings that I do truly love, and thou art one and the other Sir Fidelis thy right sweet and noble lady-- so is it my joy to serve her when I may, thus daily do I go aid her with the sick."
10064-8{_}8020{_}"And what of him that singeth; saw you this troubadour within the garden?"
10064-8{_}8021{_}"Troubadour?"
10064-8{_}8022{_}quoth Roger, staring.
10064-8{_}8023{_}"Why verily," nodded Giles, "my lord meaneth the tall and goodly fellow in the cloak of blue camlet, Roger."
10064-8{_}8024{_}"Ne'er have I seen one in blue cloak!"
10064-8{_}8025{_}said Roger, "and this do I swear!"
10064-8{_}8026{_}"None the less," said Beltane, rising, "I will seek him there myself."
10064-8{_}8027{_}"At moonrise, lord?"
10064-8{_}8028{_}questioned Giles.
10064-8{_}8029{_}"Aye," said Beltane grimly; "at moonrise!"
10064-8{_}8030{_}and scowling he turned away.
10064-8{_}8031{_}"Aha!"
10064-8{_}8032{_}quoth Giles, nudging Roger with roguish elbow, "it worketh, Roger, it worketh!"
10064-8{_}8033{_}"Aye, Giles, it worketh so well that an my master get his hands on this singing fellow--then woe betide this singing fellow, say I."
10064-8{_}8034{_}CHAPTER LXVII  TELLETH WHAT BEFELL IN THE REEVE'S GARDEN   The moon was already filling the night with her soft splendour when Beltane, coming to a certain wall, swung himself up, and, being there, paused to breathe the sweet perfume of the flowers whose languorous fragrance wrought in him a yearning deep and passionate, and ever as love-longing grew, bitterness and anger were forgot.
10064-8{_}8035{_}Very still was it within this sheltered garden, where, fraught by the moon's soft magic, all things did seem to find them added beauties.
10064-8{_}8036{_}But, even as he paused thus, he heard a step approaching, a man's tread, quick and light yet assured, and he beheld one shrouded in a long cloak of blue, a tall figure that hasted through the garden and vanished behind the tall yew hedge.
10064-8{_}8037{_}Down sprang Beltane fierce-eyed, trampling the tender flowers under cruel feet, and as he in turn passed behind the hedge the moon glittered evilly on his dagger blade.
10064-8{_}8038{_}Quick and soft of foot went he until, beholding a faint light amid the leaves, he paused, then hasted on and thus came to an arbour bowered in eglantine.
10064-8{_}8039{_}She sat at a table where burned a rushlight that glowed among the splendour of her hair, for her head was bowed above the letter she was writing.
10064-8{_}8040{_}Now as he stood regarding her 'neath frowning brows, she spake, yet lifted not her shapely head.
10064-8{_}8041{_}"Well, my lord?"
10064-8{_}8042{_}"Helen, where is he that came here but now?"
10064-8{_}8043{_}Slowly she lifted her head, and setting white hands 'neath dimpled chin, met his frown with eyes of gentleness.
10064-8{_}8044{_}"Nay, first put up thy dagger, my lord."
10064-8{_}8045{_}"Helen," said he again, grim-lipped, "whom dost wait for?"
10064-8{_}8046{_}"Nay, first put up thy dagger, messire."
10064-8{_}8047{_}Frowning he obeyed, and came a pace nearer.
10064-8{_}8048{_}"What do you here with pen and ink-horn?"
10064-8{_}8049{_}"My lord, I write."
10064-8{_}8050{_}"To whom?"
10064-8{_}8051{_}"To such as it pleaseth me."
10064-8{_}8052{_}"I pray you--show me."
10064-8{_}8053{_}"Nay, for that doth not please me, messire."
10064-8{_}8054{_}"I pray you, who was he that came hither but now--a tall man in a long blue cloak?"
10064-8{_}8055{_}"I saw him not, my lord."
10064-8{_}8056{_}"So needs must I see thy letter."
10064-8{_}8057{_}"Nay, that thou shalt not, my lord," said she, and rose to her stately height.
10064-8{_}8058{_}"Aye, but I shall!"
10064-8{_}8059{_}quoth Beltane softly, and came a pace yet nearer.
10064-8{_}8060{_}Now because of the grim and masterful look of him, her heart fell a-fluttering, yet she fronted him scornful-eyed, and curled her red lip at him.
10064-8{_}8061{_}"Messire," said she, "methinks you do forget I am the--"  "I remember thou art woman and thy name--Helen!"
10064-8{_}8062{_}Now at this laughed she softly and thereafter falleth to singing very sweet and blithe and merry withal.
10064-8{_}8063{_}"The letter!"
10064-8{_}8064{_}said he, "give me thy letter!"
10064-8{_}8065{_}Hereupon she took up the letter, and, yet singing, crumpled it up within white fingers.
10064-8{_}8066{_}Then Beltane set by the table and reaching out sudden arms, caught her up 'neath waist and knee, and lifting her high, crushed her upon his breast.
10064-8{_}8067{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}8068{_}said he, low-voiced and fierce, "mine art thou as I am thine, forever, 'twas so we plighted our troth within the green.
10064-8{_}8069{_}Now for thy beauty I do greatly love thee, but for thy sweet soul and purity of heart I do reverence and worship thee--but an thou slay my reverent worship then this night shalt thou die and I with thee--for mine art thou and shalt be mine forever.
10064-8{_}8070{_}Give me thy letter!"
10064-8{_}8071{_}But now her eyes quailed 'neath his, her white lids drooped, and sighing, she spake small-voiced:  "O my lord, thine arms are so--so tyrannous that I do fear thee-- almost!
10064-8{_}8072{_}And how may a poor maid, so crushed and helpless thus, gainsay thee?
10064-8{_}8073{_}So prithee, O prithee take my poor letter an thou wilt ravish it from one so defenceless--O beseech thee, take it!"
10064-8{_}8074{_}So she gave the crumpled parchment into his hand, yet while he read it, nestled closer in his arms and hid her face against him; for what he read was this:  "Beloved, art thou angered, or sorrowful, or humble in thy foolish jealousy?
10064-8{_}8075{_}If angered, then must I woo thee.
10064-8{_}8076{_}If sorrowful, cherish thee.
10064-8{_}8077{_}But being Beltane, needs must I love thee ever--so write I this, bidding thee come, my Beltane the Smith, for I--"  The crumpled letter fell to the ground.
10064-8{_}8078{_}"Helen!"
10064-8{_}8079{_}he whispered, "Beloved, I am all of this, so do I need thy comfort, thy cherishing, and all thy dear love--turn thy head--O Helen, how red is thy sweet mouth!"
10064-8{_}8080{_}Then stooped he, and so they kissed each other, such kisses as they ne'er had known, until she sighed and trembled and lay all breathless in his arms.
10064-8{_}8081{_}"O my lord," she whispered, "have mercy, I pray!
10064-8{_}8082{_}Dear Beltane, loose me for I--I have much to tell thee."
10064-8{_}8083{_}And because of her pleading eyes he loosed her, and she, sinking upon the bench, leaned there all flushed and tremulous, and looking on him, sighed, and sighing, put up her hands and hid her face from his regard.
10064-8{_}8084{_}"Beltane," she whispered, "how wondrous a thing is this our love, so great and fierce it frighteth me--see how I tremble!"
10064-8{_}8085{_}and she held out to him her hands.
10064-8{_}8086{_}Then came he and knelt before her, and kissed those slender fingers amain.
10064-8{_}8087{_}"Dear hands of Fidelis," said he, "but for their tender skill and gentle care I had not lived to know this night--O brave, small hands of Fidelis!"
10064-8{_}8088{_}"Poor Fidelis!"
10064-8{_}8089{_}she sighed, "but indeed it wrung my heart to see thy woeful face when I did tell thee Fidelis was lost to thee--Nay, Beltane, stay--O prithee let me speak--"  Quoth Beltane 'twixt his kisses:  "Wherefore wert so cold and strange to me but yesterday?"
10064-8{_}8090{_}"Dear my heart," she murmured, "I needs must make thee suffer a little-- just a very little, for that I had known so much of pain and heartache because of thee.
10064-8{_}8091{_}But I was glad to see thee bear the wallet of poor Fidelis--and O, 'twas foolish in thee to grieve for him, for he being gone, thy Helen doth remain--unless, forsooth, thou had rather I came to thee bedight again in steel--that did so chafe me, Beltane--indeed, my tender skin did suffer much on thy account--"  "Then soon with my kisses will I seek--" But a cool, soft hand schooled his hot lips to silence and the while he kissed those sweet arresting fingers, she spake 'twixt smiling lips: "Prithee where is my shoe that was Genevra's?
10064-8{_}8092{_}Indeed, 'twas hard matter to slip it off for thee, Beltane, for Genevra's foot is something smaller than mine--a very little!
10064-8{_}8093{_}Nay, crush me not, messire, but tell me, what of him ye came hither seeking--the man in the long cloak--what of him?"
10064-8{_}8094{_}"Nought!"
10064-8{_}8095{_}answered Beltane, "the world to-night doth hold but thee and me--"  "Aye, my Beltane, as when sick of thy wound within the little cave I nursed thee, all unknown.
10064-8{_}8096{_}O love, in all thy sickness I was with thee, to care for thee.
10064-8{_}8097{_}Teaching good Roger to tend thee and--to drug thee to gentle sleep that I might hold thee to me in the dark and--kiss thy sleeping lips--"  "Ah!"

10064-8{_}8099{_}O Helen, sure none ever loved as we?"
10064-8{_}8100{_}"Nay, 'twere thing impossible, Beltane."
10064-8{_}8101{_}"And thou art truly mine?"
10064-8{_}8102{_}"Beltane--thou dost know this!
10064-8{_}8103{_}Ah, love--what would you?"
10064-8{_}8104{_}For of a sudden his mighty arms were close about her, and rising, he lifted her upon his breast.

10064-8{_}8109{_}"Nay, love, I--I--thou art so sudden!"
10064-8{_}8110{_}"Aye, within this hour shalt call me 'husband'!"

10064-8{_}8112{_}"Aye, verily," said Beltane, "as God sees me, I will!"

10064-8{_}8115{_}But, as he turned to leave the arbour, she stayed him:  "I prithee, now, whither dost take me, Beltane?"
